Transfer from BA review on 1-3-14-

 2013 vintage poured from bottle into a snifter

 Appearance – The beer pours an almost pitch black color with a tiny brown colored head. The head fades almost instantly leaving a trace level of lace on the sides of the glass. Upon swirling the brew in the glass, its thickness could be seen, with fingers of the beer clinging to the sides of the glass and slowly receding to the bottom of the glass to its resting place.

 Smell – The aroma of the beer is massive of sweet smells with caramel, molasses, dark fruits of raisin, plum and cherry, as well as a little bit of vanilla all there. Along with these smells are lots of darker aromas of chocolate and roasted malt smells as well as some other lighter aromas of coffee. Rounding out all these smells, and as the name would suggest, a huge bourbon smell as well as a nice woody aroma mix with the rest of the smells, producing a delicious, very dark, sweet and warming aroma overall. 

 Taste – The taste begins with a big roasted malt flavor along with sweeter flavors of molasses and darker fruits of raisin and prune. Right from the start, there is also a big bourbon flavor. The bourbon flavor is big and smooth tasting with lots of oaky and woody flavors mixed within. The bourbon gets even richer as the taste advances, bringing with it just a hint of bitterness as more woodsy flavors and a bit of coffee come to the tongue. Along with these increases in the boozy tastes, other sweeter flavors of vanilla and a bit of chocolate come to the tongue more toward the end complementing the other flavors nicely. In the end, with all the nice roasted, sweet, and bourbon flavors of the brew, a very pleasant and still very smooth, yet somehow very warming taste is left to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is super thick and creamy with a carbonation level that is on the lower side. The thick and creamy body are most fantastic for the darker and heavy boozy and sweet flavors of the brew, with the lower carbonation only enhancing these flavors even more. With the lower carbonation and super thick body, all the fantastic flavors really get to sit and coat the mouth allowing the taste buds to be bathed in all the delicious flavors and soothing the mouth with a fantastic feel.

 Overall –This is a super flavorful, yet massively smooth and balanced stout with an amazing blend of bourbon, sweet, and roast flavor. A sipping stout like no other, and up at the top of my list. Oh so delicious and enjoyable.

A thin-head-pour. Seems very oily... and indeed; this follows up during tasting. Caramel malts, licorice and an intense alcohol burn in the nose. At first monotonous but enriching after a few smells and sips. Very delicate but poignant taste character, perfectly enriched by the intertwining of the alcohol fume - breathtaking in a literal sense, almost takes a man’s oxygen away. Taste is slightly sticky in aftertaste, I detect some oak and a bitterness in the background. An oily stout from the malt extracts and barrel aging. Everything in this beer feels like being offered with moderation and balance, but still poignant in it’s simplicity. Lovely stout, really, but over-priced in Belgium (13EUR).. Hype is a dangerous thing. Although, with the correct aging time an excellent experience well worth it.
Very dark brown with thin head. Aromas of bourbon, chocolate, lactose and smoke. Taste complex, sweet and some bitter. Oily mouthfeel. Some alcohol burn.
Rate #900. Bottle at home, 28th September 14. Aroma, liquorice, leather, bourbon, palate is silky, thick and rich, taste is slick, liquorice, bourbon and leather, very decadent. Good stuff
Really nice black thick viscous malty beer with some plum, molasses. Not that bitter, no head at all, but really nice!

2013 bottle. Pours black, with a medium, brown, bubbly head. Strong coffee and milk chocolate aroma, peanut butter (?), molasses, oak, vanilla, and a hint of green pepper. Very sweet, light bitterness, but not really burnt or roasted. A little spicy. Very heavy and thick, creamy, with an acidic, pleasantly biting feel in the finish. This is immense, but surprisingly approachable and smooth. Really delicious and well-balanced.

tap from cafe nadery in new york. 2013 (14.9% ) most likely as per their menu.

smell of bourbon, caramel, some chocolate, alcohol, malts to an extent
poured deep black, no hint of light with a deep brown dissapating head. 

flavor is like the head, extreme bourbon backing with heavy caramel and a bit of chocolate. good thing i like bourbon so much. definite taste of alcohol but is to be expected with the alcohol content. it got more drinkable as it warmed as the bourbon flavor lessened a bit. 

not for bourbon dislikers, but then again, for the percentage and the name, i wouldnt expect anything different. id drink this again in the winter.
Bottle bought at fermentorencph. Great beer, difficult to find something bad to say about it. Probably the best stout I have had along with speedway's.

2009, specially aged in barrel for 5 years. [10-4-9-5-19] (4.7)



Deep bourbon aroma, smells right when poured all over the place, smell of the empty bottle is just pure bourbon. Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, loads of it, vanilla, oak and oak and oak. It’s very very flavorsome, but the booze and bourbon overtakes it a bit too much. The stout quality and the roast is close to gone, and lean more toward a very very dark barley wine, loaded with vanilla, caramelized sugars - marshmallows style, plum, raisin with a big butterscotch bourbon finish. nevertheless, this is a great drink and very special and is indeed world class, but different, and even if it was like I wanted or expect it to be it might not be better.




2012 Vintage [9-5-9-4-16] 4.3




Aroma of vanilla, butterscotch, booze, chocolate and oak. Taste is a full chocolate with vanilla and bourbon very well integrated, not as complex, to begin with - but is obviously amazing. As it warms up it opens new flavors and aromas, molasses, slight salty licorice with more butterscotch to it, chewy chocolate cake with big caramel, it is a bit too boozy and thin.




2013 Vintage  [9-5-8-4-16] 4.2




Aroma upfront is bourbon - vanilla, lots of oak, coconut, almonds, salted caramel. As it warms up there is a slight soy character to it, and more licorice forward than other years, also more dates and plums, almost a rye spice from the bourbon. Taste is less vanilla on 2013 compared to other years, much more rum like, with dark fruits - blackcurrants, dates and plums, a bit more dark malt character, but less chocolate. Feels more complex, but more nuanced compared to other former years.



2014 Vintage [8-5-8-4-15] 4.0



Big oak and booze, not as much caramel as former years in the bourbon, back towards chocolate and vanilla. A bit spicy character, subtle cardamom, rye like spice. Taste is more chocolate and vanilla, oak tannin is very much present, a bit astringent like a red wine, and has notes of black currants and licorice, this felt thinner than I remember it, was probably served a bit too cold to begin with, which gave a bit worse impressions to start with.

Smells like bourbon, wood and smoke. Flavour is much the same with bourbion being the most prominent; vanilla, chocolate and sugar sweet. Alcohol is present in this one. Lives up to its status as one of the best BA stouts. 2012 vintage 355ml.

2012 bottle. I’ve had this lots of times, and from different vintages, but apparently never rated it. Pours pitch, oily black with no head. Aroma has a huge buttery, coconut, vanilla bourbon sweetness up front, accompanied by dark, chocolate roast, licorice and lots of dried fruits like dates, prunes, figs and raisins. Toffee, caramel and a bit of coffee as well. Taste has a big, boozy, vanilla-bourbon and chocolate up front, but is balanced out well by the more bitter roast, and a good chunk of coffee. Starts out pretty sweet, but as time goes, it grows darker in the chocolate, and the booze becomes more complex and delicate. Molasses and gunpowder comes through. Still a bit of butter, and besides that some port wine, and again all these dried fruits. A great balance between the powerful sweetness, and boozy, roasted opposites. Despite the lack of head, it doesn’t lack carbonation too much. Body is thick and oily.

2008 Bottle from Moscow Wine Co. 
Aroma: Smoke, Bourbon/wood, rich dark chocolate and vanilla
Palate: Full-bodied but not heavy, probably thanks to aging.
Flavor: Rich dark chocolate, chocolate liquor, woody Bourbon with finishes with all the above plus vanilla. Great intense flavor holds well on the finish and shows dryish notes of wood.
Comment: Deft use of bourbon barrels that doesn’t overdo the vanilla character and shows wood flavors. 

2008 bottle tasted 8/18/2016.  
Aroma and Flavor:  Lots of dark licorice, fig, dark chocolate, bourbon and vanilla.  Rather boozy on first few sips.  Aging may also have brought out a note of molasses character.

SIde by side comparison of 2012 and 2013 bottles. Both have a very predominant bourbon note, with the 2012 having quite strong soy sauce/chocolate notes white the 2013 being quite a bit more restrained in the aroma, mainly bourbon comes through. Especially with the 2012, interesting and complex nose. Completely black and viscous with a quickly fading brown head. 2012 amazingly complex flavors blended very well together, toffee, caramel sweetness, bourbon/vanilla notes, soy and metallic characteristics all make their way in and out after taking a sip. Sweet/syrupy vanilla, but not cloying, finish. 2013 similar but not as complex, more of a single note experience, slightly sweeter and less integrated. In each, no sign of alcohol, just great flavors and a lot of sweetness/hoppy finish. Thick bodied, moderately carbonated. Great, great beers, especially the 2012 (not sure if due to aging or just the recipe used).

Chocolate, creamy, molasses and maple syrup, black as night, smells...like heaven must smell -- but I’ll never know. :( That’s ok cause this beer will be in plenty supply in the other place. Truly one of the tastiest, most enjoyable beverages on the planet Earth.
Shared bottle. Black colour. Delicious bourbon chocolate, sweet, coffee, alcohol

Bottled 09/11/2012, drunk at home.

Smell is slightly boozy, dark chocolate and coffee with slight caramel notes. Midnight brown, no head, far from motor oil in density.

T: Wow. Starts out with milk chocolate that turns darker and darker as time goes on and eventually fades into some really nice coffee notes. The bourbon lingers at the edges throughout, bringing nice flavours through it all.

P: An experience you need to try to understand. Amazingly complex, stays around for quite a while.

Overall one of the best beers I’ve had the pleasure to sample. I think it’s my last bottle, sadly.
Powerful bourbon aroma with dark stout. Pitch black with dark tan head, dies quick. Taste is percent, bourbon and dark coffee stout. Perfect beer.

355 ml bottle. Pours black with a short lived beige head. Aroma is bourbon, wood, roast, dark chocolate and hazelnut. Flavor is dark coffee, dark chocolate, bourbon, wood, figs, dates, booze. Finish is boozey, roasted, coffeeish, black cherry. Lingering molasses flavor. Thick body, soft, oily mouthfeel, weak carbonation. Wow.

Bottle from Rainhall Drinks, Barnoldswick. 2008 Edition drank in 2014: Inky black with ruby red highlights and no head at all. It has a thick, oily mouthfeel with a very rich chocolate, liquorice and oak-whisky flavour, toasted vanilla and a very powerful warming alcoholic chocolate and whisky finish.

Je me gâte pour mon 700e rating! Bouteille 355ml, 2013, gracieuseté de biere_froide, merci Yannick! Couleur noire comme la nuit, mince collet de mousse moka fuyante. Arôme d’alcool, malt torréfié, boisé, noix de pécan. Goût de malt torréfié, alcool, chocolat noir, boisé, pointe de vanille, très sucré. Carbonatation faible, corps très dense, presque "mâchable", huileuse. Superbe stout impériale.

12oz bottle courtesy of CHI tasting crew 2013, shared @Tristate Tasting II, Freiburg. 2013 edition if I remember correctly. - Vanilla and dark chocolate fig compote perfectly contained by suave, near-leathery bourbon barrel tannins and make for very easy sipping. Lush dried berry aromas and dried toffee escape from the contained velvet creamy dark mass of all-encompassing vanilla bourbon as it warms. Late gentle hops join in the sweet butterscotch finish to round off this elegant, yet nearly mono-purpose dessert treat. #1600

12 oz bottle. Tasted on 8/7/14. Beer from my brother In law Chae thanks!!! Vintage 2009. The beer pours to a rich deep black color with almost no head. The aroma is overpowering with bourbon with slight coco & licorice. The taste is very rich & extremely complex. You get the bourbon on the front end followed by a rich chocolate & dark fruits finish. You really have sip on this one to enjoy it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle pour, 2013 vintage, black body with a ring of espresso colored foam. Aroma is raisin, dried plum, cherry, molasses, vanilla, bourbon. Taste is plum, raisin, cherry, BIG vanilla (but not that fake burnt flavor, good, rich, oaky), bourbon, molasses, black coffee, black malt. Palate is rich, but not syrupy, carbonation subdued. Warming, but not boozy, sweet initially, but the bitter finish is nearly perfect contrast. Just ever so slightly too sweet to be perfect.

Tasting again, growler, first time this has been retail in Alaska. Same tasting notes, still too sweet to be perfect. I might rduce my rating a couple of points.
Pours black. Aroma is bourbon, chocolate, coffee, oak, and vanilla. Taste follows the nose with a wonderfully long and lingering aftertaste.
Bottle at home. Pours black, aroma and taste of chocolate, vanilla, toffee, bourbon.

shared@2nd D/F/CH TriStateTasting, courtesy of bartlebier, thank you! aromas of oak barrels, dried plums, chocolate; taste with components of melted dark chocolate, raisins, bourbon, with a distinct finish of coffee and malt-coffee notes. Alcohol very well hidden. Wonderful!

Bottle 33cl @2ndTSRB, a dark beer with low head. Nose is on dark chocolate, oxidised, fig and prune, very nice. Aroma is very nice on dark chocolate, fig, sweet candied prune, round caramel, vinous, oak, vanilla, tannic, creamy, very complex, licorice. Exceptional brew, delicious, very long aftertaste on dark chocolate and fig notes, the kind of beer I like most.

Bottle 2013 vintage. Pours a dark black with receding dark brown head. Aroma is intense bourbon characteristics such as vanilla, wood and coconut. Some dark chocolate and tobacco, bourbon, vanilla. Taste is huge: dark chocolate, ashy, tobacco. Very rich and mouthcoating. Reconforting alcohol burn.Truly, a classic.

First enjoyed this brew in honor of my lovely girlfriend&apos;s birthday, this barrel aged stout is absolutely delicious, exceeding my already high expectations. This was a random gift from a friend of a friend, and am I thankful to have tried this&#033; both 2013 and 2014 vintage bottles poured a ridiculous dark black color with some dark tan head, looks like liquid dark chocolate. Aroma likewise is of chocolate but also vanilla, red fruit, and of course bourbon whiskey. Taste is amazing, fresh dark chocolate, oak, roasted malt. Finishes with a sweet caramel/toffee, almost like I took a bite out of a chocolate bar. Also bourbon accents like I just took a shot of Jack Daniels too. Just awesome, the only subtraction is for the boozy/alcohol bite that I would rather not have, but it&apos;s not overpowering. Oh and the mouthfeel/texture is perfectly full-bodied, smooth, and rich. I'm becoming more of a barrel aged stout fan, as this is among the greatest beers I&apos;ve ever tasted&#033; hard to find and only released once a year as far as I can tell, be sure to buy and keep in stock for special occasions&#033; Great dessert beer too.

Draft at Blue Monk. Wow, what an amzing beer. Poured a deep black and had a medium beige head. Aroma really hits you with with bourbon, oak, chocolate, alcohol, and vanilla. Taste follows the nose pretty well. It’s a sipper, but I found myself wanting to drink it faster because it was so good. This was my first bourbon county offering from GI and hopefully I will get to try more.
This beer is simply amazing.I would walk 500 miles.... Climb the highest mountains... All for this one. But seriously, this isn’t for beginners. It has a heavy flavor and drinks so smooth.

Sweet with flavors of bourbon, toffee, light cocoa. Kinda straightforward and not particularly my thing past having its flavors in the right places. Certainly a good beer without obvious flaws, but also not exciting for me.
Bottle. Black pour with no significant head. Wild beer. Aroma has coffee toffee and malt. Fresh taste with complexity.

From the 12 fl. oz 2013 batch bottle. The pour is jet black and completely blocks any light from getting through. The aroma is mostly of chocolate malts but the bourbon liquor really cuts to the quick and rips through my nose. Dark fruit and yeast. The body is as full as it can be and chewy like gum. The bourbon on the nose is not as powerful in the taste but that hard liquor bite really can’t be avoided along with the sweet chocolate and long bitter finale. Everyone loves this one and I can’t argue with them and it probably gets my highest rating in the seven years I’ve been on Rate Beer. If the booze was mellower I’d give it 5 out of 5.

355 ml bottle, 2009 vintage, at home. Black color with small beige-brown head. Aroma is bourbon, wood, roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, raisins and alcohol. Taste begins sweet, it becomes bitter and it is almost like the aroma with flavors of bourbon, chocolate and vanilla. Full body with creamy feel, soft carbonation and bitter alcoholic finish. Very good! The first BCBS that I tried was 2008 vintage at Mikkeller bar (Viktoriagade) 1 hour after I had woken up and before going to Sparta Hallen for the second day of CBC 2012. That was perfect! The best BCBS I ’ve had so far. I tried vintage 2012 just after it was released and the bourbon and alcohol was too much! So I think that this beer becomes much better after some years!

355 ml bottle @ home. Pours a pitch black, thick oily like fluid with a minimal head. Nose has licorice, dark chocolate and some vanilla. Taste is boozy bourbon heavy at first but balances out as it warms up. Some light tartness with the bitter chocolate and vanilla.

Poured into 10 oz snifter from tap.
Appearance: Black body, tan head.
Aroma: Roasted malt, dark chocolate, slight hint of vanilla.
Taste: Big chocolate flavor on the front, roasted malt, subtle bourbon flavor, slight malt bitterness on finish.
Palate: Medium body with a creamy consistency. Very smooth.
Overall: Such a balanced imperial stout with regards to the big chocolate flavor and the very light bitterness on the back end. It truly is a dessert in a glass. Serves as such a strong starting point for all of the variants in the series.

5/IV/14 - 12Fl. Oz. bottle @ home - BB: n/a, 2012 vintage (2014-341) Thanks to Filip for sharing this one!


Note: apparently I forgot to enter this review, weird. Thanks to PriorL for pointing this out by bringing another bottle of this to share at my place! :-)


Dark brown to black beer, almost no head. Aroma: some caramel, mocha, lots of cocoa powder, chocolate, quite some vanilla on warming up. MF: ok carbon, full body. Taste: caramel, dark chocolate, sugary, some alcohol, bit of mocha. Aftertaste: caramel, lots of chocolate, sweet, some vanilla, mocha, fruity touch, cherries and dark fruits, little bitter, more chocolate. Very decent stuff!

Drunk 22/06/14 with cam. honored to share this. pours sticky and black, golden ruby around the edges, almost no head. smell is great. sweet with a cut of alcohol. taste surprised me. perfect balance of woody vanilla, treacle, cream, with walnuts and slight roasty bitterness. i dislike the charred flavour imps can have but this was smooth and creamy and warming. thick and chewy, it stuck to the sides of the glass until the last drop. totally delicious

Enjoyed on 6/15/14 @ The Farnsworth House in Bordentown, NJ. Served in official Goose Island half pint glass. Looks amazing in the glass. Black with a nice khaki head. Smells of bourbon, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, maple, and brown sugar! The taste starts off with smokey bourbon, along with slight bitter coffee, and then a sweet vanilla, maple backnote. Syrupy texture and on the heavy side. I'm surprised for a craft brewery owned by In-Bev could create such an awesome beer! This is why I gave it a 5/5!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap into Bourbon County Tulip Glass

A - Black motor oil, no real head after pouring, maybe a slight brown

S - Vanilla and booze

T- starts with heavy bourbon and vanilla. Comes in with chocolate and coffee. Oak, Maple, and Vanilla really bring it together.

M - Very thick. The booze and the chocolate last for a while after sip. 

Overall - Very heavy and complex. Perfect. Favorite BA RIS so far. Thank you GOOSE ISLAND!
Dark, beautiful pour. The bourbon sticks out on the palate. The caramel and vanilla notes are there, but the stout overpowers them at times.

Bottle (2012) from Voldby (thanks to Niller for the share) - very dark brown near on black with no head. Dark roasted malty, dark chocolate, caramel, subtle vanilla, bourbon wooden nuances throughout, lovely and complex, vinous and oily mouthfeel, has a great roasted boozy bear hug at the end. Spectacular.

2013 Vintage.
Ar: Bourbon, tar - molasses and heavily roasted caramel - chocolate and burnt coffee.
Ap: Pitch black with slight brown highlights on the edges - very small light brown head - low retention, leaves a thin, but solid ring of of foam.
T: Sweet bourbon, some clean alcohol heat - burnt caramel, molasses - highly roasted coffee, turbinado sugar - toffee, nougat, and blueberry - bitterness is medium - char, and more bourbon and coffee on the finish.
P: Full body with medium-high carbonation - finish is medium.
O: A stellar bourbon barrel RIS - dense, complex, and warming.
Bottle, pours dark black with a thin brown head, noticeable bourbon aroma, sweet taste of the bourbon, some chocolate, vanilla, and some coffee, very good imperial

On so many occasions and in so many different fashions have I tried this beer. I get it, it’s the "Grandfather of Bourbon Barrel-Aged Beers"....it certainly deserves respect for being a trailblazer. However, I just cannot get behind this beer like so many others seem to. It is just too big. 

2012 vintage. Poured into a Bell’s snifter. Color is jet black, like spent oil. Thick brown head that recedes into a ring around the glass with spotty lacing. Aromas of subdued bourbon, oak, anise, roasted nut and smoke. Much calmer than when this was fresh....I remembered smelling this 15%’er from across the table before each sip....not so much now. The taste has muted bourbon notes upfront with a decent chocolate/anise interplay. It creates a bit of tobacco flavoring....which leads into the smoke character. Some sweetness in the middle ground....light vanilla, oak, molasses. But, the bourbon is still very much the centerpiece of the finish. It still dominates over any other subtleties this beer may offer....I can almost taste the delicacy in the base, but the bourbon just overwhelms my taste buds and palate. The beer being so oily, it resonates even further down my tongue, leaving little respite for any flavor that may be contained in the following sips. Just an exhausting beer. 

Don’t get me wrong, I enjoy a gluttonous beer as much as the next person...but I feel that since Bourbon County broke down the door for Bourbon Barrel aging, other brewers have refined the style with more tenderness in the process.

Petite bouteille vintage 2013. Merci Patrick. Le liquide semble visqueux au versage. La robe est profonde comme la nuit. La mousse ne tient pas la route, un simple anneau. Un premier nez fort sympathique, je ne sens pas l’alcool. Il semble avoir un boisé bien intégré. Un bouche étonnante, racé, les saveurs enveloppent le palais. Ils sont interminables. Combien de caudalies ? La texture est crémeuse. Un arrière-goût étonnant de chocolat, de vanille. Superbe.
This is a beer that will blow you away in more ways than one. It looks, smells, and tastes like the "angels share" itself - not the dregs left in the barrel!
Pitch black, no head. Wood, Bourbon, chocolate aroma and taste. High alcohol Bourbon warm aftertaste, sweet finish

Pours pitch black, sirupy with almost no head. 
Nose is heavy chocolate, mild coffee, some vanilla maybe? 
Taste is very heavy on the chocolate, coffee. Very damn tasty but quite fierce with alcohol. Best stout I had, together with the Hunaphu.

Deep brown, very opaque. No head. Heavy notes of caramel and molasses. Some bitterness but very sweet from start to finish. Heavy body, very upfront alcohol. Quite balanced though. Very long finish. Almost no carbonation to speak of. Exceptional.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Everything you would want in a imp stout. Lots of coffee, dark chocolate, licorice, figs and loads of burbon. Pretty much a perfect stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Chocolate bourbon deliciousness in a bottle. Tried this for the first time in 2013 and didn't know what I was getting myself into. Put
Away one of the bottles in the four pack to try next year.
Boozy bourbon in the nose. Jet oily black with tan oily head. Taste is chocolate, oily bourbon with hints of
best stout ive ever had. super boozy. and the warmer it gets the hotter it gets which is what i personally enjoy

Flaske, 355 ml. Årgang 2012. Knaldsort med en rødlig kant og et skum, der står stolt i 5 sek og så flader ud. Det gør smagen heldigvis ikke. Masser af bourbon, vanilie (på den ikke-klamme måde!!!), vådt træ- Også en ret tydelig note af alkohol/booze/procenter. Meget fyldig, sødlig mere end sød, klistret, ret indladende i munden, med masser af vanilie og bozze. Og nedenunder nogle bløde choko-noter. Fylder munden helt ud. Lang eftersmag. Heftig og blid på en og samme tid. I den grad en øl til de sene timer og komplementation.

I have had an entire 4-pack since the 2013 release. The pour into the snifter is just as exciting as the first time I tried it. Deep abyss black with the signature dark khaki head that fades into a beautiful ring. The aroma is incredible; sweet with burnt sugars, oak, vanilla, chocolate and cocoa. Upon taste it is toasty and sweet with bourbon all over it. Cocoa, coffee tones and bitterness are rounded out immediately by the sweet sugars and vanilla. This beer changed the way I perceive beer in general, try it and it will change you too. Thank you Goose Island!
Poured at GI 26th anniversary 2013 batch. Poured black tan head minimal. Aroma of bourbon vanilla complex. Light carb thick bod. Tingles on tongue with nice bourbon oak vanilla choc flavor.

from: 2012
duft: stor dyft af bourbon fade, ege, sødme. kakao.
smag: meget meget sød. en smule brædt malt som bliver pakket ind i den store sødme, kaffe. kakao. en varm eftersmag. en smule salt, 
en super god øl hvis man elsker mørker meget søde øl :D
Love sharing this beer with friends. Good bourbon, roasted malt, coffee balance. "almost" too syrupy, but awesome.
Bottle -2012 Edition - pours pitch with a nice big bourbon alcohol aroma, malty. This is very drinkable, mellowed with aging, seriously good stuff. Yum!

Bottle from unknown vendor. 2012 edition. Pours black with a thin khaki head. Doesn’t leave much lacing. Big bourbon on the noses it’s a waft alcohol that lingers a it. The bourbon’s mellowed on the tongue. Has a. Bit of alcohol on the tongue but is quite quaffable. This is really dangerously drinkable.

Fantastic beer. Sour and tart Stout with sweet chocolate and bourbon flavours. The beer is almost oily in texture, with a jet black tar look to it. You just want to sip and smell it for hours. The 15% ABV is well woven into the rest of the experience, although it gently tickles your nose.

2013 bottle thanks to Eddie.

Pours a syrupy, deep brown (bordering on black) body with no discernible head. Sweet bourbon is on the nose with plenty of vanilla and rich roasted notes. Dark chocolate, vanilla, and bourbon wash through on the first sip and a little black licorice is also there. Thick, viscous body with low carbonation. Very sweet up front with a mildly bitter, roasty finish. Delicious!

Wow, what a beer and this is only the ?normal? version. Delicious taste of roasted malt and the Bourbon vanilla. Black awesomeness with lucious thick creamy vanilla, milk chocolate and roasted malt. Such a diverse and tasty beer.

Bottle @ Fermentoren, Aarhus. Pours an almost black with a hint of red. Very dense and oily. Aromas of bourbon, roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee. Tastes like a sweet chocolate dessert with sweet bourbon and a slight roasted taste after swallowing. Theres also a deep taste of dark, burned coffee. Great stout. 8-4-9-5-17.

Bottle at Studenterhuset. Pours pitch black with a shortlasting creamy mocha head. Aromas of bourbon, coffee roast, vanilla, dates, slight raisin, melted dark bitter chocolate. Taste is bourbon up front, vanilla, bitter dark chocolate, coconut-like sweetness, dark dried fruits, raisins and dates. Damn, this beer is still great.

Bottle from Voldby. (2012 bottle). Black pours with no head. Lots of bourbon in the aroma. Flavor is roasted malts, coffee, barley, chocolate, lots of bourbon. Creamy mouthfeel. Very complex, smooth and powerful beer. Nearly no carbonation. So far, my best stout. Excellent.
Stout, check. Chocolate, check. Coffee, check. Plan on drinking this as a dessert. The high ratings are well deserved. Awesome beer drinking experience.

2013 vintage. Pitch black pour with a viscous, syrupy body. There is a slick, chewy feel to this beer with the bourbon notes hitting you from the outset. Great interplay between oak and vanilla with a hint of anise and smoked malt. 

Recently had a sample of a 2007 bottle. Wow. Aging BCBS is going to give you phenomenal results, with a mellowing and deepening of the flavor profile.

2009 vintage from bottle at Church Key. Pours a still black with sugary lacing. Aroma is bourbon and oak with notes of vanilla and char. Flavor is massive: cacao, oak, bourbon booze, vanilla. Lasting finish. Amazing.

Bottle courtesy of Marsiblursi. 2006 vintage. Pours oily pitch black with a small dark mocha head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is sweet and malty with roasted malts, roasted coconut, vanilla fudge, alcohol, leather, high quality dark chocolate, moist soil, alcohol, lemon zest, bourbon and hints of leather and lemon zest. Taste is sweet, slightly bitter and tiny salty with roasted malts, sweet soy sauce, roasted coconuts, vanilla fudge, alcohol, high quality dark chocolate, sweetened dark roast coffee, leather, salty liquorice, orange zest and toffee. Mouthfeel is round, boozy, tiny tart and full bodied. Finish is slightly sweet, bitter and tiny sour with vanilla fudge, orange zest, high quality dark chocolate. Leather and lemon zest. Clearly oxidized and possibly past it’s prime (haven’t tried this fresh) but this is very good. 4.1

Re-rate! Several bottles of the 2012 vintage. Really bleeping good!4.4

Even more bottles sampled. Chocolate, vanilla and bourbon desert awesomeness. Last time we had this we paired it with raspberry cheesecake and it blew our mind. One of the best RIS out there! A great intense boozy desert-beer... 4.5

Re-rate! Goose Island Bourbon County Stout - Monks Blend. This is a verision of the 2009 vintage BCBS where the entire barrel was acquired by Monks and was kept in the bourbon barrel till 2014 when it was bottled and released which means it was in the wood for almost 5 years. Bottled @ Monks Café Stockholm courtesy of "Calle" who I met at the bar. Pours oily pitch black with no head worth mentioning. Smell is intense with roasted malts, bourbon, high quality dark chocolate, vanilla fudge, shredded coconut, alcohol, raisins, prunes, charred wood, sweet liquorice candy, sherry, caramel, toffee, Schwarzwald cake, dark roast coffee, hazelnut paste, raisins, prunes, dates and hints of sherry and sweet Indonesian soy sauce. Taste is incredibly rich and complex, sweet, tiny bitter and malty with roasted malts, high quality dark chocolate, raisins, bourbon, vanilla fudge, shredded coconut, caramel, chocolate cake, raisins in rum, prunes, creme brûlée, liquorice fudge, brown sugar sweetened dark roast coffee, alcohol, sweet soy sauce and hints of alcohol. Mouthfeel is round, creamy, tiny boozy, rich and full bodied. Finish is sweet, slightly bitter and malty with roasted malts, rich dark chocolate, bourbon, vanilla fudge, roasted coconut, moist soil, charred wood, chocolate cake, hazelnut paste, creme brûlée, dark roast coffee, soil and hay. The impact of the barrel during the incredibly long aging time is incredible. Smell and taste is absolutely ridiculous. One of the best beers I’ve ever tried. It’s Kaggen good!!! 4.8!

Hands down the thickest, richest, tastiest substance I’ve had the honor to ingest. Pours dark as night with a dense thing dark mocha head, loads of bourbon on the nose. Taste is sweet, loads of bourbon with vanilla notes, as it warms chocolate and oak and s a bit of smokyness

Bottle.Pitch Black colour with small beige head.Aroma of Bourbon and Vanilla,sweet strong Warming alc,and hint of dark berries and earth.smooth and good full body feels oily and nice.But this beer is not over the moon good but still o.k.Happy to try this.
This is an unbelievable stout but if you like coffee in your stout then try the coffee. Best ever.

Pours black like oil. Bourbon on the nose and a little cocoa. Bourbon on the palate, very hot when fresh, and after a year I’ve noticed that that the bourbon cools off. I think I prefer it fresh to aged.

Wonderful beer, it makes everything else taste weak in comparison.
Great mix of coffee and vanilla and the alcohol is very well hidden.
Bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is bourbon with vanilla with a hint of chocolate. Taste is all bourbon with some vanilla and chocolate. Syrupy mouthfeel. Amazing beer.

On draught at freakin frog Las Vegas - pours pitch black with small tan head. Nose of bourbon, booze, malt. Very nice and soothing, warming beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On draught at Freakin’ Frog. Chocolate black color. Aroma is bourbon, licorice, smoke, oak, molasses, and dark chocolate. Taste is prune, bourbon, oak, molasses, chocolate, and toffee. Smooth syrup mouthfeel, but doesn’t feel heavy. Taste profile lingers long after you finish drinking.

Bottle. Pours a completely opaque oily black with a heavy, fine-grained, brown head. Nose is Mexican chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, espresso, pecans, and kecap manis. Creamy and sweet on the tongue -- bourbon, coffee cream, chocolate, turbinado sugar, dark roast coffee; some amazing stuff going on here, all merged together in something as heavy and heady as a triple-creme cheese or chocolate mousse. On the palate, it’s a dead ringer for dairy cream. Wow.

Was able to score just one 12 ouncer of the 2013 batch from my favorite bottle shop - Abe’s in Bethlehem, PA. Cracked this baby open for my birthday (8 December) and enjoyed it at cellar temperature.

Pours a deep, dark, dark, dark brown with ruby edges. There was less than a finger of tan head that dissipated pretty quickly and left some lace, but the lace itself was not very thick or sticky. The bourbon notes in the nose are striking. The mouthfeel is creamy and the roast profile is quite hearty, but secondary to the bourbon notes in the flavor profile. The bourbon and roasted notes blend perfectly on the finish.

This is a gem of an offering that lives up to the hype it receives on this and other beer sites.

2014 bottle. Pours an oily black with a thin and very dark tan head. The aroma is very powerful. It is big on bourbon along with heavy vanilla. Additionally, there are hints of chocolate and coffee. The taste is mildly sweet. As strong as the nose was the impressions from the taste come across even more. It remains dominated by bourbon while complimented by lots of vanilla. There are oak flavors, some chocolate and espresso coming through at the end. Aftertaste is long and lingering, being bourbon and espresso. Minimal carbonation, very slick in texture, and a heavy body. The alcohol content makes itself known immediately. Despite this fact, it is extremely easy to drink. I could see myself getting carried away quite easily with this one. This is what you look for in a stout, and its pretty close to perfect. If you find this, its an automatic purchase. With very few contenders, it might be the best beer I’ve ever had.

2012 vintage bottle, poured into a boston shaker.

No head, but thin lacing around the sides. Thick, oily and totally opaque. Really nice looking beer.

Nose is sweet bourbon and vanilla. Oak notes.

I remember having this in 2012 and it was a lot rougher; the aging has treated it well. Obviously big on the bourbon taste, big hints of vanilla, coffee, dark fruits, even maple syrup. A lingering aftertaste of butter/butterscotch was apparent in this bottle, which I had never experienced with younger bottles.

Feels oily and dense in the mouth, very little carbonation.

Overall a wonderfully complex beer, worth it’s rating in every way.

Amazing beer! Jet black pour, very thin tan head. Full bourbon aroma filling the nose followed by dark roasted coffee. Amazing balance of flavor. Prominent bourbon but not overpowering, allowing the roasted malt and coffee of the base stout to be present as well. Wonderfully smooth for a 14% beer. Almost makes me wish for cold nights in front of the fire again.
Wonderful and thick mixture of the most different aromas. Coffee with malt, some sour moments, a bit of chocolate and sweetish sirup. Very different, very special - good one.

Bottle from trade with BenH - thank you a million for it! The stout pours out of the bottle in a beautiful deep dark black colour with creamy and low head and a smooth body. Wonderful aroma of chocolate, biscuits and coffee. Taste of cake, malt, rye, barley, bread, chocolate, coffee and cream. Very quaffable, smooth and tasty beer - it is a real taste explosion.
Tap at Bricks. Pours black with reddish brown head. Good lacing. Nose is bourbon, chocolate and caramel. Taste is straight bourbon and a little chocolate.

The barrels must be soaking... So much bourbon booze coming through on the nose along with various roasted and vinous notes, vanilla and chocolate just to balance it out. The mouthfeel is heavy/creamy with so much medium rosted malt, chocolate, vanilla and even light notes of coconut, some licorice and big bourbon flavour. Long aftertaste.. So glad I can get theese year round in Denmark and I’m happy to pay $12 for a small bottle of this. Now send some BC coffee and such over here too.
Rerated feb 2018
Haven’t seen in Denmark for years now. Still love this beer - actually even more so. OG of BA stouts. Bumping the score from 4.2 to 4.4

Bottle from Ølbutikken i Copenhagen. Pours a pitch black with little or no brown leather head. Wow, this is a treat. Almost sirupy and oily mouthfeel. Nose is oak, burnt wood, bourbon vanilla and coffee. Taste is like sipping a nice glass of bourbon - warm and soothing - then comes great espresso and dark rich chocolate. Absolutely the best stout I've had till this day.

- with thirst, Niklas

My bootle of Goose Island's BCS 2012 was picked up at a shop in Copenhagen & dragged back to Japan. Opened to celebrate hitting 1300 ratings on ratebeer. Served in a snifter. 15% an inky black viscous pour with ruby highlights & a thin ruddy tan head. Potent aroma of smooth bourbon, vanilla, oakiness & creamy chocolate plus a little bit of sharp booziness. Wow, very smooth body, creamy thick meaty mouthfeel with a ton of warmth as it pleasantly burns it's way down my throat. Meaty, savoury umami flavor, roasty, some cherry syrup candy like notes, bourbon, light oak, vanilla, coconut. One of the smoothest barrel aged beers I've ever had. Aged 2 years it is simply grand, I'd love to try it fresh though to see if it is as smooth!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2013 bottle....Oct 10th. Great blend of vanilla, toffee, and charcoal laced with roasted malt on the nose. Ebony black in appearance, almost no head however. Ultra sweet, but balanced with bitter chocolate notes at first. Then the burn melds everything together nicely. Slightly slick mouth feel. Finishes with a warm glow, and muted remnants of the initial flavors, slightly muted.

20012 Bottle from Trembling Madness in York. Pours black with a chocolatey head that disappears very quickly. Loads of flavours going on. Sweet with bourbon very much at the forefront. Oak, vanilla, chocolate, caramel notes in there. The alcohol is prominent, but warming rather than intrusive. Personally I felt the bourbon overpowered the flavours from the stout a bit too much. That said, this is still a mighty fine beer.

Walked into Top Hops on a whim while in New York with my cousins and boy was this a joy to stumble across. This is one of the most complex beers I have ever drank. Big bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, and roast are all wrapped together by a silky, dare I say, motor oil like viscosity. Absolutely fantastic! Glad this one is still made in Chicago!

On tap at waterfront ale house, never thought I would walk in here and find this.. All the better. Pours jet black with very thin pretty brown head. Aroma is toffee, raw coffee, chocolate, vanilla, some bourbon / booze, sweet malt. Taste is vanilla, blast of sweet sugar / malt, caramel, coffee, and oh yeah... Bourbon! Really boozy on the back end, but it's great... Especially if you love bourbon. thick thick stuff, almost have to chew it. Full mouthfeel, low carbonation. Hype warranted.

Reviewed from notes.
The appearance had a jet black body that leaves a two finger dark tan/brown head that quickly dies to a film coating the top of the beer, no lacing.
The smell had bourbon straight up, wow, mainly bourbon for the 2 hour sipping period, however, some chocolate did come out.
The taste was sweet and hot due to the alcohol and chocolate combination, sweet sticky aftertaste and finish.
On the palate, she sits a medium to heavy as the alcohol was felt perhaps a bit too much for me. Carbonation seemed spot on and did feel pretty smooth all around, probably would make a nice winter sipper.
Overall, well, it seemed like a bourbon bomb to me, but I would say that was a bit my fault for having it when I did, still I will say this is good for its style and I wouldn’t mind having one again and hope its aged a bit more.
Complex bourbon, coffee, vanilla, roasted malts full bodied flavor and aroma. Goose Island can rest its reputation on this beer alone. Happy that it’s still brewed in the City of Big Shoulders.

Bottle. I’ve had this a few times now and never got around to rating. Pours as described MIDNiGHT, you can encourage a dark khaki head if poured aggressively, but it disappears just as quickly as it develops, no lace. Aroma is so creamy sweat, like Irish cream without the mint, milk chocolate, hint of coffee, and obviously bourbon. Tastes silky smooth, a touch bitter and a 
Title bite. Alcohol, vanilla, woody. Great stuff.

35,5cl bottle (2012) from Micro bar, Manchester. Pours dark old motor oil like, with a rather small beige head. Complex and quite intense. Bourbon whiskey is quite dominating in aroma. Malt, caramel, chocolate, wooden notes and hints of vanilla also present. Fairly sweet, but very well balanced - slightly sour notes and a balanced bitterness. Smooth, very flavourful and delicious.

On bottle with Visionthing, thanks a lot!! Black color, some brownish foam, very high viscosity. Aromas of bourbon, malt, dried fruits; high aroma intensity- also chocolate and vanilla . Full body & high complexity. Long lingering aftertaste. Very enjoyable
@Nedre Mölla 26/3-14. Flaska från Kihoskh, Köpenhamn. Arom: Vanilj, trä, lakrits, bourbon. Smak: Samma som arom men även en kakao och choklad. Ganska lång avslutning.

2013 bottling, aged 5 months. Poured opaque black with a small, thin dark tan head that was gone quickly. Vanilla and wood aroma, with a boozy note of bourbon and some chocolate underneath. Medium-to-full body, mildly oily. Roasty and chocolatey malt flavors giving way to notes of vanilla and wood. Light boozy astringency in the finish. Really good.

Lote del 2012. Color negro opaco, espuma beige que desaparece pronto. Aromas de dulces de frutas confitadas, maíz, pasas, bourbon. Muy densa en boca, con inicio dulce pero, sobre todo, de licor y, nuevamente, fruta confitada y bourbon. El regusto es ligeramente amargo, cálido y licoroso. Excelente sin duda, si bien en Europa tenemos ejemplos a la altura.

Rating number 200. Shared with my future son in law Russell... Bottle to a snifter. Big complex nose full of bourbon, dark roast coffee, dark chocolate and toffee. Fills the palate with waves of deliciousness, great balance hides the ABV well. One of the best Stouts anywhere. Meant to be savored slowly while thinking deep thoughts and solving all the problems of the world ... Or watching March madness... Go Bucks!!!

Wow. I can’t say enough good about this beer. Notes of chocolate and bourbon, a little alcohol, thick but silky texture, high ABV gives you a warming sensation after every sip. As good a beer as I’ve ever had.

Pours like molasses. Oak or cherry taste, like pouring dark chocolate into your mouth- could only have a few sips. Absolutely delicious, hard to find, so should only be used for drinking, but if I had a few bottles of it I would use it to make a beef bourginon or duck sauce.

A great bourbon stout. Pours a deep black with little head. Smells like bourbon and cream. Very thick taste, lots and lots of bourbon, with a finish reminiscent of creme brÃ»lÃ©e. Great stuff, but boozy. More balanced then many Bourbon beers. Had on tap at Olde Sonoma Public House. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from north Carolina. pours thick and black. Smells thick and sweet of vanilla and raison. Tastes thick, sweet of raison, peat, and a little bourbon.

Draft@ Roanoke VA Rare Beer Festival 2014: Walnut hazelnut, dark roasted malt aroma. Murky dark brown, thin beige head, legs. Chewy full body. Fudge, walnut, and bourbon flavors swirling together in equal proportions. AB owned or not, this is a fantastic beer. Delightful.

Bottle from Fort Lauderdale. Black with some tan lacing. Smells of booze, then bourbon then some mild woody gear. Taste is booze, bourbon and vanilla. Not especially sweet like too many bourbon stouts, but there is a strong heat and alcohol bite. Gets better as it warms; far less astringent with booze and malt combo. Still way too much - apparently needs plenty of ageing (3.8).


Update on this one. On draught at Local Option, Chicago. Lovely caramel and bourbon flavours. Not at all as boozy as bottle I had in Florida. Overall, a great stout (4.2).

Second update. Drank a 2013 vintage bottle March 2015. Now the booze bite is almost non existent, but the flavours and big body remain. A great beer! (4.3)

2012 bottle poured into a tulip. Complete darkness with the smallest chocolate brown head. Big nose full of bourbon, dark chocolate and vanilla. Can’t remember another beer smelling this great. Taste follows. Great bourbon character that is silky smooth with dar chocolate, vanilla , malt and a subtle sweetness. Very balanced considering the abv. Great brew

2012 vintage. Pours a deep dark thick black brown with a small brown head. Aroma is a rich dark roasted chocolate malt, dark dried fruit of raisins plums, has strong sweet bourbon barrel alcohol essence with some wood barrel undertones. Taste is a sweet rich dark bourbon alcohol flavor with a bit woodsy notes, some chocolate and dark fruit raisin, plums, some vanilla notes, roasted malt and bitterness on the end. Palate is a full rich creamy viscous body, leaves a bit of an oily resin mouth feel, but smooth going down. Seems a bit heavy on the bourbon though, a bit overpowering on the alcohol. Leaves a long lingering flavorful sweet bourbon alcohol flavor and a bit of woodsy vanilla notes on the end. This is definitely one to sip and share on a cold winter eve.

Thick dark dark brown almost black. No affect from room light. Scents of dark chocolate vanilla and bourbon. Milk thick smooth creamy nutty taste then the bourbon kick comes in with force. Sweet but with a bourbon bite.

I never thought I’d taste something this close to perfection. Bourbon County was an excellent find, and I will be on the prowl for this whenever i need that ’something special’ to share with a friend.

Bottle share, thanks, Stein! Aroma is dark and boozy. Appearance is black with a brown head. Taste is bourbon. There is hints of dark fruit. The finish is dark malt with a bourbon sweetness. Overall, a good beer. A little strong, but hey, doesn't like gettin a good buzz going?

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pure bourbon glory. I popped a fresh bottle and poured it. The nose is big on the bourbon and hot..nice. The taste is out of this world bourbon glory. Some people age this to "mellow" out the hot bourbon fire but they are fools. If you consume more than 1 bottle in a sitting your shards will be black as the deep ocean and smell like bourbon. Great beer, highly collectable.

Like nothing you'll ever try. 
Smelled beautiful and had very full flavour. 
You won't want too many though! Not at 15%

Full flavor, rich and delicious. The 2012 release was the best beer I've ever had to that point; still true two years later.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Avery Strong Ale Festival. Appearance: slight redish brown head, black color, good lacing. Aroma: bourbon, chocolate, oak, caramel. Palate: alcohol heat, full body, soft carbonation, oily texture. Taste: swee, slight woody bitterness. Overall, one of my favorites of the event.
I love bourbon, so I was incredibly happy to finally have this. The smell and taste just oozed with bourbon. It was fantastic!

I don’t think I’ve ever rated a beer a perfect or not, but this deserves it. Black in the glass - completely opaque. Tiny short lived tan head. Aroma is oaky with mild vanilla bourbon notes. Fine carbonation gives it an active mouth feel. Flavor is huge. Deep roasted malts, dark fruits flavor, mild vanilla sweetness. All those flavors are in perfect balance. Fantastic beer.
This may be the best beer I’ve ever had. Pours a deep ruby brown, with a dark cream colored head. Smells of dark fruits and caramel and warms as it goes down. Amazing.

Bottle sample at a tasting at our place. Thanks avrashi. 2012 bottle. Pure black and opaque. Very alcoholic but after a few minutes some vanilla and then alcohol again. Alcoholic, vanilla and faint bitterness in the mouth. VERY smooth, full-bodied, a little chocolate finish.

2012 Vintage and big thanks to my kids for knowing what Daddy "really" wants for Christmas! Poured a lovely dense oily dark brown colour with a round, glass hugging, tan head and a little fizzy when first poured. The aroma is rich roasted malt, molasses, coffee, dark chocolate. The flavour is moderate to strong bitter, moderate sweet with a lovely rich smooth creamy caramel, alcoholic liqourice, malty palate with an oily mouthfeel and a long creamy bitter finish. Full bodied with flat carbonation. A real whale of a beer and fully deserving of the rating. In fact, if I could buy this stuff by the case i’d probably give up ticking altogether!

12 oz bottle. Pours a thick black with a small brown head and little to no lacing. Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, oak, and molasses. Taste changes with every sip. Chocolate, bourbon, and dark fruit are prominent.

Big aroma of bourbon initially with some charred oak in the background. Color is black with only a small thin beige head. Mouthfeel is delicate and smooth with a warming alcohol sensation. Finishes a bit dry. Flavor is outstanding, roasted malts, chocolate, charred smoky wood and bourbon. Has a distinct sweet syrupy bitter finish. Just perfect!
One tasty delicious beer. Lives up to all the hype. What a bourbon barrel stout should taste like.

Aroma - packed full of alcohol, roast, dark fruit, caramelized sugar.
Appearance - * on draft *; very dark black/brown body; tan head but from tap it never really had a head at all ~ that greatly affected my notes
Taste - it’s super complex - roast, caramelized sugar, fig, prunes, raisins, dates, abundant alcohol, coffee - there is a lot going on here
Palate - body is full, texture is thick/slick/creamy all at once - chewy even; carbonation is soft; the finish is packed with alcohol. This is a big, big beer. Not for beginners at all.

Bottle. 2012. Huge toffee, dark fruit aroma - massive - puddingy sweet dark fruit, figs, prunes... Fullish body, medium carbonation. Big, stupid beer... lots of booze, lots of soy, sticky dark fruit... Puddingy. Tasty.

Amazing bourbon flavor here but super smooth and balanced. Overall excellent beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, thnx for timfoolery for sending me this! VIntage 2012. I was really looking forward to this beer and actually refused several small samples before because I wanted to rate an entire bottle for myself.. Greedy me. And what better way to rate this as rating #2000. Anywayzz.. It pours liquid blackness out of the bottle with a very thin, brownish head on top. Aroma is bourbon all over, with touces of burnt malts, vanilla, booze, molasses and licorice. Absolutely amazing. First sip is simply astonishing. Full, very thick mouthfeel and exploding flavors. Very sweet and sugary to start off with, loads of barrel characters and slight boozyness. There is some vanilla presence in there for sure. The alcohol is defintely present in a long lasting, light burning sweet aftertaste. Really need a knife and a fork for this beer, amazing. A great sipper, very thick and creamy. This is how a barrel aged imperial stout should be. Amazing stuff!

bottle at the Hoppy Pub - Pours really black with a dark brown head that leaves thin laces on my glass. Perfect bourbon aroma, vanilla, oak wood and coffee. Full body with low carbonation. Silky mouthfeel with notes of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, wood but most of all perfect bourbon. Lasting aftertaste that dries my mouth. One of the best beers I’ve ever had. This was 2012 batch with 15%abv. Kept my 2 last bottles for aging...

Bottle. From notes back when this stuff was on the shelf with an ugly label. Pours a deep jet black with slight tan head. Aroma is boozy chocolate with some toffee and slight unroasted coffee. Taste is a thick chocolate milk shake with a burnt finish. Great stuff when this was easily obtained and consumed in a graveyard watching old movies. #cinespia 2007

On tap at GTWM 2013. Pitch black body. Brown-beige head. Massive, sweet, sticky. I don’t get many defining traits between this and the original. Nice.
Earlier Rating: 11/15/2011 Total Score: 3.8
Numerous drafts at Dexters.  Opaque black with a thin, oily, brown head.  Big boozy aroma.  Rich chocolate bourbon tones, not much hop character to speak of.  Oaky vanilla with a harsh alcohol note.  Mellows as it sits, but this is a beast of an Imperial Stout no matter how you slice it.  Oak, vanilla, coffee, booze, chocolate.

Sweet trade extra. Pours nearly black with thick lasting brown head. Scent is booze, chocolate, caramel, bourbon, and coffee. Sweet up front that drops into an earthy bite. Thick like a milkshake with great liveliness. Bottle - Received as Extra.

Pours jet black with a thin head. Aroma of bourbon, malt and alcohol. Tastes like heaven in a bottle, notes of chocolate, coconut and malts. Absolutely fantastic beer, smooth mouthfeel and no alcohol burn, even at nearly 15% abv. I would drink this every day.

Bottle.
Very dark pour, light brown head. 
The bourbon is very apparent in both nose and taste. Undertones of malt. Sweet finish. Full body. Soft carbonation.

Every time I drink it, I think this is one of the best beers I will ever taste. Pours very dark with a tan head that dissipates very shortly. Aroma is traditional stout with the oak and vanilla of bourbon shining through. Taste is sweet stout up front with a kick of alcohol Port in a good way. Leads to a very nice roasty and balanced aftertaste. There is nothing more I can add that hasn't been said about this. Top quality all the way and the standard for all other bourbon barrel aged beers.

Still a favorite session. A fabulous monster of a beer, not to be trifled with. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It is a great beer compared to the alcohol volume. It is quite strong but still smooth

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is the holy grail of beers. If you haven’t tried it, you must. Do your best to find a pre-acquisition bottle. The latest year seems to have lost something. Smells like creamy bourbon and toffee. Pours black as motor oil with very little head. Taste is a perfect combination of oak, vanilla, chocolate, and smoke. Lingers nicely on the palate.

@ Holler’s Hops and Grill / Florence KY --- Opaque brown/black, thin rim head, no lace. Taste is burnt toast and malt that blooms in a big way through the palate, adding light hints of chocolate along the way. A touch of bourbon provides all the balance that is needed in the finish. This is a huge brew that drinks much more easily than its 14% would imply. One of the best. Highest recommendations.

12oz bottle, 2013 Vintage, compliments of Dave. F. Black hue, zero visibility fully-diminishing dark brown head. No lacing (this may be due to not having proper glassware). The only aroma that I could pull out of this beer was bourbon, I had this confirmed with the three other people that I was enjoying this with. Strong bourbon on the initial taste with hints of chocolate on the finish. The bourbon was so overpowering that it took away from the flavor. May be better to let it sit a year or so. I will look for it next year.

Bottle thanks to klimaet. 2016 Edition. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, light burnt malt, toffee, light boozy,  sweet caramel. Black with no head. Taste is moderate sweet and light bitter. Full body, smooth oily feel and bourbon boozy finish.8/4/8/5/18

2012 bottle. Aroma of booze, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, spicy, roasted malt. Black with no head. Taste is light booze, moderate sweet, spicy, bourbon. Full body, smooth feel and bourbon finish. 9/5/8/5/18
Nice kick to it, the bourbon kick. Sooper sweet with a bitter note. The kick is a nice balance of alcohol. Won best beer in Illinois 2013 RateBeerBest!

2012. Can’t beat the aroma of this thing (actually, you can -- see: Rare BCBS). Fudge, whisky, mountains of milk and dark chocolate, vanilla cake, dark malts, and only the slightest suggestion of roast. Very sweet and powerful. The taste is sweet and powerful, with a nice chocolatey bitterness to it, but it can be overwhelmingly intense. Sticky, syrupy, oily mouthfeel with nominal carbonation. The alcohol becomes more evident as the thing approaches room temperature. A meal, and quite an inebriating one at that.
12oz bottle pours a thick oil dark brown with no head and little brown oil lacing. Bourbon barrel stout goodness.

One of the highest-quality beers I have ever had. If you have the chance to purchase it, buy as many as you possibly can. It has over 14% ABV, but you cannot tell at all! Absolutely incredible beer. So creamy and rich...tones of chocolate, coffee, toffee, caramel, and bourbon come together BEAUTIFULLY. TOP-NOTCH beer.

Tasted 2015, 2017, 2018, 2019. Opaque. Nose of vanilla, chocolate, almond. Full body, silky/oily texture, very intensely flavored, amazingly dense, hot mouthfeel, avg length. Sweet, just a little bitterness. Flavor is very fruity, roasty, jammy and alcoholic, like spirits (Tia Maria), blackcurrant jam, vanilla, dried fruit (dates, raisins, prunes), earthy. Delicious, tried the 2014, 2015, 2017, 2018, 2019.

The appearance of this brew is an opaque black with a large tan head, and the aroma is a rich blend of chocolate, caramel and roasted malts, bourbon, booze, and vanilla. The taste is a completely amazing blend of a heavy umami, mild sourness, and a touch of sweetness, and the palate fuses an oily texture, full body, long and robust finish, and a soft carbonation.

Ran out of snifters and boy am I regretting it. This dark beauty pours a soulless black charcoal with a burnt root-beer colored top-hat. Just wow. Aroma sweet molasses, bourbon, vanilla, butter, butterscotch, and malt. Taste and palate are near perfect for a beer that’s TOO GOOD to have with a cigar. Although I’m sure it would pair nicely, I can’t imagine putting anything else in my mouth that would take away from this masterpiece. The body is THICK and allows the flavors to linger minutes after tasting. I pull all the flavors in taste that I get from the nose and I’m not left confused by too many flavors. Its a stout like this that’s simple, elegant, and delectable that make me want more and saying "damn, that’s a good beer." Thanks again to BMILLSY for the beer. Damn good and easily a top 3 for me. I hope to grab more of these in the future. Woah, this is strong stuff...

Bottle (2013) poured into a snifter. Pours a jet black with a finger tan head that recedes fairly quick. Aromas of dark fruit, big bourbon, light tobacco, dark chocolate, light vanilla. Tasting notes of big bourbon, dark fruit, dark chocolate, roast, Full body, semi-dry warm finish. The booze creeps up easily with how smooth the beer seems.
Big aroma and full flavored! Coats your palate with Bread, Caramel, Bourbon, Roasty, butterscotch

Pours inky black with a very small tan head that quickly dissipated. Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, roasted coffee beans. Taste is sweet with a hint of bitters, mostly sweet. Heavy body, oily and smooth. Alcohol is exceptionally well hidden. An excellent imperial stout.
2012 vintage. Previously I had only tasted the 2013 coffee variant. Predictably delicious.

Pours an opaque (almost oily looking) black with little-to-no head. Minor lacing which settled into a small ring. 

Strong coffee and bourbon notes up front.

Silky smooth texture without being syrupy. 

Definitely strong but not overly boozy. 

Drank in Kentucky Bourbon Barrel snifter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark black with light brown head. Has a strong bourbon, vanilla, and roasted malt aroma. Taste is very strong and rich with coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, bourbon, and some spices. After taste is a mix between what you’d expect with a stout (chocolate/coffee) and bourbon combined.

Très noire. Peu de collet. Nez: bourbon. Alcool. Banane. Vanille. Bouche: très riche. Grosse chaleur d'alcool. Anis/racine de réglisse. Chocolat noir. Très boisé. Fruité. Cerise noire. Datte. Pruneau. Forte amertume bien dosé avec le gros sucre de malt. Vanille. Belle présence du bourbon sans détruire la bière. Sublime.

A: black, tan head
S: bourbon, bourbon, bourbon
T: chocolate, dark roasts, boozy
M: slick, oily
O: one of the best bourbon BA stouts hands down

Love this beer! Rich boozy comforting and savory. Sought after for a reason. Big abv but not overwhelmingly boozy. Well balanced, try it with some cheesecake. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A: Dark black, tan head, nice alcohol legs. 

S: Strong bourbon, coconut, vanilla, molasses, toffee, caramel, roasted coffee, and dark chocolate. Absolutely love this aroma more and more the more I smell it.

T: In the beginning the flavor strongly resembles the aroma - dark chocolate, molasses, dark coffee roast, vanilla, coconut, toffee, caramel. Then it goes more into the roasted malts special roast, roasted barley and get hints of the alcohol. The aftertaste is sweet with some residual sweetness with a mild aftertaste.

M: Full-bodied and thick, with calm alcohol burn for how much is in it.

O: Im not really into Bourbon aged beer but this one is just amazing. Saw a liquor store that still has a few cases left, might have to stock up a bit.
Pitch black, chewy BBA goodness. Spice, licorice, vanilla, mocha, bark/earthy undertones. Very strong alcohol on the front and the back...just constant booziness actually. Love it.
Real good beer! Lots of bourbon taste, high abv (hidden well) and the color is perfectly black with thin light brown head.
Dark as night. Smells like a nice glass of bourbon, rocks. Taste like coffee, bourbon, bourbon barrels. Super creamy velvet finish. Don’t know if there can be a better beer

?/2013: Opened Jan 2014. Dark as night. Smells of vanilla, bourbon warmth, a little coffee. Taste is the same; very intense and rich, intensely creamy and thick. Alcohol warmth in the aftertaste.

10/14: 13.8%. Opened 4/11/15. Opaque black. No head in 12oz. snifter. Smell is fresh, warm, chocolate, rich molasses, rye, floral raisin. Taste is intense, smooth and rich rum/bourbon flavor. Slightly sweet with cocoa bitterness, body is not too heavy. Another six months sounds about right.

2017: Color is jet-black as ever. Smell is dark, thick, leather sweet. Taste is tobacco, rich dark fruit, marshmallow fluff, huge coffee and cocoa flavor. It's the stout that keeps on giving.

2019: yup, it's BCBS. Super boozy this year, maybe I'm just getting old
Sweet. licorice, and some alcohol in the aroma. Molasses, brown sugar malt flavor; not a lot of roasted flavor. Moderate bitterness.
On tap at Belmont Station in Portland. Black pour. Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Very sweet with flavors of roasted malts and chocolate. Not as creamy as expected. Nice but too sweet.

33cl in a Delirium Tremens glass. 2012 Vintage. Pours a thick black colour (second only to Black Albert). This truly is the best beer I have tasted. The amount of aroma and flavour really has to be experienced to be believed. The mouthfeel is thick and rewarding (and very sticky). The most flavoursome (Bourbon, smoke and dried fruits) of any beer I have ever tried or could even imagine. As a diehard Belgian fan I have to admit that this is the best beer I have ever tasted. Perfect.

12 oz bottle into a snifter. Pours black with a small tan head that leaves light lacing. Smells of Bourbon, vanilla, oak and chocolate. Tastes of the same things. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with good carbonation. Awesome barrel aged stout! Top notch all around. Lives up to its hype.

Perfect stout. As soon as you own it you smell bourbon, chocolate, an vanilla. Tastes the same, starting with a strong hit of bourbon that eases into vanilla and chocolate. For my money this is the best beer out there. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Looking forward to t finding this beer for a long time. Don’t know if I had to high of expectations for this beer or what but I was disappointed. Great beer none the less just not what I expected. Still looking forward to trying the Java version, hopefully it’ll redeem itself.

2012 and 2013 were poured in a side by side taste test.

A - Black as night with a dense dark mocha head that takes it’ time going down. This coated my glass turning it brown.

S - Bourbon, vanilla, dark caramel, loads of sweet barley, cherries, decadent chocolate, strong coffee, very rich aroma. More vanilla and cherry in the 2013. The 2012 had more of a leathery/melded caramel malt aroma.

T - Big bourbon flavor, thick caramel with a hint of char, huge vanilla and amaretto flavor, aggressive whiskey soaked wood, a complex mix of cocoa, coffee, sweet dark fruit, alcohol was more evident in the 2013. The finish flashes all previous flavors with a nice whiskey roundness.

M - The silkiest, smoothest beer I’ve had to date. Carbonation is medium to low with incredible creaminess. Heavy and viscous body coating the palate with a velvety feel.

Wow! This is one of the best barrel aged stouts, if not the best I’ve ever had. It’s pure bliss. I liked the 2013 better than the 2012 but both were incredible. Highly recommended.

Serving type: bottle

01-15-2014

On tap at Whole Foods Devon. Opaque black with oily tan head. Bourbon, vanilla, toffee, roast, alcohol. Moderately bitter, quite sweet. Thick malty body with light carbonation. No subtlety whatsoever. A little too over the top.

Saved for 200th rating. Pored from bottle into glass. Aroma hits you quickly, bourbon and chocolate. Taste is same with a bit more chocolate in finish. Overall very smooth given abv. Would love to try this 1 year from now after being aged.

2012 bottle @ Kitty’s Public House, Helsinki. 

Black stuff with thin layer of dark brown foam. Strong and enjoyable aroma, feels like now it’s real thing! Taste is "pretty easy" and balanced for this ABV. Good partner for long relationship. Finally found this :) Something still missing, maybe more age to soften?




2009 bottle @ MBT. Thanks Senior!




Black stuff with thin brown foam layer. Whisky a like aroma. Pretty awesome... Last time I wished more age to soften. Now it’s a real thing. Brilliant beer, empty with words. 9-4-9-4-18.
The aroma is really the perfect blend of Bourbon, vanilla, and chocolate. Taste is similar. An amazing stout.

2012 Vintage into a snifter, BB Nov 2013 apparently. Big black pour, forms a short-lived brown head. Smell - lots of bourbon as expected, sweet, alcoholic, burnt plastic. Body is medium to big and smooth, a touch of carbonation and ever so slightly foamy. Taste - sweet boozy molasses and liquorice. Very punchy up front but not overdone or sharp. Some chocolate comes through as the flavour trails off. A little tang from the alcohol but it’s not drinking like it’s 15%. Very good.   An imperial stout that my girlfriend likes?  Hats off to Goose Island.

Draft at Proof. Pours dark black with very thin cream colored head. Smell is rich chocolate, aged bourbon, and vanilla. Taste is roasted malts, bourbon, fresh vanilla, oak, and coffee. Probably the smoothest stout I’ve had, quite tasty, well balanced, but does not live up to hype or price point.

Pours black with a thin tan head. Wood, roasted malt, alcohol, chocolate and soy sauce aroma. Chocolate, roasted malt, oak, bourbon, soy sauce, vanilla and coffee flavors. Full body with low carbonation, Slightly sweet with lingering roasted flavor and a oak, chocolate and boozy finish. 13, 14
A man’s beer! A very dark appearance with a strong bourbon aroma. The taste is sweet with a bourbon finish.
Very dark, strong caramel flavor, nice mild and smooth bourbon after taste, almost over powering amount of dark roasted malty flavor

2012 bottle into a snifter. Appearance is pitch, pitch black, absolutely no light escaping. No head at all apart from a few bubbles around the side. Aroma is complex- lots of smooth chocolate, dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee, vanilla, bit of leather. Taste= wow! Rich chocolate syrup, coffee/espresso, bitterness, some burnt malty notes, lots of vanilla and whisky in the finish. Amazingly well balanced and the alcohol is pretty much hidden until the finish. A smooth, silky mouthfeel, bit like chocolate fudge, with a long and satisfying finish. An absolutely amazing beer!

This beer has an amazingly rich black color. It has the aroma of vanilla and smoked oak. Flavors of burnt brown sugar creme brûlée make this one of my favorite beers ever!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 vintage, bottle. Pours pitch black, oily, small mocha head that disappears quickly. Smells of bourbon, some oak and very round tones of burnt malt. Phenomenal taste that really lives up to the hype. Lots of dark fruits, bourbon, vanilla, oak and layers upon layers of burnt tones. A must-try beer.

Bourbon County Brand Stout is one of those beers that has a reputation that precedes it. The problem with beers like these, is that they don’t always live up to the hype, especially BA beers. I poured a 2013 BCBS into a snifer at about 48 degrees F.					
					
					
					
					

BCBS pours like motor oil and generates almost no head, even when poured straight down the middle of the glass. The beer leaves impressive legs on the side of the glass, with a slight stain effect lasting for 15-20 seconds before it dissapears down into the murky depths below.					
					
					
					
					

The aroma is intense, with dark chocolate and touches of coffee hitting you right up front. The bourbon character saturates the nose and leaves no question that this is a huge beer with lots of boozy character. I get touches of anise, licorice, and molasses present with other touches of vanilla, caramel, and smoke/roast present.					
					
					
					
					

The taste is big, bold and boozy, with molasses and dark chocolate syrup dominating the tongue from the beginning. There are notes of vanilla and oak that come through the middle, along with roast and bourbon that scream BA imperial stout. 					
					
					
					
					The finish and aftertaste is almost entirely hot and boozy, with the dark molasses sweetness of the imperial stout shining through until the very end. Absolutely excellent.					
					
					
					
					

The mouthfeel is lush and velvety, and there is enough alcohol presence that this is definitely a sipping beer all around. The palate is perfect for a BA stout.					
					
					
					
					

BCBS definitely lives up to the hype, and while I wouldn’t say it is the absolute best BA imperial stout I’ve ever had (that distinction belongs to Founders KBS), it’s probably the 2nd best. 					
					
					
					
					When this was released on Black Friday, I bought a full case, and I’m looking forward to trying this every few months as it ages.

Hot boozy aroma hits the nose. Vanilla, raisin and plum, some toasty notes. Goes down fiery at first with long bourbon notes of vanilla and toasted coconut. Great beer on a cold night. Would do well with some age
A beer wich I wish I had a case of, it would last a few years at least. took me 3 hours to savour this splendid brew with a friend.

Aromas of coffee and chocolate, some other complexities present but not overpowering. Absolutely pitch black, no light shines through, even at the very edges, only complaint is no discernibke head. Tastes sweet initially, then the bourbon kicks in, and finally the heat joins the party. This beer is 14+% and is not afraid to let you know it. Surprisingly drinkable with a body not unlike warm maple syrup. Quite possibly the best beer I have tasted, tossup between this, KBS and Backwoods Bastards (bourbon lover? Me? Not a chance.)

Very flavorful, very good beer. Surprised InBev cares about flavor suddenly. /snark

Pours black as night, with a paper thin, almost non existent head. Aromas of oak, vanilla, and a little bit smoky the14.9%alcohol comes through in an overall intense and epic aroma. Tastes of vanilla, bourbon, and caramel mask the alcohol. Ends with a thick mouth feel.

What a beer - considered by many to be one of the best beers in the world. 


I am not the biggest fan of oak-aging in general, but I will try not to be too biased. Oak-aging is normally reserved for spirits (40% alcohol or higher), in order to mellow them, filter out some unwanted flavors, and add some new ones (mostly vanilla). For beer, barrel-aging is generally not necessary and in my opinion it often does more harm than good.



For this beer, they brewed a very strong, flavorful stout, with an ABV that is very high for beer, but of course still very low compared to spirits. Thankfully, it stands up to the barrel-aging pretty well.



In terms of flavor, there is some smoke and wood flavor here, but it also has an almost overwhelming level of malty sweetness, molasses, vanilla, brown sugar, and creme brule. Burnt and roasted malts are there as well, although the classic stout flavors are pretty much drown out by everything else. At 60 IBU’s, there are not enough hops to adequately balance out all of the extremely strong, sweet, malty flavors.



I had this at a tasting - maybe I would have enjoyed it more if I could spend a few hours drinking one bottle, to savor it a bit more slowly. But to me it was excessive, almost cloying, and a bit harsh. I’ll admit that it did have the complexity they were aiming for, but I feel that they have sacrificed enjoyment in the name of making something bigger and more extreme.



It would probably be better with a bit less malt, at 11-12% ABV, with more hops for balance. As it stands it is a great stout, but certainly not the best.

It clears the nasal passages. Taste is extremely rich and thick. More alcohol on the finish with vanilla, caramel and oak. Sweetness rounds out the finish. Excellent beer.

A 12 oz bottle of the f-ing holy grail of bourbon barrel stouts. 2013 edition son! Pours out a midnight black. Like black hole in space black. No head what-so-ever. Wonderful smells of vanilla, oak, and sweet sweet bourbon. The taste hits hard with vanilla caramel. But the oak really comes through as well. Gives it a nice smokey wood taste. A really awesome aftertaste with this as well. Smooth notes of sweet bourbon linger and burn in your mouth. Which is a good thing. In my honest opinion, pretty close to perfection. This beer made my karate chop my sofa in half. It’s that good.
This is perfection in my humble opinion. The flavor is so complex but yet so smooth and so very drinkable.
so this is the infamous BCBS. certainly is pretty good, one of the better ones out there. nice to finally try it.

Absolutely incredible. I love bourbon barrel stouts, and this is at the absolute top of my "best of" list. Was lucky enough to get the last 12oz bottle ar my local beer shop. Couldn’t have had a better beer to bring in the New Year. I looked forward to having this in great anticipation. And what a payoff. This stuff is black as motor oil and syrupy. The aroma is just over-the-top: bourbon, roasted malt, and even a soy sauce kind of smell. The bourbon flavor is what hits you first. Then, this beer has a smooth middle that’s hugely chocolatey with some coffee notes. The finish is very dry and has oak and caramel tones. Beer like this should be consumed like sacrament. It’s more than just a beer; it’s a monumental achievement that is a gift to those of us lucky enough to appreciate it.

Re-rating for 2015. Pint bottle poured into Finnish pub mug. The beer pours caramel black with a thin, dark khaki head that dissipates into a pencil collar. Wet, scattered lacing drips down the glass without sticking. Little to no carbonation can be seen. Aroma is malty, bourbon, caramel and coffee. The flavor is char and bourbon up front, with hints of oak, vanilla, coffee, and roasted malt. Thick body with a medium oily mouthfeel. The finish is a long, boozy char with round edges, not the bite of a typical charred imp stout. 

This is easily one of the finest beers ever crafted by man. The palate is balanced and distinct, with the ABV not tasted as much as felt. I’ve acquired several bottles with intent to age for years. Get your hands on this while you can.
