Une bouteille de 12 onces payée 4.99$ à Miami. Elle porte la date du 4 septembre 2013. À l’œil, le liquide qui est presque noir ne montre qu’un petit anneau de mousse. Sa viscosité est palpable. De longues jambes s’écoulent avec grâce et dangerosité. Le nez de cette concoction s’ouvre sur des parfums complètement décadents de gâteau chocolaté, de vanille, de friandise composée de miel et d’amandes, de bourbon richement caramélisé, de noix de coco et de sirop d’érable foncé. Gargantuesque, c’est peu dire. Une première lampée me permet de découvrir une impressionnante densité de malts opulents. Une seconde et les suivantes pour sentir sur mes papilles de stupéfiantes notes souples et épaisses d’un bourbon qui cherche à peine à se camoufler derrière des notes de sucre d’orge, de mélasse et de raisins secs qui ont préalablement macérés dans une vieille barrique de rhum épicé. Une réunion de l’énormité. Une fortune colossale qui érotise tous les mouvements de ma langue. Au palais, un liquide qui montre un corps qui possède une densité et une masse volumique optimales. La texture est pleinement unique, intense et très construite : j’ai l’impression folle qu’elle tend à se rapprocher de l’étape de la solidification. La finale est vicieuse, brûlée par les braises de l’enfer, douce comme les cuisses d’une Ukrainienne et florissante comme la démarche d’une Haïtienne qui se déhanche sur la Lincoln Road. Un beau cadeau pour ma 200ième bière noire impériale.// Few bottles since my first one.  Still an amazing impy sout.  2016 is so goood, awesome like every bad girls that I’ve met over the past years.
2013 edition. 12 oz bottle. Wow. Bourbon, vanilla, charred taste. A thick, chewy beer that does not taste like 14.9%. Very balanced. Long lingering after taste. A must try.

Nice bourbon warmth throughout the taste without it being overpowering. Typically I don’t like a ton of bourbon booziness in a stout, but this holds it up extremely well. Bourbon taste without the booziness. Nice vanilla sweetness in the front with some toffee and chocolate up there as well. Mid-palate is some of that molasses with the bourbon and earthy oak at the end. You certainly don’t get any of the 14.9% abv in this bad boy. Mouthfeel is nicely viscous without being thick, very low carbonation. Great beer...but I am slightly underwhelmed by all the hype.

There’s really not much else to say about this that hasn’t already been stated. It gets better with time and the new 2013 is off the charts! Do yourself a favor and seek this out if you have never had the chance to drink one.

Draft at Aces and Ales. Assume 2013 vintage. Pours black with a coffee brown head. Aroma of raisin, roasted malt, caramel, licorice, dark chocolate. A powerful brew with flavors of licorice, dark chocolate, raisiin, vanilla. Can’t really hide the abv. A big beer!

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a snifter tasting glass at about room temperature.

Aroma - Over powering smoke and wood smell. Some dark chocolate, leather, vanilla, and licorice. 

Appearance - Dark coffee pour with about two finger head. Has some carbonation and very little lacing at the top of glass.

Taste - Bourbon, wood, chocolate, and black licorice.

Palate - Very complex taste but the bourbon and wood stands out with a dry sweet finish.

Overall - Hopefully, overtime it becomes better as some ingredients mellow out and some mixed in more. First time tasting it and I have to say its worth seeking out if you are a bourbon or oak aged beer lover like me.

Bottle share taster. 2013. Black body with dark brown edges. Aroma is super hot with bourbon, traces of the dark chocolate fill the sinus cavity after, with licorice. A lot. Taste is very sweet. Dry, tingly finish. Will mellow out nicely over the next few years. Pretty hot right now.

2013 Bottle. Pours a deep black with very little head or lace. Aroma is most noticeably bourbon, with shortbread cookie and caramel. Flavor is richly malty, toffee, caramel, and the wonderful bourbon. Low carbonation helps keep the "spirit" of this one, alcohol well hidden. Fine beer that I think is worthy of the hype.

caramel, roasty, coffee, nuts, chocolate, herbs, resin, earthy, leather, licorice, raisin, vanilla, soy sauce, black, brown foam, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, umami, full body, oily feel, creamy, slick feel, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish,

After a few months in the cellar, I had to re-rate this. No more excessive bourbon flavor. Raised from 4 to 5 rating. Black as a winter?s night, strong enough to be bourbon and coke. Smells of bourbon. Don?t really detect any other smell. The Taste : Rich coffee, vanilla, and chocolate with a shot of whiskey right in the middle just in time to kick your ass. Great tasting overall just a little strong on the bourbon. The more your glass declines the better it tastes.  After all it is really smooth Kentucky bourbon and it gets smoother and grander as it warms. Overall a really nice drink. I think you could probably start your lawnmower on this stuff.

A 14.9 ABV Stout which drinks accordingly. Very black in the glass with not much head. It’s overall demeanor is like a kick in the head. If you drink for taste, however, you will do better if you dial it down to a lesser ABV. (Bell’s Expedition, for instance).

On draft in a snifter. Came a dark black with faint beige head. Aroma of chocolate, molasses, coffee and bourbon. Taste is more of the same. Sweet almost cloyingly so, but not crossing the line. 15% alcohol? Where? Holy Crap its sneaky. Despite being so sweet it is not appreciably sticky. Good Stuff.

I have to admit, I was wondering what all the hype was about. Honestly....it was ALL worth it! This beer is seriously unbelievable. I would give you appearance, taste, smell etc. But you can read all those below. Just know that a person that was skeptical about the hype is now a believer.
Bottle. Pours pitch black with not much head. Aroma is bourbon, chocolate, overall yumminess. Taste is the same, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, thick. Aftertaste sticks around, really good.

They were not kidding about the beer being dark. I feel like I could shine a light through it and still not see it on the other side. I didn’t know the abv beforehand but I knew this beer was heavy. Very thick feeling. Smoky and licorice malty tastes. The bourbon comes later but is impossible to miss. Thebooziness is very obvious and almost takes away from it some. There is a lot of flavor here but not necessarily in the perfect blend. Can’t drink more than one.

2013 12oz picked up today for a pretty pricey $6.75ish... Pours with a very short lived dark brown head... No cap. The brew is of course black... very viscous on the pour.

Aroma is like a bourbon spiked brownie batter... but man.. the bourbon punch is surprising.. thankfully I like some of Kentucky’s Finest. a lot of whiskey and vanilla... but quite a bit of caramel and chocolate too... but it is definitely the bourbon that is the star of the show.. if I put my face over the glass, I swear I can feel the whiskey burn my eyes (in a good way).

Flavor starts out as a vanilla caramel sweetness but get’s wiped off my palate by the bourbon.. melts slowly into chocolate with a little bit of char.. quite a bit of cherry.. almost like a kirsch.. but the cherry is fleeting as it transitions into a slick rush of bourbon that lingers forever. The body is very viscous.. accentuated by a lite little bubble carbonation.

This brew really is worth the hype... no doubt. I am keeping the drinkability down just a notch.. but it isn’t a bad thing.. I want another sip immediately following the previous, but the thick mouthfeel and relative lack of carbonation hurts it for me... plus it still seems quite rough around the edges.. but still fantastic for sure.

Until I have something better, I say this is the best beer in the world. The bourbon is massive, but only in expressive flavor, to my taste there is no harsh bite. Toffee, oak, dark chocolate espresso, honey, black cherry, cinnamon, nutmeg, plum, strawberry covered in brown sugar, butterscotch ice cream...I could go on forever. Basically every dessert flavor that has ever tasted good was combined flawlessly to make this beer. Spend whatever you have to, this has to be experienced.

2013 bottle @ 14.9% less than a week after release. Not as hot as I remember. Great bourbon, vanilla, oak, chocolate, dark malts, and gingerbread on the nose. Deep black and viscous. Sweet with chocolate and dark malts and warming boozy finish. Incredibly smooth, even this young.

Not sure it can get much better than this...I have a cellar full or excellent beers: Bells Expedition, Founders Backwoods Bastard, Victory Storm King, Old Rasputi, etc., but this beats them all hands down. Not sure how Founders Breakfast is anywhere near this in the ratings, maybe time for a new scale!

I had this at Global Brew. Pours black with a tan head. Taste boozy, roasted malt. I thought this was so so. I would skip this down the road.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

14.2% ABV. $5.00 exactly for the 12oz. bottle purchased from New England Wine & Spirits earlier today. Had it not been for my abrasively geeky questions, I don’t think the cashier would have presented this year’s BCS as if it were the holy grail and I was part of King Arthur’s crew. I hadn’t rated this, nor have I ever consumed this, so I knew I might as well see what all the fuss was about. To oversized snifter, it pours a purplish deep brown with a quickly dispensing razor-thin khaki head barely a fingernail in length. Aromas of bourbon oak, mint, roasted malt, and hops. Huge and overwhelming alcohol presence. Tastes start with molasses straight up, followed by date syrup, chocolate, cinnamon, tobacco, oak, and burnt rubber. Blood orange peels, char, and pine needles by swallow. A tad zesty with undertones of earth at its finish. Heat experienced by first sip. This is a massive beer: complex, but perhaps too hot at the moment.

08NOV13 bottle - 14.9%.
Aroma is super bourbon barrel character. Light chocolate and roasted malts. Medium high coconut, vanilla and almond notes with lighter bourbon and oak character. This beer really highlights the barrels and their contributions.
Pours black with a faint hint of a dark tan head that immediately disappears. No lacing and moderate legs.
Flavor is moderately sweet with a lot of dark chocolate and lighter roast and coffee notes. Light anise note adds a bit of complexity. Medium high bourbon character with lighter barrel notes than in the aroma. Light coconut and vanilla with a touch of leather and tobacco. Strong alcohol finish.
Mouthfeel is full bodied with low carbonation. Slight oiliness to the beer. Low but present alcohol astringency and medium alcohol warmth.
Overall a pretty darn good beer, but the bourbon charger in the finish is a bit strong for me. I do not remember older vintages being this bourbon forward so maybe it’s a factor of youth as other bottles have always had some age. I wish it treated the way it smelled.

An amazing & complex stout that has so many nuances & intricacies each year, I have tried to take notes on all of the different releases I have sampled. Appearance is nearly always the same, huge, black body with a timid tan foam that never seems to last for more than a few moments.



[2014 / tap / fresh] The bourbon on this one is exceptionally smooth out of the gate. HUGE chocolate fudge & brownie character with a nice amount of vanillin & barrel. Smooth, delicious. Probably one of the "easiest" drinking fresh BCS’s I’ve had.



[2013 / tap / fresh] Tons of bourbon on the nose, along with lots & lots of chocolate. Incredibly smooth, even with the heavy bourbon notes; very warming & full bodied. Mild roasty finish, light char & bitterness in the aftertaste. Nice vanilla character picks up with time. Lovely oak & bourbon throughout.



[2012 / bottle / fresh] Big-time oak & vanilla aroma on this one; the booze takes on more of a raw whiskey character. Bittersweet chocolate, lots of syrupy goodness with a mild roast in the finish. Oak, whiskey, & chocolate aftertaste, mild brown sugar.



[2012 / tap / 1 year old] Has mellowed out with a year, but the bourbon character is still nice & robust. Picked up a much bigger dark fruit (currant & date) character this time around, with a very deep & roasted malt aftertaste.



[2011 / tap / 2 years old] More subdued aroma than any other vintage, but very well composed. Bigger roasted char-like bite with a very smooth bourbon character. Nice chocolate fudge finish with some bitter roast & cocoa in the aftertaste. 



[2009 / bottle / 4 years old] Thanks, Mike! 12 oz bottle. Amazing chocolate aroma & flavor with lovely notes of currant & brown sugar covered black cherries. Bourbon is insanely smooth, lots of chocolate in the finish with a little bit of finishing oak & vanilla. This was simply fantastic, probably the best vintage/age, along with a couple of the 2008 bottles I’ve had.



[2008 / bottle / 4.5 years old] Thanks, Jeff! Even with this age, the bourbon character is very robust but so, so incredibly smooth, it is unreal. This vintage/age showed the largest molasses, vanilla, & brown sugar characters of them all. Big chocolate in the finish, too, with lighter inclusions of oak. Tied for my favorite vintage/age of BCS, along with the 4 year old 2009 bottle.



[2008 / bottle / 5 years old] thanks again, Jeff. Very, very slight oxidation. But this is still a beast... Caramel covered chocolate bourbon fudge cake. Like a dessert with bourbon. Caramelized sugar finish, some vanilla, sherry. The last bottle was slightly better, but this was still great. I think the sweet spot for BCS is around 4 years.



[2007 / bottle / 6.5 years old] Thanks, Jeff! Carbonation is mostly gone, but that doesn’t stop this from being a badass stout, even at nearly 7 years out. Surprisingly, this was less oxidized than a few, younger bottles of 2008 that I’d had. Still a largely complex aroma of dark fudge, tangy dark fruit, very mild soy, oak, subtle molasses, brown sugar, & vanilla. Tastes like Devil’s Food cake drizzled with more fudge, vanilla, & bourbon. Dark cocoa & brown sugar finish, bourbon is smooth as hell. Outstanding!
A great bourbon aroma. Poured dark in a glass with a little bit of brown foam. Long lingering bourbon and chocolate flavor on the palate. Worth the wait!

On draft. Pours black with small tan head. Strong bourbon aroma. Chocolate and bourbon flavors. Finishes strong. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very strong bourbon aromas which continued through the initial taste. Really potent brew with all kinds of deep dark coffee and fruit flavors. Tends forward the sweeter side of the scale. Definitely a one beer experience or make sure you have a designated driver.

Draft - pours black with almost no head. I even swirled it around to produce head but no go. Nose is wood and vanilla. Sip adds roast, sugar and bourbon. Sweet and dry. Long bourbon finish that satisfies. Worth the hype.

Bottle poured a thick black hue w/ a small tan mostly diminishing head. Bold bourbon barrel aroma. Initial flavor is bold sweet w/ a moderate bitter finish. Tastes are bourbon, dark roast coffee, wooden barrel, molasses, and light cherry. Big bodied, syrupy mouthfeel, soft carbonation, and a boozy warm finish.
Huge bourbon aroma and taste but better than bourbon itself, IMO. Wood and vanilla, chocolate, caramelized sugar. Doesn’t hide the alcohol but not overwhelmed by it either. Tasty stuff!

2013 bottle served slightly cool into a snifter. Superb. Notes of booze, bourbon, chocolate. I also detect a lot more cherry than I expected, both in aroma and taste. Mouthfeel is silky, creamy and rich. I would have to have a taste testing with other of my top picks, but this is certainly up in top 5 stouts for me. Great 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from a bottle it is dark brown with a tan head andthe aroma is of Bourbon and it tastes of chocolate and Bourbon that lingers on the palate

355ml/12floz bottle into a tulip glass. Served cool.

Aroma: Very rich chocolate. Boozy. Some coffee notes. Very rich aroma. Exceptionally nice.

Appearance: Pitch black body. A very minimal dark brown head that dissipates away into nothing.

Taste: Bittersweet chocolate. A little cream. The flavor is big, but it’s not over-powering. A little boozy.

Palate: Rich and full bodied. Long, bittersweet finish.

Overall: Fantastic, fantastic stout. Lovely flavors and a fantastic body.

Dark dark pour with a tan head that doesn’t hang around long. The aroma is whiskey, malts, sweetness, vanilla, and chocolate. The taste is beautiful. Even though it’s fresh, the bourbon wasn’t too strong. Dark malts, fruit, bourbon, vanilla, and cocoa nibs go down with light carbonation and a warming sensation. I’m happy to of been able to buy a case of this after that first sip.

Pitch black with a filmy brown head that disappears fairly quickly. Nose consists of vanilla, oak, chocolate nibs, cherries, and roasted malts. Very Vanilla and chocolate nibs are very strong here along with cherries and roasted malts; Sweet Vanilla & Roasty aftertaste. Thick heavy body paired with some mild-moderate carbonation. Very good but enjoy this in moderation.

I was able to score one four pack of 2013 Bourbon County and this is my first time scoring this whale of a beer. Opened at about 50 degrees, it pours pretty much black with a slight rim of brown foam of a head, it dissipates almost instantly. Not much carbonation, when I hold to the light and swirl I get slight nuances of ruby and brown. Putting this to my nose and I totally get the hype. I never smelled a beer or barrel aged stout smell so much like bourbon. As much as it doesn’t make sense, it almost smells more like bourbon than "some" bourbons. There’s aromas of huge whiskey barrel, vanilla, oak, sweet chocolate, honey. Upon my first sip, I get sweet vanilla up front, then heat from the bourbon and then it finishes with tons of coconut and more vanilla. Amazing. After the first sip, I proclaimed this is the best beer I’ve ever tasted! However, as I drink through the bottle, the ABV does start to wear on me a little. This is a truly special beer, but I definitely enjoyed the first half more than the second half. Toward the end I felt like I was in fact drinking bourbon or whiskey rather than a beer. This still certainly among the best. I will probably allow the rest age for a while. Cheers.

One of the best overall beers I have had! The only complaint would be how intense it is! That is a tough argument but if we are splitting hairs this lacks a little balance in the exploration of how high the gravity should go! Excellent brew!

Aroma of vanilla, oak and roasted malt. Definitely smells like bourbon. Flavor is strong bourbon with a slightly sweet stout backbone. Bourbon flavor dominates. Very smooth for the strength. Very thick but not sticky on the palate. Great imperial stout, but really need to split the bottle. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Flesje bij brigantes in York. Diepzwart bier dat uit schenkt als olie, visueel eindigt het met een minimale bruine schuimkraag. In de geur bourbon wiksky maar ook de stout die duidelijk naar boven komt, met brood, donkere chocolade en mokka. Op de achtergrond iets van teer. Volzoet bij het eerste slokje, daarna de smaak van brood en appelstroop, alcoholwarmte de chocolade en biscuit. Erg volle afdronk, wat een killer.
Absolutely stellar barrel aged imperial stout. Gorgeous lacing, very bourbon forward in the nose and mouth, and obviously heavy malts. It might even edge Parabola out as my favorite in its class.

FROM NOTES: November 29, ’13 on draft into a snifter at the Black Friday event @ Kraftrwork, Philly.

A: Bourbon and sweet malts mostly with some dark fruits and hints of bitter coffee. Some vanilla and oak also come through with a definite char.
A: Pours a very dark almost black with a small head and not much lacing.
T: Bourbon initially, with a syrupy sweetness followed by a roasted bitterness. Strong notes of oak, coffee, dark chocolate and bourbon with some faint black licorice notes. Sweetness and bourbon with strong alcohol burn in the finish.
P: ULTRA thick and oily, with little carbonation with an extra long finish.
O: IMO, there are better bourbon aged beers out there. That being said, this is a very good one, perhaps even one of the better ones. Slightly cloying with a high ABV makes this one a long sipper.

Big bourbon in the aroma. Chocolate and slight coffee flavors upfront. Followed by a nice bourbon booziness. The booze dissipates quickly and is replaced by a very smooth chocolate mouthfeel. Really good.

Tried the 2013 Bourbon County out of a 12oz bottle. Very smooth. Slight bourbon taste at the beginning, along with a roasted malty flavor and Carmel finish. Honestly one of my favorite stouts. Very smooth and refreshing. 10/10. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark black with small tan head. Smells of oak bourbon vanilla and booze. Tastes like chocolate , bourbon, some wood and vanilla. Silky creamy and smooth a very delicious offering and a must try.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Blackest beer I have ever seen. Aroma of toasty caramelized sugar, bourbon, camp fire. Really interesting. The smell is familiar, but I can’t put my finger on it. Maybe some raisin smell too. Very complex aroma. French toast maybe? Sweat, yummy taste. Wow is this good. Picking up on caramel, raisin, definitely bourbon. At 15%, I thought I’d taste more alcohol but I don’t. Even with taste I’m getting this familiar toastyness, but can’t figure it out. Maybe French today again. This is very good. Would recommend even though it is pricy.

whiskey, smoke, caramel, coffee, roasty, leather, earthy, black, raisin, vanilla, 
an astonishing achievement of the brewer’s art. Have always loved the (512) Whiskey Barrel Aged Double Pecan Porter, of which this reminds me, but does surpass even that fine ale from the south Austin brewery. Speaking of pecans, this would be a fine paring with pecan pie. Or a chocolate silk cake. Would love to try this with a La Flor Dominica Double Ligero or Liga Privada Cigar!

Dark coffee colored pour. Little to no head. Smells of coffee, bourbon. Tastes of chocolate, bourbon, coffee, vanilla, prunes. Silky, carbonated mouthfeel. At 14.2% this is a bodacious beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle pour. A perfect way to end Black Friday. This jet black bourbon stout is extremely tasty. Super strong bourbon notes with smoked coffee and vanilla flavors; a great sipping beer.

Just cracked a bottle of my freshly recieved haul. Pours oily pitch black, with an almost non existent dark brown head. Wow, the aroma blows me away. Lots of huge bourbon, vanilla, oak and caramel notes up front, quite boozy, lots of bitter dark chocolate, some dark fruit, and wonderful roasty coffee. Taste is just as good, lots of dark fruits, then lots of barrel character with plenty of bourbon, oak, and hints of caramel, then there’s creamy rich chocolate, and super dark roasted coffee. Surprisingly smooth beer, although you can feel a little alcohol burn. The bourbon doesn’t overpower it at all. I can’t wait to see how this holds up over the years.

2012 bottle from Bry as an extra, Thanks man!! Well I figured with all the hoop law surrounding today’s realease I better crack a regular one of these and see what the fuss is about. Pitch black pour, brown tan head bubbles up, about a pinkys worth. Big aroma of chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, and ash. Taste, there’s lots of roast, some nice bourbon, medium creamy mouthfeel, woo doggy it’s hot my nose hairs are burning. Yea it’s good, but yea it’s hot, too damn boozy for me, I have another bottle stashed away I’ll have to revisit this with some age.
Black color, minimal head. Strong bourbon aroma. Taste is strong bourbon as well. If your into bourbon aged beers look no further.
Draft at Capone’s in PA. What else needs to be said? Warm, sweet, sticky, dark as tar, thick, dreamy.
Unexpected pleasure at Hurricane Vero Beach. Thanks Kristyn! Pours an opaque black. Nose is huge bourbon and chocolate notes. Taste is very boozy, hard to hide 15%, but man, this is delicious!
Big boozy chocolate roasty, bourbony aroma. Big boozy rich chocolate flavor, , bourbon, chocolate, oak, so much going on. Everything goes well together. So delicious.
Amazing beer, amazing taste, even though I only had a little sip. Really enjoyed it.

Birthday beer from a friend. Wonderful stuff. Opaque and thick pour with a thin brown head. Aroma hits with oak, vanilla, bourbon sweetness, and alcohol burn. Tastes brings in dark fruits and cherries, but still has a great oak presence that lingers. Alcohol present even more in the warming. Very complex and lots of long lasting tastes. Full bodied and somewhat drying. Excellence.

Bottle, 2012, via Archer Liquors, Chicago, pours a thick black pour with a nice java head, the aroma hits you as soon cap is off. Nose is sweet, whiskey, fruity with deep cherry vanilla oak flavors. Taste is whiskey, chocolate cherries and warms one right up. Full of deep palpable flavors. with a beautiful complexity. Finish is warming from the ABV, and ends on the same tasting notes. Enjoyed with a good Padron, a wonderful sipper. quaff score 9 / 10

Pours a dark black with a brown head and nice, strong aroma of bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, and chocolate. Taste is rich and strong, thick mouthful, of alcohol, tons of sweet bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, chocolate, liquorice, and oak with roasted malt and a warming, long, bourbon-barrel finish. Strong, nice bourbon barrel brew

Holy shit! Darkest syrupy pour with no head I?ve ever seen. Bourbon smell right up front and coffee and dark chocolate even a hint of licorice in the smell. Whoppa! ! Great taste of dark bitter chocolate and dark coffee and beautiful bourbon whiskey. The thickest mouthfeel I ever experienced in a beer. Low carbonation. Really superb aged stout. Jimmy, thanks so much for this one. Best stout ever tasted. Edit 12/31/2013.  Had this for the second time now, and I really want to bump it up to my number one beer, but i’m having doubts. This is so good but it is difficult to call it beer it seems. It feels almost more like a liqour in my opinion.

A: Dark Opaque Hue, Passes No Light, Thin Brown Head Ring, No Lacing

S: Bourbon, Vanilla, Chocolate, Boozy

T: Bourbon, Chocolate, Vanilla, Boozy

M: Mediocre Carbonation, Full Bodied, Semi Boozy, Mildly Drying

Overall, pretty solid taste with the bourbon and the barrel definitely present but also the ABV fully present too. This beer would be better if the carbonation would be more prominant.

Tap pours a lovely dark black with tan foam. The nose is thick of boozy warmth while carrying some of the roasted malts and sweet bourbon. The flavor at first bursts with a sweet fruity medley of dark fruits but quickly gets covered by the sweetness of all the fermentable sugars and bourbon. The sweetness follows to a bittersweet chocolate cake thickness with a dark roasted coffee undertone. The fruits round out the roastiness of it all at first but the finish has a hint of near charred malted barley along with more sweet sugary bourbony oaky goodness. Obviously overboard but still thoroughly enjoyable.

Smells like soy sauce mixed with makers mark
Very thick almost like velvet with little fizz not that that is a bad thing 
It’s taste is like an explosion of flavours on the tongue black coffee vanilla port bourbon 
This was the 2012 version and it was strong 
I could feel it warming my legs as I drank it 
A beer I have become more obsessed with the more I have tasted it 
This is my fifth offering in a year and it keeps getting better 
A wonderful beer

beige head disappears quickly without lacing. coffee colour. aroma of vanilla, boozy, wooden barrels, oak. taste like aroma, roasted malts with a sweet and boozy finish.  2008 version / thanks for sharing belgBG

bottled dated 11/06/12 poured into snifter.

aroma: baker’s chocolate, molasses, spicy bourbon note. appearance: motor oil body with quickly dissipating khaki head. minimal lacing. taste: deep and decadent dark chocolate that is both sweet and bitter.. sweet caramel and spicy bourbon notes play nicely on tongue. palate: lively carbo and slick texture. luscious body on this one, but it doesn’t coat the tongue in a sickly glaze like some big bourbon stouts (I’m looking at you, 50/50 eclipse! get your shit together!). finishes crisp and dry.

this beer has deeper chocolate at a year’s age. bourbon is spicier. and I think it had an umami flavor when fresh--that’s all but gone now.

0,355l bottle from England. Clear, opaque, black colored beer with medium, creamy, drak brown head. Epic, coconut and cocoa odor. Silky and mature feeling because of the barrel flavours. Although it’s intensive and a little bit smoky. The flavour reminds me of a good whiskey. Alcohol, caramel, malty sweet aroma, Strong sweet taste. Creamy texture, huge body, average carbonation. Dry, smoky finish. Unbelivable whiskey aftertaste. Strong, intensive, filling stout. Mature, balanced, but lively. At the beginning intensive, caramel, chocolate, malt flavour, later barrel flavour and smooth aroma. Very-very good!

Revised with rerate: Tap at gravity 3rd anniversary. Much better than previous experience. Thick black with small head. Quite sweet. Moderate bourbon, but very smooth. Lots of chocolate as well. Light oak.  While it's a pretty good beer, I still don't get the crazy hype. Lots of better bba stouts out there.
Previous:bottle. thick and black with very small head. perhaps expectations were too high, but i found this really underwhelming. if you were to mix equal parts bourbon, soy sauce and chocolate syrup, i'd imagine you'd end up with something very similar. there's a lot of interesting flavor here, but together it just feels a little too much like a unbalanced mess.

2008 12 ounce bottle from Timfoolery for my birthday. Carbonation is gone, great aroma and flavor. Dry. 

Re-rate in 2014 on fresh bottle.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
many heavy aromas. caramel, heavy roasted malt, liqurish, almonds. appear black without head. a fine balance between sweetness and bitternees. and a perfect mouthfeel.

2013.10.22 - Goose Island Bourbon County Stout - on tap at Broad Axe. Second draft I’ve had. Hard to rate other than to say complex and tasty. It pours quite dark. It’s a 15% stout, what else would you expect? Not much carbonation or head when I get it. Complex taste. Different flavors reveal themselves with each drink, and as it warms. An unexpected sweetness. Suffice it to say, quite good. I also happened to find 2 x 12oz bottles of it on the way here tonight. So it’s repeat purchase worthy.

Killer aroma. Killer taste. Warm, full bodied stout blended with a bold bourbon flavor. It is hard to say if the beer or the barrel is more overpowering, but you can still smell it after you set your glass down.

Oily black colour, dark brown foam, disappears very quickly. Low carbonation. Full body. Aroma of dark chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, coffee and bourbon (a bit too much). Well balanced beer, Alcohol is very well hidden.

Tried at Bottle Share at the Syb Pig in Boca Raton, FL. Small snifter. Pours a jet black with a thin tan head. Head gone in about 20 seconds. Let it warm up some before going to town. Aromas of wood (oak), roasted malts, vanilla, sweet milk, and caramel. The taste was blissful. Roasted malts, the oaked barrel, vanilla, earthy wood, and dark chocolate. I really wish I had a whole bottle! Full body, smooth and not oily. Finishes big with flavors still exploding.

2011 12 oz bottle shared with Jasonn. This is just astounding. The pour is black with a dark dark mocha head. Thin, no lace, quick fading. The aroma is gorgeous! Heavy in licorice, vanilla, chocolate and bourbon. The taste is just the same. It's a little more bourbon-ey, but the alcohol is well hidden, and only comes through on the very back end of the mouth feel. It's beautiful. I can't wait to get more of this beer!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a pitch black with a thin ring of brown bubbles. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, coffee and oak. Flavor of bourbon, coffee, roasted malt, vanilla, and dark chocolate. Quite bitter and a lot of alcohol in the finish.
Awesome beer. Smells great. À bit of cocos. Tastes very Nice. Nice and thick. Great dark sweet taste with lots of alcohol. Also again The hint of cocos.
2012 bottle @ home. Pours black with a minimal head. Aroma is bourbon, oak, chocolate, vanilla, molasses. Flavor is bourbon, molasses, malt, chocolate, vanilla. Fabulous beer.

shared a 2011 bottle. poured pitch black with allmost na head. a huge smell of the bourbon. when it warms up the hints of chocolate, vanilla, coffee, caramel, chocolate fugde, some cherry, and the alcohol are comming true. verry thick and smooth mouthfeel. wow huge stout! hook me up with more my american beer friends

Bottle from Vinspecialisten Aalborg shared with edvard & daje

Pours quite dark, black in glass, with a thin tanned laced head. Smells of bourbon, vanilla, oak and malts, very excuisite. Heavy sweet, quite malty, a solid dose of roasted malts as well. Coffee, booze, vanilla, oak and bourbon. World class stout

2012 vintage consumed this evening. Poured into snifter glass. 

A- Pours a jet black with a thick two-finger mocha head. It quickly recedes to a ring around the edge of the glass. Significant alcohol legs. Looks perfect for a beer of this style, very inviting.

S- Dominated by bourbon. There is some vanilla, roast malt, and a slight chocolate as well as coffee, but it is definitely minimal compared to the liquor aroma.

T- Up front there is more bourbon, vanilla, and some chocolate. As I swallow, there are some fruit esters, predominantly cherry with some fig, as well as a ton of alcohol. The finish is quite long, and the bitterness becomes present to help balance out the syrupy sweetness of the malts and bourbon. 

M- This is a thick and viscous beer, almost syrup in consistency. Although the feeling of the beer coats your mouth for some time, it is silky smooth. The only downfall I can note is the alcohol sting that you can feel almost immediately after you take a sip. 

O- This is a fantastic beer, but I think the 2012 still needs a few more months for the bourbon to calm down. It is an awesome beer, but I see improving in the future.

Very dark black color with a brownish head that quickly dies down. Tons of complexity but a smooth silky feel in the mouth. Tasts of chocolate, coffee and a splash of bourbon. Finishes with a smooth coffee chocolate bitterness and then the warming bourbon flavor comes on. Very good.
This one has a ton of favors going on here. It’s very good but not the best from bourbon county.

2012 Bottle. Pours black as night with a thin khaki head that dissipates almost instantly. Aroma is big booze, vanilla, oak, caramel, chocolate, coffee, roasted malt and slight raisins. Taste is big bourbon, vanilla, oak, barrel char, roasted coffee, malt, and bitter chocolates. Full bodied, minimal carbonation and well balanced beer. Very good beer!

2012. Bottlebrush opaque black with fleeting minimal tan head. Nose bourbon, vanilla, and alcohol. Taste, lots of bourbon, then some chocolate, roast, vanilla, and toffee. Slight bitter finish. Bourbon barrel aged, but they failed to mention the barrels still had bourbon In them. Slid beer with many layers of complexity, but for me, the bourbon is overdone.

12 Oz bottle, 2012 vintage. Dark, almost black, rich mocha tan head which doesnt last, settles to a hint of tan on the liquid. Lovely intense nose, wood, oak, dark chocolate, coffee, nuanced bourbon, lots of vanilla and burnt notes. So rich in flavour, sweet chocolate notes up front, coffee bitterness next, finally a rising bourbon bite and some warming alcohol. Big thick mouthfeel, carbonation is soft but its there alright. Finish is long lush coffee and bourbon. Amazing.
Bottle from Dada, Sheffield. Is it me, or does this weigh more than the same volume of any other liquid? Big everything. It’s like alcoholic prunes and custard. Ridiculous beer.

33cl bottle thanks to omhper. Thanks a lot Per! Lovely very dense dark color with thin brownish head. Texture is oily and carbonation is soft. Taste is medium sweet and medium to high bitter. Aroma is high chocolate, high roasted, alcohol, high coffee, spices. Really really nice!
Bottle. This is motor oil thick and richly bourbon flavoured. Be prepared for the most whiskyish beer possible.

Viscous black with thin dark mocha head. Burnt oak and vanilla, rich bourbon, cinnamon and cloves nose. Taste is rich vanilla and hard charred oak, slight cream, coffee and chocolate mid palate, dark dried fruits. Body is big, with a creamy texture and light carbonation and alcohol slightly showing through.

Solid. Probably what most people into bourbon barrel-aged stouts aspire to in a beer. Strong bourbon aroma for me even a little much but I always this the barrel should enhance rather than overtake a beer. Makes the leftover Allagash Black I have taste like watery brown ale in comparison, however. Thick, oily consistency with a tangy and bitter finish. Bottle at Lion’s Pride.
About 1/3 of a bottle of this stuff is nice. much more is hard to enjoy. Molasses. Chocolate. Coffee. Nice beer to try but a bit over the top. Lots of alcohol.

Absolutely great stout. Chocolate, treacle, vanilla, coconut. Sat and enjoyed this for 90mins. Every sip is a joy! Now, I’ve almost finished I feel like crying. It cost me £7 but it was honestly worth every penny. Gonna stock up on a few of these. World Class. The Zinedine Zidane of imperial stouts.

Thanks tommy! Pours a near pitch black with only a slight reddish hue. Aroma is chocolate, bourbon, wood and something very sweet like a toasted marshmallow. Taste is very well balanced and the 15% is almost hard to believe. Really opens up nicely when it warms. Lots of bourbon barrel, smoke, sweet caramel. Pretty amazing.

Eben black, short thin brown head. Strong aroma has ripe dark fruits, bit medical herbs, lots licorice, coffee, bourbon. Sweet and roasted, bitter, lots bourbon, medium body, low carbonation, long tasty finish is sweet and surypy, sticky palate. Sweet and tasty one to enjoy with good time.

Bottle, 2012 (thanks stfun!)


Aroma: Molasses, alcohol, coffee, hint of chocolate


Appearance: Opaque black with almost no head


Taste: Very well integrated vanilla, chocolate, licorice, coffee


Palate: Medium body with flat mouthfeel


Overall: Absolutely lives up to the hype. Really well integrated, awesomely complex flavors.

On tap. Pours black and thick with almost no head. Bourbon, vanilla, and coffee on the nose. Palate is thick and sweet with a smooth slightly btiter finish. Flavor is very rich and nicely balanced. An excellent imperial stout!

At brewpub. A very good stout. Each one is always great. A good blend of flavors, will be interesting if this continues due to change..

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Black with brown head. Bourbon, wood, alcohol, dark chocolate and vanilla. Taste of bourbon, vanilla, dark chocolate. Oily texture. Alcohol well hidden. Delicious.

Slighly reddish really dark brown, almost black beer with basically no head at all, or any carbonation. The aroma is really sweet in a liqueur kind of a way, with chocolate and some alcohol, but not as much as one would expect from the ABV. The taste is first salty, then sweet in a chocolate cake kind of a way, with some coffee, cocoa, caramel and vanilla. Really full, surypy and oily mouthfeel with the alcohol warming up the finish but not tasting too much. I would have preferred a bit less sweetness, but this is a really awesome beer to enjoy on a cold night.

Can’t believe I haven’t rated this yet. Probably my favorite beer and I’m sure I’ve had it over 100 times. 2012 12oz at cellar temp. Oily black with dark tan head that fades fast. Aroma is strong toasted marshmallow with some alcohol burn. Taste is very similar, bourbon, toasted marshmallow, lots of alcohol, chocolately malts. Palate is hard to characterize, its quite oily and thick while at the same time very high alcohol so it doesn’t coat the mouth like many stouts. World class.

Bottle 2012 Ed.
Pous a black body with a fast subsiding tanned head leaving no lacings. Intense aroma of vanilla, bourbon and oak.Tar, leather and some alcohol also. Taste is rich vanilla and bourbon, the roasted grains really have to fight to get through.. Some warming alcohol notes and a sweet finish with lingering vanilla and and hints of liquorice. Thick and oily on the palate, and has alot of carbonation also even tho the head formation is not present.

Pours black, finger tan head, light carb, good lacing. . 

Smell oak, vanilla, wood, bourbon. Light red fruits, but wood dominates. 

Taste sweet leather, tobacco, oaky vanilla, chocolate. Roasty. 

Smooth and silky, would not pick it as 15%. Bit of burn on the end. 

Very good.

Pitch-black motor oil stout without foam. 
The aroma is whiskey, oakbarrel, vanilla and plenty of coffee style roast and salty liquorice. Balanced and strong. 
The taste has roasty coffee-chocolates roast. Whiskey, oak and a hint of vanilla, and liquorice. The aftertaste is a bit dry, bitter appropriate. A little alcohol taste through.
Palate is full-bodied and thick.
 Excellent IS, tonight’s final nightcap, which gets smiling, and the earthly pain to go away.

12oz bottle (2012). Pours a jet black color with a thin, almost fizzy dark brown head that settles to nothing fast. Aroma is full of oak, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, caramel, and roasted coffee. Some alcohol present in the after smell. Tasted at room temperature. Notes of dark chocolate, roasted malts, resinous oak, vanilla, some dark fruits, leather, warming alcohol, and a butterscotch aftertaste.

Bottle from kris wines, london. Black color, nice dark brown head. Big aroma of roasted malts, licorice, coffee, chocolate, alcohol, wooden barrels. Huge taste, licorice, chocolate, bourbon, wood, coffee, spices. Some many flavors and great balance.

Draft poured jet black with minimal tan head. Smelled of toffee, bourbon and alcohol. Tastes reflected the aroma, with a whole ton of Bourbon and booze in the finishing and aftertaste. Awesome yet lethal beer.

bottle, thanks to ungstrup for sharing. jet black with a medium brown head; full aroma of figs, vanilla cream, cocoa powder and rich alcohol; loads of flavour with warming alcohol up front leading to rum’n’raisin chocolate, more vanilla, prunes, whipped cream and a dark chocolate finish. plenty going on here and it’s all delicious

Bottle shared at home from Appellation Wines, Dalry. Jet black with a decent creamy brown head. Big aromas of vanilla, chocolate and liqourice. Initially quite sweet, but the finish dries out nicely with roasted and oak notes. Surprisingly thin texture, which was slightly disappointing, but very glad I’ve tried this beer.
Aroma is bourbon boozy, appearance is black, taste is amazing bourbon strong flavors, palate is hot.

Pours black with red highlights and no head. Nose is some dark fruits, raisin, bourbon, a touch of oak barrel, a touch of burnt sugars, chocolate. Taste is chocolate, vanilla, some burnt and brown sugars, barrel, bourbon, a touch fruity, a little burn at the end. Mouthfeel is super creamy, velvety, borderline syrupy. As compared to an aged 2012, the 12 was significantly boozier even having sit for a year. 13 reigns supreme.

2013 Re-Reviewed from bottle. Pours a pitch black with a small ring of mocha head that sits with the whole beer. Decent amount of lacing. Nose is a ton of bourbon and vanilla up front. A lot of roast and chocolate with a hint of licorice and anise. The alcohol is present, but its very sweet. The sweetness melds perfectly with the alcohol. Mouth is incredibly thick but very smooth. A lot of bourbon and vanilla up front. Once again the alcohol is present, but blends prefectly with the alcohol. The roasted malt is much stronger on the tongue. Not as hot as I remembered last years being.

Had it on tap. Pours pitch black with a finger and a half of tan head that dissipates slowly into nothing. Aromas of vanilla, bourbon, rubbing alcohol, and milk chocolate. The alcohol is much more well hidden on the tongue. Big time on the roasty malts. Leaves aftertastes of vanilla and bitter dark chocolate. Bourbon is there, but not as much as a name like this would suggest. Really big mouthfeel, like drinking syrup. Not only an awesome imperial stout, but actually quite unique compared to others I’ve had.

Kolsvart utan skum! Lite för mycket alkoholsmak och inte så mycket annan smak! Har köpt 3 st flaskor som jag ska LAGRA några år! Testade en nu som är lagrad över 1 år!  Nu har smaker gift sig! Riktigt bra!

Bottle - Vintage 2010 - Light bourbon nose with vanilla, soy sauce, dark fruit very mellow. Inky black with no head. Dark fruit, bourbon, big vanilla, but so very well rounded. Beautiful.

Vintage 2012 - Soy sauce and bitter dark malts. Inky black with a thin head. Robust chocolate and raisin. Body is remarkable and finish to die for.

Bottle says 2012. 



Poured thick and without any head. I get a thin ring when I tilt the glass and some alcohol legs. Nose is oaky, boozy, bourbon whiskey, smooth dark chocolate and some vanilla. Roasted malt and a bit of coffee. Tiny bit of dark fruit but I am actually glad that it’s not too pruney with all the bourbon barrel qualities. 



One very small sip to start and it’s beer heaven. This a smooth roasted malt, deep full and rich like hot melted caramel. The bourbon is luscious and because it’s hot from the alcohol has a sweet warmth. Dark creamy chocolate, buttery toffee, oak flavor and just a touch of raisin,prune and fig. it reminds me of english butter toffee candy that’s coated with nuts and chocolate. It lingers like whiskey with a little burn at 15% abv and is full and smooth. 



Thick and rich, creamy and decadent. This is no lightweight stout. Coats the palate and the back of the throat and is a terrific experience. I would have this anytime. Sip slowly as it’s such a big beer. The complexity unfolds as it drinks. 



Thank you Kerry. I feel lucky to have had the chance to try this.

2012 bottle. Pours a very dark brown with medium creamy tan head that diminishes rather quickly. The aroma is dark chocolate, roast, oak and bourbon. Thick mouthfeel with strong chocolate, oak, booze, roasted malts, and nice lingering sweet finish. Alcohol hidden well, very impressive imperial stout.

Bottle at Patrick's mansion with Taylor Patrick Garrett Chelsia and Jonathan. Pouts flat and black. Aroma of vanilla whiskey and chocolate. Taste of delicious vanilla chocolate and whiskey. Finish is long and savory. Delicious.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep, dark brown, really just a shade from pitch black. Light does not penetrate it. A half-inch of medium/dark brown foam. Aroma of wood, bourbon, and dark chocolate; can also smell the alcohol. Feels very thick and creamy in the mouth -- just wonderful. Taste is of dark chocolate, roasted malt, bourbon, maybe a bit of coffee. Bittersweet overall, with a strong burn from the alcohol. Tremendous. If they backed off the bourbon just a tad, it would be perfect. This is a 2011 bottle, by the way, that I am drinking in August 2013.

Bottle to glass. Strong aroma of chocolate, coffee and bourbon. Pours thick black with short tan head. Initial taste is sweet with notes of coffee and chocolate. Finishes with a hint of bourbon. Excellent well balanced beer. My favorite stout to date.

Poured into a snifter from a tap.

Appearance-thick rich blackness with a malty brown lasting head

Aroma- coffee, mocha, smoke, char, brown sugar, caramel.

Taste-line it smells only better. Potent stout and malt. Smooth . Hides abv well. 

Palate- rich thick and creamy. Viscous. 

Overall- this is a very special beer and I would seek it out again. Well balanced. Almost perfect.

Bottle - Pours dark black, a slight tan head, and some viscosity around the glass. The aroma is filled with bourbon, oak, and chocolate. The taste is rich dark chocolate, lots of booze, roasted malts, and some dark fruits. The finish was dry and bitter, but still pretty good.

I poured a 12oz 2009 vintage bottle into a snifter. It was bottled on 11/12/09. I’m not sure how much it cost at the time it was bought.



Appearance: Opaque ink black all around. Perhaps some dark maroon highlights on the edge, but definitely one of the darker beers you’ll see. Initially forms a small coating of brown foam, but it fizzles away quickly and leaves no lacing.



Smell: Highly aromatic as it can be smelled from an arm’s length away. Massive black licorice, dark cherry and bourbon notes.



Taste: Goose Island Bourbon County Brand Stout is a monster of a beer. Even after three and a half years of aging, this vintage still packs a punch. Massive sweetness in the first half followed by overt boozy character on the second half. Black licorice, chocolate syrup, black cherry, vanilla and a hint of plum or grape can all be detected throughout the palette (in that order). To call it sweet would be an understatement, but to call it sickly or cloying would be a lie. 



What’s so impressive about this beer is the fact it’s so well-balanced. While there isn’t hop character per se as far as citrus, pine, flowers, etc., there definitely is a prominent bitterness to this palette. This makes the beer drink like the imperial stout it is rather than any kind of borderline spirit other "extreme" beers tend to be like. The bourbon character is quite pronounced as well, leaving a slightly woody aftertaste along with hints of scorched sugar or vanilla. Sure there’s a raw alcohol component as well, but it complements the taste so well I can’t imagine this beer without it.



Drinkability: This is not exactly the type of beer you drink on a whim. At 13% ABV, and a high price tag, Goose Island Bourbon County Brand Stout is a special brew. That being said, savoring the experience is the drinker’s responsibility. It’s not simply syrup plus alcohol, it’s a genuine stout body. Thick and viscous in the mouth for sure, but not sticky or chewy sensation. I’d describe the finish as clean if it weren’t for the alcohol drying out my tongue. A fantastic liquid dessert by itself - there’s no reason to distract your palate by attempting to pair this with anything other than serenity.

Thick black pour with think caramel colored head. Nose is roasted malts and bourbon. Rich velvety texture. Notes of Coffee , dark fruits, nuts and strong on the booze. Very bitter and boozy finish. 

Gets creamy and chocolately as it warms up.

4.

On tap @ Local Option. Pours deep ink black with thin oily mocha head. Aroma is huge bourbon soaked roasted malt. You can pick the bourbon up from feet away. Taste is big roasty dark malt, followed by heavy bourbon and notes of port, molasses, espresso, and dark chocolate. Only demerit would be the slightly thin body - a bit thin for this high of an abv. Still, amazing beer.

’12 vintage 12oz poured into Founders tulip. Pours like motor oil black with a thin, chocolate khaki head. Strong bourbon with a little vanilla and chocolate to the nose. Taste follows the nose, though the bourbon seems a little more balanced in the taste. Pretty good drinkability in it’s earlier age, definitely not as hot as lets say, the ’10 vintage. It’s thick and sticky but kinda ends dry with a little booze and bitterness. The taste will linger around for awhile. Overall a great BA stout for those who like big stouts.

7/18/13 traded with Dave (first trade ever!) 2011 vintage. ABSOLUTELY AMAZING!!!! Sad to say I kept the bottle and couldn't stop smelling it. I think something's wrong with me. It was drank while watching the last episode of season 5 (1st half) of breaking Bad

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Betyg gäller 2007 +2008. Tidigare kommentarer vittnar om försämring i 2011, vilket jag måste hålla med om. Testade 07, 08 och höll på att ramla av stolen. Fenomenalt bra. Det kan man inte säga om 2011.

Rerate: 2012 kan egentligen inte hitta något att gnälla på. Perfektion och världsklass. Fasen vad jag skulle vilja testa 2010 eller äldre... 

2012. Lite väl " in the face". Onödigt pumpad alkohol, och bourbon är faktiskt rejält kraftig. Chokladen är tydlig.
2012 Edition. Bottle. Black with a minimum of a tanned head. Aroma is dark fruits and bourbon

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a snifter. Pitch black with a great mocha head that dissipates super quick. Smell is bourbon up front, vanilla, caramel, rich chocolate, and slight coffee grounds. Taste is very sweet, caramel and chocolate. Followed by bourbon and vanilla undertones. Decent carbonation and while it is thick and coating going down, it wasn’t as much as I was expecting. Great stout for a cool night in the Great North Woods.

Bottle @ unibaren, 13 / 7 2013. Pitch black, almost no head, good lacing. Aroma, sweet roasted malts, a lot of alcohol, bourbon. Taste, sweet roasted malts, bourbon, oaky. Leaves a warming dry bourbon/alcoholic aftertaste.

Very interesting for a stout... I'm used to Magic Hat, Long Trail, Guiness, Harpoon, Sam Adams style beers I live in MD with ready access to Flying Dog, Dogfish, DuClaw, all breweries with serious credit when it comes to dark beer. The Goose Island (poured from a growler) was spectacular! Excellent work! Strong notes of chocolate, caramel, coffee... 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle at Punavuoren Ahven, Helsinki. Originally rated 02062012. Colour is deep black with brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Alcohol, coffee, chocolate, sweetness and roastiness.

35 cl bottle @ home (2011 vintage). Pours black with some sediment and a small tan head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, oak, and bourbon. Flavour is roasted malt, bitter chocolate, vanilla, and some warming alcohol – with a bitter finish.

How have I not rated this yet?! 2012 bottle, enjoyed with friends overlooking the beach on July 4th. Hell yeah. 



Dark, molasses-looking pour yields minimal head. Huge aroma of bourbon-soaked chocolate fudge. Blissfully smooth on the palate as well, as the roasty stout base melts into the bourbon with grace. 



Viscous, sticky body. Hearty, filling, full of flavor. Love it. And call me crazy, but I can drink this all day long on a sunny beach. Bourbon County might be the best widely-available shelf stout anywhere. Cheers!

2012 Edition. Bottle. Pitch black with a minimum of a tanned, roasted looking head. Aroma is really complex; sugar, dark fruits, almost vinous, a nice suttle bourbon and oak character, malt, - a very sweet and complex smelling beer overall.
Talk about a full-bodied beer!!! The second it hits your lips your entire mouth is completely covered - really intense. My thoughts go quickly to a port wine. Taste follows the aroma pretty well, maybe with a very small(!) heat in the throat - but not as hot as when it just came out - ageing has done this pretty well.
Any flaws? I honestly can’t see what it could be? To me, this is just how a well-crafted BA imperial stout should be like - big, dark, full, heavy, creamy, intense. Needless to say, this is a sipper :)
2012 year thanks to GT2, Pitch black and insanely complex with notes of bourbon, dark chocolate, and red berries. Amazing stout! Watch out Event Horizon...you have a rival!

2008 vintage, from a 12oz bottle. Wow, this was interesting. The nose is phenomenal, as deep and complex as a great wine. On the palate, a little disappointing - very boozy. Lots of deep coffee flavors, bourbon, almost no carbonation. Not delicious at all, but incredibly interesting.

Original:12 oz bottle shared at Yia Yia’s (Lincoln, NE).  Black with a small head.  The aroma and flavor is bourbon, vanilla and chocolate. 4.5

Update: 12 oz pour on tap at Yia Yia’s.  Black and thick with a minimal dissipating brown head.  Chocolate, caramel, vanilla, bourbon, oak, light smoke.  A complex, full bodied sipper.  849417: 4.2.

Update: 2014 bottle, 13.8% batch. 939419.. 4.4

Update: Just had a 2014 bottle with 15 months on it and it was tasting awesome.  Huge fudge bomb, an excellent sipper. 4.6

Update: 2017 bottle shared.  Thick black appearance with a small brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, charred oak, bourbon, caramel, mild vanilla and light roast.  Similar flavor, rich, malty and moderately sweet with a light bitterness.  Full body with soft carbonation, a creamy feel and a smooth finish.  Back in the 4.2 range I suppose.
Bottle from 2012. Pours pitch black. Very thick texture. Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, bourbon and wood. Very smooth, especially considering its abv. Awesome beer.

HUGE beer, lot going on and it all works great together..  very thick oily body, can feel the richness... Flavors of vanilla, bourbon, sweet bbq, oak all come through and very well balanced.  ABV is high at 15%... so much going on in this beer. Can’t say enough about it.

Rerated. Originally scored a 3.8 when sampled on draft. 12 oz. bottle, dated 8/20/13. Pour is motor oil black with a thin wispy head that all but disappears in 30 seconds. Only a tight tan ring around the glass remains. Aroma is intense. Big notes of caramel, toffee, coffee, wood and bourbon. Alcohol penetrates the nose and sticks to the glass. Taste is big. Lots of sweetness, with caramel, bakers chocolate, bourbon and molasses. Big warming alcohol burn on the way down but doesnâ€™t resonate nearly as much in the flavor. Some mellow and smooth port notes shines through as it warms up. Enjoying this as much as the first time I had it which was before I rated beer. My first rating I think may have been on a flat draft from an old keg. Mouthfeel very smooth and slick with a creamy texture which compliments the style well. At $25 or so a 4 pack, some may be steered away, but the bourbon barrel aging really gives this imperial stout a complexity thatâ€™s hard to find elsewhere.

2012 vintage.  Pours dark black with almost no head what so ever.  Aromas of big bourbon with oak, caramel, and mild hint of vanilla.  Flavors of medium sweetness with the mild burn on the finish from the booze.

Really nice deep coloured stout with a small dark brown head that dissipates quickly. The bourbon aroma hits you pretty quickly but you also get a hint of the maltiness in the back ground. On drinking its very smooth with a slight sweetness that turns into the deep bourbon and malt flavours, there’s a slightly salty finish to it too which is quite nice.

bottle, 2012 vintage. strong oak chips, vanilla bourbon nose, signaling the onslaught of flavors to come (and it’s still cold!). body very oily, tar like thick. sweet vanilla, wood, roasty bbq sauce, boozy breath. this is a very big, heavy beer.

-- bb/wp8

This is the best stout that I have had... And I have drank A LOT of beer. BC pours a deep black with a small tan cap. The aroma is bourbon and chocolate. Flavor is amazing. Starts with a bold bourbon kick and then followed with notes of chocolate and espresso. It finishes sweet and with a subtle hit of alcohol. This is exactly why Goose Island is so good at what they do.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I’ve had this a number of times and I’m staring at a glass right now. Surprised that I haven’t rated it before. The pour is dark black. It does look brownish and a bit transparent towards the rim when you tilt the glass. Not much head but it’s there. It lasts too. Carbonation level is perfect on the palate. Smells woody, roasty, and bourbonesque. Dark fruits, chocolate, coffee, and mocha. Tastes strong but heavenly. Begs you to sip it. For 15% it is pretty smooth. The alcohol simmers a bit in my stomach but I don’t taste much heat. Great beer. Amongst the best Imperial Stouts in the world hands down.

Bottle of 2012 vintage, pours thick and black, no head despite best efforts. Little to no carbonation, in fact no lacing or bubbles at all.
Smell is lovely; raisins, caramel, a little coffee, and boozy! Punchy oak and, of course, bourbon hit immediately. Can taste the 15% moreso than others I’ve had of this strength. It’s nice, very nice, but I’ve had better (and no sign of the ’thick foam’ from this bottle).

Amazing, strong, rich taste, dark, just right, I had it too cool witch I then let sit for a while so it warms up

Draft at Eulogy. 2012 vintage. Snifter. Poured pitch brown with a dark brown head that quickly reduced to a foamy ring. Flammable dark fruit off the top. Intense Bourbon flavors. Raisins. Dates. Prunes. Molasses. Liquorice. Not a typical stout. Some slight dark chocolate and a bit of smoke but no particular coffee, ashy or leather notes. Mostly deep rich complex brown fruit swimming in Bourbon. High ABV is not hidden. Heady and dizzying at 15%. Keep away from open flame! Need I tell you this is wonderful stuff!
THis is one of my favorite beers of all time.  The only other beer I can think that is like this one is the John Henry 3 Lick Spiker Ale which is only available in select stores :/

2008 bottle, consumed 2.6.13. Pours black, no head. Raisins in the nose and oh so smooth on the palate. Perhaps a hint too much alcohol left in the follow through as the swallow goes thin, but still a great beer. 

Tried the 2013 (bottle in New York) on 29.11.13. Good but will I am sure be better with age, at the moment the alcohol lingers in the aftertaste. Current rating 3.9
