Pours black with small tan head. Aroma is vanilla, bourbon, wood. Taste is big with black licorice, vanilla, bourbon, caramel, earthiness. finish is warm, malts, bourbon, wood.

Huge bourbon characters on the nose. Pitch black hue. Big bourbon at the front of the tongue with almost a milk chocolate on the backend. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Opened a bottle of 2008. Most of the bourbon has gone. The aroma is still a big bold stout with caramel, malt and some coffee but the bourbon is absent. Taste is sweet roasted malt, coffee, molasses and some bourbon. Very mellowed. No alcohol. Very little carbonation left but the heavy mouthfeel remains. It’s still excellent but I think past it’s prime. Bottle says it ages for 5 years but 2-3 is best in my experience.
From bottle.  Pours black and clear with little head.  Aroma of raisins and brown sugar.  Taste is strong sweet.

Purs pitch black into the glass, with no head at all.
Aroma is full of bourbon and chocolate
Full bodied. Sweet, not much alcohol.
Taste is full of chocolate and bourbon. Hints of coffee and prunes. Maybe some over riped bananas in there as well.

Absolutely sublime. Full-blown sensory assault. Bourbon, vanilla, chocolate and molasses on the nose. Mouth is... insanely complex. Bourbon. Vanilla. Brown sugar. Dark dried fruit. Raisins. Cocoa nibs. Espresso notes. Liqourice flakes. Aftertaste just won't go away. And through it all à fabulous balance and smoother than a polished billiard ball with a creamy, amazingly full mouthfeel. How on earth am I going to be able to store the bottles I have left instead of devouring them at once?

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: Smelling of molasses, dates and raisins, dark chocolate and vanilla. Sherrycask, bourbon.
Appearance: A black brownish beer. A low brown head with some lacing and some curtains.
Taste: Tasting of dark sweet bread, dried dates, dark sweet chocolate chocolate, soy sauce, sherry, bourbon and a whiff licorice.
Palate: Low carbonation, a soft, sticky and yet oily texture. A big body.
Overall: Well, well, well! All is well done in this!
Note: Bottle 355 ml. (Vintage 2012) Reviewed 2013-02-08.

First time having this in quite some time (we don’t get this in WA anymore).

Viscous and black with a very minimal dark chestnut colored head that quickly retreats leaving nothing but a wisp of light tan colored film on the surface. Aroma is of bourbon, chocolate, light roasted malts, dark fruit (prune, fig), some toffee/caramel and light ethanol (for 15% ABV this is insanely impressive...as it’s barely detectable). Taste is incredible...and complex! Dark fruit, vanilla, coconut, toffee, some underlying roasted malt, chocolate, bourbon...lots going on here! It feels almost slightly "chewy", but drinks very easily despite the complexity and high ABV. Leaves a sweet, chocolately aftertaste. This is a superb bourbon barrel imperial stout. Wish I had more!
Wow!  Aroma of pure bourbon. Taste of coconut, vanilla, chocolate, bourbon, and roasty love. Silk feel. One of the best stouts I have ever tasted

Bottle brought from Stirchley Wine Birmingham pours dark black with tan head, bourbon on the nose, smooth on the palette, taste is ok but bourbon spoiled it for me

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wow!  This beer was amazing.  Aroma was pure bourbon.  Taste did not match the aroma.  the taste was very complex with coconut, vanilla, chocolate, bourbon, and roasty goodness.  Silky mouth feel.  Warming.  High alcohol content was well hidden.  Perfectly in balance.  I don’t know that I could drink this everyday, but a nice occasional nightcap beer.

This is one of the best imperial stouts I have ever tasted. So rich, with a straight bourbon nose that leads into smooth dark chocolate on the palate. Finishes with a bitterness that only adds to its dark chocolate flavor. It’s almost 15 percent ABV but you can’t taste it.
Nothing to say that haven’t been said already. The 2007 and 2008 were just awesome and the most rescent 2012 does not disappoint in any way.

AMAZING!  Love the flavor packed into this stout by the bourbon barrel.  Aroma and flavor of the sweet bourbon cuts well with the imperial bitterness to produce a finish that is not too sweet and not too bitter.  Absolutely worth the extra $$ to get your hands on this monster.

Ar: bourbon, vanilla, toffee, lots of alcohol, boozy, raisins, dried fruits, prunes, some notes of sherry, oak, cocoa, milky coffee, hints of licorice and light roastiness, just lovely! 
Ap: black colour, Brown head That quickly disippates, colour of the body is not as thick as I would have expected. 
F: warming, bourbon, dried fruits, prunes, raisins, licorice, slightly salty, soy sauce, sweet, Brown sugar, vanilla, roastiness, smoke, ending in a sweet, richly flavoured warming finish exquisite! 
P: small very Lively bubbles, thick almost chewy body. 
T: world class!

Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, oak, prunes, tar, molasses, and licorice.  Black with mostly diminishing, brown head.  Some sweetness, some chocolate, booze, and strong, roasty bitterness.  Creamy, full body, average carbonation, spicy, hot, and lingering, boozy, espresso-like and chocolatey flavors.

Bottle from SB cons 2013-02-02 Göteborg and shared with friends 
AR: rich thick dark chocolate pudding, bourbon vanilla, sweetnees
AP: black, high frothy dark brown head
F: rich thick dark chocolate pudding, bourbon vanilla, sweetnees - great brew simply
Momma, this is very boozy, not my style, but I love it. A beer that lives up to the hype or maybe surpasses it. Not a session beer at all but def- a must try before its all gone !!

Bottle from Stirchley Wines, pours pitch black like the dark recesses of hell, tan head that immediately disappears, heavy bourbon aroma, bourbon taste that leaves other flavours struggling to get noticed, once warmed up some of these tastes were revealed some raisins vanilla leather. I’m getting this big BA stouts, sorry this doesn’t live up to the hype for me.

Bottle 355 ml. Pours black with a small, dark brown head. Lots of oak in the aroma, vanilla, dried fruits and bread. Sweet to the taste, oak, vanilla licorice and dark chocolates. Nice, but a bit to sweet.

Black with a thin dark khaki head. Intense lovely aroma of roasted black malts, dark chocolate, and bourbon-y oak with some boozy vanilla. Rich deep flavor of dark chocolate, bourbon, sugar cane, boozy vanilla, oak, roast, and more chocolate. Lovely from top to bottom.
Extremely nice aroma and taste. Some time in teh basement will probably improve it further and remove some of the alcohol taste.
Rich chocolate malt aroma, slightly hot on both aroma and palate. Rich and complex, amazing beer.

Pours pitch black with a small brown dissipating head. Thick mouthfeel, aroma of heavy milk chocolate balanced out with coffee, and hints of vanilla. Very good stout. A flagship, if you will. Nice balanced, and that special chocolate note makes it wonderful.

Pours a deep rich black color with a trace of bubble. The nose is big boozy bourbon, deep dark fruit, chocolate and charred oak and tobacco. The palate is huge with tons of dark deep notes that complement one another but have not completely harmonized just yet. Slick oily mouthfeel coats the palate and keeps the flavors coming and coming nice licorice, vanilla and chocolate linger with boozy bourbon finish....

2012 Vintage. Poured draught at Stag’s Head in NYC. Pours black as night with a ruby tinge without much head at all. Aroma of raisins and chocolate. Tastes of dark fruit, chocolate with a bourbon edge. At 15% ABV it’s definitely boozy but better hidden than you would think at that ABV. A very interesting, incredibly complex beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 bottle.  Pours black with no head and a sweet boozy aroma.  Thick syrupy flavor with a strong taste of bourbon.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 bottle.  I had high hopes for this beer after reading so much about it.  I was genuinely impressed with the aroma of this beer.  Raisins, wood, chocolate, molasses.  It had a small and short lived caramel head.  The flavour was sweet, sticky but not cloying, figs, sherry and very warming. An amzing beer and one ill be comparing others to.

Bottle from the Microbar, Manchester. Dark brown pour, no head. Peaty nose. Rich aromas of raisins and chocolate. Intriguing. Rich warming flavours of dark chocolate, dark malts, raisins. Most vinous. Long, long warming, tingly finish. Excellent.

Bottle of 2012 vintage at Porter Beer Bar, Atlanta. Pours very dark, with little head. Aroma is bourbon front to back, with a bit of vanilla peeking through. Body is thick and rich, slightly syrupy, alcohol being really well-hidden, especially for the ABV. Finish is surprisingly abrupt, yet smooth, bourbon makes itself known. Pretty good, but maybe a bit over-hyped. Definitely delicious, but my mind wasn’t blown.

2012 vintage. Poured slowly into 12oz snifter. Pitch Black, with minimal head. Smell of Bourbon/Barrel/ and Vanilla. Tastes about the same with slight alchol burn at the finish. Slightly bitter in the taste which balances well with bourbon and deep malts. This is what I would consider the flagship of bourbon aged imperials. A little concerned after the InBev purchase about a quality drop off, but no worries here at all after tasting. One of the best!

Pours black as hell with only a small brown film that dissipates quick. The nose is massive vanilla and would. Chocolate and coffee makes appearances but are drowned out by the booze. The taste is sweet yet the bitter is still there to keep it in check. The mouth feel is pure silky smooth and cream, body is extra heavy and the finish is enormous.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I have been sitting on this beer for so time. A 2012 bottle pours deep dark murky jet black with a surpirsingly small tan head with no retention. Nose is full of booze and bourbon. Taste is a strong punch of bourbon followed by light vanilla and oak. Big full body sits heavy on the palate. Good..... but not all its claimed to be.

Location: Bottle at Nerd Beer Epic Weekend, 1/26/13, 2009 Bottle, 13%




Aroma: Tastes sugary and bourbony, with malty notes, dark fruit, chocolate, coffee, and caramel


Appearance: This one pours a thick black pour with pretty much no head or lace to it


Flavor: The taste is fairly sweet with a bunch of malts and a good amount of booze too


Palate: It has a fairly full body, it is on the creamy side for sure, with a soft-average carbonation


Overall Impression: 
Damn is this some good stuff.  I have enjoyed this one before.  Honestly, you cannot help but enjoy this beer, it is quite good.

Aroma of bourbon fills the room upon opening. Pours black with a thin head. Aroma of the aforementioned bourbon, sweet malt and caramel.  Taste is sweet, but balanced with the amount of alcohol. Bourbon taste is strong, I don’t think too much, but about as much as I’d like.

On tap at the Roast Public House in Madison. Pours deep deep brown with a thin layer of mocha head. Smells of black licorice and booze. Tastes of licorice, chocolate, black malt, and alcohol. Phenomenal, and it should be for ten bucks!
Aroma is a little unpleasant with a mix of bourbon and chocolate. Taste is strongly on the bourbon side, with an aftertaste of sweet chocolate. Overall it’s interesting, but not for me.

Bottle - Dark brown, almost black in colour. Raisins, vinous fruits, plain chocolate and bourbon in the aroma. Roasted, fruity, spicy and slightly sweet taste with notes of caramel, fudge, dried fruit and coffee. It gets a bit sickly after a while.

Second consecutive year drinking Bourbon County Stout thanks to some kick ass friends. Dark pour with about a half inch of head in a brandy snifter. Vanilla, oak, and bourbon on the nose. Vanilla, oak, and slight carmel up front with an oaked bourbon barrel finish. Bourbon taste is well done as it is not overwhelming.  Still #1

From keg on special Goose Island night. 10oz pour into snifter. Extremely complex beer. Notes of vanilla and other florals reminiscent of lavender. Sweet, but not cloingly (sp) so. Dark, but not thick. A true sipper. Not my favorite taste, but an amazing beer nonetheless. UPDATED: 2013 version, vanilla, molasses and alcohol nose. Half finger of dark foam, solid black with alcohol "oil" on top. Starts with molasses and raisins (dark fruit) up front, finishes with dark cherry and an alcohol tingle. Super smooth, super complex, and an absolute joy to experience. I enjoyed ?13 over ?12. UPDATE: it’s the same as last year, and that’s a great thing! UPDATE: BCBS 2015. Kinda missed this year. Consumed with this year’s KBS head to head, and it lost hands down. As it warmed, it added in some of the complexity, but it was so, so, so syrupy and sweet. I would still have it over the vast majority of stouts out there. 8, 5, 7, 5, 16
330 ml bottle, vintage 2008. Aroma heavy with bourbon, thick, sweet, syrupy with lots of dark malt notes. Taste: lots of chocolate and coffee. Sweet and thick. Wonderful!

Bottle at The Stout Tasting Part I, London - big thanks to Jack. Vintage 2011. Pours clearish, black-brown with a fine brown cream head. Dark fruit aroma with raisins, rich dark bread, dark malts. Big sweet flavor with rich sugars, light licorice, brownies, moderate earthy bitterness, some molasses. Full bodied with fine, chewy carbonation. Warming finish, somewhat hot even, with strong and gooey dark sugars, raisins, prunes, chocolate cake. Rich, ballsy and delicious.
Lightly sweet with a sharp alcohol aroma. Black color with a small brown head. Sweet beginning with a sharp bitter alcohol finish. Creamy palate.

Pretty heavy on the booze flavor.  Complex taste.  Hard to find.  Slightly overrated in my opinion.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at Top Hops. Pour is jet black with a well formed, inch high, dark tan head. Aroma is sweet dark fruit, light bourbon, oak. Taste is sweet.. vanilla, prune, molasses with a boozy bourbon finish. Oily and viscous in the mouth. A bit too boozy.. would have been nice to have some age on this. Overall a fine bourbon aged stout and very drinkable for ABV.
2012 Bottle.  Pours an oily black with very thin tan head.  Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, caramel, roasted malt, toffee.  Thick, smooth mouthfeel with a warm boozy finish.

Very oaky and vanilla notes throughout-- as to be expected.  Very warming palate, given the 15% alcohol.  Strong deep flavors.  Many of them.  Not much roastiness or stout flavor, unfortunately.  It tastes more like a very strong barleywine.  It’s obviously a very well made beer, but these strong beers are simply not my preference.
This is it.  I’ve found the holy grail.  Wow.  I really need to make this last.

Pours a very thick black with a thin dark head that fades very quickly.  Tastes of Licorice, chocolate and malt.  A bit too high of alcohol content for me.  The balance of taste/alcohol is off  a bit.  None the less, a very tasty beverage.
Black.  Very very hot.  Too high alcohol....(it’s not balanced out).  Tastes more like a whiskey than anything else.  If I liked Whiskey, I would like this more.

Straight in a tense, Burrbun burn - brownie sweetness and delicious. Peppery Cinnamon before a sticky spiciness, bunts of malt trench palate before a calculated sweetness. I could probably drink this all day. It’s thicker/sweeter/woodieer but retains what I slammed down a year ago - nearly 53 weeks exact. LOOOVELYYYY 

As a dense pouring as you’d expect, charred black with a plum tint. Wink of a tan broon head, surprisingly aerated that slips away meekly. Total whirlpool of equally distinct, sugary stout aroma, ash, and succulent dried fruit - like some really well soaked prunes, in a good way.


Initial taste kicks onto a high pitched chocolate, like sipping dusting off a frothy coffee before dunking into an elasticated vanilla and raisin moistness. There’s a seeping carbonation mid-glass that pricks with hazelnut wafer mid range which carries things far too quickly. 


There’s a big, vacuous gap between the settling of the dusty mouth-feel with the Oak laden palate and the dense gritty sweetness of some serious ABV.
Pleased to finally get a full dunt at a bottle to myself. Superbly packaged amount of ageing, booze and an overall smoothness that most high grade wine would struggle to match at this pace. There’s little sparks in at kick off but by conclusion there’s not enough swell to the Bourbon throughout. I look forward to 2013’s and tasting the one on the shelf before then, but would be mad keen on sinking into some of the variations on what is an inextricably enjoyable and expertly put together beer.


Bottle, 2012 Vintage, Cornelius, Edinburgh

2012 bottle from pellegjr - cheers Joey! Pours jet black - viscous like oil - with no head/lacing to speak of. Aroma is a big hit of bourbon, oak, light licorice, vanilla, medium/dark chocolate, and booze. Taste balances the big roasty characteristics with the bourbon & oak sweetness very well - wonderfully smooth altogether. Plenty of vanilla and dark chocolate hitting the palate. Mouthfeel is fairly full bodied, but still highly sinkable - especially given the huge ABV. Booze warmth as it goes down. Long lasting bourbon note lingers on the palate. I must admit that I'm not a usually a big bourbon fan, but this brew comes together so well that I absolutely loved it.

Bottle at DØE tasting, vintage 2012, 15%.
Clear black, no head. Aroma heavy of barrel, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, licorice. Flavor medium+ sweet, medium spicy, light bitter, complex. Full body, almost flat, the alcohol well hidden.

Pours motor oil black with decent mocha colored head and good lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, dark fruit and molasses with a definite bourbon smell.  Taste is big and complex with everything I could want from an imperial stout.  Chocolate and coffee with the dark fruit not as prevalent but still detectable.  The bourbon shows up with a vanilla character and hint of oak from the barrel.  The flavors just envelope your palate and develop so nicely.  Alcohol is apparent but not overpowering.  Best stout I’ve ever had and possible best beer period.  2009 bottle was smoother and the best.  Age helps an already great beer.  2011 and 2012 bottles were very similar but you can still tell it improves with age. Fantastic beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours straight black with very small light brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, raisin, some vanilla and a little booze with a slight funk and some bread. Taste is chocolate, vanilla, caramel, coffee, and bourbon all layering throughout every sip.    Slightly sweet with just a hint of the booze, very well balanced.Palate is slick and smooth, almost perfect.  Hard to find a better stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: lots of rich chocolate and caramel, molasses, toffee, sweetness, some coffee, notes of bourbon, roast malts.
Pours jet black, opaque, thin brown head from an aggressive pour dissipates almost immediately, very little lacing. 
Flavor: chocolate, rich and sweet, caramel, medium-high bitterness, robust roast character, touch of oak, bourbon, warming alcohol and a bit boozy.  
Palate: very full body, low carbonation, thick and silky, fairly sweet finish.
Nice brew.

Bottle: 2012 vintage.
Pours purple-black with a very dark brown head.
Aroma os wood and chocolate....bourbon.
Taste is bourbon and coke with melted chocolate floated into it....malty...thick.
Surprisingly smooth, easygoing bourbon accent.
Wonderful.

Shared a bottle with greenclansman. Wow what a beer. Pours pitch black with very little head. A bit on the sweet side but with a slight chocolatey bitter finish. So smooth that the alcohol is well covered with hints of bourbon only on the finish. What an amazing beer.

Amazing!!! Best bourbon barrel beer I've had.  Finally getting around to trying it.  Tastes exactly how you'd think a bourbon stout would taste; very boozy.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The most amazing bourbon stout I have ever tried.
Great black color, super strong bourbon aromas.
Roasted malts, oak, wood...on taste, with an amazing bourbon aftertaste.
You can sense the taste of alcohol, but it burns in a smooth way.
The best beer, for the end of a very special night.

This isn’t the same label but based on my research I will assume it is the same beer. Bourbon County Imperial Stout. Picked up in Manchester, Vt.

Going to to have to just go freestyle here because this is one the most amazing beers I have had in some time. I grabbed it simply because I liked the style, the label and the sound of it! Imperial Stout and Bourbon...how can that go wrong? It was a gift for my man Nate at WoB in Tampa. And he is so cool ...and he shared it with me :) Cuz that is what cool beer aficianados do.

The aroma was smooth, layered...complex. Touch of soy sauce, chocolate, cedar, yeasty nuttiness...dark fruitcake! Like a good tawny port...but BEER!  It was deep and dark and chewy and decadent. 

I started to get angry that sample sips were wasted on people saying things like "too much, it’s too sweet, yuck.." so I took their their samples from them and gladly drank away...sparing them the horror of imbibing something so epic!

Now I am just angry with myself for not picking up MORE! This has now become my most memorable beer.

It poured a starless midnight sky black, with an ever so small mocha colored head that immediately dissipated. The aroma was a beautiful blend of bourbon, coffee, roasted malt and vanilla. The taste mimicked the aroma but also brought flavors of tobacco and chocolate. The body of the beer was thick and viscous, coating my tongue and leaving a warming sensation in the back of my throat.

The beer poured from a 12oz bottle was bottled on 11/8/2012.  The beer pours a black viscous color that pours out like motor oil.  Little to no head.  The only head that exists is the thin ring around the outside of the glass.  It is a dark mocha color.  I had this beer right after it was bottled…and just by the nose I can tell it has changed over the last 60 days. Aroma on the beer is big milk chocolate and toasted coconut from the barrel.  There is a bourbon oakiness present as well. Tiny bit of booze on the nose but it is very well masked by the vanilla. Also a hint of dark cherry.  The beer leaves tremendous alcohol legs on the glass.  The way that this beer has mellowed out over only 60 days is amazing.  
At the front of the tongue is an initial slight pop of carbonation followed by milk chocolate, toasted coconut, oak, bourbon flavors. There is a sweetness, from the vanilla, alcohol, slight dark fruit, cherry, fig, plum although it is slight.   Finishes with almost a bitter espresso flavor as well. Finishes dry.    Nice warming in the chest.  I really had to search for the dark fruits in this beer.  I didn’t initially taste them, but when I really looked for them they are there.  As the beer warms, I did notice that some of the dark fruits coming forward more.  Mouthfeel is great too.  Coats the whole mouth.  Great beer.

This was a beautiful stout. Truly delicious. Pours a jet black into the glass with a dark tan head. Lots of aromas of coffee and chocolate and bourbon on the nose as well as some roasted malt character. Big flavors of coffee, chocolate, and bourbon. Such a complex and wonderful flavor combination. The abv is slightly noticeable (I mean it’s15% what are you gonna do?) but it isn’t overpowering and adds a nice warming character. Big and bold this bad boy is a slow sipper. Build yourself a nice fire and relax with this one.

Served on-tap on three separate occasions this year, the last of which being this one at the brewhouse restaurant.

A - Pours pitch black with a small half finger tall tan head leaving very tiny trails of lace down the top part of the glass.

S - Smells of melted milk chocolate, dark roast, fresh vanilla beans, sweet molasses and plenty of warm bourbon booze. This is simply intoxicating.

T - Starts off with a big dose of milk chocolate sweetness slowly giving way to hints of warm vanilla, dark fruit, molasses and dark roast. The bourbon heat is ever present, never really fading away. Finish is sweet with a bit of warm booze, lingering on the palate long after the finish.

M - Heavy body with moderate carbonation. Smooth feel with lots of residual sweetness and mild booze burn. The alcohol only grows as it sits in the glass.

O - Definitely one of the better stouts out there and well deserving of the attention it garners. Worth seeking out if you have the chance. I will get my fill while I can and I hope to see this more often in the future.

Chilled 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a snifter at a JStax tasting.  Pours black with no head.  Very little lacing, medium body, and soy sauce/alcohol aroma.  Taste is lots of bourbon and some alcohol.  2011 drinks better than 2012.  Rating is for the 2012 which is very hard to drink.

2011 and 2012 vintages poured side by side. 2011 was better, so I’m rating that one. Dark brown with no head. Big booze aroma and fairly sweet. Sinking shot of bourbon feeling in the stomach. Bourbon is much stronger in the new version, that’s why I liked the older version better. The sweetness was a little more dominant than the booziness. Still not for me, though.

Bottle. Pours a deep black color with hardly any head at all. Strong licorice aroma with some roasted malt and an intense sense of bourbon. Very intense and complex. Nice vanilla sense with some roasted malt and oat. Solid bourbon finish, For being so high in alcohol you cannot really sense it. Great stout.

One of the best bourbon aged beer I have had. Look if you are not a bourbon drinker you will not  enjoy this beer so save it for us that do. Pour is black with a think,large dark tan head. Aroma is bold with notes oak,carmel and bourbon. A think palate coating that sticks with you and will over power  a lot of foods and yes a lot of cigars.

2012 edition. Thick with strong bourbon and chocolate. Warming finish but incredibly smooth for a 15% abv brew. Very heavy with a lingering roasted malt flavor. Excellent beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2008 bottle. Pours pitch black with a dark tan head that disappears quickly but comes back with agitating. Deep oily texture, resonates with spirit, sooy sauce, vanilla, leather and ripe berries. Powerful, smooth, medicinal and outstanding. Well worth leaving alone for nearly 5 years!

Poured a oily black color with a brown head that faded away quickly.  Kind of loose looking.  Aroma had some soft roasted malt notes but it was overshadowed by wood and bourbon notes.  Some alcohol in there too. Flavor seemed to have a lot of bourbon flavor, roasted malts were present, but took a back seat to the nice flavors of the bourbon and wood.  At times it seemed a little harsh, but overall was smooth. Kind of light on the palate and boy was there alcohol here.

Re-rate. 2016 in Vintage Ale House Balham. Oily, black,some clarity. Nose is Marmite, dark chocolate, barley sugar, caramel, molasses, dark fruits, boozy, plum, fig, prune. This is really good. Taste is hop resin, dark fruits, prune,fig, caramel. Bottle of 2012 from Kris Wines. Pours very dark opaque brown, brown tan thin head. Nose is rich dark chocolate, lots of wood barrel, lots of bourbon whiskey. The bourbon on the nose is a bit overpowering. The first taste is remarkably soft and smooth, but pretty quickly there is a raw bourbon bite. There’s rich dark chocolate but it’s getting blown away by a raw whiskey sour and sweetness. Result is hard and cloying. Overpowering. This is most definitely the emperor’s new clothes of beers. It’s really a whiskey bourbon flavoured beer. I like a beer to at least taste like a beer. This is hard and cloying.

Truly one of the best beers I have ever had, by far the best overall stout. Not to mention aged in Whiskey Barrels which gives me the best of both worlds Beer + Whiskey! The 2012 is a 15% ABV but you would never tell by the smooth taste!

2012 bottle. Pours thick, jet black, thin coffee head. Nose is big bourbon, vanilla, some wood, and port. Taste is bourbon, very sweet dark malts, booze. Alcohol burn at the finish. Very sticky, smooth mouthfeel.

Bottle of the 2012. Black with a small chocolate head. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, dark fruits. Slick mouthfeel, full bodied, complex on the palate with a touch of booze on the finish. Taste is chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, oak, dark fruits, fig, dates. Tasty!

Bottle.  Pitch black with little head.  More bubbly on tongue than I would have thought.  Awesome flavor.  Heavy on bourbon; solid burn.  Easily one of best bourbon/oaked beers I've had.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared with pentaz' girlfriend. Pours black with no head. Aroma is heavy sweet and heavy bourbon, milk chocolate, dried fruits. Taste is thick and oily sweet dominated by bourbon, booze, milk chocolate with some roasted malt underneath. Sweet, thick, bourbon chocolate juice. This is nice. Pentaz' girlfriend agrees.

This beer was bought in Chicago by friend as a Christmas gift.  Pours black with almost non-existent brown head.  Aroma of bourbon, coffee, vanilla.  Strong vanilla flavor fades alcohol, smoke, wood replacing it.  Chocolatey malts balanced with vanilla from the bourbon is very interesting.  Alcohol taste is strong, but not unpleasant.  Palate is thick, creamy.  Delicious beer, very complex, but not something I plan to drink all the time.  I really like this more than Founders Kentucky Breakfast Stout because despite the ABV being higher the alcohol burn is more subdued.  I plan to age a bottle 1-2 years and review again.

(bottle; Dec 29, 2012 and Dec 31, 2018) Opaque black body with a medium, quickly vanishing reddish-brown head. Delicious aroma of bourbon, and sweet roasted malt; coffee, light chocolate; fruit (cherry), vanilla. Full bodied, creamy texture. Strong alcohol and bourbon flavor, very warming; vanilla, dark chocolate, oak, light coffee.

7 oz pour on tap the the Holy Grail. Ink black with dark brown head which quickly disappears into the oily darkness. Aroma of raisin and booze. Thick buttery taste fades into boozy bliss. Complexity at it's best!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from 2008.  Smells of prunes, bourbon and malt.  Pours a thick black with no head.  Sweet like amazing candy.  Boozy, fruity with malt and a slight coffee bitterness.

2012 poured in a goose island tulip. Pours extremely black with zero visibility. Hardly and head but a slight brown ring in the end. Very boozy aroma with hits of vanilla and wood. Instant smoky bourbon vanilla and chocolate taste.

355ml bottle, 2012 vintage, 15%.
Pours black with small espresso colored head that quickly disappears.
Aroma is vanilla, bourbon, chocolate and a little roasted malt. Rather sweet but in a very appealing way.
Palate is full body, very creamy, well balanced carbonation, and the finish is boozy and warming.
The flavor is heavy on sweetness but in a surprisingly good way. Vanilla, chocolate, oak, bourbon/whiskey and fruit. Underneath there are hints of roasted malts and some licorice - especially in the finish.
It all comes together very well in a well balanced and rounded imp. stout, with a long and enjoyable finish.

Wow! Black with nearly no head. Aroma is fruitcake. Figs, raisins, dates. Taste is sweet dried fruits, cinnamon ,nutmeg, chocolate.  Syrupy and boozy.  An ultra rich and decadent treat - sweet nectar of the gods.

Reviewed 12/23/2012. 12 oz (2012 vintage) bottle poured into a Duvel tulip.

A: Pours a wondrously pitch black color. However, there’s hardly any head. Any vestiges of a tan-colored head fade quickly and leave almost no lacing. Really, we’ve got to start talking about alcohol legs when we get to this gravity. And they’re pretty impressive.

S: Tons of bourbon, augmented by dark fruits and vanilla. Not much in the way of roasted malts; it pretty much hits on the sweeter aspects of a good imperial stout, rather than the more savory ones. It’s really not that boozy for 15%, either. Not the strongest aroma ever (due to the low carbonation), but incredibly evocative.

T: Sweet? Yes. Boozy? Yes. The flavor I notice first are stewed plums, raisins, and figs - this has a hell of a dark fruit note to it. Ultimately, it will finish with its trademark bourbon character and vanilla-infused chocolate. A slight note of smokiness will appear after a while. It’s warm, yes, but given its gravity, the booze could be a lot worse. Basically, it has the hallmark character of a proper boozy beer - an alcohol character that blends with the flavor profile instead of clashing. This definitely bears a passing resemblance to FW Parabola, only with a lot more in the way of finesse and balance. The only thing missing is some complexity; thankfully, what’s there is very enjoyable to savor slowly.

M: The finish is ultra syrupy, wet, and sweet. Very creamy in its palate texture, aided by the subtle (at best) carbonation. Some oak tannins come out in the late aftertaste in an attempt to dry the palate a little, but to no avail. This really is the type of beer that sits indolently on the tongue with massive, thick sweetness. You will NOT drink this quickly, so don’t even dare - just veg over it for an hour or two and everything will be peachy keen.

O: Well, what more can be said? It’s a big monster, but with enough deftness and sophistication to help give it a little extra ’something’. On the other hand, there is enough harshness to suggest this needs to lay down in the cellar for a bit. Regardless, this is something everyone should try at least once in their life.

Bottle, 2012 vintage.  Pours a thick black with a light tan head which dissipates fairly quickly.  Aroma is a blast of bourbon, with some wood, chocolate and vanilla notes.  The flavor is similar, though a bit (and only a bit) less bourbon-dominated.  In addition to the chocolate, vanilla, and toasted malt notes, there are also a lot of dark fruits on the palate.  The 15% ABV sounds high (and is higher than the past versions that I’ve had), but it’s not overbearing, and it contributes to the flavor.  As it warms up, the bourbon becomes a bit more muted, allowing the other flavors to shine through to a greater extent.  For those that dig bourbon, this one is a winner.

33cl. bottle. Pours pitch black with a twofinger brown head. First thought upon tasting it was "Motor oil and cough syrup" (but in a good way). Very thick and viscous...just the way a good stout should be. ;-) It’s very sweet but although you can taste the 15% alcohol it’s not as dominating as I’d feared so that’s a plus. Taste is: chocolate, liquorice & roasted malts - and bourbon of course, which isn’t as overpowering as I’d feared either.
I love it. A very good stout.

12oz Bottle 2012 Vintage A - Pours thick black crude oil. Small tan head dissipates quickly. Decent lacing. S - Bourbon laden aromas, chocolate, lots of alcohol 15% abv Wow! T - Chocolate covered whiskey shot! Molasses, Really boozy, possibly to a fault. M - Heavy and thick a real sipper. Lingering sweet molasses finish. O - Gaint Barrel Aged Stout Worth Trying.

Pours jet black, not much head but a steady carbonation. Enormous aroma of dark chocolate, rich chocolate truffles, balanced with some cherry and some slight banana, but mainly thick, lovely chocolate. The balance is great, it’s just lovely to sip. Fantastic stuff

2012 Bottle (drank almost 3 months old).  Pours near black with a small brown disappearing head and some legs but no lace.  The aroma is very sweet roasted malt and some fresh rustic dense brown bread.  Fruitiness is mostly absent from the aroma.  The flavor starts beyond cloying sweet then a fresh espresso, one with a good bit of tang, takes over before ending with soy, roasted cherries and pineapple as if in a ham, woody, of a lot of bourbon.  The palate is cloying sugars, thick syrup, lively still, drying and tightness at the end with alcohol prickles.  The MF isn’t very pleasant. Perhaps it would improve with time but this beer is way overblown IMO. It’s good yeah but it really doesn’t have much complexity or depth, mostly just brute force.

2009 version. Dark and thick, bourbon barrel shines through with a chocolate sweet. Very sweet chocolate syrup taste with coffee overtones. Really good after taste, sweet coffee with not a lot of bitter.  Boozy at first but after a few sips you don't mind so much. All and all a superb stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottles. Vintage 2008 and 2009. Almost no difference. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Black colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Bourbon present- Heavy bitter powerfull flavor. Coffee and bourbon notes. Long heavy bitter finish. Creamy palate.

pours a viscous black. lovely bourbon, oak, vanilla and chocolate in the nose but there is also a good amount of alcohol present. I rally like the thick viscous, sticky, chewy yet velvety mouth feel. It in intense in the mouth with flavors of bourbon, vanilla, oak chocolate, roasted malt and a high but not oppressive alcohol presence.

Thick texture with bourbon flavour updront and a very creamy follow. Nice dark red color

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at JL Beers in Fargo. Pours a beautiful dense black with cocoa head that quickly fades. Aromas are nice bourbon, vanilla, oak, and a hint of sweetness. Strong dark chocolate and roasted malty flavours. Soft, rich palate. Warm and delicious on the way down. Excellent.

While this is definitely the top end of my beer $ scale, I’d sit down with one of these on numerous occasions if I could be so lucky. This is a heavy duty beer that warms the innards and has a great bourbon-laden aroma. I can see why it was one of the top rated beers this week/month.

Huge thanks to xscottypx! Been waiting to try this for a long time and knew it would show up eventually. Cheers man! Inky black pour with a bubbly brown head. Aroma of toasted coconut, vanilla, bourbon, wood, roasted malts and bittersweet chocolate. Sweet creamy cocoa on the front followed by toasted coconut, vanilla beans, more sweet bourbon and roasted. Silky mouthfeel with light carbonation and a hint of warming booze, and I like that. Wish I had more than one to see how it ages. Great beer.

12 oz bottle: Pours dark black with a thin light brown head. Small bubbles persist around the glass,  and somewhat oily. Aroma of bourbon, charcoal, dark chocolate Taste is heavy on the bourbon but balanced well with a thick, viscous chocolate malt that is almost like drinking syrup. Very nice feel. Very enjoyable to drink with a slight burn. Not a bad burn perse, just powerful. Lives up to its reputation, I will try to age a few as well.

Bottle at home (from Beer Ritz) 20/12/12. 2012 Vintage.
Pours black, very dark mahogony brown in light, with a dirty coffee coloured head that soon clears to nyadda.
Nose is powerful roast malt, wood tones, bourbon, light vanilla, leather, molasses, tar, booze - a little on the harsh side.
Taste comprises roast malt, wood, bourbon, big boozey kick, molasses, leather, dark treacle toffee, bitter chocolate, like drinking liquid chocolate maltesers that have been bobbing up and down in a bourbon barell for some weeks!
Full bodied, fine carbonation pitched perfectly, boozey finish.
Excellent stuff if a little on the sweet and boozey side, glad I only had a 35cl bottle to myself as more would have been a bit much!
Smells like straight up vanilla whiskey. Tastes like an exact cross between aged whiskey and stout beer. No head, super dark pour. Doesn't taste like 15% beer but super tasty.

On tap at House Pub, St Charles into snifter. Pours deep black with small sheen of head. Smells of butter, chocolate, caramel. Taste is creamy, bourbon and alcohol, roasted malt, chocolate. Mouthfeel is medium with moderate carbonation. Special

2012, on tap. Unexpected cola-like appearance, indicative of a thinner body than most imperial stouts. Pleasant dark fruits on the nose, very pronounced bourbon aroma.

Cloying on the first sip, and it didn’t improve any after warming up. No coffee/chocolate, the flavor profile would simply consist of dark/red/candied fruits and molasses if not for the absurd amount of bourbon. That, coupled with a relatively thin texture, means this doesn’t even drink like a stout. I REALLY like bourbon (or any other whiskey), but I feel it’s used haphazardly here. I can’t help but feel like this beer is all hype. One of my biggest beer disappointments.

12oz bottle, thanks very much to Alden for sharing. Initially pours with a nice brown head, though it fades to nothing soon, as I’d expect for a 15% brew. Very nice nose. Vanilla, dark chocolate, very rich. Sweet, but not cloyingly so. Very rich and decadent. Balanced bit of bourbon. Big body, chewy texture, but not dry or sticky. Alcohol does not burn at all. Just a nice light warmth. Super good stuff. Wish I could find this more easily. $20 for a 4-pack, I think that’s a reasonable price, considering how massive this is. 8/4/8/5/17 

Re-rate, 6/1/18: 500ml bottle, been in my fridge since I bought it. Bottled on 29 Jul 17, labeled 14.7%. I started reading "Barrel-Aged Stout and Selling Out" and I got in the mood. Poured into Sahm Hamburg goblet. A couple peanutbutter pretzel things on the side. Rich caramel syrup, milk and dark chocolate, coffee (ranging from latte to mocha to espresso) in the flavor, some nut (walnut, pecan, almond). Big bodied, slightly sticky. Bigger sweet, but thankfully not sickly sweet like many super stouts can be. It doesn't seem undrinkable and only meant for splitting at a bottle share, like many of these tend to be. These types of beers often exhaust me with their obnoxious sweetness, but it seems like I'm on good pace to handle this offering one-go solo, so far. It's in balance, which seems to be the rarest and most difficult and least-celebrated quality to nail down in this style. That's saying a lot for a beer that is simultaneously in the maybe the most extreme category of style and the pioneer of it. Moderate bitter, light bite, and some alcohol warmth -- though not really much heat aside from a brief wave. Really enjoyable to swig while reading this book, which was the main thing I was pumped for tonight. Been craving another AB story since Bitter Brew.

2012 bottle at bar in Palmer House hotel. Incredible aroma: bourbon (duh), vanilla, wood (oak?), chocolate, caramel, nuts, and rich dark malt. Mouthfeel was big and velvety. Alcohol content was hidden incredibly well-- I still cannot believe I was drinking at 15% ABV beer! Very smooth and a true pleasure to drink as a special treat. Would love to have this again.

This beer catches your eye with it’s dark hue, so dark as a matter of fact, that you wonder if there is any color that can truly be any darker.  The aroma produced intrigues you instantly, with a strong scent of oak mixed with subtle hints of vanilla and bourbon.  The palate feels like a liqueur, goes down like a liqueur, and has a bourbon taste.  It is by far the best stout I’ve had

Pours jet black, with a rich mocha head....Smell of bourbon, raisins, coffee and chocolate...Taste is a thick bourbon carmel with a chocolate taste, hangs on the pallet just great...This is for sure going in my top 3 beers so far...

I had went to the brewery and tasted one right out of the barrel.
Taste notes of how it is brewed, very oaky and bourbon with chocolate and vanilla flavors.
One of the best stouts I have drank

Bottle. Pours black with quickly fading tan head. Aroma is malts and bourbon  with a noticeable booze nose. Flavor is terriffic. A blast of bourbon and malts overwhelms the senses. Great mouthfeel, very thick and creamy. This is an awesome beer.

11/11/12 750? ml Bottle - 14.3% ABV. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and bourbon. Completely black pour with dark tan head, minimal lacing.  Taste does not disappoint the nose...very heavy mouth feel with rich complex tastes.  Nice sweet finish.. Although expensive, will definitely be an annual holiday purchase.

Bottle. 2011. Bottled 11/11/11. Jet black with dark brown edges. Dark tan thin head. Nose is rich. Bourbon, rum, coconut, chocolate, like a melted bounty bar soaked in alcohol. A little slick in the mouth, imparting bourbon, whisky, coconut, Licorice, chocolates and coffee. Aftertaste is glorious. Smokey wood, reminiscent of a backroom poker game. A taste so solid you feel you can chew through it while you drink. The slickness of the beer is cut through by the carbonation making it not as sickly as other beers of this type. There's some nice hop bitter action making the whole thing balance well with the bourbon sweetness.

The aroma through me off, but after a sip I was in love. To quote my friend "I don't want it to stop." Great stout!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A swirly midnight with flashes of lush malts (and that’s just the color). The 2012 jumped to a 15% in order to jump out and grab the taste buds for a ride. Though it is strong and distinctly tastes like wood aged bourbon, it is amazingly smooth and leaves a very clean finish. Thank you Lewiston pub

Pours a thick black with the smallest of a light brown head.  it has the smell of booze, molasses, and the bourbon barrels.  the 15% and the sweetness of the beer are perfectly balanced.  The taste lives up to the smell of the beer.  Rich molasses and chocolate taste and the taste of the barral aging is bold finish.  Amazing beer.

Wow... The scotch lovers beer! Pours thick as motor oil. Opaque. Little to no head. Aroma is Scotch and black licorice. Body is thick, full. Mouth feel is chewy and coating. Taste... oh the taste! This is outstanding! Mixture of strong bourbon flavors, figs, molasses, brown sugar. The alcohol and hops make this not too sweet where it could have easily gone that way. This is wonderful... Be sure to let it warm to near room temperature. Night cap for the hop head.

Black pour with a thin brown head. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, coconut, raisin, wood, and booze. Taste is chocolate, syrup, vanilla, booze, coconut, and some bitterness to go along with the sweetness. Chewy velvety texture.Great beer.
Aroma is bourbon, light vanilla, oak, and chocolate roast. Taste follow suit with a smooth velvety texture. About what I expected. Very nice.

In bottle, thanks Craig. Pours a very dark brown colour with a lacy light tan head. Aroma of bourbon, coconut, chocolate, caramel and oak. Similar flavours with mild carbonation, light CO2 prickle and an oily mouth-feel. Alcohol is quite prominent with lingering coconut and alcohol again.

12oz Bottle

Appearance - Thick, black body, brown head

Aroma - Chocolate, raisins, vanilla, oak

Taste - Tootsie rolls, coffee, oak, bourbon



This beer was huge and flavorful. Lots of complex malt/oak flavors make for quite a sipper - not just the generous amount of alcohol presented here.

Pours a dark black with no head or lacing. Aroma of bourbon and vanilla, caramel. I don’t normally mention palate but this one is smooth and thick, very nice! Tastes of bourbon, caramel, vanilla creme, bitter scotch. A really nice winter brew! Supposedly very hard to find. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: vanilla, bourbon, chocolate, woody, alcohol. Not as bourbon forward as some suggest.

Appearance: black as black, minimal tan head. Decent lacing and great legs.

Taste: A BIG beer. Taste is similar to aroma...vanilla, bourbon

Palate: A nice, flavorful, long finish. Very full body. 

This is a beer worth trying. It is expensive, so treat it well. It is a great beer for special occasions. It is big. It took me a good 45 minutes plus to topple this giant.

Dark as the blackest night, smells of bourbon, bourbon and more bourbon.  Taste of some vanilla (develops more vanilla with aging), wood, and smooth bourbon taste.  An excellent "BIG" beer, definately worth trying if your into big barrel aged stouts.

12 oz bottle   This was a gift from a friend.  The stout poured a pitch black with a disappearing brown head.  The aroma is sweet boubon with notes of wood, prunes, and raisins.  The bourbon aroma and flavors overpowers the hint of roasted malt, and chocolate.  I think this was held in the barrels too long.  The bourbon dominates the stout.  The finish was smooth with a modest carbonation. Another 12 oz bottle in 2014 from a friend.  I noted more licorice in the taste this time.  A big time stout.
Dark viscous oil pour off of the draft, pure black. Very complex scents of coffee, bourbon and oak. Great big alcohol flavor with the bourbon and a nice blend with the stout. One of my favorites.

The scent is rich of bourbon, oak notes, and smokey carmel malts. The flavor is top notch. The BCS has a nice mild caramel sweetness. The vanilla is noticeable and adds a good mix with the bourbon flavor. My favorite part is the malts. They’re delicious. This is a great drink because it allows each prime ingredient to stand out and play a definitive role in the flavor of this beverage but not overpower each other. I did not rate this drink when I first had it. I figured the hype would spoil my judgment. Yet this is a delightful and must try stout.

2012 vintage from bottle. This is the nectar of the gods. One bottle will get you going. Great to start cold then sip as it gets warmed up beyond room temperature in your hands over 20 minutes. $18.99 / 4 pack

Pours a dark black with no head and impenetrable to light, looks delicious. Smells of Bourbon and dark fruits, taste about the same. Heavy mouth feel and certainly can taste a lot of alcohol and some burn. Stout and Bourbon mix and blend nice and complement each other. I think this is good for fans of this style but I have no Idea why you’d want your beer to taste like hard alcohol. High octane and pretty rough but probably good for Bourbon fans.
Great taste! Thick flavor. No head on a stout, which I found strange, but liked and love the brewery!

Thanks to TheHopster. Bottle poured into Chimay glass. Inky black with mocha head, notes of cherry, bourbon, smoke, tobacco, bacon, oily palate alcohol pretty well hidden for a 15% brew, well done!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tastes good. Got me drunk. No headed stout is strange. Very thick. Might try it in a beer float
Bottle shared with northropfrye. Delicious sweet bourbon and chocolate aroma. Delivers on the flavour as well. This is delicious. Loved it!
Nice aroma of sweet malts, dried fruit, bourbon, bread, dark chocolate, wood. Dark cola colour, very thin quickly fading head. Taste is a marvelous boozy coffee, chocolate. One of the greats.

Delicious.  Upon first taste the the coffee and chocolate start out the party then the bourbon tingles on the way down.  Second sip smooth once you realize what you are dealing with.  This beer just gets better and better with each sip.  The sweet bourbon flavor is prevalent but not over bearing.  A great beer.

(4-pack bottle).  Aroma features oak, bourbon and alcohol.  Absolutely intense flavors of malt with bourbon sweetness and warming alcohol.  Silky palate.  A winter malt-cocktail sipper. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a near black with a fizzy light brown head that didn’t stick around. 

Smells heavy on bourbon, wood, vanilla. Lots of cherry too.

Taste is similar to smell.  Sweet cherry and vanilla up front, supported by a bourbon backbone that finishes up chocolate. Strangely tastes like a chocolate covered cherry. 

I’ll buy one more pack to have one or two to compare over the next few years. Impressive beer.

2013 release, fresh - opened first day available.   Just as I remembered it.   Aroma is thick, syrupy, complex, nuanced, etc.  It takes a while for the first sip, partially because the aroma is so good, and partially because it’s so imposing.  Taste is aggressive.  It’s a little raw from being so new, but you can tell this will age well.  Buried deep within the aroma is coffee and roasted malts, but it’s smothered with a thick layer of syrupy bourbon.  Packs a punch in every aspect, and it’s so smooth despite its increasingly insane alcohol content.  Hoping to grab at least one more 4 pack and let these age.



This was much better than last time.  Not sure how much was the age (5.5 months), and how much was my improved taste.  I bet it’s mostly the age.  The flavors are still bold, but are now all within the realm of tolerance.  Pours a jet black with brown head that’s aggressively fizzy and fades quickly.  Aroma is sweet molasses, bourbon, smoked wood, chocolate, vanilla, and alcohol.  Taste is sticky sweet creamy chocolate, building fast to a huge wave of bourbon and earthy, woody roasted malts, then hollowing out in the finish to a great aftertaste.  The age has made this go down much easier, and the ABV is a little less prominent.  I’d like to age it longer, but it’s too hard to resist.  10+4+9+4+17=4.4



People apparently love this beer.  I must not be experienced enough to appreciate it, or something.  I’m not well-versed in bourbon or any other hard liquors, and haven’t acquired the taste required to enjoy it. Pours dark brown, very dark with some red on the edges.  A tan, short-lived head.  Aroma packs a punch - super sweet molasses, vanilla, and tons of alcohol.  Taste is enormous - it requires effort to drink it.  Definitely a drink to sip slowly and (try to) enjoy.  So unlike any beer I’ve had.  Absent the label, I wouldn’t have even guessed this was a stout, or even beer in general.  Overwhelmingly sweet, syrupy taste up front, a small glimpse of complexity in the middle, but then right into a tidal wave of bourbon and alcohol heat.  Insane 15% ABV is obvious, for better or worse, in every aspect of the beer.  Good for up to 5 years in the bottle, and this was only 30 days old... so I’ll let the rest of the 4-pack age for a while and see how that affects the experience.  7+4+4+4+11 = 3

Incredible nose of cherry, vanilla and bourbon. First sip revealed deep hop levels, slight smoke, chocolate with a smooth velvety finish. Impressive to say the least. Would bang. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Oily black pour with almost no head whatsoever. Intense boozy aroma, charred oak, vanilla, anise, blackcurrant, plum, cherry, and malts roasted black. Chocolate and burnt sugar in the taste. Velvety smooth with lively carbonation, warming and bitter finish.

Holy amazing!  Warming alcohol effect.  Dark chocolate at the finish.  Huge bourbon nose.  This is a fantastic stout.

*I can’t believe I didn’t mention the vanilla notes, and the oaky bourbon flavor that shines through.  Sweet, big, and bold.
New batch. Sweet garbage juice for dorks. Malt liquor is infinitely better.
Powerful bourbon flavour with sides of chocolate and coffee. Definitely will try again...now.

2012 vintage..bottle pour into snifter..jet black pour..aroma is booze dominated..but what do you expect from 15%..bourbon nose..vanilla goodness.Glad to be able to try and find this..mouthfeel is quite complex surprisingly I am not getting the full on high abv undertone but only had a small sample..does pair nicely with dark chocolate..going to hang on to the rest of the pack and see what some age will do this..have a feeling this will be even smoother with a few years..

Billowing smoke in the neck of the bottle when opened. Nice brown thinnish head which disappears quickly. Obviously the first whiff of the glass yeild smoke, bourbon and wood. The bourbon is definitely there but in the background. Burnt , chewy & meaty with tobacco  Caramel and some cola. And the bourbon  is restrained. Potent, delicious but in no way was it a brain rattler

Very tasty although I thought a bit harsh. I saved the rest of the four pack for a year or so of aging. Intense black with a tan head. Oak, Bourbon, vanilla, roast malt, booze in the aroma and flavor. The 2112 version comes in at 15% and you get every bit of it. Can’t want until next year.

12 ounce bottle. 2012 vintage. My 217th rating, so i thought it should be something special!? Opague brown, black color with a very short-lived tan head. Big oaky roasted malt aroma. Sweet toffeeish treacle/molasses flavor. very complex with hints of vanilla, bourbon, prunes, figs, bittersweet chocolate and charred oak. Silky and smooth going down, but the warming alcohol appears once you swallow it. Outstanding now, I think this will get better with age.

Fantastic bourbon aged stout. Booze flavor is strong but not overpowering. Perfect compliment to the wonderful typical stout characteristics; subtle chocolate, coffee, and bitter notes, all of which are blended and balanced flawlessly. A bit pricey and hard to find, but definitely worth trying. Fantastic brew.

Pour from a 12 oz. bottle (2012).  Dark black pour, scent is bourbon and chocolate.  Syrupy mouthfeel, very smooth taste.  Delicious brew.

Bourbon aroma and dark black appearance with a strong bourbon taste and smooth mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

My 200th rating thought I would have something special. 

2012 in 12oz bottle. Aromatics start hard with bourbon and vanilla. Straight carmelly, boozy, and fruity. Lots of dark fruiting this. Appearance is deep dark black. When swirled you can see that it is actually a deep dark brown, like molasses. Very little head. Taste is complex. Starts with dark fruit, specifically raisins and dates. Then it grows sweeter into brown sugar and caramel. Lingering with a slight bitterness. Palates deep and viscous. It gives quite a mouthfeel, very pleasant. Overall, I can’t wait to age this and try the coffee and cherry soon!

11/08/12 one of the last batches of 2012. bottle to oversized snifter. the aroma is very similar to last years. Nice amount of sweetness with out all the flame from the bourbon. there are notes of vanilla, oak, bourbon, chocolate, i dont get any roast. the appearance is amazing as always, its black as night and when poured properly makes about a half finger of chocolate milk, very vibrant head. the taste is sweet semi bitter chocolate, with hints of dark fruit. the bitter to sweet ratio is off as expected but its worth it. this years batch is sweeter than last years which i thought was absolutely perfect. this reminds me of all the Kuhnhenn BB4D’s I’ve ever drank. the palate is nice and chewy, very thick with a little heat at the end that drys the palate and leaves one longing for another sip. Overall, this pretty much rocks. its great for the price and wonderful for the cellar. one of the only was to get me to give ab/inbev money.

What a great brew, had the 2011 on draught. Dark as midnight with a small creamy head that left some lacing. Huge nose of smoke and caramel. Great taste with a good hint of alcohol. Didn’t feel as heavy to me as I thought it would. What a treat.

This poured a darker brown color with a tan head.  Aroma was lighter fruitier BCS, still lgiht bourbon notes, but not in the face, and some dark chocolate.  Flavor was much the samel, most stout character and less barrel, which seems to be the same difference fomr year to year anyways,
Earlier Rating: 5/11/2008 Total Score: 4
Pours a dark black with a nice tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, licorice, alcohol and some espresso. Taste is very sticky sweet dark chocolate with a nice coffee finish with the alcohol present the whole time.

2012 12oz from a 4-pack from Bacchus liquor Kalamazoo. Pitch black thick pour into snifter. Had a brown sheen reminiscent of a dark stained mahogany. Head was very dense and dark brown, inch high at first and settled to an eighth inch within a minute. Sweet and malty scent-foremost aroma of brown sugar, perhaps some molasses and complex fruits/berries like date, raisins and currants as well (a little bourbon-like nose tingle too). Thick, syrupy mouth feel, very little carbonation. Bitterness at first, strong , almost spicy flavors/feelings of bourbon with oak, vanilla and strong cherry or raisin just slightly. Strong smoky vanilla and bourbon finish that did not leave my mouth very dry. Can’t wait to try one of this vintage cellared.
