Heavy notes of Bourbon and vanilla.  Pours pitch black with a heavy mouth feel, lots of alcohol.  Very nice sipping beer, like to see how it ages
Pours pitch black.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, chocolate.  Taste is bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits.  Palate is thick but a little hot.  Very enjoyable.

Fairly hard poured from a 2012 vintage 12 oz. bottle into a 9 oz. Perception rocks glass.

Pours an opaque black with a thin fizzy light brown head which quickly dissipates. The nose is dominated by big bourbon booziness and heavy oak barrel with lighter accents of dark fruit. Opens with a blast of bourbon and oak joined by vanilla, raisins, plum and notes of black cherry. Finishes with strong bourbon booziness and more vanilla and oak. Full bodied, low carbonation, smooth and at times syrupy mouthfeel. This beer is a bruiser and delivers exactly as advertised: a big tasty imperial stout that packs an unmatched bourbon punch.
Absolutely fantastic.                                                 My only concern is that I can't find anymore of it.

Got bottle in a trade with Adam Jackson. 2011 vintage. 14.5 % ABV on label. What can I say about this brew that hasn’t already been said??  Pitch black head with a thin beige head in a snifter.  Aromas of bourbon, vanilla oak, chocolate malt and toffee. Complex flavors intermingle with each other. Smooth flavors of bourbon up front followed by roasted malts, dark fruits, licorice. Slightly more harsh flavors of whiskey booze in the finish. BUT not in a bad way. Mouthfeel is on the thick side and has malt and bourbon that linger for a good while. The ABV makes itself known with lots of warming alcohol on the way down your throat. This is a sipper without question… and every sip is absolutely amazing.
Shared from a 12 oz bottle at home.  Pours a viscous dark, dark, dark with a tan head,  Aromaof raisins and vanilla.  Flavors of figs, dates, vanilla and oak -- masks the high alcohol. Wow!

The pour is motor oil black with a thick mocha head that leaves lacing. The aroma is dominated by the sweet bourbon smell but it certainly shows it’s potency. The taste, while very thick in body, uses evert drop as a flavor explosion. The bourbon is prevelant throughout as it starts off sweet & winds up finishing rather bitter. This is an experience for true beer lovers!  Rich, powerful, & very impressive!
Arôme d’alcool, de bourbon et de fruits noirs. Goût assez différent, davantage sur la vanille et le café. Excellent équilibre, considérant l’imposant % d’alcool. Une bière de catégorie supérieure!

12oz 2012 bottle. 1/4 inch brown head. Low carbonation, deep dark color that rings of Bourbon and sweet dark chocolates. Overall very drinkable. Only draw back is cost but rest assured I will purchase this brew again.

On tap poured black with aroma of bourbon, molasses and dark fruits. Taste is bourbon up front followed by vanilla, dark fruits, molasses and some smoke. Thick smooth body. Very good beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012. Pretty flat, almost no carbonation at all, overly alcoholic tasting, even for a 15%. Not a bad taste right away, but way too sticky sweet

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle. 2012.  Pours black with a minimal brown head.  Aroma of bourbon, dark fruit, chocolate, smoke, and alcohol.  Taste is bourbon, dark fruit, vanilla, chocolate, caramel, and smoke.  Rich and warming. Amazing!

2011 bottle. Pours pitch black with no head. The aroma is deep chocolate and bourbon. The palatte is smooth and silky with a silky mouthfeel. The taste is lovely with deep chocolate and espresso with a touch of smoke. This is just a wonderful beer.
2012 bottle. Viscous black pour.  Slight brown head. No lacing. Aroma is chocolate.  Taste is chocolate,  coffee,  toffee,  vanilla,  oak. Nice bourbon finish that lingers.

First proper review on ratebeer. 12 oz bottle dated 9/17/12 into Duvel tulip, live tasting.

Pours solid pitch black, with no light showing through at the edges, a very, very thin tan colored head pops up for a moment before dissipating. Lacing is non-existent. 

Aroma is of coffee, dark fruits, raisins, bourbon, figs... 

Taste dives into bourbon, dates, vanilla, oak, chocolate, raisins, coffee and dark cherries appear on the finish as a mild bitterness that concludes with a bitter chocolate flavor...

Mouthfeel is oily, and Bourbon County goes down smooth, with just the slightest hint of alcohol.. Exceptionally easy to drink given the alcohol content.

Overall, not even close to a 15% beer, Bourbon county drinks fantastically given how "young" this stout is, I cannot wait to see how it evolves and opens up. Fantastic beer and absolutely worth seeking out.

It’s been a few years since I’ve treated myself to a Bourbon County, and apparently this is a special year-- 15% abv and all (ouch).

Holy cow the taste though.  It’s like chocolate wrapped up in leather wrapped up in tobacco leaves buried under some musty black soil for a few months (though apparently they used bourbon barrels. . . ).

Totally worth it for the taste, and I’ll cellar a couple accordingly.

But, in fairness, the drinkability is almost totally lacking; this is like 200 proof motor oil.  Gourmet, top of the notch, 10W-5 stars 200 proof motor oil.

12 ounce bottle. This was a thoroughly enjoyable beer that didn’t taste at all like 15% abv and still had copious amounts of coffee, malts, cocoa and coffee beans. Plus, it didn’t go overboard with the bourbon flavor. It’s pitch black, motoroil-heavy bodied, and puts off a welcoming, roasted wood and slightly sweet aroma. All around a solid beer and one of the best I’ve had in the no man’s land that is >12%abv  country. This is an excellent beer to settle in with during or after a big meal. The slightly sweet, malted, roasted flavors would pair nicely with some turkey and stuffing, and it tastes appropriate as a goodbye to fall and a hello to winter. In other words, I recommend a bottle of this for Thanksgiving.

Fobab. Seemed to me that is was a bit of a lighter side of bcs.  Pours a thick dark black with a fine head. The flavor is the usual bcs with more sweetness and with less flavors from the bourbon barrels. Smooth.
Earlier Rating: 5/22/2008 Total Score: 4.4
12 oz bottle, finally! Wow this is a fine ass beer... Impressively done, silky smooth, tasty, gentle, rich and so on so on. Pours like motor oil, dark black with a slight head the comes well after the pour and dissipates quickly, minimal lacing. Aroma of warm alcohol/bourbon, oak, dark chocolate, malts and just a touch of vanilla. Thick silky taste with oak, molasses, caramel, alcohol and roasted malts. Lovely brew, bourbon doesn’t dominate, but just adds background complexity to a beer that would have been excellent anyway. Loved it! Go Cubbies!

Rating 400, making it a bit special with some brand new 2012 bourbon county stout, bottled 11/08/12. No surprise here but this mug is boozy. Bourbon for days, years perhaps. Vanilla toffee and caramel all back it up. Smells like a good ass beer. There is some raisins out chere as well. Chocolate and wood round out the smells. This is one black beer. No head slight ring. Black as the chiefs are bad. Oooohhhh. Sticky bourbon with chocolate, vanilla and caramel rolling through when the booze ducks down.  This really is a momentous beer. Obviously Ill stick on what I have left but fresh is a great experience.

2012 bottle poured into a snifter.  slight head that dissipates immediately. Pitch black, looks like motor oil.  This beer coats the glass when you swirl it around.  The aroma is dark chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, dark fruit, a little bit of booze.  The taste is amazing.  Flourless chocolate cake spiked with bourbon.  It’s big and rich, but very smooth. It hides the 15% very well. World class beer

Baudonia version: Definitely one of the more unique BCBS variations out there. It has more of a fruitiness. Actually since the barrels are closer to the ground it is a higher gravity pulling on the beer as it ages.


Earlier Rating: 2/21/2011 Total Score: 4.2
2009 vintage, ive had it once before, gonna review it now. 12 oz twist off (dumb).

Pours a thick black with only the slightest bit of ruby and a dark tan head that is really loud and fizzy and dissipates pretty quickly.

Smell is thick with bourbon, tons of woody oak scent along with some bourbon/vanilla notes makes up a bulk of the scent. There is also sweet smelling chocolate, caramel, roasted malt and thick alcohol.

The flavor is intense at the moment, it could use some calming down, it has a huge malt sweetness, tons of bourbon flavor, some dark fruits, just a large bundle of barrel aged maltiness.

The mouthfeel is very thick and the alcohol burns nicely.

It is a sipper, it will only get better with age, I also have an 08 cellaring, it will make a nice vertical once they keep coming, it is a great but hot beer when it is fresher though.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-12-2010 22:34:34
Draught.  Pitch black with faint head.  Aroma is chocolate and bourbon.  Taste is boubon over bourbon. This beer pulls no punches.  Too hot for now, needs to be cellared to calm down.
I have drunk this beer several times, from different years. The 2008 is my favorite. It never ceases to amaze me. It’s the closest to a perfect beer I’ve tried.

2011 vintage at 14.5 ABV. Wow. I was a little unsure as to how I’d find this, with the ratings mentioning a heavy bourbon flavour, but it’s simply amazing. Pours a pitch black, very thick, like oil, has a very small, deep brown head which almost instantly dissipates, there are plenty of alcohol legs. Smell is obviously quite a lot of bourbon with chocolate and roasted malt notes, some alcohol is also present. Simply amazing tasting beer, there is a strong bourbon taste but it’s not overwhelming, it’s well balanced but very noticable. There’s also a big dark chocolate taste which coats your mouth, there is a strong roasted malt flavour too. It is quite sweet all ofver the tongue. Has a beautiful bourbon finish with some alcohol burn as it goes down, really warms your chest. Very thick and oily yet smooth, a beautiful mouthfeel.

Simply stunning.

2012 vintage. Pours jet black with zero head. Great aroma with notes of toffee, vanilla, and bourbon. Silky smooth with tons of bourbon almost over-powering the taste. Each taste lingers and changes with time. Worthy of the hype and effort to locate.

Pours pitch black with small head that dies quickly; no lacing.  Aroma is mega-super-duper - I could literally smell this about half a foot away after I poured it.  Up close, it’s vanilla, bourbon, the best dark chocolate aroma I have ever encountered, licorice, booze, and maybe even a bit of fruit.  Taste: @*#&!  This is ... WOW!  *@&#!  I do not even know how to describe right now.  Let me try now that I have settled down.  Bourbon, dark chocolate, vanilla, booze, more bourbon, more dark chocolate.  Greatest mouthfeel ever - not thin at all, but not thick - just silky and enveloping.  Flavor lingers for ... I feel like I am going to taste this another 20 years.  Demands to be savored slowly, and good thing, because that ABV sure is high.  &*@#!  This is the most flavorful beer I have ever had, and everything works together so well.  Founders Breakfast Stout was great, yeah, but this...this is just in another dimension.

9/20/12 bottle. S: Delicious, incredibly enticing - huge caramel, chocolate and bourbon.  Oak, vanilla, slight coconut and light coffee.  A: Pours a dark dark brown and sits a midnight, completely opaque midnight black.  The head fizzes away - a very unattractive quality and unique to the bourbon counties as far as I can tell.  T: Very big, boozy, and brash.  All the flavors selfishly assert themselves - no layers.  Mixture of caramel, bourbon, and chocolate.  The nuances of the bourbon are lost.  However, still tastes very good.  P: Big, but not nearly as big as expected - active, noticeable carbonation. Smooth and slightly chewy. O: A very very good beer that I am confident needs age to mellow out.

10.	Vintage 2012 (I always try one fresh) 12oz bottle to Duvel tulip, Thanks Luke! Pours ink black, black hole black ,with a half inch brown sugar head which dissipates quickly. Smells like someone poured a hefty amount of Woodford into my mocha! Tastes very smooth, the alcohol is well masked with only the slightest discernible burn on the back end. Flavor profile is bourbon, vanilla bean, worn leather, bourbon, and also bourbon. The vanilla borderlines on being cloying for me. Super smooth mouth feel and long lingering complexity of tastes, deep cherry + robust cigar wrapper. Overall, this beer is awesome, but I feel like there is just one slight thing holding this back from being totally epic and I cannot put my finger on it. Perhaps this review is being skewed by my first Speedway Stout tasting which was near perfection. Again, still love this brew!
I absolutely love this beer.  I’m really looking forward to the Coffee Stout they are releasing on Black Friday this year.

2012 - a bit hot but still pretty sweet, smooth an rich
2006 - very mellow, low carbonation, considerably diff than fresh. big chocolate, moderate roast without bitterness, sweet bourbon

Quite possibly the best beer I’ve ever had.

A - Dark with minimal head.  Not fizzy by any means.  Pours extremely thick.

S - Chocolate & Bourbon.

T - Bourbon, bourbon, and bourbon.   Did I mention it has a strong hint of bourbon?

M - Carbonated perfectly. Not much head, but great mouthfeel all the same.

O - Quite possibly the best beer I’ve ever had.  Its hard to imagine anything better.  Maybe 20% for all 5’s?

Pours a thin but thick black with a slowly rising head that eventually makes itself into a 1 finger size before disappearing quickly. Aromas of booze, alcohol, paint thinner. Taste is not as bad as the aroma and not as sweet as I thought it was going to be. Pretty easy drinking for 15%. A touch hot, but not as hot as dogfish head olde school @ 15%. Laid back, easy sipping (or pounding in my case) beer. Fuck it, I like it. Not as good as the hype but pretty decent none the less. Fuck you. 



RE-RATE
This is just macro swill garbage juice for dorks.

Purchased at the Greeks in Narberth.  Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a brandy snifter.  Pours very dark brown with little head and zero lacing.  An oily sheen is present on top of the liquid.  Massive nose of coconut, alcohol, cloves, molasses and yes, bourbon.  Mouthfeel is very very slick and very very carbonated.  Even after sitting it’s too carbonated.  Taste is alcohol, booze, EtOH, hot, bourbon, sweet, candy, lead and some fishyness.  Meh, this was OK fresh.  I got three more and I’m setting them downstairs to cool off.  Bourbon bombs aren’t my thing but hopefully this will mellow over time.

Pours jet black with a teeny tiny brown head even with a relatively aggressive pour. Aroma of heavy bourbon and more vanilla than I have smelled in a barrel aged before. Small bit of roasted grain. Bourbon flavor explodes on the palate up front even more than I expected. Lasting vanilla & cocoa after swallowing that is pretty intense. As it fades there is an additional punch of chocolate and hint of espresso out of nowhere. Very complex. Heavy on the palate, very warming. Just the right level of sweetness. Want more...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle dated 9/13/2012 pours and opaque black with no head or lacing.  Stong aroma is full of licorice, dark chocolate, cloves, and dark fruit. Flavor is alcoholic with vanilla, coffee, and toffee. Tastes sweet with some alcohol burn in the finish. Full body, creamy.slick mouthfeel, and average carbonation.  An incredible big beer, which is one of the most memorable I’ve ever tried.

Original review for 2012 bottling, 2013 updates in parentheses. Opaque black, zero head. With some swirling, I see the beer clinging to the glass. Aroma has dark chocolate, licorice, clove, over-ripe banana - very rich. No alcohol surprisingly. (Update: 2013 release is much more alcohol-forward) The alcohol is definitely present in the flavor however, along with toffee, coffee, dash of vanilla. Kind of sweet with an alcohol burn.  Pretty heavy body, almost syrupy but not so much to put me off. Quite different from the brew I remember from 4 years ago but a worthy entry.

12 oz bottle, 2012 vintage.  Pours dark black, with a very thin tan head.  Nose is molasses, vanilla, bourbon, chocolate.  Taste is vanilla, dark fruit, raisins, vanilla, chocolate.  Very sweet and complex, with full mouthfeel and low carbonation.  ABV is well-masked; a single bottle kicked my butt.  Every bit as good as people say it is.

Very strong hints of bourbon absolutely envelope your palate. Pours flat with no head. Palate is very strong, but not as many different flavors as expected. Deep chocolate brown in color. Aroma is pure bourbon, 2012 bottle. Definitely one of my favorites.

12 oz bottle - Pours creamy jet black, thin tan head, diminishing, little bubbly lacing. Huge strong aromas of molasses, vanilla, warm oak, bourbon, charcoal, smoke, and bitter chocolate. Esters with bananas start to come through as it warms. Really complex.  Round bourbon notes. Taste is creamy vanilla, dark fruit, figs, plums, raisins, going to a warming maple vanilla, finishing with bitter chocolate notes and a looooooonnnnnggggg end. Keeps on giving.  Awesome. Winter warmer. Page turner.

Finally snagged one of these in MD!  2012 bottle poured into snifter glass.  Very dark black with thinnest of tan heads.  Aroma of bourbon alcohol, dark chocolate and smoke.  Taste adds sweetness, hints of dark fruit & vanilla,  ending with coffee bitterness.  Rich creamy body as I take sips, alcohol fumes really hit the nose.  Warming alcohol and hop burn aftertaste.  Wow what a beer, glad I grabbed this as the bottle store I went to only had 2 cases.  A 4 pack where I will have 1 every year.  Look forward to it!

Pours a deep black color with a thin brown head. The flow is like syrup. Nose of bourbon, smoked malts, caramel, chocolate. Very sweet flavor with a bit of alcohol burn. Full bodied and exceptionally creamy. I bought a bottle to age for a bit so I’ll reassess my rating at that time.

Bottle, 2011 vintage, from Justin Thanks a lot for this one!
Pours black with almost no head.
Aroma has bourbon, chocolate, raisins, alcohol fumes.
Taste is luxurious. Velvety chocolate, bourbon, dark fruit, especially plum and cherries, some other sweet notes, perhaps raisins as well. A small warming alcohol sensation at the end. Very complex. The only downside with this imperial stout is the after taste - it’s not there at all.
Full bodied, low carbonation. Mouth feel is thick. 

2012 vintage: As above but with a lot of vanilla in aroma and more prominent alcohol in taste. Lively carbonation and a bitter, smooth after taste.

Bottle 2012 poured into a tulip glass. Pitch black with a small tan head. Nose is bourbon, smokey, burnt caramel. Taste is similar, rich and creamy with a very noticeable alcohol burn. One of these goes a long way. The bourbon is a little strong for me...a great barrel aged stout though. This is a great example of the style.

Bottle. Wow. I love this. I think this is better than KBS. Rich thick bourbon stout. Awesome. Creamy. 

Also had it a couple of times on draft at raleigh rare beer fest.  didnt notice too much of a difference.
---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, 2012 vintage. Pours opaque brown black with a small brown head, no lacing. Aroma is Bourbon, coffee, dark roasted malt, dark chocolate, vanilla. Flavor is the same, strong bourbon, medium sweet, strong alcohol warming, light coffee bitterness. Full bodied. Unfortunately for me the very strong bourbon overwhelms the traditional stout characteristics. A pretty good, not great imperial stout. R rate, same vintage. Upped the score a couple of tenths.

Had the 2012 variety. Fresh from bottle. I bought this case as a blind buy, and couldn’t be happier with the purchase. Not unlike Avery’s Uncle Jacobs or Mephistopheles, this is a sweet and malty beer. It also has a great overall balance of the malt and bourbon flavors. This would go on my "must try" list for any beer aficionado.

Pours black with big brown head.... Super strong alchol aroma, with distinctive milk chocolate aroma almost taking over...    Taste is crazy smooth for the alc.percentage..  coffe, chocolate taste... Would buy again for sure!

A delicious stout, and among the very best high-ABV beers of any kind that I’ve had.  It pours milk-chocolate brown with a trace of a peach-colored head, and the aroma is bitter chocolate, coffee, and a HUGE presence of bourbon.  The flavor is bourbon through and through, and other tones, but not a lot of heat.  That 15% ABV is buried behind an avalanche of  chocolate, molasses, candied fruit, black walnuts, and some hoppy burn.  I absolutely loved this beer and I’d buy it again if AB would make it available more readily in my area.

Re-rate 2/2/13.  2012 bottle poured into snifter.  Pours pitch black with very little head.  Aroma is rich sweet bourbon mostly with hints of light roast, tobacco, raisins, and chocolate.  Bourbon overpowers a bit in the taste too but not too bad.  Still get some raisins and tobacco.  Finish has almost no alcohol burn with a slight booziness.  Medium body, silky smooth mouthfeel.  A really good bourbon stout but not my favorite.  I prefer when the bourbon is a bit more subtle.  Re-rate 3/6/13 - Doing a side-by-side tasting of a 2008 bottle with a 2012 bottle with John.  2008 bottle from trade with Crajun, Thanks!  2008 bottle pours pitch black with no head.  Aroma is one of the best I’ve smelled.  Bourbon is much more subtle in the 2008 than the 2012.  Getting tons of tobacco and chocolate in the 2008 which I absolutely love.  Taste also has an amazing balance of tobacco, chocolate, and bourbon.  Mouthfeel on the 2008 is almost perfect too, would like just a touch more carbonation but it’s silky smooth, sticky, thick and chewy.  Having this aged version has really changed my opinion of this beer.  One of the best I’ve had now.  I will definitely lay down the rest of my 2012’s in the hopes that the difference in taste is just from aging and not a recipe change.  My new rating of this beer is based on the 2008 version.  Re-rate 9/18/14 - 2009 bomber thanks to Tim.  Delicious and smooth.  Don’t have much to add except that I could drink this all day.  This beer seems to peak and about 4-5 years for me.  Re-rate 12/12/14 - Love the 2014 bottle fresh.  Just drank it side by side with 12 & 13 and I was surprised I like the 2014 best.  Somehow less bourbon than the others and it was smoother.
Great beer, as advertised.  It’s definitely unique and hides the 15% well.  A+
Wow.  So much flavor here.  Tons of bourbon but not alot of heat.  Cant believe this is 15% ABV.  Lots of sweet to balance it out.  It doesn’t get any better than this.

Jet black, small faint coffee coloured head. Where do you start with the aroma? Loads of chocolate, raisin, hazelnut, expresso, dark fruits, plummy, licorice, vanilla and covered in oakey bourbon notes. Awesome! Mouthfeel is slick, a little oily. Taste is all the above. The warming alcohol is welcoming and comforting. Bourbon comes through massively with all the vanilla, coffee and chocolate all lingering around my mouth. I’ve been wanting to try this for 4-5 years and it hasn’t let me down. The best stout I think I’ll ever have the fortune of trying!

Bourbon forward nose, tons of vanilla, molasses and some booze.  Taste is Bourbon forward with chocolate, molasses, figs some dark fruits on the back and lots of oaky vanilla.  Smooth and viscous.  An excellent booze forward example of the style.

It’s amazing this beer - the availability, the continuing quality and the easy drinking.  

Yeah, it’s not super rare - but, it deserves it’s status.     Bourbon, Blackness.  Delish.

Bottle, 2012

Dark brown with very slight tan head.  Aroma is intense bourbon wood.  Taste follows suit, bourbon, vanilla, oak, perfectly aged.

2008 vintage. Wow. Pours midnight black with a rich, brown head. Smells like the most incredible adult candy; bourbon, chewy toffee, salted caramel, smooth chocolate. Wow again. The taste is unreal. Raisin, dark chocolate, bakers chocolate, smooth bourbon, . One of the best beers I’ve ever had. Hopefully will get it again.
Had to delete my rating from 2012 and redo it. Fantastic. Chocolate bourbon and perfection for the style
This tastes like tar with alcohol in it.  Very thick and not a fan of the taste. I would not recomend this however love strong beer and cask beer.

2012 bottle. Pours deep black with a brown head. Aroma is intensely rich bourbon whiskey, vanilla & oak. Incredibly complex stuff. The first thing you notice is the bourbon flavor, but its not so intense that it takes everything else over. Then there is some chocolaty malts, little bit of vanilla, lots of oak barrel flavor and some smokiness, and a little alcohol. Super dark and roasty stuff. At 15% its pretty ridiculous how easy it is to drink and smooth it is. The texture is thick and creamy. This is the best stout I have had so far, and one of the best beers.

bottle shared with friends. thanks to tom10101 and david paquet. drank 2009 vintage. dark brown pour with a decent beige head, little retention. sweet bourbon, dark roastiness, soy, pepper, belgiumness (!). full body, soft carbonation, superb bitter coffee, peppery, boozy finish. abv well hidden too. very rich and yummy.

Pours jet black with a half inch of light brown head. Great aroma of dark fruit caramel, dark malts, vanilla, bourbon, and a little boozy heat. Nice sweet flavors, lots of vanilla and carmalized sugars, dark fruit, bitter dark chocolate,  and bourbon followed up with some heat. Super creamy, very smooth, light carbonation, excellent feel. My first time with this off the self, so good.

2012 bottle. Pours a viscous motor oil black color with no head. Just coats the side of the glass with alcohol legs. Very little lacing. Smells of bourbon, oak, vanilla, dark chocolate, some coffee, like figs or raisins, maybe some soy sauce. Amazing aroma. Taste starts with lots of oak, rum soaked raisins, chocolate, some coffee, bourbon. Then turns a little bitter from the hop presence I imagine as well as more chocolate, dark fruits, and booze. Do get somewhat of a soy sauce taste at this point. Really smooths out at the end. More of the same flavors, but the creamy finish neutralizes the bourbon/booze presence. The booze is definitely there, but it blends really well with the other complex flavors. As it warms, the booze mellows out and you are left with a pleasant warming sensation. The finish makes it. Full body and very little carbonation. Oily and slick texture, but not sticky which is good for such a high alcohol beer. Very impressive imperial stout that is drinkable at 15% abv. Meets the hype in my opinion.

Pours a viscous black liquid. A mocha head that fizzes away instantly. Look like black motoroil! Aroma is intense, bourbon, vanilla, wood, alcohol, coffee, sweet. Taste is very sweet, alcohol, wood, bourbon, vanilla, some classic roasty coffee and chocolate. A nice stout but they could tune down the alcohol a bit although it was very well masked for a 15% beer! Nicely done!

Bottles [2009,2011,2012]
Pours black (very dark brown) with no head. Aroma is of chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, bourbon. (+vegetal note in 2011 (I guess I was eating celery at that moment)). Taste is of chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, booze, bourbon, warming alcohol. Very complex. Palate: Full bodied. Overall: Those vintages were pretty similar to me, only very faint differences. One thing is sure, this beer is pretty good, and there is alot of bourbon involved.  [2009: 3/9/10/4/18] [2011:3/8/10/4/18] [2012: 4/9/9/4/17]

Pure black with short lived tan head. Aroma is bourbon and chocolate. Taste is complex, very chocolatey at first with some roasted coffee. Alcohol burn at end, as it warms more flavours emerge. Hints of smoke, bourbon, and dark fruit. Alcohol gets more pronounced as it warms. Thick, sticky, creamy beer. Very, very good.

Bottled 9/20/2012



A: Pitch back body with only a thin tan ring on the pour, no ring after the pour.



S: The nose is strong of bourbon barrel aromas. Coconut is the most prominent with vanilla, oak and bourbon backing it, bourbon and oak outweigh the vanilla though.



T: This is an intense been chalk full of flavor. Dark chocolate and coconut are very strong in this with light oak throughout and a prominent bourbon and oak finish.



M: This is the thickest beer I’ve ever had, syrupy and silky, very good.



O: This is a good BBA imperial stout, but I think KBS and Parabola are better. This is definitely worth trying though and the $25 4 pack is worth the price.
Ratings: Ar: 7, Ap: 4, Ta: 8, Pa: 5, Ov: 16


Cellar Review: Bottled September 20, 2012 (9 months old)

Appearance: Pitch black body with no head despite a hard pour, only a thin tan ring.

Aroma: The aroma is a complex medley of coconut, sweet cocoa, caramel and bourbon. The aroma is a lot more complex and balanced than I remember it being fresh.

Taste: There’s a lot of sweet syrupy chocolate that makes itself known right away on the intro, this is backed with sweet and syrupy caramel and a prominent dose of roasted malts. Overlying this sweet malt base is a mild bourbon presence that sticks through to the finish with the oak to provide light tannins with alcohol noticeable on the finish that comes off a bit spicy.

Palate: Thick and syrupy, very little carbonation.

Overall: Very few beers that I’ve aged have actually gotten better, Bourbon County Stout is one of them. This beer was a bourbon bomb fresh and 9 months later it has a layered complexity to it that makes me want to buy it again when it is released this year. Well done.

Rating: Ap: 4, Ar: 8, Ta: 9, Pa: 5, Ov: 16


Bottled September 11, 2014 (3 months old).

Glass: Firestone Walker Reserve Glass.

Appearance: Pitch black with a creamy and dense brown head. More head than in previous years.

Aroma: Chocolate, raisin, cherry, bourbon, oak, vanilla, and a hint of roast. Really nice here.

Taste: Much like the aroma, big and chocolatey with a fruity backing. Bourbon is noted on the finish with lingering oak and a dash of smoke. This is complex and balanced.

Palate: Thick and creamy, very nice.

Overall: A really well done BBA stout again and again. Well worth getting a bottle or 4 of and enjoying as a celebration or sharing with friends. This is an excellent sipper.

Bottle - 2012 Vintage poured a deep pitch black with a barely recognizable mocha head and notable lacing.  Initial aroma is huge on bourbon followed by hints of bakers chocolate and coffee beans.  Taste also begins with bourbon flavor before several additional layers reveal themselves including vanilla, roasted malt, and a hint of coffee.  Nice creamy mouthfeel and slight booziness on the finish.  Wonderful sippin imperial stout with brilliant flavors and a well hidden ABV.

aroma..oak, maple wood plenty of malts and bourbon not necessarily in that order..appearance..black with slight edge of brown and red with disappearing head almost no lacing..taste improves as it warms at first tastes like sweet stout/porter boilermaker with a heavy shot of bourbon oak maple and vanilla flavors come out as it warms.. oily and sticky on the palate with a lingering vanilla bourbon finish with moderate alcohol burn..good but too heavy on the bourbon flavors to me and way overpriced and too rare for my taste however this is an accurate rating if you like  heavy bourbon and wood flavors you may love this

14-10-2012 Bottle (12 oz). Vintage 2009 and 2011 tasted back to back. Shared by David, huge thanks! Pours black with almost no head. Some lacing when stirring the glass. Aroma is very complex with bourbon, caramel, wood, vanilla, dark fruits and hints of smoke. Taste is about the same with a slight peppery finish in the 2011 vintage. The 2011 vintage is more harsh than the 2009 which had the time to mellow. Full budy. Damn rich beer. A perfect example of a bourbon barrel aged Imperial Stout.  Warning: I was beginning to be quite tired when we opened this one so this rating may change a lot when I’ll crack another bottle of this. Hope it will be sooner than later! 9-3-9-4-17 = 4.2

On tap @ Lion’s Pride (Brunswick). + 1 for the appearance because of a medium fully lasting beige head. and +1 for the overall because the carbonation was pinpoint and the beer was a little more flavorul that what I remembered. 9-4-9-4-18

EDIT: Bottle (22 oz). ’09 vintage, thanks to David for this bottle. Black with a small ring of beige foam and light lacing. Aroma is super fudgy with a tons of vanilla along roasted malt, light fruitiness and wood. Taste is also super fudgy with roasted malt, caramel, vanilla, wood and light fruitiness. Full bodied. Moderate carbonation. Creamier mouthfeel than other BCBS I’ve tried (including on tap). Thick. Light alcohol warming despite the fact that the alcohol is well hidden. Good balance. Really complex and so much fudge. Probably my favorite vintage in bottle so far. 4-9-4-9-17 = 4.3

It's everything you've heard it to be and even more. Poured a pitch black with literally no head. Bourbon aroma dominates this gem. No doubt the king of bourbon barrel aged stouts. The only negative I can come up with on this legendary beer is that it's sweeter than any other stout I've had. By no means should this stop you from indulging into this fine beer. A legend at it's worst and a king at it's best. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wonderful smell of bourbon as soon as the bottle is opened.  This is a sipping beer, sit back and enjoy slowly.  Beats all other bourbon barrel ages beers.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pitch black, opaque color, small light brown head. Smell dark malts, roasted malts, slight hint of burned malts, wood, bourbon, light to medium sweetness but not bothering at all. Great aroma! Taste dark malts, roastyness, wood, bourbon again strongly, light to moderately sweet, some liquorice, slightly alcohol. Superb taste, absolutely love it! Medium oily to syrupy texture, full body, medium carbo. Superb!
Bottle 2008. Given as a thank you from the guys at Halftime in Poughkeepsie.  Very, very nice.  pours with no head, pitch black.  Flavor, palate.  Great brew

draft. top hops. amazing dark color with a beautiful brown head. aroma is incredibly complex with oak, chocolate, and alcohol. flavor is also overwhelming and delicious. nicely hopped and layers and layers of vanilla, chocolates and malt.

This is definitely one of the best. A little boozy in the palate, aroma, but not in a bad way. But still the only knock on a perfect score!

Review #100

2008 Vintage. 12 oz. bottle poured into a Founders snifter. 

A: Pours a jet black, slightly viscous with quick half finger dark caramel head that quickly dissipates into nothing leaving some slight popping bubbles. 

S: I’m picking up the bourbon right away and it’s still fairly strong for being almost 3 years years old. This makes me happy. I’m picking up some light oak notes, almost like wet wood chips, with very faint hint of smoke. 

T: From first sip there is a multitude flavors. It’s a roller coaster of flavor enjoyment. The opening of this brew is a slight kick of bourbon with a charred oak smokeyness, like the embers of a campfire. It’s smoothes out in the middle to a very light vanilla and finishes with an almost roasted coffee malt. As the beer warms the heat from the alcohol becomes more pronounced. 

M: Slightly syrupy on the mouth, heavy bodied with little carbonation. The brew coats the palate leaving an oaky and light dark chocolate mix. Minutes after a sip the taste still clings to the tongue. 

O: Wow. I saved this for my 100th review and I’m glad I did. I’m so glad the bourbon held up  and I’m glad there was still a whirlwind of flavor after the last 3 years. This is definitely a sipping beer, no questions asked, and  A must for any fan of BA stouts.  

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-01-2011

Much different than last years batch. Not too hot fresh, 15% alcohol is very well masked. Color is dark, minimal head, nice lacing. Texture is thick, flavour is outstanding, hints of chocolate some coffers flavour from the malt, dark fruit, bitter and sweet delicious bourbon. Can’t wait to see how this tastes in a year.

’12 vintage.  Draft.  Pours espresso brown with no head.  Rich sweet aroma.  A little thinner than previous years perhaps but still nice and syrupy.  Big barrel fwd character with sweetness vanilla, chocolate, and light roasty malts. Pretty hot but  Improves dramatically as it warms to room temp.

2012 version on tap at Twenty Tap. Pitch black pour with rich dark brown head. Aroma is of bourbon and sweet molasses. Taste is heavy bourbon right now but as you progress through the drink you get the oak, molasses, and caramel sweetness. Maybe some vanilla as well. Velvety smooth. The alcohol is noticeable as there is a considerable warming down my throat and into my belly. Rich and complex. Incredible beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 vintage: Pours black as night with no head. Strong aroma of black cherry, vanilla and alcohol. You could get a pretty good buzz just from the fumes. Thick, coating mouthfeel. Alcohol warming sensation, but not in a bad way. Taste matches the aroma, black cherry, dark fruit, vanilla and alcohol. I am not a big bourbon fan, but can see why people seek this one out. Glad I was able to find a bottle. My local Detroit area store received 190 or so bottles a couple of days ago. Only 6 left when I picked it up. If you like bourbon, you must try this beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 bottle. Pours strong coffee black with the barest mocha head. Aroma of chocolate, molasses, solid bourbon and burnt dates. Bourbon forward on the taste with chocolate-covered raisins late, with a boozy warmth that spreads.  Light body for an imperial stout; very smooth. The bourbon notes complement instead of overpowering the taste. Absolutely delicious.
A wonderful beer. Alcohol, smokiness in the aroma. Sweet, oaky, smokey, bacon, tannins all present in the flavor. Thick tan head. Syrupy, thick, heavy body.

Bottle (2012). Pours an oily brown-black with a thin mocha colored head (more like a film than a head) little retention. Nose is molasses, coffee, booze and some faint licorice. Mouth is thick and oily, tingly on the tongue, with a boozy warmth throughout. Chocolate, gingersnap cookies, vanilla and bourbon, slight spice in the back of the throat, bittersweet finish. I’ve had boozier stouts, but never one this complex and rich -- the latter adjective not often would I use that word to describe a beer. Sublime. I’m going to cellar a bottle or two for a year and see what this is like after aging a bit.

Draft-pours black w/ small cardboard brown head. Good retention. Aroma of chocolate, bourbon, faint, faint licorice. Taste is roasty, bourbon, burnt marshmellow. Sweet mostly but a  taste of salt as well. Like there is a licorice flavor salt water taffy at the bottom.  Mouthfeel is full & oily. Finish is roasty, sweet bourbon w/ a touch of saltiness.  Lives up to the hype.

March 28th, 2010 - Goose Island is proud of this one, and they should be. This is an ode to the style, a culmination of science and passion and personality, packed into individual bottles. Opening the Goose Island Bourbon County Stout ’08 is like opening a bottle of pure, distilled artisanal craftsmanship. This is bottled joy, and I feel totally undeserving in having my grasping share in it, but since it somehow slipped out of its bottle and into a glass, I guess I can’t let it go to waste. The body is deep black, but shows a light brown underbelly on the edges of my “beer chalice.” The aroma lunges from the glass, controlled but powerful, and at once vegetal, deep, and spicy. Smells of cobwebs, old wood, clove, all-spice, pomegranate and a high and dry bitter edge seduce me closer to the glass. The aroma is more powerful here, and under the control of the brew I take a light sip - a medium-heavy body greets my palate, and bubbles tickle the roof my mouth. Unctuous flavors of licorice and molasses crawl out of the beer, balanced by deep, dark chocolatey malts, and militating against a heavy oak quality and a strong-armed alcoholic burn. This is a glass bristling with intensity, where all the forces, titanic behemoths, are perfectly poised and balanced against each other, quivering with strength, but none of them ever gets the upper hand to upset this beer’s adroit flavor profile. This is masterful. Hats off to Goose Island.

Rich black color; Heavy creamy body; Aroma of smoky malt, oak, vanilla, bourbon, & licorice; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, caramel, molasses/syrup, dark fruit (notably plums & prunes), raisons, and chocolate; Warm finish; Very nicely balanced & quite complex; Wow - this stuff is awesome!

Famous for a reason.  I had it the first year it came out and was immediately impressed.  The bourbon barrels are intense lending it a thick dark cherry, vanilla, and wood aroma.  Of course the coffee and chocolate are present, but they are truly subordinate in this beer.
Thanks dcschiller for the bottle.  Black pour, small tan head.  Bourbon , chocolate, molasses on the aroma, taste is similar with a little dried fruit sugar aftertaste.  Lovely brew!!
2011 bottle. pours redish black with no head. big vanilla and coconut aroma. very warm and soothing bourbon flavor

2012, 15% ABV. Pours a dark dark black with nearly no head. Aroma is sweet and strong. Sweet dark chocolate and alcohol. Flavor is bright and sweet, deep and dark. Dark chocolate, raspberries, blackcurrants and black cherries. Delicious.

Thanks to Marcus having a 2008 beer. Has a raisin dark fruit smell.
Has a slight vanilla taste good beer.

2008 12oz courtesy of Pawel. Thanks!

A: Dull lightless abyss. Very, very thin lacing. The beer definitely sinks into the glass,though.

N: Caramel and vanilla over chocolate. The bourbon is front and center here, as it should be. A very little soy sauce saltiness which is actually pleasant.

T: Bourbon and soy sauce. I know there’s no smoke in this, but it’s got that element hiding in the back end. Salted caramel and chocolate. Prunes and raisins. Very noticeable alcohol presence, still. This should probably have graduated at this point. 

M: Slick and oily. 

O: I’m going to suggest this bottle was a bit over the hill. There’s a dominant saltiness which detracts from the proceedings. This is something I have found from time to time in BCS, however, as the first time I ever got my hands on a bottle, I was disgusted by the sodium ’content’.
Bourbon barrel, caramel, dark head.  Amazing. I didn’t want the bottle to end. Better than dark Lord, imo.

Rated on October 18th 2015 - (2012 vintage; 35 cl bottle from Bradley’s Off-Licence, Cork; BBD: 08/11/2013; 1816) Poured at room tempeature into a Rochefort goblet reveals a pitch black body with one finger of quite foamy and seriously light brown head that disappears after 30 seconds leaving only a thin ring of lace and a small bubbly spot in the centre (coming from the Rochefort "R" that is chiselled in the centre of the glass). Aroma has subdued brandy notes that still carry traces of vanilla however there’s a more dominant note of rye bread, syrup and booze. No visible trace of oxydation in the aroma. Creamy texture, soft carbonation, full body and a long, warming finish that also introduces a drying sensation where the barrel notes are more pronounced. Flavour is very rich and gratifying and mostly on the sweet and boozy side. Very pleasant even after all these years.

Rated on March 18th 2013 - (2012 vintage; 35 cl bottle from Høkeren) Pours black with little, toffee head that diminishes quickly. Poor regeneration and little lace. Potent, perfumy aroma of oatmeal, vanilla and coffee. Soft carbonation, creamy texture, full body and a strongly sweet, warming finish. Taste is mostly sweet and slightly buttery. Alcohol is very well integrated. Very dominant yet pleasant.

Rated on September 15th 2012 - (2011 vintage; Saved this for my rating #500 - courtesy of Steasy66 - big cheers!) Pours black with medium, coffee head that dissipates quickly leaving a bit of lace. Aroma is smooth malty with notes of bourbon, confectionary, coconut, vanilla and oak. Very inviting and accessible. Viscous, creamy texture, full bodied, flat and with a warming, wooden tobacco-humidor finish. Taste follows the nose and is rather more sweet than roasted with the alcohol extremely well integrated. Quite special and dangerously seductive.
Wonderful find.  Pours a dark black.  Flavors of chocolate, fine bourbon, and coffee.  Can’t wait to taste it after it ages.

2011 vintage. Bottle pour into Snifter.  Motor oil black with no head. Sweet, boozy aroma.  Bourbon, roasted chocolate, maple syrup taste with a high alcohol aftertaste that first feels like it will burn, but then warmly mellows.
Sweet like a wee heavy. Great sweet aroma. Alcohol comes out in the taste. Glad to have found this on tap at Mondo’s in Iowa.

Tap.  Pours a thick dark black with a fine head.  The flavor is malty and sweet with lots of flavor from the bourbon barrels.  There is a strong alcohol flavor and is very warming as you drink it.  I actually think this may be too strong.  This one flaw keeps it from being at the top of my beer list.

Bottle: I think I have to thank Soren for this one (has already been two years ago...)
So thank you Soren! 2009 Vintage (When  Goose Island was still Goose Island!)
Well this poured a really darkened black beer (almost that motoroil blackness again, but still at some points also that darkened ruby shine). A very small thick brown head, which unfortunately disappears fairly quick and after some seconds the look is a simple headless but black colored beer.
The smell is sublime, one of those imperial stouts which the barrel aging really caused a positive effect to which your nostrels are flathered, a smile is put on your face and even some shivers rise on your arms and back.
I am a fan of Bourbon Barrel aging, well if it is done correctly (never had any that was r
(really) bad), but this one is done very well!
The aroma is nicely balanced, with a nice mix between spicy, bitter, sweet: there are vanilla tones with some buttery undertones, there are hints of some spicy wood with brown sugars and sweet flower (lightly floral and hop) in the far distance, nice roasted ingredients like roasted barley malts and roasted herbs, some light bitterness but mostly it’s the gentle whiskey tones like wood, vanilla and spices. All the following are just hints in the aroma; mocha and flower (dough), tar and darkened molassess, syrup, slightest hint of something sour.
The flavours are a fine, pretty smooth soft yet spiced mix (but maybe a bit too much alcohol) of vanilla, wood, roasted malts, liquorice, sweet vanilla liquorice, full bitter, very peppery, roasted creamy viscous barleys, toffee, salty liquorice, some coffee/espresso/molasses mix, mocha/ caramel, toasted leaves, some dried liquored fruits (raisin, plums, prunes), some tar, wood roast and dark chocolate. Delicious!
After a while the liquorice comes very well through (together with the firm warm bitterness).
The aftertaste is warm with a firm malty backbone,  roasted spices/herbs, bitter, light caramel, mocha, chocolate, different kinds of liquorice, viscous and well balanced But unfortunately a pretty short aftertaste.
Low carbo, soft creamy light spicy mouthfeel, full body and a lovely oily viscous sticky texture.
Ok, you can drink it right when the bottle is opened and you can drink it after you let this breath for a while both are sublimely balanced and outspoken but you taste the difference.
I am happy I got a bomber, small bottle (355..) would not be enough, lol.
Guess the only things that withold me of giving this a 4.9 (a 5 can’t be given in my optique) are the strong alcohol notes, that there is no head (it’s not bad if a beer has no head, but the (dark) brown head from the beginning should be a bit bigger and disappearing slower and not leave a headless beer after some seconds) and the aftertaste which seem to loose some of the awesomeness which is in the taste itself and is missed in the aftertaste. That said: it’s a wunderschönes biere!
Had this at the 2012 Great American Beer Fest in Denver, Colorado. Big rich bold bourbon and chocolate scents. Taste is similar with a very nice roast and creamy mouth feel.

Thought I was ready for this. One of 4 things happened.

1. I was too drunk to appreciate it. This is definitely true, but still I didn’t enjoy drinking it, struggled to swallow... though I was so gone I was horribly sick shortly after about 10ml.

2. My palate isn’t ready for it. Feels true, but I spend most of my life feeling like a charlatan and hell I’ve drunk loads of lovely imperial stouts I’ve adored (well, about 5... is that loads? No.)

3. It doesn’t taste very nice. Shock! Horror! But why? Tasted like a fortified wine to me (sorry, too drunk to remember any particular flavours... not sure why I’m apologising, you don’t care)... but as I have explained previously, I don’t think I know what I’m talking about... see... charlatan, told ya!

4. ?

I guess it’s all down to taste, that’s the beauty of all this nonsense right?

08 vintage. Pours a pitch black color with almost no head, what is there is a small tan lace. Aroma is of roasted malt, bourbon, oak, vanilla, some lightly oxidized notes, coffee, dark fruits, tobacco and almost burnt notes. The flavor is also slightly oxidized with flavors of roasted malt, bourbon, oak, vanilla, burnt notes, tobacco, dark fruits and coffee. The body is full with an oily mouth feel. Overall a really nice BCBS vintage, except for the slight oxidation.
Very dark brown pour. Aroma is bourbon and alcohol for sure! Flavor is more bourbon and alc, with vanilla notes. So tasty! Harsh burning mouthfeel. Very complex, interesting and delicious!

355ml bottle @ Monks Cafe Wallingatan, Stockholm. Vintage 2008, poured by master barman Alejandro;) Thanks a million man, had a great time! Pitch black, opaque color, small light brown head. Smell dark malts, roasted malts, slight hint of burned malts, wood, bourbon, light to medium sweetness but not bothering at all. Great aroma! Taste dark malts, roastyness, wood, bourbon again strongly, light to moderately sweet, some liquorice, slightly alcohol. Superb taste, absolutely love it! Medium oily to syrupy texture, full body, medium carbo. Superb! -- 2012 bottle (15% ABV) @ home shared with Dutchdrebus 15th of May 2013. Opaque pitch black color, small brown head. Smell malts, dark and roasted malts, wood, bourbon, lightly vanilla, a touch of alcohol, wood and a touch sweet. Taste malts, dark and roasted malts, bourbon, wood, a touch of alcohol, a bit sweet, a bit bitter, oh boy oh boy. Perfect mouthfeel, full body, perfect carbonation. Absolutely superb again. 10-5-10-5-19=4.9! -- Upgraded to 5.0 as I just realised I hardly ever had a more perfect beer. RvdV 010218.

35,5 cl bottle vintage 2009 @ home. Batch #1441, bottled on 02.10.2009, BBE 02.10.2014

Aroma is somewhat sweet and rather malty with oat, dark chocolate, vanilla and hints of whisky‐like smoke. Flavour has vanilla, some slightly harsh bourbon, malty oat, dark chocolate and warming alcohol. Sticky palate. The whisky comes through a bit too much, but still rather nice beer to be sipped slowly.

On tap yesterday at the brewery party. Thanks Goose Island! Just utterly massive. Looks like motor oil. Mild head appeared a good 20 seconds after pour. Nose has bourbon, coffee, chocolate, but also tons of dark fruit (cherries, raspberries, figs). Mouth-feel is velvety, luscious. Matches the nose flavorwise, but also has licorice, raisin, wood, leather. Not always a fan of bourbon barrel aging, as the bourbon ends up overpowering the original flavors of the beer, but this guy can handle it.  An exceptional Imperial Stout.

2009 vintage

A-- Poured black, maybe with a splash or two of red. Half finger of dark chocolate head that fizzled to spotty film. A bit of retention. Visible alcohol legs to this. Honestly, pretty darned ominous looking beer.

S-- Smoky bourbon, vanilla and chocolate flavors come out. Bourbon drops off with more air on this beer. Booze is there but soft.

T-- Bourbon, vanilla, chocolate. Bourbon taste is not that bad, or imposing. ABV is pretty decently subdued.

M-- Rich, thick, and a bit creamy. Alcohol burn is very apparent in the mouth as it is still a bit hot. A lot more vanilla in the mouth and it finishes with a big bourbon kick that left my mouth very dry.

D-- Honestly this beer needs long term cellaring. With one year of age on this it is good but still a little hot. It is balanced well with chocolate, vanilla and bourbon but the bourbon is still a bit much. I have a 660 of this and it was a task to finish it. Another year and will revisit it.

Bottle from a trade with LEMONHEAD. Black pour with a thin head, and aroma of chocolate, malt, and alcohol; very nice. Somewhat sweet. Taste is complex and deep with notes of chocolate, licorice, alcohol, bourbon, slight cherry notes. Really, really nice. Finishes with lingering, slowly fading tones of all the flavors. Could probably stand up to aging simply because this is so big and complex. Another favorite. One to have in the cellar always.

BCS 2009 @ gibson city IL 26/07/2011 and draft in wrigleyville earlier in the year. Pours big black opaque liquor like. Head vanishes quickly. Aromas of bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, wood, toffee and toast. A piney grassy bitterness shines through the complex malt aromas. Full body, medium carbonation, caramel, dark chocolate starring. Finish sees caramel sweetness, complex malts, chocolate, caramel and a citrusy pine bitterness shining through. A boozy hot bourbon note on the finish, but overall a great complex satisfying brew.

Pours a dark brown/black with a small, creamy head. Smells of bourbon and chocolate with some stone fruit. Slightly boozy taste - smooth chocolate and bourbon. Aftertaste of coffee and chocolate. Stellar - at Madison's in Madison before GTMW.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is the beer that all great beers should be measured against. Thanks GI for buying me one at the pre party for GTMW 2012. Amazing nose, bourbon sweet chocolate and vanilla notes. Dark with a thin tan head. Amazing mouthfeel, chocolate toffee bourbon vanilla goodness.

Bottle. 2011 ABV 14,5 %. Pours pitch black with a small tanned head. Aroma is rich malty, complex with roasted malts,vanilla, chocolate and mold. Smooth and thick oily mouthfeel, and the taste is almost too complex for a lager boy, but as my palate is still evolving, this is like coming to beer heaven, rich moderate sweet malty, roast almost hides the alcohol, also lots of chocolate, bourbon, wood, spices and herbs. Delicious de luxe.

Erittäin musta imperial stout, joka on lähes vaahdoton. Tuoksu on bourbon viskinen, vaniljainen, tamminen, tumman suklainen ja paahtuneen sekä makean maltainen. Maku on vaniljainen, bourbon viskinen, lakritsainen, tamminen ja paahtunut. Makeaa tavaraa, mutta tähän olueen se sopii hyvin. Voisin hyvin kuvitella juovani tätä sikaria poltellessa. Suutuntumaltaan olut on liukkaan öljyinen ja paksu. Bourbon County tulee kuin sähköinen käsi taivaalta ja läpsäisee maistelijaa takamukselle. Herkullinen juoma.

2007 Vintage. Pours pitch black with a very tiny dark brown fizz. Smells nutty, coffee, and hints of bourbon soaked fruit. Taste is bold, dark chocolate, nutty, coffee, bourbon, and dark fruits. Full-bodied with a smooth texture and mild mouth-carbonation, Goose Island Bourbon County Stout finishes nutty with fair amounts of dark chocolate and bourbon sweetness.

Bottle.  My favorite reasonably attainable stout.  I like when fresh the bourbon is straight forward, mixing with the dark malt making this a very two flavored beer.  Even better with age when the bourbon mellows a bit, bringing forward a vanilla and caramel flavors mixing with malts.  I NEED MORE!!

Another big thanks to TenderMorsel for bringing this one over for me try.

A - Pours a pitch black with a caramel colored head that fades quickly to a decent lacing

S - Bourbon, vanilla, dark brown sugar, reminder me of an overly sweet breakfast cereal for adults

T - (In no particular order) Chocolate, vanilla, burnt brown sugar, Oak, slight smoke, the warmth of alcohol throughout

M/D - Very smooth and creamy, definitely a sipper

Very well crafted but a little too sweet for me, which is crazy as this would have been my favorite beer back a few years ago. I do see what all the fuss is about though.

Fantastic flavor, serve at room temperature. High ABV but not a strong alcohol aftertaste

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
2009 Bottle) Nose is bourbon, wet wood, alcohol, spice, chocolate, coffee...Taste is Chard wood, bourbon, vanilla, dark chocolate, wet wood, light coffee, roast..Palate is bourbon and vanilla wood..

Tap. Pours opaque black with thin, fizzy tan head; short retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is roast malt, dark chocolate, vanilla, dark berries, figs, oak, bourbon, earthy hops, and faint smoke. Flavor is heavy bourbon, roast malt, dark fruit esters, and supporting hops; light smoke towards the end with a lingering, dry, bourbon finish. Full body, low carbonation, and high warmth.

7/31/12
On tap at Max’s.  Nose is all bourbon...but it’s delicate and I really dig it.  Sweet and smooth.  Outstanding, assuming you enjoy the sweet smell of bourbon...

Pours an oily black with thin head that leaves nothing but a bit that catches around the rim with tiny bubbles.  I swear the thing glows.  Lovely sight

Taste has the bourbon that you’d expect, but really it’s mostly upfront.  It than changes all kinds of shape and you get everything else.  Chocolate just before the swallow, and then you get the hit of  bourbon on the actual swallow, and the the lingering afterward is all chocolate, vanilla and smokey bourbon.   30 seconds after after my first swallow I had to smile when the taste was still lingering in a big way. 

One of my favorite beers of all time.  
(*Disclaimer: i grew up in a household where knob creek and makers mark were poured on the reg!)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 good head, brown, mostly diminishing, good lacing

Roasted and booze aroma

Very smooth with almost fruity taste.

Medium to full body

2013 Batch on tap at Goose Island Brewpub - Black Friday, ’13 4 Ounce pour at room temperature.



A -  No head formed. Poured a viscous pitch black into the glass. Midnight black with some motor oil sort of texture. Nice alcohol legs on the swirl.



S - I can smell the bourbon from 2 feet away which is always a great sign. Big burning bourbon scent up close. Hints of vanilla and campfire. Some roasted malts 



T -   More licorice than the 2011 and 2010 I sampled. Lots of up front licorice. Hint of cardboard taste. The bourbon takes over and coats the tongue with charred oak, vanilla and the finish is all raisins and caramel. On a second sip, I get this hint of pure cane syrup like molasses that my family makes back home. Having had 2009 - 2013, this is the first one I’ve had fresh and boy is it boozy, almost biting like grain alcohol. 



M - 25% carbonation. heavy body. Boozy burn on the back of the throat and to the chest. The oaky bourbon taste with vanilla sticks around for a while.



O -  I’ve had vintages ’07 and 09-11. Each of them are very delicious. This is a delectable beer that I would enjoy more often if only it was more readily available. Very hot and certainly can use at least a year before someone opens their bottle. I’ll open a bottle every few months but boy does this need time! This is still the best mass produced BA stout on the market. Simply amazing.

Bottle to snifter (2008 vintage, sampled next to BCS Rare; thanks mikem409).  Looks decent; pitch black with virtually no lacing.  Smells good; bourbony.  Tastes like it smells.  Average on the palate.  Great beer, but the ’08 should be drank asap, as it’s beginning to fall off.

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar. 2009 version. Pours black with almost no head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, dried fruits, bourbon, dark sugar/molasses. The velvety sweetness and the bourbon barrel flavors give it a port wine-like flavor. Rich and creamy.

On tap at Friscoe Grille & Taproom in Columbia, MD.  Retasted on tap at Siena in Centreville, VA. 

Opaque, near black with tiny head and trivial lacing. Small head and good lacing on retasting in 2018. 

Sweet aroma of vanilla, toffee and molasses. Aromas of chocolate, rm, vanilla, and bourbon on 2018 retasting. 

Taste of dark fruit, vanilla, bourbon, brown sugar and chocolate. Bourbon in the forefront in 2018 retasting.  

Very full body and light carbonation.

Bottle at home. Pitch black, small brown head. Aroma: sweet, vanilla, bourbon, alcohol. Full bodied, some alcohol but nicely balanced. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is perhaps the best beer I have ever had! I was able to snag a 4pk of the 2011 brew from work in Winter 2011 when we only got 1 case of it. Pours a bitch black color with the slightest head. Scent is fantastic as it is rich with bourbon and roasted malts tones. The flavor is amazing! It’s rich, creamy, smooth, and chalk full of delicious bourbon flavors. An absolute treat if you can ever get your hands on some!

Bottle label as Bourbon County Brand Stout......trade from FullObs....It pours pitch black with a nice looking creamy longlasting tan head.....The aroma is roasted malts, dark fruits, bourbon, oak and caramel......The flavor is sweet roasted malts, dark fruits, licorice, bourbon.... it is smooth and creamy..... Great complex Impy..... This is one of the best after my opinion......

What an amazing stout. Thanks to Romans Pub for sharing this amazing brew. While not quite as complex as some other barrel aged stouts, this is incredible for what it is. Straight up bourbon and chocolate, with the velvety smoothness that is second to none, and a thickness  I’ve never experienced in a beer. Can’t wait till this goes year round release, do I can really enjoy some, as well as cellar some...hopefully.
2010 (2yr old) barrel tapped at Romans on 75% nitro.  Aroma of bourbon.  Tastes like a chocolate milkshake with whiskey.  Unreal how good this is.

I love bourbon and stouts, and this did not disappoint. Strong bourbon flavors with nice coffee, chocolate, and caramel notes to name a few. Very noticeable alcohol with lightly carbonated, very dark and thick pour.

Bottle thanks to Mane Liquor. Pours jet black with a dense tan coloured head. Lots of alcohol on the nose plus some dark fruits. Some wood and roasted grain coming through. Flavours are sweet with lots of alcohol plus roasted grain. Full mouthfeel.

I decided to re-review this beer upon having it on draft and in the bottle this weekend, after not having it for the better part of a year.

2008 Vintage

A: Deep black with a thin, beige head that fades quickly, leaving no lacing.

S: Alcohol, roasted malt, bourbon. The aroma is huge and detectable from several feet away.

T: This is a big, rich beer, with a potent dose of bourbon, alcohol, and roasted malt. Wonderfully delicious chocolates also make up a large portion of the flavor. I find it to be very enjoyable and well done. The 13% abv is definitely evident in the nose and the taste, but the beer is so well crafted, the flavor doesn’t come across as hot, just robust and powerful.

M: This brew could use a bit more carbonation. This would greatly enhance the overall feel, in my opinion. The feel is sticky, sweet, viscous, and chewy with a rich roasted malt and alcohol finish that lingers for a good while between sips.

D: The sweetness and high octane nature of Bourbon County Stout make this a great choice for sipping on a cold winter night, which is exactly what I did. While this is a nice brew I enjoy on occasion, I am satisfied with a small serving.

Had this one side-to-side with the Rare, Vanilla and the Coffee Stout.
Look: the beer pours a dark black color with a very small brown head.
Smell: Chocolate, malts, coffee and some bourbon.
Taste: Sweet chocolate, coffee, bourbon with a nice bitter aftertaste.
Mouthfeel: Medium-low carbonation, medium bodied.
Overall: Nice beer, just not as good as the rare and the coffee.
This is a big flavour , jet black with thin tan head lots of bourbon flavour and aroma, very good depth of flavours, chocolate, coffee, leather, alcohol, licorice, vanilla but most of all bourbon

The only thing keeping this from a perfect score was the non-existent head and lack of any lacing. Honestly, it’s not missed. A wonderful and perfect blend of aroma, texture, and flavor, this surpasses all the other bourbon stouts I’ve tried by a comfortable margin.

Updated rating. 2012 edition, now 15% abv, served in a Duvel tulip. Pours a motor oil black with a very thin tan head that quickly disappears, leaving nice lacing. Aroma is oak, bourbon, toasted barley, soy sauce, brown sugar, dark fruits, and a sharp hoppiness. Very complex. Taste is roasted barley, oak, bourbon, cream, brown sugar, coffee, semi-sweet chocolate, and some dark fruit. Once again, very complex. Mouthfeel is thick and it lingers forever. Overall this year is the best I have had to date. I cannot wait to see what aging will do to various bottles from this batch. Superb. Almost as good as Dark Lord.

Poured on tulip. Its black with a brown head a very thin head. The smell is amazing vanilla, coconut, popcorn butter, caramels and just sweetness. The smell translate so well to the flavor, right up front you get all the flavors talked on  the smell but heavy on the sweet and alcohol essence with notes of  coffee, vanilla, coconut, caramels at the back its strong sense of alcohol. this beer is the best.

Bottle. 2011 vintage. Opaque. black liquid with minimal tan head. The aroma has lots of bourbon character with notes of vanilla, coconut, wood, dark chocolate, booze, licorice, caramel, leather, soy and some coffee. A bit buttery bourbon action as well. Less booze than BCBS and a bit more balance. Really complex. The taste is medium sweet and light to medium bitter with a really complex, vanilla and bourbon finish. Extremely velvety and smooth mouthfeel with a full body and soft carbonation. Wow, awesome taste and mouthfeel. Overall, really balanced. Really looking forward to try my ’07 bottle and see if the booziness has died out, and most importantly how tis one handles some oxidization.

My first real topscorer ever, and still a personal favourite. A great combination of vanilla bourbon flavours as well as sweet molasses, coffee and chocolate, as well as a hint of licorice. It’s just soo good.

2012 On tap at the Dutch....I nearly fell off the barstool after drinking this with lunch like it was a regular beer.  On all other occasions, I had shared a bottle.  Up.2!



2011 Bottle via sloth, shared with my Dad as we transferred my home-brewed impy stout into the Tuthilltown bourbon barrel in my basement. Yeah...half a glass is what I needed and not much more.  It looks just as silky smooth during the pour as it is at first taste. Big black and shiny with a dark sienna head.  Boozy nose.  Large robust body that fills your entire palette.  Oak, and Bourbon notes abound as expected.  No lacing.  Big lingering nose even as glass empties.  Nice!

12 ounce bottle, 2011 vintage, poured a dark black color with aromas of roast, oak, vanilla, bourbon, and oak.  Flavors follow the aroma, more bourbon shines through as it warms, but for over 14% ABV, what do you expect.  Really great beer that I would love to get more in my hands.

2011 Bottle.  Black beer with a very thin brown head.  Aroma is coconut, bourbon, molasses, very little roasted notes and not a hint of alcohol.  Taste is sweet, of bourbon, wood, coffee, chocolate, coconut, caramel.  Finish is sweet, roasted, a little bitter, reminds me of good caramel popcorn.  Full bodied, soft carbonation, very smooth, silky.  I have a new favorite beer.

355 mL bottle of the 14.5% 2011 at Sheffield Tap into a Goose Island pint glass.  Black and oily looky, with almost no head.  Sweet, strong and sherry like aroma, bit of cereal really nice.  Sweet, boozy, fruity, dates?  Lovely sipping beer, gets better with every taste.  Shame it was £10.80 but its one of the world’s best beers.

Black body that has a dark frothy head. Bourbon, oak and roasted coffee on the nose. A little alcoholic and rough in the flavour. Bourbon and oakiness definitely come through. Would benefit from some aging me thinks.

Poured into my bruery snifter. 2009 vintage. Pours pitch black with a 1 finger head that dissipates into a nice ring clinging onto my glass. Aroma of bourbon, oak and some vanilla, flintstone vitamin taste . Taste follows the nose, still a bit hot but not in a bad way, cant shake the vitamin taste. Alcohol is there but doesn’t hit till the end of the taste.

2011 bottle.  Very dark pour with a small head.  Aroma of roast and a little sweetness from the oak & bourbon.  Taste is very complex.  Some raisin with vanilla and bourbon.  Some roast in there too.  Nice and toasty.  Not overly sweet.  Super creamy mouth.  Very tasty beer.

2007 Vintage.  Black pour, very  tiny head, low carbonation.  Beautifully balanced in both aroma and taste - Bourbon, Vanilla, high quality belgian dark Chocolate, slight bit of black coffee w/ cream and sugar, slight oak, dark caramel.  Very slight alcohol warming while drinking with almost none detected in the aroma.  The2006 vintage I later had fell short of the majesty in the 2007.  If you have one of these in your cellar, consider opening it now.  Superlative.

2012 edition - a tad cloying, but still fairly nice  3.8

Bottle shared in line at DLD. Chocolate malt and strong bourbon aroma.. Black with a small tan head. Chocolate malt, cola, and strong bourbon flavor. Smooth full body.  Personally, I thought the bourbon flavor was too boozy and overpowering.

Vintage 2008 bottle (12oz) poured into tulip glass

A: This unbelievable beauty pours as black as night with absolutely no head at all. There is no carbonation visible except if I stare at the side and strain I spot a stray bubble or two pushing its way to the top. It poured like motor oil of the 10w 30 type and that is no exaggeration! I love the appearance of this awesome imperial stout. THIS is the way this style should look!

S: The nose on this gem is f*cking outstanding. When I popped it open and even before pouring I caught a few whiffs from the bottle. Now when I got my nose in the glass I literally got the chills and goosebumps. This smells wonderfully of sweet molasses, chocolate, figs and dark fruits. The bourbon has melded together with the other scents like a masterpiece. The aroma is so damn smooth with almost no alcohol to speak of. Where is the 13%?

T: It can’t get much better than this! WOW!! At first the sweet caramel hits my mouth along with a cloyingly sweet molasses. I get the bourbon but like the smell it is so damn smooth and not overpowering at all. I love the chocolate notes flirting with the vanilla notes from the barrels. The dark fruits come out mid sip and in the finale the alcohol makes itself known but does not burn. I mean there is absolutely no burn from the alcohol like you’d think at 13%. It has aged perfectly and the heat is GONE!

M: Perfection and this is not an understatement IMO. The viscosity is lovely as it coates every nook and cranny of my mouth including on the swallow. This is so smooth for a huge beer I can’t describe it. This baby lingers forever and even coates my lips as I take a drink. I do get that wonderful alcohol warming sensation after a while as it is now hitting my head. This beer has the perfect mouthfeel for its style for me. It is chewy, thick and oh so good!

O: This has always been my favorite Imperial stout and the 2008 vintage only shows itself off even more so. This is absolute, unbelievable, mind blowing perfection. If you get a chance to trade for a 2008 vintage I recommend you do it. Believe me you will not be disappointed! This is still one of my favorite beers and definitely my favorite of this style especially cellared as it has just melded together like a beautiful masterpiece!

Pours pitch black with a very low brown head. Aroma is strong and very complex. Bourbon, roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla, mudcake....Full bodied flavor is dark fruits, bourbon, chocolate, alcohol, salt liquorice and roasted malts. Some sweetnes. Long lasting after taste is espresso and roasted malts and chocolate. Gotta love this beer! Extremely swell!!

Pours black with just a bit of bubbles visible just inside. Off-white fluffy head. The smell is deeply malty, with hints of cocoa, vanilla, and bourbon sweetness. The big flavor is definitely sweet caramel maltiness, with a notable amount of cocoa feeling. bourbon is apparent, but not overpowering. It’s a good one.

Originally reviewed: 11/16/09. Vintage 2008.

Poured into my goblet. Pours a very viscous deep black with no head at all. No lace present. Smells like booze, chocolate, fresh coffee, vanilla, and cream. 

The mouth is creamy smooth. No carbonation bite at all. This is a big-time bourbon beer! Huge sweet vanilla notes, some oak, and malted chocolate. The liquor quality hasn’t worn off very much after a year in the cellar. Alcohol is very present in the flavor. This is a very good beer, but I could not drink any more than this 12oz. Too boozy for me.

2011 Bottle, opened 5/3/2012. pours a dark oily black, with a finger of dark caramel head that dissipates to a quarter finger. Nose is all bourbon. Lots of vanilla and oak. Very full bodies. Finish is all bourbon, chocolatey roasty stout to start. But this is mostly a bourbon monster, complete with burning. I’ll be interested to see how it mellows out. 

2008 Bottle, opened 4/7/12: Pours a thick, oil like black, with no head. Tons of bourbon aroma, sweet chocolatey flavor, with oak and bourbon all the way through. Does a decent job masking all the alcohol, with the exception being the bourbon flavors. Sweet, dark chocolate finish. I’m impressed with how well it’s aged.

Pours pitch black, with a minimal brown head that forms a ring quickly around the glass.  Aroma is of alcohol and sweet bourbon. Taste is carmel, coffee,  and burnt malts. Bourbon comes out towards the end. Body is on the full side.

Bottle (14,5% ABV). An opaque black beer, with a small, fully diminishing brown head. The aroma is heavily malty (roasted/burnt grain, caramel, chocolate, molasses, touch of coffee), with strong notes of bourbon and vanilla, other notes of alcohol, raisin, dark fruits, smoked/burnt wood. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Full body, sticky/syrupy/thick texture, soft carbonation, very long finish with moderate bitterness, heavily alcoholic. On one hand the aroma is simply amazing (complex, of course very bourboney, yet enough "beery" and super palesant), on the other, flavor and mouthfeel are super sweet, dense and syrupy to the point of being cloying after 5-6oz. Burning alcohol in the aftertaste, too. I usually prefer non bourbon barrel aged impys, so the score is something in the middle, but this is a nice stuff.

Black color with a small brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate,coffee oak bourbon, vanilla,  alcohol. Flavor is bittersweet, chocolate,coffee alcohol. Body is  full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft ,  finish bitter and alcoholic. Superb..
Bottle @ Mikkeller, thanks to Theis. Black pour, maybe too shiny. Oaky bourbon, vanilla, and the burn of alcohol. Thick, full-bodied, low carbonation.

Pours a jet black color with medium sized brown head that quickly fades to a ring resulting in decent lacing. Aroma is of bourbon and alcohol. Taste is similar bourbon, and a nice alcohol burn.  Mouthfeel is medium to full.

Bottle.  Pours just black .  Thinner head with a dark beige color.  Smellis is some oaky bourbon with vanilla and vibrant dark malts.  Taste is rich for sure - vanilla, molasses, incredibly smooth butch not overpowering  bourbon.  Some dark chocolate, sweet but not cloying.  Never had this before but 2.5 years is doing some amazing things.  No real booze for 13% at least just a bit of a back burn but only a hair.  Amazing

Pours black as night with a lacing of beige and a continual erruption of small bubbles that burst on surfacing. Vanilla custard and caramel liquer on the nose. Thick and rich and warming with chocolate, robust barley, through coffee, chicory and a long warming vanilla finish. Coffee comes in afterward and rumbles on alongside oaky influences and a final whisky kiss. This is a fantastic beer.
Negra de giste marrón. Aroma a fruta madura, sabor torrefacto y amargo pero perfectamente equilibrada.

Two or three years ago, when you could actually find this in four packs and bombers on the shelf at some stores, I was not yet at BBA anything in my beer geekery.  Ah to be cracking one of those now, with a little age on it....  Instead, I’ve not been able to find any until the 2011 release.  I had to put my nose to my snifter several times to confirm all of the aromas it is pulling.  It found caramel, chocolate, chocolate, coffee, toast, resin, butterscotch, licorice, soy sauce, vanilla, and woody notes.   The ale pours as deep as brown can be without actually being black, with a decent brown head that fades to a slight ring quickly.  A sip reveals medium sweetness that turns into slight bitterness and lingering umami as it rolls across my tongue.  Its body is full with a thick, creamy, and sticky texture.  The carbonation is very soft, but serves this ale well by gently pushing over your tongue.  One of the finest beers I have ever had.

2011 vintage. Pitch black pour with a milk chocolate colored head that is gone in a flash. Smell is intoxicating with bourbon, raisins and chocolate. Taste is a mix chocolate, bourbon, raisins, and alcohol. Really an amazing beer. Thanks to breaks808 for this great beer!

Jet black with small tan head, that dissipates quickly but hangs around the edge. Oaky and bourbon hits the nose throughout. Sweet maltiness at first, with a kick of bourbon/alcohol in the middle. It ends off with a bitterness similar to dark chocolate.

--2009 bottle in 2016. Aroma of anise and licorice. Taste charred wood, dark chocolate, milk chocolate. Pretty mellow but still strong flavors. --2009 Bottle in 2013... Same appearance and score. The smell has mellowed. The alcohol is less intense. The alcohol in the taste has lessened as well. I like it more, but I can’t score it any higher. It smoothed out in the year. I’ll see what it does in another two years next time. --- 2009 Bottle Poured into a snifter. Looks like tar in color. A tan head barely covers the surface and quickly dissipates to holding on the edges of the glass. From a foot away I can smell it. Strong alcohol and oak. Up closer it is molasses, caramel, vanilla and port. Taste like alcohol, roasted and burnt malt, vanilla, charred wood at the back of the mouth, a light grabbing bitterness at the end.
