Very rich flavor. It looks like tar and has the same viscosity. It could stop a bullet. Hardly any carbonation. Very well done. I tend to not enjoy the barrel aged beers as much as others. Usually it is because of an overpowering alcohol taste, however, this one balances out the alcohol very well. It is still very rich and a slow drinker; but it is quite complex and drinkable.

The aroma is very strong.  Lots of bourbon and alcohol in the aroma.  The appearance is like used motor oil.  Just pitch black.  The taste is very sweet and a very strong bourbon flavor.  There is a little burn from the alcohol but that mellows as it ages. The palate is the best part of this beer.  It is a very thick stout. Overall BCS is outstanding. One of the best beers there is.

Black pour with a faint bit of brown head that quickly went away. You can smell the bourbon right away. Noticed a hint of chocolate. Taste has hints of chocolate and some smokiness and bourbon again. Thick and smooth.

From bottle. 2012 Thick black with zero head. Slightly boozy aroma, vanilla and licorice. Taste is rich, less alcohol than aroma, lots of vanilla and licorice with a chocolate finish. Heavy on the palate, fairly clean finish with only a slight lingering stickiness  4.1




Bottle 2009. Black with tan head. Big bourbon aroma, vanilla, coconut, chocolate. Taste is well balanced chocolate, vanilla, oak, coconut. Thick madsweet with a clean ffinish. Very good.  4.3




Bottle 2012. Black with ring of tan head. Thick aroma of licorice and bourbon amd chocolate. Taste has lots of coconut and chocolate, wood, licorice. Thick and sweet. Much nicer than original tasting 8 4 9 5 17 (4.3)
Viscous black liquid with aromas of bourbon, vanilla and roasted malts. Taste is the same with slightly too much carbonation. Amazing beer!

Pours black with a red/tan head which disappears quickly..  More carbonation initially but that also goes quickly.  Aroma of caramel, vanilla, toffee and bourbon.   Similar flavours plus molasses.  Viscous, leaving tears running down the glass.  You know this is seriously strong.
Bottle pour almost black taste of bourbon chocolate, coffee, roasty, alcohol, soy sauce, raisin, Such a great beer very warming can’t get enough
Bottle from the boys at nejaime! Thanks guys. Poured a dark brown, somewhat oily into the tulip glass. Almost no head. Aroma is buttered bread and sweet bourbon molasses. Good stuff.

2011 vintage bottle in a snifter.  Pour is almost black with a small carmel head that turns into a ring.  Aroma is powerful upfront of malt and bourbon.  Taste is absolutely amazing with the bourbon not overpowering.  Taste of molasses and vanilla accompany the bourbon taste quite well.  Finish is clean is a little unusual fizz to it, but the bourbon stays on your lips.  One of the best beers out there....cheers!

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, 2011 vintage bottled 11/11/2011.  Pours viscous pitch black color with a small tan head that fades away to a ring of lace quickly.  A fair amount of carbonation streaming up.  Aromas of big bourbon, caramel, dark chocolate, toffee, roasted malt, molasses, vanilla, oak, and a touch of herbal, and booze.  Damn nice and complex aromas, and hardly boozy at all.  Taste of huge dark chocolate, caramel, toffee, bourbon, vanilla, oak, molasses, roasted malt, butterscotch, and a touch of herbal earthiness.  Hardly any bitterness noticed on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, toffee, chocolate, bourbon, and molasses on the finish for a bit.  Fantastic balance of flavors; with absolutely no cloying sweetness.  Light-medium carbonation and very full bodied; with a huge creamy and lush mouthfeel as expected.  Definitely a sipping beer, but is surprisingly smooth for 14.5%; with only a warming alcohol presence on the finish.  Overall this is a phenomenal barrel aged imperial stout.  As it warmed up it got much more smooth and complex.

2011 bottle @ home. Pours black with hardly any head whatsoever. I do see a decent amount of carbonation around the edges of the glass. The nose is decadent. Big bourbon, milk chocolate, cherries, dark wood, some vanilla, sugar. Boozy, welcoming. The taste is hot up front, boooooozy alcohol, plenty of tangy dark fruits. Suprisingly fruity. More milk chocolate and toffee. The finish is long, some roasted malt flavors on the finish. The texture is oily, thick. The body is full, big (suprise, right?!). Overall, really nice impy stout. The concentrated sweetness *almost* reminds me of an yquem. This feels a little hot  and overwhelming for me right now, I’d love to see how the 2011 tastes in a year. Luckily, I’ve got a few bottles held back for just that purpose. *HIGH FIVE BRO*

2011 version. 14.5%. Jet black slick pour with a thin biscuit head and lacing. Wow the aroma of bourbon is really strong. Also aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, oak and liquorice. Sweet, slightly bitter, peat, leather. This is huge. Bourbon County packs a real punch. My lips are sticking together. I feel like I need knife and fork for it. All of the above are distinctly present on the palate and a nap would be definitely needed if you were to drink a pint of it. Its just fantastic.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a bottle in Sätila New years evening 2011. Black beer with a tanned head. Bourbon aroma with amlt, vanila. licorice, tar. Bourbon oak flavour with vanilla. licorice in this beers big flavour palett. Lovley beer :-)

pour opaque black, letting no light trough, with a ring of tan bubbles as head.
Aroma is so packed, with chocolate, roasted coffee, loads and loads of vanilla, some licorice, some dark fruits (soaked in bourbon?) molasses, syrup, caramel, toffee, wood. The lots. Well done, with the bourbon present all the way through, giving a little heat at the end.
Taste is dominant sweet, but not overpowering, (to me), almost feels like drinking maple syrup. 
Full thick oily body, with more carb. than i expected. (still not much)  

I really love this with a little age on it, adding a little more complexity…

Bottle. 2011 vintage. Pours engine oil with almost non-existent tan head. Smells great. Sweet woody, bourbon. Flavour is enormously complex. Very sweet. Vanilla, chocolatelight coffee rind bitterness and the whole thing soaked in bourbon like some sort of trifle. There’s a bitterness midway which quickly makes way for a syrupy finish. A real treat.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/19/2008.

Had to have two of these before I felt comfortable reviewing it. 
Poured from a bottle into a goblet.

It is amazing how thick this stout actually pours - a chocolate brown, nearly black. A dark caramel color appears around the edges of the glass, but there is no chance any light is going to make it through. 

Quite a smoky smell overlaying the other aromas: chocolate, molasses, and some soft vanilla. Overpowering. 

The power bourbon county stout employs is phenomenal. The smokiness is the overlying characteristic of the entire sip, but flavors abound. The chocolate my nose devoured is slightly less apparent in the taste, but strong caramel, some light coffee, and vanilla flavors are all present. The toasted malt is stronger than any other flavors for the first few seconds. Finally, the bourbon comes through, with a strong alcohol taste. The 13% ABV definitely makes itself known, and it burns a little as it slides down my throat. The strong smokey flavor ensures that I finish my sip out on a toasted, almost burnt malty note. Incredibly intense.

As thick as a milkshake, it has a creamy feel with low carbonation. This stout is so thick it actually takes a few seconds to melt in my mouth. 

This is defniitely one to sip on. The brewers don’t know of a cigar that can hold up to the bourbon county stout, and I could not pick anything, much less a cigar, that does. Everything fades in its presence...

I have not encountered a beer with such an intense flavor. I took almost 2 hours to drink the first one, and the second one was not much quicker. Impossible to session, but extremely enjoyable as a single glass. It is very difficult to rate this beer, as it is very different than other beers I have tasted. I am also curious how it will age; will the flavors become more subtle, and will the bourbon flavor blend with the other tastes? Overall a fascinating beer.

2008 vintage. Thanks to MSUBulldog25 (BA) for this. 
Black as oil. Pours like it too. No head what so ever. Thanks to the etching on my NB balloon tulip I can see a dark head trying to come thru. 
The smell is an incredible dark chocolate aroma. Bits of boozyness in the background.
The taste is more of the same. Dark chocolate and bits of alcohol. 
Expect the mouthfeel of this to be huge. It covers your mouth with chocolate goodness and doesn’t go away anytime soon.
Overall, this is a good beer. Very sweet. The 13% abv is non-existent. This is an after dinner sipper. And I will love every sip.

#1615 Bottled on 12/18/2009. Poured an oily black with a very thin dark brown head that disappeared to nothing almost immediately. The aroma was strong with a great bourbon aroma with some vanilla and a good amount of dark roasted malt. The beer was nice and creamy with good smooth bourbon flavor that lasted all the way to the finish. Some licorice flavor develops and some dark chocolate. The longer the beer sat in the glass a more sweet roasted flavor of dark fruits and caramel came through and mixed with the mellow bourbon flavor and a very good alcohol warmth. Excellent beer!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I am thrilled to announce the popping of my BCBS cherry:

Many thanks to MordorMongo on BeerAdvocate for this, and so many other phenomenal beers.

Pours a dark, ominous sludge.  A thin fizzy cap of light chocolate head dissipates to a ring within a minute.

Smells dangerous.  Surprisingly little booze that I notice, even at a relatively low temperature.  Sweet caramel, molasses, toffee, sweet bourbon of course, earthy foundation.

Here we go.  God DAMN.  The best part hits you right off the bat - thick, sweet cloying caramel, chocolate, fading into a sweet bourbon burn with a candy-like oil slick finish.  The mouthfeel is so perfectly in line with the taste that it’s nearly impossible for me to consider the two independent of one another.  The feel is perfect in my mind - tons of substance, really appropriate for the taste.  I love nothing more than experiencing the way that brewers utilize and grapple with high alcohol content - these guys have absolutely nailed the art of it.

I now see why this beer is a definite must.  Cheers!

2nd bottle out of my 4 pack I got this year.  Pours jet black with a small dark brown head.  Lots of bourbon in the nose, roasted malt.  Incredible flavor in every sip.  The alcohol has mellowed a little in this one, but its still pretty prominent.  Overall, just fantastic though.  If you like big stouts, you’ll love this.  Can’t wait to open another bottle.
TAP. Tasted in a flight with BCS, BC Vanilla and BC Coffee. BCS is amazing. Dark and dense. Palate is thick like a port. Tons of bourbon, but balanced with caramel and smoke. Oily palate.

2011 bottle at home. Black, no head, Massive, caramel, toffee, (almost!) sweet paprika nose. Enormously rich flavours, boozy, sweet, toffee, caramel, almond, huge marzipan finish. Certainly extraordinary, absolute madness, in my opinion really really great.

2011 bottle at home. Pitch black, viscous pour, no head. Massive rich nose of bourbon, vanilla hints, chocolate, booze also present. Sweet rich palate, milk chocolate, really smooth bourbon, hint of coffee, big booziness, super-smooth but incredibly rich. Notes of toffee and marzipan also. Sticky rich finish, big alcohol hum. Incredibly, ridiculously unbalanced and sweet, but still great in its own way. Looking forward to trying my aged version.

2008 vintage 12 oz bottle shared at City Beer in SF. A - pours pitch black/brown like motor oil with almost no head. S - bold and very complex aromas, chocolate, oak, vanilla coffee, toffee caramel, and bourbon. M - surprisingly light feel, no carb. Lingering alcohol warmed ending. T - this is where BCS shine. Bold and subtle, very complex. Notes of chocolate and toffee on the front. Coffee, vanilla, licorice, oak on the palate. Lingering alcohol warmed bourbon, oaky, chocolatey malts end. O - fantastic well balanced dark dark stout. One of my favorite beers 9

(2011) pours deep black with a dissipating tanned head. strong aroma of smoky whisky, chocolate and coffee. taste is a strong, complex, and insanely rich. layers of chocolate, vanilla, bourbon and coffee bitterness. its dense and almost syrupy in consistency. great warmth from the alcohol (very well concealed), and lovely lingering taste of infused oak barrels. its basically a grown up chocolate sauce! you almost couldn’t call this a beer at all. I’ve marked down because its so damn rich I struggled to finish the whole bottle. beautiful and bonkers!

I’ve drank this beer twice now. The first time I couldn’t rate it because it was so absolutely wonderful that I was distracted. It has the perfect blend of bourbon, vanilla, and malty nose. It’s smooth almost to its fault, as I can drink it as though its simply dessert(to be quickly devoured and absolutely enjoyed). I could and would drink a 6 pack of this for a hefty price. My description might not be concise or helpful but know this...if this beer hits your lips and you don’t enjoy it, something is wrong with you.

355ml bottle. Pitch black with a scant ring of mocha bubbles. Aroma nearly knocked me out... wow. Lusciously thick moutfeel with chocolate, vanilla, tobacco. Lingers on forever. A huge beer in every sense, deserving of its reputation.

12 ounce bottle. I found this beer to be syrupy sweet in both the aroma and flavor. Its viscosity was like cold syrup as well. The nose and flavor also contained huge bourbon notes. Maybe blended this beer would become more appealing to me, but as it stands it is to far out of balance for me to really enjoy it. I am impressed with how well the alcohol is hidden. This beer is not for me.
This beer is damn near perfect. 2011 vintage. Bourbon compliments the malt really well. So smooth and delicious. I want so much more

had this stout several times but a first for me rating it.pours black as motor oil with 25k miles on it.very thin brown head that dissapates almost immediately.on of the most fragrant stouts ive ever had.licorice,vanilla,chocolate and raisans and very boozey bourbon aroma.flavour is the same as the aroma.this is one of those stouts when you smell it,you know what your going to taste.full body with moderate carbonation that has a slick feel on your tongue.very nice long warm finish.i had the pleasure last year of having the rare of this version.this has been my favorite stout and my overall favorite since i first tasted it two years ago.if you have a few extra bucks get the rare if it becomes available.

2010 edition bottle 9/24/10. Pours black as used motor oil with just a tiny brown foam that quickly dissipates to lacing. Huge aroma of vanilla, bourbon, and caramel. Simply the best aroma of any beer. Flavor of oak and alcohol. Very smooth drinking. Chocolate, caramel, bourbon and licorice. Finish is sweet and hot. An excellent stout.
12oz 2008 The unobtainable standard for barrel aged stouts.  Just the right amount of bourbon and sweetness, my favorite year by far.

12oz bottle thanks to thirdeye11.Pitch black pour with some bubbly tan head.  Smells amazing - vanilla, oak, chocolate, and tons of bourbon.  Rich and decadent.  The high ABV is there but isn?t overpowering.  Flavor dominated by chocolate and bourbon with some graham cracker and roasted malt.  Absolutely delicious!
very strong taste but very good’ could taste the amount almost immediately and was overpowering in some aspects but then the taste of the beer arrived and it smoothed it out
What a beer. Way way better than last time I had it. Heaven in a glass. One of my favorite beers ever.  Unreal.

Bottle 2011, pours dark brown/black with a very thin tan head. Aroma of licorice, caramel, oak, chocolate and Bourbon. Wow, everything about this is intense. Thick and very sweet, flavors similar to aroma, lots of booze and licorice. This becomes too much for me to really enjoy. Will revisit with some age on it.

Opened last night.  2011 bottled 11/11/11.  

This is always fantastic stuff.   Very dark black with a little head.  Perfect mix of stout flavors and bourbon flavors.  Definately a slow drinking beer.  You can feel the heat and it’s very soothing.

Bottle, 2011, 14.5%. Pours like black engine oil. Smells of beautiful caramel, brown sugar, bourbon and butterscotch. Tastes heavily sweet with a mild bitter. Full bodied. Soft carbonation. Finishes slightly cloying. Very good, though the sweetness might use some tempering.

2011 bottle. Pours like motor oil in my snifter with only a thin tan ring. Aroma is boozy, with a lot of vanilla, chocolate, and coconut. Body is thick & viscous. Flavor is also chocolatey, with vanilla, coconut, with a little warming heat from the alcohol. Incredibly smooth for 14.5% abv. One of the best vintages I’ve ever had!

2009 bottle with friends.  Aroma of sweet brandy, black cherry, and a hint of chocolate.  Pours deep ruby brown with no head whatsoever.  Tastes sweet of black cherry, chocolate, vanilla, tobacco, and port.  This is a finely blended bourbon stout!  Thank you Chris!

This is probably one of my favorite barrel aged stouts!  Appearance is black and as thick as motor oil.   Tasty is big time bourbon. I bought some 2011 and plan to age it for a year pr two! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

650 ml bottle.  2009 vintage.  Pours a dark black with a small tan head that settles to a ring and leaves some light lacing on the glass.  The aroma is big chocolate brownie, bourbon, vanilla, a lot of alcohol, and some roast.  The aroma is sweet and boozy.  The initial taste is sweet brownie.  Then some roast, booze, bourbon, and a bit of vanilla.  The finish is really boozy with some bitterness and has a warming feeling.  Full bodied with low carbonation.  I did not find this very enjoyable.  It is cloyingly sweet and extremely boozy, even two years after bottling.  I found the sweetness to overwhelm the other flavors present.  Drinking more than an ounce or two is a chore.

2011 version. Merry Xmas to me! Yes, this pours jet black, the slightest brown highlights around the edge. Nose is toffee, vanilla, oak, and bourbon. Taste is very rich, moderately sweet with plenty of bourbon barrel. Palate is smooth smooth smooth with hardly any alcohol burn at 14.5%. The alcohol hits the dome about half way through it, but until then it’s not noticeable. Glad I found a bottle as this is hard to come by. I don’t think I would go crazy trying to locate one, as there are so many bourbon barrel stouts out there now, but I will say Goose Island has pretty much perfected what they’re doing with this.

35cl bottle.  Vintage 2009.
This head which disappears very quickly.  Very deep dark pour.  Chocolate coffee and alcohol in the aftertaste.  Yummy!
Deep black color with thin head. Aroma of alcohol and chocolate. Taste is rich of chocolate (little too much chocolate) with notes of cocanut.

2011 tasting in 2011: Of note, I do like bourbon and I do like stouts. This pours a very dark brown, not quite opaque with medium head. Smells highly of bourbon, caramel.  Medium body that is not overcarbonated. Tastes very strongly of bourbon upfront an in the finish.  Caramilized sugar sweetness up front with very boozy finish.  Again, I like bourbon, but I think there is more bourbon influence than beer in this. 

2014 tasted in 2014. Rating based on most recent release.

Pours dark black with tan head, small with moderate lacing.  Complex aroma of a little oak, lots of bourbon, licorice, coffee, a little clove. dark chocolate. Smooth, silky, full body with just the right amount of carbonation. A bit boozy, but well balanced given the age of this beer. Long mildly bitter and bourbon finish. This is great. 

2013 Tasting in 2013: Pours an opaque black with reddish brown head that leaves moderate lacing. Aroma of sweet, bourbon, oak, boozy. Hints of vanilla, cherry. Moderately sweet with a hint of bitterness. I suspect this beer will mellow out nicely. Full body with soft carbonation. Long bourbon finish.

12 oz into HFB stemware, 2010. Pours a midnight black, tiger eye around the edges...not even a bubble. As the name suggests, BCBS has a distinct bourbon aroma and a bit of sweet malts(very slight). Taste follows nose with additions of roast, slight char, and sweet toffee. Although carbonation is very low to non-existant, the full body helps to carry the high ABV and heavy bourbon tones quite well. I find this vintage pretty harsh and young, I am looking forward to trying my other bottle a few years down the road.

2011 -- Pours as black as can be.. the tiny head is a great burnt caramel color.  Smells STRONG of bourbon, oak, and maybe a hint of chocolate.  Can smell it from 4 feet away.  Unbelievable mouthfeel for 14.5% -- dangerously smooth, just a tad bitter.  Nice and thick, almost chewable.  Taste is not as strong w/ the bourbon as the aroma is -- it’s got a hint of vanilla and a decent amount of caramel in there.  Great taste. Very little alcohol on the taste.  Awesome stout.

2017 - Aroma of chocolate, malt, bourbon.  Velvet and thick on the tongue.. very little burn, subtle perfect carbonation.  It is real deal.

Chevy Chase, DC 12oz ($6): Pours a black color with a minimal brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, vanilla, whiskey, and burning. Really, really intense flavour. In fact, it might be too intense. Syrupy texture. Long lingering chocolate/vanilla aftertaste. Kind of on the sweet side of things. Hard to drink in a way, but each sip is certainly rewarding. People have said virtually everything about this beer, so I’ll leave it at that.
Pours a pitch black body. Little carbonation. Chocolate, vanilla, coconut, and a heavy whiskey component. Almost overpoweringly alcoholic but darn delicious.
Tirata fuori dalla cantina, questa spacca il culo a tutti! Una bestia di imperial stout, una birra diddio!

2008 vintage from the cellar courtesy of Pairings in Minnetonka. Very complex aroma of bourbon, chocolate, oak, and molasses. Pours dark and thick with little to no head. Very bold flavors of bourbon, alcohol, chocolate, and finishing with notes of oak, prunes, anise, and honey. I like this huge sipper and I think the aging served it well. It could age for many more years and still be a champion.

Sampled at the Saint Louis Ratebeer Gathering into tulip glass. 2011 vintage. Poured an opaque, very dark brown color with weak tan foam but nice lace and alcohol legs when swirled. Aroma typical of oak-aged Imperial Stout (we drank many that night) but this one has more noticeable bourbon and vanilla than most. Rich malt-sweetness with bread, toast, caramel, and lots of roasted barley. Nuts and toffee, dark chocolate, coffee and cream, plums and sour cherries. Distinct hops bitterness made it all the way through. Heavy body, "chewy" mouthfeel. Lasting fruity, roasty aftertaste. The syrupy thickness and dark tannins actually stained the glass. Wow.

Sampled at the St. Louis RB gathering.  It poured a black color with a brownish head. The aroma was roasted malt, dark chocolate and vanilla. The flavor was very sweet and somewhat bitter. This was a very good Imperial Stout.

2009 bottle...pours deep brown/black with a medium mocha head.  Aroma has notable rum, fig, coffee, vanilla, and cocoa...boozy!  Flavor has cocoa, vanilla, a bit of fig, some caramel...rum is milder than expected but present.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy...finish is roasty with coffee and rum...warming!

After around five or six bottles of this at separate occasions, I feel it’s time to do a re-rating. No question about it, this is a world-class beer and one of the best I’ve ever had. It pours black as night with pretty much no head. Aroma is pure magic, with coffee, vanilla, fudge, muscovado, port barrel, chocolate... One of the best smelling beers I’ve ever had. Taste is a sweet alcohol sensation, while there are some nuances there, it’s all about dark sweet fruit, vanilla, milk chocolate and sweet port barrel. Finish is lingering alcohol sweet and warming. Incredibly rich and creamy body with a surprising amount of carbonation to keep it somewhat balanced but the 2012 edition is still sweet, sweet, sweet. A great beer that would have been even better with just a hint of balancing hop bitterness.

Huge chocolate notes, with some burnt toffee and light coffee notes. Rich and roasty, The bourbon really makes this beer incredible, the flavors are very balanced. Light vanilla and oak combined with chocolate and coffee malt flavors.

2009 Edition: A deep dark stout with a thin dark brown head. In aroma, a smooth licorice chocolate with light woody notes, cedar notes, alcohol, nice and smooth. In mouth, a smooth soy sauce chocolate with woody notes, alcohol burn, wonderfully smooth and complex. Bottle from GRM, shared with Probstk, GRM, Mike and Shaun, Nov. 20 2011.

This was the 2006 version. This beer has been lovingly cellared in my basement. The beer was lightly chilled and served in a wide mouth goblet.

Ar- I remember this beers bourbon aroma being off the scale very ragged and rough. The years in my cellar have been kind. The vanilla oak and bourbon have wrapped themselves around darkly roasted malt. The char of the malt has fallen away over time. Dark cocoa and silky sweet chocolate. Dark fruits have went more to the figgy region. Again I must stress the vanilla oak and bourbon have laced themselves into the beers aroma.The beer looks like spent motor oil. The body is perfectly black with no ruby opaqueness to light. The head looks like burnt caramel and quickly resolves. An oily sheen marks the glass as the beer is quickly consumed. 



Ap-  The beer looks like spent motor oil. The body is perfectly black with no ruby opaqueness to light. The head looks like burnt caramel and quickly resolves. An oily sheen marks the glass as the beer is quickly consumed. 
 
T- Darkly roasted malt bitter sweet cocoa, dark fruits mostly fig all the above infused with very mellow bourbon. A bit of alcohol heat is still present but more warming in nature. A bit of oxidation rounds this beer out. 

P- The body is full and very slick and oily. No alcohol heat at all. The carbonation has fallen off but isnt still. The lower levels of carbonation greatly aide the beers fullness of body.

O- Aging Bourbon County Stout has gotten rid of any rough edges on this beer. A bit of oxidation has crept in but has rounded out the beer for the better. 5 years in the bottle and this beer isnt near exhausted.

Aroma- massive bourbon, other boozes, barrel qualities, chocolate, vanilla. malts
Appearance- pitch black, viscous, no real head present, puffs of a smoky white film when swirled
Taste- big roasted notes, vinous qualities, chocolate, smoke, char, tobacco in the middle and a great alcohol burn in the finish
Palate- super full and creamy, excellent
Overall- Wow, what an unreal beer.  A sipper for sure, but just an excellently done over-the-top stout.

Wow I’ve had this so many times and swore I’ve rated it but apparently I haven’t. This beer changed my perspective on beer a few years ago. 2009 bottle from ryandevilhorns. Pitch black as oil pour. Aroma is amazing with tons chocolate, molasses,  bourbon, oak, vanilla. Taste is also amazing with lots of chocolate syrup almost like german chocolate cake, bourbon and vanilla and some tingly booze one back of my throat. One of my favorite brews.

Bottle from 2008, pitch black with a non existent head, Aroma, is bourbon, oak, dried fruits, vanilla, liquorice, sweet cream, butterscotch, dark berries, roasted, light smoke, mouth feel is full, rich and smooth, very low carbonation, taste is vanilla, oak, bourbon, herbal, some grassy notes,  roasted bitterness, very balanced, not too sweet, sweet cream, molasses, butterscotch, lakridskonfekt, sweet liquorice, tingly on the palate, dried fruits, raisins, prunes, figs, light sugarburn

Rating 3000! +++ Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick, black and oily with a medium sized foamy dark brown head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was vanilla, bourbon, cocoa, toasted malts, port wine and raisin. The flavor was strong sweet cocoa with moderate notes of bourbon, rum, port wine and toasted vanilla. The finish was very long with cocoa, vanilla and bourbon lingering. Thick and silky body. Excellent.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours pitch black and even with an aggressive pour, it only musters a slight dark tan head.  The head fades very quickly.  The nose is monstrous with notes of unsweetened chocolate, raisin, oak, bourbon, and a touch of alcohol.  The flavor is definitely on the sweet side with notes of vanilla, oak, chocolate, coffee, unrefined sugar, and slight roasted malt notes.  The alcohol is difinitely present and warming on the way down your throat.  Thick and rich, full bodied isn’t the word for this syrupy brew.  Very low carbonation and a linger sweet finish.  I would mind a touch more roast and a hair less sweetness.  Enjoy this one in moderation as it is certainly capable of setting you on your ass.

Bottle 35,5 cl, Alko Arkadia. Pours pitch black with a  small bubbly brown head. Aroma is sweet, vinous, bourbon, vanilla roasted malts and barrel with some fruity notes. Mouthfeel is fullbodied velvety, yet drinkable. Flavor is sweet, acidy, vanilla, phenolic and alcohol in front. Behind roasted malts, dark fruits, salty licorice, coffee, coconut, almonds. Has nice bitterness and is a bit pungent. Finishes with a nice warming feeling of alcohol, sweet, vanilla, bourbon and good almondy taste. A complex and well balanced stout, excellent.

Stout Day 2012, 2007 vintage; huge thanks to Kan. Just amazing complexity in aroma and flavor; vinous velvety dark fruits raisins sweet vanilla coffee chocolate all in great so well balanced combo. I’ll sit with this one for a long while.
My favorite beer, upon drinking my first an aged 2006, I exclaimed, "Amazing, the blood of a chocolate snow god!" I’ve since had each year successively and my first declaration still rings true.
Nose is sweet-acidic espresso, heavy roasted malt, vanilla, oak, feel is quite broad, carb is low, taste is port, some coffee, warm alcohol, roasted malt, sweet licorice, earth.

355ml bottle poured black in color with a modest light brown head and loads of nice lacing.  Aroma is dark roasted malts with chocolate and coffee and a hint of whiskey and alcohol.  Taste is dark roasted malty sweetness with some chocolate and coffee and alcohol and a lighter hoppy bitterness underneath.  This is a complex beer to describe and is very tasty and highly recommended.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a medium sized dense dark tan head.  The nose is heavy chocolate malt, bourbon, vanilla, wood, coffee beans and roast.  The words by themselves don’t do this justice.  Poured into a snifter on a cool fall evening the aroma encourages one to take the first sip.  The flavor is a decadent blend of chocolate, roast, bourbon, vanilla, wood and touches of coffee.  Mouth fell is spot on; viscous and smooth; full bodied and delicious.  As much as I like this when it comes out each year, it is even better with a couple years on it.  I’m amazed that I haven’t rated this until now.

Brown bottle, 650 ml, purchased at Beers of the world (trip with Louise), in memory of Paul Hines, savoured on October 12 2011; eye: black, opaque, beige head that turns rapidly into a tiny ring, no lacing; nose: woody, bourbon, roasted malt, molasses, dark candied fruits, light alcohol, liquorice; mouth: woody, bourbon, roasted malt, molasses, light candied dark fruits, alcohol, alcohol warmth, liquorice, finale in bourbon with presence of roasted malt, full body, slightly sweet, velvety texture; overall: really good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 650 ml, achetée chez Beers of the world (voyage avec Louise), en mémoire de Paul Hines, savourée le 12 octobre 2011; œil : noire, opaque, mousse beige qui se transforme rapidement en un petit anneau, pas de dentelle; nez : boisé, bourbon, malt torréfié, mélasse, fruits confits noirs, léger alcool, réglisse; bouche : boisé, bourbon, malt torréfié, mélasse, léger fruits confits noir, alcool, chaleur d’alcool, réglisse, finale en bourbon avec présence de malt torréfié, corsé, très légèrement sucrée, texture veloutée; en résumé : très bon

Thanks to daknole for this bottle. Pretty sure 2008 vintage. The beer pours black and thick with almost no light getting through the beer at all. The head is tan with a serious molasses and smoky aroma. It’s smooth, delicious and the
molasses is incredible! Great great beer!

36cl, Vintage 2013, at 14.9%Vol, American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex sweet Stout, heavily roasted/alcoholic and slightly woody, heavy, yet balanced, hazy, nearly no head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

head: capuccino , bubbly , away fast 
colour: black as hell 
smell: chocolat , coffee, bourbon , vanilla coconut, roasted malts, candy sirup, ashy , smoke , cigars ( higher level brands ) 
taste: start is deep black chocolat with praliné filling , candy sirup , caramel and vanilla followed by a boozy bourbony alcohol flavour that burns the mouth a bit , bitter cocoa powder and sweetness of brown chocolat, when swallowed alcohol remains, together with a beautifful bourbon/whiskey palate and a bit of smokeyness ... end is a bit roasted malts and semi dry , oily texture , AWESOME I WANT ANOTHER BOTTLE OF THIS ! sipping this beer is obliged !

I have been ratting beers a bit too generous. After all of the beers I have had today, I cannot say I am on the right frame of mind with my palate. All I can say is this is so much better than good! I am so pleased.

12 ounce bottle, 2008 vintage, bottled on 10/16/08.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown/black with pretty much no head at all, but with it being a 13% ABV beer, I didn’t expect much of a head on this one.  Not much lacing at all, either.  Aroma is roasted malt, dark fruit, coffee, molasses, bourbon and a bit of vanilla and soy sauce.  It tastes like bittersweet and milk chocolate, dark fruit, coffee, bourbon, molasses and vanilla.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, it’s creamy, coating and slick with low/moderate carbonation.  I think it’s a very good brew, it’s definitely one of the better bourbon barrel aged beers that I’ve tried.

1/2014: splurged on a glass of this at Proof - can’t remember what it cost, but a lot ($10-12). Anyway, kind of worth it. Smooth creamy oak, bourbon and chocolate. Great brew. Too expensive.  10/8/2011: From a really old note (no idea where or when):  bottle.  black pour with a thin tan head.  aroma of dark fruits, roasty malts and alcohol.  sharp taste up front of herbal minty vibe, sweet dark fruit, coffee, molasses and bourbon.  Tingly palate.  Dry finish with nice burn on the way down.  Great sipper - lots of contrasting tastes.  Even better as it warmed.

Had this in my fridge for about a year and a half or so, very different from a fresh one. Pours a as dark and viscous as motor oil. The aroma HUGE coconut flavours mixed with thick anise/licorice and coffee notes, with undertones of a good port. The flavour is also big on the coconut flavour, with thick anise/licorice and coffee notes, undertones of chocolate, leather, and smoke. The mouth feel is thick and syrupy, carries the heavy flavours nicely, anise and coffee, with a sweet alcohol warmth trail off into the finish. A very epic stout.

(2009 edition) Thank you Gully!!!!!!!! Mind blowing brew!!!! This aroma is epic!!! So Good!!! Droooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooool………………………………………………………..Silky smooth vanilla, pleasant bourbon, milk chocolate, heavy roasted malts, traces of smoke, chocolate coffee, more yum then you can shake a stick at.  Oh ya the beer looks brown. I can die happy now that I have tasted the breast milk of god!! Brew is so thick and smooth, the 13% is completely hidden. I’m loving the mild coffee combining with the vanilla bourbon flavours. Beer is sweet and desert like, but balanced with a slight salty smoke. Perfect bitter finish! WOW!! What a beer! this lives up to its god like reputation. Thank again Jeff….and thanks for not choking me with toe socks that your stuffing down my  throat using the handle of a plunger while wearing festively coloured clogs and pig ears, so you can take back my share of your beer

Re-rate February 1st 2013

On bottle at Öl&Whiskymässsan
Pours black with no head. Low carbonation.
Aromas of dades, figs, brown sugar, honey, you name it. It’s a nose explosion. Taste is absolutely marvellous. Thick and creamy with a sweet and round ending. One of the best beers around!
In my opinion, this was one of the best beers at ABR.  Absolutely wonderful!

Bottle thanks to ygtbsm94: Poured a deep black oil sludge color with a bubble across the top head, but very thin. Thick bourbon aroma with hints of chocolate. Taste is rich chocolate, coconut, loads of malts and a alcohol bourbon burn in the finish.

355 ml bottle. 2009 vintage. Bottled on 02.10.2009.
Rated on 20191107
Rating: 9+5+8+4+17=4.3
Very intense chocolate and bourbon lingering both on nose and flavor, salty licorice is also strong as it was almost five years ago, the sweetness has faded maybe slightly, vanilla, strong malty presence, alcohol warmth at the end. Quite similar experience compared to previous tasting of this same vintage. Obviously this can handle the age with ease. Excellent.

355 ml bottle. 2009 vintage. Bottled on 02.10.2009.
Rated on 20150106
Rating: 9+5+8+4+18=4.4
Still quite the delicacy, lots of roasted malts on the nose, dark bitter chocolate with vanilla and sweet syrup. Bourbon and vanilla on the flavor, smooth chocolaty malts with some syrupy sweetness. Overall no major changes to previous tasting(s), maybe a bit more salty licorice, which is a good progression. Still one of my top Imperial Stouts.

355 ml bottle. 2009 vintage. Bottled on 02.10.2009.
Rated on 20110924
Rating: 9+5+8+4+18=4.4
Pours pitch black color with small beige foam on the sides. Aroma of sweet caramel malts, syrup, dark roasted malts, chocolate, mild vanilla, some distant notes of soy and peat, mild tar and smoke also. Flavor of dark roasted malts, peat, vanilla, light fruits, caramel, toffee and soy. Palate is slick and oily with a little alcohol burn at the end. Rich with flavor, full-bodied and definitely a complex brew. Majestic.
4316

Originally rated on 20090614, 2008 vintage (8+5+9+4+18).

2009. Bought at the cool beer place me and Kyle went to during RBSG 2010. I’m sharing this with brad but ive came up with at least 10 ways of quickly murdering him so I don’t have to split this - all deaths are humorous in nature like choking on toe socks that I’m stuffing down his throat using the handle of a plunger while wearing festively coloured clogs and pig ears. The beer is black and is in a glass. The aroma is just silly: eveything is colossal: deep roasted malts with hints of smoke but slightly burnt as perfect, bourbon, sweet tobacco, vanilla, wood shavings that are not new, dark yet not overly bitter chocolate, salt and a bit meaty. Yea, this is amazing. Taste is equal. Massive smooth roast with burnt and an in and out smokiness, hidden fruit, spice and mild burn that is perfect as there is no hint to the 13%, vanilla, nutty, licorice, warm melted chocolate, plum. This is an incredible succulent liquid - the finest of the fine - a beer than more than lives up to legend and reputation. So smooth and silky, a healthy not quite ashy aftertaste to go along with a multitude of flavors that blend together to keep every sip living on in taste bud memory.
Pour is dark dark black almost no head. Smell is vanilla sweet little roasted Yummy. Taste is raisons vanilla white chocolate.

Ratings are for 2009 vintage (my favorite of the group) included tasting notes for all.

2007- Very chocolate tasting, however very oxidized. No real bourbon notes. A little past its prime.

2008- Heavy on chocolate, some bourbon, a little bit of oxidation. Most at tasting liked this one best.

2009- Great balance between bourbon and sweet malts, which I preferred over the heavy chocolate of 2008.

2010- Bourbon forward, cooled off significantly from when this beer is fresh. Very sweet.

Smell of strong wine and barley. Very dark brown colour with minimal copper head. Aroma of raisins, leaves and alcohol. Small faints of salmiak and chocolate to be found. High alcohol content means quite sharp alcoholic palate. Great stuff.

Date: September 6, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Stout Tasting, Lakeville, MN Appearance: Opaque black, no head. Aroma: Bourbon and chocolate. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, thick bodied, oily and strong alcohol finish. Other: This was really good, but not quite as good as the Rare.  2009 vintage.

12.5.11 - had the 2011 vintage and think this version is smoother than the 2009 bottle with a sweeter more licorice finish.  Upping palate to 5, this stuff rocks!
fresh, this beer is a bit much for me. It is big hot and very bourbon laced. I have collected several bottles of each vintage since 08’ and find they just keep getting better with age.

Bottle, 2008 vintage. Finally cracked one of the bottles that I’ve had in the cellar for some time. Pours close to pitch black with practically a non-existent head, looks viscous, oily. Smells of bourbon, coconut, vanilla, chocolate, roasted malt. Tastes of again bourbon, coconut, vanilla, roasted malt, bitter chocolate. Full bodied with an aftertaste packed with coconut that seems to linger forever. Truly a great beer!

2009 vintage bottled 10-16-09. Pours like used motor oil, you could barely make a head on this one if you stood on a chair and poured it into a glass on the floor.  Leaves patches of reddish brown head, has legs like a nice red wine.  Aroma is bourbon whiskey, alcohol, smoke, bittersweet chocolate, a hint of dried fruit, vanilla.  Taste is bourbon, chocolate, warming alcohol, vanilla/spice/boozy aftertaste.  Body is full, rich, creamy, bittersweet finish, minus points for clearly present alcohol.  I drank one of these back in ’09 and it tasted like bonfire but has smoothed out since then.  This beer should be aged at least 2 years before consumption to smooth out its harsh edges.  The ’09 vintage is just now becoming approachable.
Cracked open a 5yr old... Smelled real boozy, but was real smoooth..  Nice dark pour with a brownish head.. Still had great chocolate flavor and roasty.  Could definitely feel the ABV..

Figured I would wait until my 100th beer for this baby. 12oz bottle from Pick’s poured into a snifter. Bottled on 10/11/2007. Pours a dark black, blacker than black. Looks like a big cup of motor oil. It even leaves a sheen on the side of the glass when it’s tilted. This beer has zero head. The nose is some sweet vanilla, oak and...whiskey? Reminds me of Maker’s Mark whiskey. Taste is lightly sweet and medium bitter. Aftertaste is coffee, oak and again, whiskey. It definitely has the same aftertaste of Maker’s. Medium bodied with a oily yet creamy texture. Has a long bittersweet finish. Overall, this beer is awesome. I can’t believe I’ve found a beer than reminds me of my favorite whiskey. If only it wasn’t  20 bucks for a 4-pack and if only I could find it again.

2009 Vintage, bottled on 11/12/2009, #1318. Reviewed on 08-08-2011, making it almost two years old. 13% abv. Poured into an over sized wine glass.

A - Perfectly black body. Even holding it up to the light I don’t get any brown or red hints, just black. Really dark mocha head that doesn’t stick around for very long. The lacing and retention is pretty awesome. A swirl of the glass produces more mocha foam that almost has a red tint. Theres even legs too! Just looks perfect. 5.0/5

S - Bourbon initially. High quality bourbon. Then oak, vanilla, cocoa powder, and lots of roasty malty goodness. The finish is certainly alcoholic. 4.5/5

T - Crazy smooth. I taste bourbon, oak, rich vanilla, and some coffee and chocolate notes. Just a hint of bitter roasted malts. The finish is alcoholic and warming. It does come off a bit strong, but in a good way. Its not even that complex of a beer. Its just extremely well put together, Every flavor flows together perfectly. Nothing really stands out or steals the show. Really fantastic taste. 5.0/5

M - Velvety smooth and super thick. Its coats your tongue and doesn’t go away until the last nuance of vanilla and bourbon fades away. Being so creamy and having fairly low carbonation, its a sipper. 4.5/5

O - This is one of my favorite stouts. The bourbon barrel notes really compliment the base beer. Its just so smooth and rich with tons of amazing flavors. If the AB-Inbev buy out means a higher supply of this stuff, then I’m game. 4.5/5

2011 Vintage, bottled on, 11/11/2011, #1711. Reviewed on 05-15-2012, making it roughly 6 months old. 14.5% abv. Poured into a brandy snifter. 

A - Pitch black body. Dark mocha one finger high head. Settles down to a thin cap and thick edging. Some light lacing but a swirl leaves behind a ridiculous amount of alcoholic legs and regenerates the head. A thin layer of alcohol just stays on the side of the glass for eternity. Perfect. 5.0/5

S - Heavy bourbon notes. Dark caramelized fruits, molasses, oak, maple, caramel, butterscotch and loads of sweet vanilla. This leads into some bitter cocoa powder and coffee beans. There is a nice alcoholic burn on the finish. 5.0/5

T - Starts off with hot bourbon notes. Roasty and lightly bitter cocoa powder with vanilla and caramel sweetness. Some faint notes of dark fruits, coconut, and maple. The finish is long and bitter. Alcohol is prevalent but well integrated. 4.5/5

M - Quite boozy, so much so that the thick syrupy mouth feel seems to become watery towards the finish. Really coats your mouth though. 4.5/5

O - For a six month old beer this is drinking really damn well. I think I prefer it with a year or two on it though. The flavors seem to meld together a bit more which helps with the intense boozy bourbon notes. The ’09 having only 13% abv also helps its cause a bit. 4.5/5

12oz bottle, 2008 vintage.  Pours a jet black color with almost no head. Aroma is bourbon.  Heavy on the palate with soft carbonation. Flavor is sweet, chocolate, roasted malt, bourbon, vanilla, with a sweet bourbon finish. Absolutely fantastic.

Poured into a  Darkness snifter. Bottle Date 10/28/08.

A- After the initial pour a thin brown head formed but dissipated quickly to nothing, slight lacing on the sides of the glass, pitch black motor oil appearance.
S- Wow the aroma is intense, very nice big bourbon aroma, strong vanilla, oak, chocolate, sweet caramel.
T-O my this beer is delicious, huge bourbon flavor, as well as vanilla upfront, nice sweet taste with a slight bitterness, alcohol is definitely present which only adds to the experience of this beer, oak presence, chocolate, caramel, malt, really warming, definitely a sipper. 
M- Big mouth feel, nice bite after every sip, coats the palate, warming as it goes down.
O- I’ve had the more recent vintages of this beer and was impressed, but with drinking the 08 I am blown away, I love this beer, only wish I had more of the 08, one of the best Barrel aged stouts I’ve had.

Black body, light foam. Complex aroma of roasted, chocolate, butter, caramel. Flavour is intense with bitterness of hops, dark sherry and vainilla, chocolate and much more. Every sip is a new one. Full creamy and oily.

Twist off bottle. Holy wtf? Dark pour with a tan head, oh wait it’s gone already. No lacing. Big alcohol nose. Some roast and malty aromas. Slight vanilla. Caramel and vanilla. Warm alcohol sensation. Bitter on the back. Not bad, but I can’t really age these with a screw top cap.

Thanks to GT2. 3 year old bottle. Well holy crap. The pour on this gives a bit of a dark tan head which quickly dissipates and leaves an inky black liquid. Aroma is cinnamon hot chocolate, with spicy alcohol, vanilla cream, marshmallow, bitter dark chocolate fudge. Taste is lots of cinnamon dark chocolate with that spicy alcohol, vanilla, fudge, maybe a little salty on the finish. Tastes like delicious high end chocolate truffles melting in your mouth. A bit of spicy pepper on the finish as well. My God. Palate is wonderfully thick, but not oily. Fluffy and creamy. Seriously?
Pour is jet black with a small tan head. Nose is of roasted malt and some bourbon in the nose as well. The taste is of vanilla, oak, dark malt and bourbon, and some chocolate of course as well.
Totally wonderful beer. Almost too full on to have in room temperature.  Very dark and creamy head

Pours pitch black with a dense medium brown head that is tight and potent. Event a few feet away you can begin to smell the aromas of whisky seared oak, vanilla, dark espresso, 80% chocolate and huge dark malt. The palate breaks open with roast, coffee, sweet oak, vanillla, caramel, whisky, smooth tar and a lush, lush, LUSH mouthfeel. This is a crazy beer that will only get more superb with age. wow

Black as sin with a beige head. Overpowering bourbon, chocolate and coffee in the aromas. After giving my nose a rest vanilla, raisins and  dark sugar appears. This is wonderful but almost a bit to much for me! The taste is creamy and full bodied of course. The bourbon is not as notable in taste as it was in the aroma which I’m glad for. Instead there is a lot of yummy chocolate, coffee, syrup, roasted malts and inevitably some bourbon. The beer really coats my mouth and gives me a warming feeling. Truly great

Smell: Bourbon, coffe, chocolait, vanilla, raisins
Taste: Raisins, vanilla, dates, chocolait, toffe.
Mouthfeel Soft, smoth, well balanced.
Notes: Lovely

12oz bottle (screw cap, really!?), bottled Oct 28, 2008.  2.5 years old.  Served at cellar temperature.  Huge thanks to Ryan for this gift.


Pours black with a one finger brown head that leaves short-lived lacing and holds a wispy cap and foamy ring.



Aroma is deep, rich and powerful bourbon, very strong on the bourbon with great underlying notes of premium dark chocolate, anise, black currants, roasted malts, coffee, and some dark fruits such as figs, raisins, plums as well as some sinus-clearing alcohol.  Excellent strength and complexity.  An aroma so strong, I taste it without having to take a sip.  Damn.



Flavor is bourbon, and lots of it, but never overpowers the incredible base beer which features notes of dark chocolate, anise, black currants, plums, raisins, figs, caramel, oak, vanilla, dark roasted malts, coffee.  Hops? heh.  There is some sweetness and alcohol on the finish but minimal considering the 13% ABV.  Dangerously drinkable and crazy complex.



Mouthfeel is full, sticky, thick, with soft-ish carbonation.



A sipper in every sense of the word.  An absolute treat.  A revelation.  A journey.  A masterpiece.
If you appreciate strong quality tastes then this is for you. Not surprisingly, prepare for the luscious roasted malts, bourbon and strong alcohol.

2010 , thx to matthew ! 


head: capuccino , bubbly , away fast 

colour: black as hell 

smell: chocolat , coffee, bourbon , vanilla coconut, roasted malts, candy sirup, ashy , smoke , cigars ( higher level brands ) 
 
taste: start is deep black chocolat with praliné filling , candy sirup , caramel and vanilla followed by a boozy bourbony alcohol flavour that burns the mouth a bit , bitter cocoa powder and sweetness of brown chocolat, when swallowed alcohol remains, together with a beautifful bourbon/whiskey palate and a bit of smokeyness ... end is a bit roasted malts and semi dry , oily texture  , AWESOME I WANT ANOTHER BOTTLE OF THIS !   sipping this beer is obliged !

355ml bottle from Alko Arkadia

2009 vintage

Pours pitch black with a nice sticky brown head. Aroma has hints of vanilla, oak, roasted malts and alcohol. Taste is quite sweet, sticky and complex with notes of vanilla and oak. Full bodied, not very roasted. Finish is smooth with some notes of coffee. Excellent barrel aged beer, well balanced. 9-4-9-4-16 = 4.3




Re-rated on 2.2.2013. 355ml bottle from Alko Arkadia. 2009 vintage, bottled on 10/02/09 -  Wow. This one has aged really well. Quite heavy on bourbony notes, vanilla and smooth sweetness. Simply an awesome beer. 9-4-9-5-18 = 4.5




Re-re-rated on 27.4.2013. 330ml bottle from Ales by Mail. 2012 vintage. Feels like this needs quite a lot of aging before it is balanced. Strong and stingy bourbony notes, some warming alcohol and vegetable notes on this fresh bottle. Not nearly as good as the aged one. 8-4-8-4-16 = 4.0

Pours pitch black with a very low brown head. Complex and strong aroma is bourbon, dark chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla and alcohol. Flavor is incredibly full with bourbon, chocolate, dark fruits, alcohol and charred malts. One of the best beers I’ve ever tried. Mind-blowing.

10’ Vintage. (6/5/11)

A: Very little carbonation for the newest vintage of the BCBS, with just a little bit of retention on the outer perimeter of the snifter. Jet black per usual.

S: Lots of bourbon in the nose still but also getting some oak and hints of nilla’. I can am also detecting the leather that people always talk about. I’ve not noticed it in the older vintages though.

T: Bourbon is the first taste but more flavors open as you get past it. Oak is very prominent and there is also an anise flavor in there. The bourbon hits again on the finish and warms as it goes down.

M: Thick with just the right amount of carbonation for the style.

O: Still pretty hot but definitely becoming better. This is my least favorite so far. Still a damn good beer.

09’ Vintage. (5/19/11)

A: Beautifully black with a small khaki head retention. Good sticky lacing throughout the snifter I consumed it in.

S: Reeks of bourbon but in the most exceptional way. I don’t think there are many better smelling beers out there. The Bourbon takes a back seat as it warms, this is where the oak and vanilla with some subtle hints of chocolate that come into play melting together wonderfully.

T: Very rich and filling with a welcomed warming in the chest from the alcohol. Everything one would expect and hope for from a barrel aged RIS. Flavor really develops from the fridge to room temp. I enjoy both of the flavors offered though, however it does open up quite a bit at room temp and the craftsmanship can truly be appreciated.

O: Overall this beer is phenomenal and one of the best beers I’ve ever had the chance to try. I prefer the Bourbon County Stout with age on it though.
Pours a jet black with a slight, dark brown head. Nose is all bourbon, maybe a bit it roasted malt. Tastes of bourbon barrel, not as complex as I hoped.

12 fl oz bottle from BOTW, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. Bottled 11/12/09. 24MA11. 



App.:  Deep brown-black with a decent deep mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Deep, slightly tangy black coffee, rich dark chocolate, wood, alcohol, some green bitter herbs, licorice and molasses notes, dark dried fruits, more alcohol, bright yet deep, interesting.
  
Palate:  Medium-full body, soft, sparse effervescence, big, thick, velvety, rich.
  
Flav.:  Strong bright fruitiness, lots of chocolate and coffee, alcohol, wood notes, some green herbal notes, more alcohol, some licorice and molasses, big stuff; sweet with sufficient bitterness, lots of alcohol and a long, rich deep malt finish



Plenty of flavour and more than plenty of alcohol.  Still a “bucket list” brew.

I have to re-rate this one.  Either my taste changed a lot or the 2011 version is just phenomenal.  Probably a little bit of both but BCS is one of the best stouts out there.  Taste is perfectly roasty, sweet, bourbon, light ash, chocolate, and coffee.  Great stuff.

Bottle- Pours a lovely dark color with a slight head of a great caramelly, chocolately color.  Can easily smell the Bourbon notes.  Taste is overwhelming- nothing subtle about this beer.  Starts with a bit of sweetness, but very quickly bites with the Bourbon.  I would say a bit too much of a bite for a good drinking stout- but what do you expect for 13%...

Bottle from 2008. Bought in September 2009 at Belmont Station, Portland Oregon during a road trip. After three years of cellaring, it’s time to try it. Pours a viscous black with no head. Overwhelming aroma of oak, vanilla, and alcohal. Taste is more of the same plus sweet fruit. Alcohal is hot and very noticeable. Can’t imagine how harsh this stuff must be when it’s fresh. Outstanding palate - thick with hardly any carbonation. It’s a good beer, but at 13% it’s not one that I’m going to be drinking regulary. Also, I’ve tried enough high-ABV, barrell aged beers to realize that they all taste very similar - again oak, vanilla, alcohal and too sweet for me. I’m not really fond of these beers and I don’t see myself trying any more of them.

Das Malz ist bereits zu Beginn intensiv schokoladig und würzig. Schnell steigt die Intensitöt wobei das Bier herrlich weich und cremig bleibt. Der Alkoholgehalt wird dabei permanent offensichtlicher und sticht am Ende in der Nase. Abgesehen davon ist das Bier aber ausgewogen und gefällt in seiner durch die verträgliche Süße ausgeglichenen starken Malzgeschmack. Ein absolut gelungenes Bier! /13/11/14/11/14

Shared at DLD, bottle from 2010 I believe. Pour is black as coal with a finger-wide coffee colored head. Aroma is sweet and bitter at the same time with notes of coffee grounds, dark chocolate, and alcohol. Flavor is where the bourbon comes through with slight notes of darker fruits, chocolate, coffee, and oak. Some sweet vanilla and booze in the finish.

Bottle @ Private tasting, Denver, thanks to Adnielsen.
Vintage 2006 bottle,  8/10  3/5   9/10   4/5   17/20
Pours black, no head. Aroma of bourbon, oak, vanilla, plums,caramel, coffee, booze. Taste is bourbon, vanilla, oak, plums and raisinss, coffee, caramel, port, booze. Full body, close to no carbonation. Just wonderfull. 100411
Vintage 2009 bottle,   8/10  3/5    10/10    4/5    18/20
Pours black with a smnall tan ring along the glasssides. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate,caramel, fruit,, booze. Taste is bourbon, vanilla, plums and raisis, coffee, port, booze. Full body, low carbonation ( but noticeable compared to the 2006 bottle ) 
Both where very enjoyable, booze and carbonation more noticeable in the 2009 bottle ( not surprising) than the 2006 bottle. 100411

Bottle 65cl 2009 vintage. Pitch black color with a quick to disappear minimal brown head.
The aroma is very pleasant: chocolate, coffee, roast, alcohol. On the palate comes the bomb: very very strong and intense woody taste, something like licking a barrel. Obviously you can also notice bourbon (a lot of it!), alcohol (boooooooze!), vanilla, chocolate, coffee, roast, molasses, cherries. The sweetness is medium but quiet balanced by the alcohol.
Not Easy to drink as the vanilla sister, It took a while to finish a glass of it, but defenetly more intense.

2010 bottle. Pours nearly black with no head. Aroma is alot of dark fruits, booze, mollasses, and tar. Flavor is asphalt, chocolate, mollasses, toffee, and booze. Medium/full oily mouthfeel. Great heat. Great beer.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and coffee aroma with hints of bourbon. Roasted malty chocolate and coffee flavor with hints of bourbon and vanilla. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish.
Holy bourbon Batman. Black as space and thick as hell. Medium bitter and a little sweet with bit of sticky. Very easy going down and I have to say that if you like barrel aged then this is your beer.
Bottle at Mikkeller bar.  Fantastic beer with rich syrup like taste, lots of vanilla and liquorice.

’08.  Barrel really comes thru soon as this hits your mouth.  Got a boozy feel to it but the alcohol hides well enough, quite warming.  Bourbon is my favorite spirit to mix and to sip but I’ve yet to find a bourbon-barrel aged beer were the barrel doesn’t dominate the beer, to include the fabled BCS.  ZERO co2, no head, just this ominous thing  that glares at you and says "Drink me, if you dare."

355ml bottle from Alko. Vintage 2009. Poured black with a very thin brown head. Aroma is very complex and tempting; roasted malt, oak, vanilla, mould and liquirice. Seems like with every sip my nose detect something new in this brew. Flavor is oak, malt, vanilla, bourbon and liquirice, warming alcohol towards finish and with some coffee and chocolate also in finish. The most complex beer I have tried so far, enjoyable to the max.

On tap at rattle n hum. Awesome is the one word needed to describe this one. Black pour with pretty much no head. Aroma brings out burnt chocolate fudge, bourbon, molasses and vanilla oak. Amazingly smooth. Bourbon again at the forefront of the taste with a thick, oily chocolate fudge following with a continual smooth vanilla backing in there. Fantastic beer

355ml bottle, vintage 2009, bought at the Alko store called Arkadia in Helsinki a few months ago. The oily pour reveals a more or less pitch black body with a disappearing light brown head. Inviting taste of vanilla oak with bourbon whiskey. Rich taste profile of dark and dried fruits, wood and chocolate malts supported by strong, but integrated bourbon, providing a long-lived, bittersweet finish. Full bodied. A delicious sipper that lasted for an hour or so (Tromsø, 20.04.2011).
Very dark black w/ sweet, raisiny aroma and only hints of alcohol. full body and very viscous. i’d never guess this is 13%. lots of licourice and raisins with a prominent alcohol taste. Superb!

Bottle at Esbjerg Beerfestival-09.Pours black with a beige head.Aroma of vanilla, coco nuts, roasted malt and bourbon.Flavor is sweet and warming with some oak, vanilla  and coffee.Full body ,  soft carbonation.Very nice.

625 ml @ mikkel:
black, black, black - if only there was a head it would definitely get a pure 5!
dark fruit- like a portwine just with out the alcohol, chockolate, oil, cofee liquorice. opens up with some air.
fat and deliciuos with coffee, chocko, bourbon and vanilla, extremely wellballanced.
Super beer, though heavy. Almost better than the vanilla stout tasted recently

Deep black beer with very little head. 

Bourbon aroma does not dominate but it’s clearly there.  There are also chocolate and some black licorice scents.

Tastes rich but not overly so.  Deep, dark malt flavors glazed over with the bourbon.  The bourbon accents the stout and does not overwhelm the rich, dark chocolate flavors.

A - Pours a very dark black color with a touch of brown visible around the edges and a thin finger of tan head. The head fades fairly quickly leaving behind a few spots of lace.

S - Aroma is full of bourbon, smoke, and sweet oak. Some coffee and chocolate. A bit of the roasted malt also comes through. Really pungent.

T - Starts off with a lot of smoke and bourbon flavor. Some chocolate flavor alongside. There is some roasted malt and a hint of vanilla. Through the middle some brown sugar sweetness and oak flavors that come out. The finish is warm bourbon and chocolate malt blend, with only a touch of alcohol flavor that lingers really nicely.

M - Full bodied with moderate-low carbonation. Creamy and even a bit oily. Flavor really fills the mouth. The finish has a nice warming feeling.

D - Pretty drinkable, especially given the strong flavors and the 13% abv. The bourbon flavor is strong and flavorful, but still well balanced.

2006 bottle @ home, courtesy of Ratman197, tasted in April 2011. Deep black appearance with virtually no head. Very nice smooth oaky, light vanilla, bourbon nose with some booze. Delicious Bourbon, vanilla, light woody oak flavor over a delicious espresso, chocolatey malty flavor. Quite boozy in flavor and even more so on the finish. It holds up well though still a little boozy. (4.2)



2009 bottle @ home tasted in April 2011. Black appearance with a small tan head that quickly dissipates. Sweet, slightly boozy, fairly mild vanilla bourbon, dark chocolate malty nose. More carbonated (and not surprisingly) than 06 bottle. Slightly thick, chocolatey, somewhat boozy finish. (4.3)



2009 bottle @ home tasted Sept 2012. Really a soft anise, rich dark chocolate, a touch boozy, sweet and smooth whiskey aroma. A bit of booze on the finish but in a good way which rarely happens. Toffee, whiskey, caramel, dark chocolate flavors that are integrated incredibly well. (4.5)

Well now I know what charred oak taste like. Vundrfull. Trust me just say it. Anyway this beer was f%$#ing bourbon grrrrraaavey! Lil Jon says Yeeeahhh! Love ta love ta love ya love ya. I would describe it all boring like everyone else, but then I wouldn’t tell you how the beer made me feel. Knowledge I’m out 1.

Bomber 2009. I was hoping for the aging to make this beer a little less hot, but it was still very hot. Pours like thick oil, aroma is of alcohol bourbon and vanilla. The taste is sweet with vanilla, but it is mostly dominated by the bourbon. Overall, a bomer for one person is to much. Its better to sip this one with a friend or go for the 12oz four pack, drink one bottle and save the rest. - (2014) Originally this was too much for me but ive gaing appreciation for this, its a sipper with a huge amount of flavor, its boozy but only carries a hint of alcohol.

Took me a couple of tries but I finally came around to this beer.  Now one of my favorite bourbon beers.  Definitely has the typical imp stout flavors, choc, coffee, roastedness, and certainly molasses in the aftertaste.  Good amount of heat too.

2006 vintage poured from a bottle into a tulip. Beer is black and has no head. There are a few tiny brown bubbles that form on the edge of the glass. There is minimal lacing on the glass. Looks like a flat stout. When you swirl the beer you get legs where the alcohol separates from the beer. Wow...

Aroma is like liquor, I suppose. Really strong. There is some sweetness. Can really smell the alcohol.

Beer is thick and has a great strong liquor presence to it. There is a strong roast character that comes up after the initial sweetness and alcohol of the bourbon. There is decent connectivity between the two flavors. The roast is not an aftertaste but a really late back flavor, there is no aftertaste. Second taste, the carbonation plays on the tongue a little, if there were more it may be better. Overall drinkability is good and so is mouthfeel. I want to try the 2009 for comparison.

Serving type: bottle

2009 bottle. Pours almost pitch black, brown edges, thin head. Big, toasted nose, lots of charred oak and vanilla, fruit, chocolate, cocoa powder, coconut, cinnamon, cloves, hops. Extremely full bodied, thick, sweet, marked bitterness. Incredibly rich and complex, very fruity, lots of charred oak, vanilla, fudge, coffee beans, alcohol, spices. (2010-12-01)

This beer is intense.  poours out of the bottle completely black.  The meal is of bourbon, vanilla, dried fruit.  Taste is like oil it coats your whole mouth.  Good thing I split this with a buddy because it would be too much to drink alone.  GREAT BEER!!

Pour les disciples de stout en général, Goose Island est définitivement LE gourou. Pourrait possiblement être surpassé que par la version ’’Rare’’ qui attend tranquillement dans mon cellier. Tout a été dit sur ce liquide maléfique.

It pours a dark brown, almost black with a finger high dark tan head, little carbonation, and decent lacing.

The dominant aroma right off the bat is the bourbon, you can just smell the alcohol oozing out. There are also notes of vanilla and smoke.

The taste is very very smooth and wonderful, not at all what I was expecting from this stout. Not the typical coffee or chocolate. It tastes almost sweet, there is vanilla, alcohol, bourbon all very present.

This is a wonderful beer.

Having now had this a few more times its still a great beer but there is definitely some variation year to year and depending on how old the bottle is. 
Bomber, 2009. Pours a jet black although not that viscous with no head and almost no lacing. Huge bourbon nose, vanilla, and light wood/oak. Full bodied, feels silky and creamy, tastes of vanilla, caramel, bourbon and malts. The finish just keeps on going and going - you just smack you lips again and again as the bourbon swirls around your mouth. What a great beer - think it might be in the top 5 of all time.

black, chocolate, roasty, resin, earthy, woody, very bitter, medium sweetness, thick feel, flat, long finish, full body, 
Much respect for the brewer, this one was just too strong and heavy, subduing all other tastes in an evening of libation.  Sorry, not my fave.

Absolutely beautiful beer. The aroma has notes of vanilla, nuts, and warm alcohol, reminds me of Utopias’ aroma. The pour is a beautiful dark brown, almost black. It leaves a syrupy film on the glass when swirled. The palate is smooth and full bodied. The taste doesn’t disappoint with warm vanilla, oak, nuts, and bourbon notes. Again, absolutely wonderful beer.

Hmmm... Bourbon County Stout... this is actually the last of the variations that I have yet to try. The bottle opens with a great wiff of delicious, delicious sweet bourbon, wow boozy. Sweet and vanilla, this is absolutely delicious. What barrel-aged beers should live up to. Take a great Imperial Stout, age it in some of the best bourbon in the world. This is dang good. A sipper, but delicious.

2008 bottle. Dark brown-black, viscous pour with a minimal tan head and minimal lace. Nose is licorice and bourbon. This huge imperial stout has a very heavy body with minimal carbonation. Licorice, molasses, vanilla, bourbon and an oaken earthiness fill this complex body. Mouth feel is smooth and viscous, with a smoky oiliness in the finish alongside some chocolate. Sip slowly and savor it - the most interesting flavors emerge between sips and as it warms. A rival to DFH’s Worldwide Stout, but this Goose Island giant seems more complex and has different strengths.
Thanks to John for this. Very delicious. Not an everyday kind of thing but for special occasions.  Smells and tastes strongly of bourbon. Smooth but with some alc. burn. Serving: Bottle

Bottle, bottled 10/02/09. Poured into a snifer, black as night, a little bit of very dark brown at the edges against the light. Very small, almost non-existent, head the color of coffee. A shame since it would probably have looked very impressive. Aroma is oak, vanilla and molasses. Taste is vanilla, liquorice, molasses, typical IS roasted malts, but not as much as you’d think. At the finish the hops try a bit of something, but are completely overpowered by the sweetness. Palate is full. The bottle hasn’t been cellared that well, but I have to admit that perhaps imperial stouts - especially these barrel-aged ones - aren’t really my style.
Strong, sweet bourbon flavor given support and gravity by the rich stout. This is one of my very favorite beers.

I’ve had this on a number of occasions, the first being back a few years ago when my palate wasn’t, shall we say, developed? Back then, I thought it was too strong, much like many people. Now that I’ve grown more of a liking to strong brews such as imperial stouts and barley wines, I thought I’d give it a second try and WHOA! Was I wrong!!! Pours pitch black with a thin, tan head. The aroma from this beer practically kicks you in the mouth! Huge hits of bourbon, burnt oak, cocoa, and vanilla. The flavor is a not-so-subtle alcohol presence from the bourbon barrels with overlays of chocolate, campfire, vanilla, dark chocolate, and bitter hops. Mouthfeel is full bodied and thick as motor oil, with a strong alcohol heat on the finish. Drinks like stout, finishes like a shot of bourbon! This beer is everything it claims to be! I’m so glad my tastes have developed, because I love this beer! But, this is NOT a beer for everyone. It’s a slow sipper. So don’t go into this thinking it’s a run-of-the-mill imperial stout with an over-exaggerated description of flavor. If anything, it’s under-exaggerated :-)

<2008 vintage> bought a 4 pk of 12 oz bottles.
popped it open and poured into a tulip glass

Appearance:
Pours Jet Black, very little head, what head does appear is just a light swirling of dark brown on the edge and through the middle but it dissipates quickly and leaves just a little sticky trelace on the side of the glass.

Smell:
I took a big wiff just after pooring it in the glass, the beer was a bit too cold when i poured it. it smelled boozy like bourbon balls. heavy bitter dark chocolate and bourbon. after it warmed a bit and i had taken a few sips off it I took another big wiff. the bourbon smell was still there but the alcohol/booziness of it dissipated into a more butterscotch smell with hints of raisin and still a nice backdrop of Bitter Dark Chocolate.

Taste:
First sip was extremely boozy and tasted heavy of bourbon and bitter dark chocolate. Heavy hits of pure espresso dark roast bitterness hit all over on the backend of the swallow. as it warmed that same delicious Butterschotch flavor that i smelled started popping out, much more sweetness up front and bringing that bitter dark chocolate espresso to the back with little hints of raisin here and there.

Mouthfeel:
Suprisingly it was thinner then I thought it would be. definately not thick or chewy. more oily and slick. the warmer it got the more sticky sweetness it left on the lips.

Drinkability: Because of how boozy it was I didn’t think i would want to drink a lot of this, the flavors are so heavy and rich that i didn’t think i would want to drink a lot. As it warmed with that delicious caramel/butterscotch coming through i think i could have drank maybe one more but really, I think 10-16oz of this is where you want it. Definately will drink more of this in the future. might even try the 20.9 oz bottle next time, i would try it on tap but the only place i know that has it, sells it $10 for a 10 oz pour. too spendy for me.

Black with a light brown head. Aroma is hard roasted malt, dark chocolate and vanilla. Flavor is very sweet and rather bitter. Finish is roasted and heavy alcohol, which gives an unpleasant mouthfeel. It’s not a bad beer it’s just too much and unbalanced. 131110

Great beer shared with great company. Pours thick and black. The aroma that hits you is that of bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, and molasses. The flavor is much of the same only more intense with an added bit of smokiness and wood. It finishes with a perfect amount of bitterness. This is great beer. I can’t wait to track done all the other versions and try them side by side.

Location/Date:2012(15%) Bottle on January 10th, 2014.



Appearance: Pours an opaque brown black with light brown head. 
 

Aroma: Aroma of bourbon, oak, vanilla, light roast.
 

Taste: Light roast, light bourbon, chocolate.
   

Palate:Over medium body, kinda thick.



Summary: I do like this beer, but any beer that’s closer to 15% really isn’t my preference. I get why people love this stuff, and I really like it, but it’s not my favorite imperial stout.

New batch, mother fuxking grand slam


This one is very boozy at the start and needs some time for you palate to adjust. Corn and vanilla comes through from the bourbon barrel aging, a very thick strong stout in the background supports this, a man’s stout.

This is a 2009 bomber, thanks MisterP. The aroma is dark chocolate, roastiness, and some booze. The beer pours dark coffee chocolate black with a very small head. The flavor is hotter since we just poured it back to back with the ’08, but still awfully smooth. It has the roasted bitterness and booze up front, with a smaller but nice chocolate ending. This beer is delicious overall, no matter what year!

Bottle. 2009. Pitch black color with a small, diminishing brown foam collar (=Motor-oil). Pretty and slick. Aroma has tons of bourbon - almost pure bourbon and vanilla on the first notes - lots of smooth oak and alcohol characteristics that blends nicely. It is nicely round and the roast is almost overshadowed by the smooth bourbon. The aromatic circumference is constituted mainly by bitter liquorice and dark chili chocolate, some faint dried fruits and smooth coffee as well - all revolving around the whisky/bourbon base. Perhaps a little high on the booze - quite hot. The taste is in the same ball-court, with tons of bourbon and oak, liquorice, vanilla and chocolate. There is a sugary - and boozy - sweetness on the first notes, but it evens out over the next couple of seconds, leaving an aftertaste of alcohol, bitter chocolate, and the more general, roasty bitterness. A very nice beer, but a little too much alcohol for me - it seems to choke the more complex characteristics - even after years in the bottle. Nonetheless, an entirely enjoyable beer; actually quite straightforward - insofar as one enjoys bourbon and whisky. Very heavy duty. I had some really high hopes for this bad boy, and it might just be the age of this particular bottle, or some other unforeseeable circumstances, but to me, it seems one-sided and could use some balancing.
Black with small head. Very strong taste and aroma. A very good stout, but also very strong.

335 ml bottle. Pours black, creamy, beer. Minimal tan coloured head. Aroma: Chocolate, vanilla, cream liqueurish, caramel, toffee, bread. Rich in notes, yet pleasantly calm. Taste: Gently sweet, lightly bitter. Malt, bourbon flavours. Palate: Nearly full bodied beer with creamy texture. Soft carbonation. Long cream liquerish and bourbon like finish. Overall: One of my all-time favourites.

4 Pk poured into a tulip.  Pours a black with a small tan head.  Little to no retention.  Aromas of bourbon and malt.  Taste has bourbon all throughout.  Interesting for a while but the bourbon to me is too overpowering.  Drinking a few of these would put me under the table.

On tap at Jerry’s.  Pours black with thin but lasting tan head.  Nose heavy with bourbon, some heat, burnt dark fruits, and caramel.  Initially sweet, but washed away with bourbon soaked cherries, then bittersweet chocolate and Irish coffee.  Sweetness dissipates, but hop/bourbon bitterness pleasantly lasts.  I like it very much, but suspect that the aging bottles in my closet will be better/more well rounded.

Received in trade from brdc, thanks for the opportunity.
2007 bottling enjoyed late 2008

A vigorous pour could barely produce any head in this solid black brew. I can smell the bourbon from the bottle soon after I pop the cap. The aroma is bourbon, vanilla, oak, hard to tell if there’s a beer under there. The taste is very complex! First you get hit with the bourbon and oak then some roast, then some alcohol, then a bit of hop bitterness finish with a smooth bourbon roast. Its really tasty, but I like bourbon too. Thick body, oily turning to creamy mouthfeel. Light carbonation. Great Bourbon that someone spilled some beer into :)

2009 vintage. Almost black with a small cappuchino head. Boozy on the nose, but none of that is in the flavour. Bourbon, vanilla and a great mud pie flavour behind. Some chocolate as well. Oily mouthfeel.
