on draft. have had this beer several times on draft. just let it set to warm up the snifter glass. very dark pour and the scent of bourbon and oak is strong followed with that hint of vanilla. if you like bourbon barrel stouts this one is a must. the warm alcohol burn accents the flavors which makes this a great beer.

650th rating and to celebrate my 2,5 years smoke free, 2 years nicotine free. 2008 bottle "brand stout" version, seems it’s not seperated at RB. The aroma is liquorish, alcohol, malts, coffee, roasted chocolate. The body is pitch black, to sad I don’t get a head. It somehow reminds me a bit at one of the Narke brewings i’ve tasted earlier (I think Konjaks). The taste also goes out that way. Wood, burned malts, lots of chocolate (most at the aftertaste), the liqourish from the bourbon comes trough, and the alcohol is there for sure. Sweet, coffee and chocolate, biterness is there but doesn’t kicks in like crazy. Not bad at all, it misses a head, a bit more carbonation, and a bit less alcohol that gets trough. But a very good brew for sure. Edit: after retasting, I only can add some points...

Bottle 650ml shared courtesy of meilby. Pours black with average, creamy, tan head. Aroma is chocolate, coconut, smoke, bourbon and vanilla. Taste is light sweet and bitter, hangs around for quite some time. Medium to full body, oily to thick, soft carbonation.

This beer is a big hit for a lot of people. I’m a huge Imperial stout fan. I liked it but man is this one of the most intense stouts ever. I haven’t tried a lot of stouts out their, but of what i have tried this thing out muscles them all. It’s thick and greasy. Coats your mouth. The flavor are all very rich and juicy. Dark everything. Bourbon is there for sure...vanilla, dark sweet cherry. The head almost gives you the illusion that you could walk on it. I couldn’t just jump into this beer with a dry mouth. I think it would have to be one or two beers down the road for me. Otherwise, a awesome stout...that will knock you on your butt.

Bottle. 12 oz. Pours deep, deep black with a thin, beige head. Aroma is outrageous, unique, and delicious; freshly baked sweet bread with butter, toffee, vanilla, caramel, scotch, bourbon, roasted malts barley, tea, and booze. Full, heavy, thick, syrupy body with a palate as smooth as silk. Finishes smoky-warm with a nice soothing, numbing effect on the throat and belly. Excellent.
Unfortunately I don’t remember much about the specifics of this one.  Of course I started rating after I had it.  One of the best beers I’ve ever had.  I will update as I remember :-).

A truly amazing beer. Had on draft at Holy Grale. The aroma is nearly unsurpassedand very reminiscent of a chewy chocolate granola bar. The taste begins smooth, although the bourbon barrel aging does interrupt the smoothness somewhat. You get a little heat, though not much for 13%. Mouthfeel rather chewy. The tastes of the underlying stout and the barrel aging meld very very well.

Bottle 650ml vintage 2009 @ home

Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt. caramel, chocolate, coffee, smoke, vanilla, oak, coconut and bourbon. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long oak, vanilla and chocolate finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Had this on-tap at American Craft in Brookline today. Review from notes.

4.0 A: Pitch black. One finger of medium brown head. Average to good retention and some lacing.

4.5 S: Bourbon is strongest, but there’s a nice roasted barley component. Coffee and dark chocolate as well.

5.0 T: Bourbon is strongest again, but the other flavors have enough strength to create a great balance. Vanilla beans, coffee, sweet chocolate, some leather. Super complex and everything exists in harmony.

4.5 M: Lighter heavy body. Good carbonation. Creamy, but is missing that second layer of creaminess that would have made this brew perfect.

4.5 D: Excellent beer - even better on tap.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 06-30-2010 02:22:22
Has a heavy molasses and light chocolate flavor. Pours black with a consistancy of cough syrup. Beer has a medium malty flavor with a heavy chocolate and oak smooth finish.

This was my second bottle of BCS and I’m still just as impressed the second time around. In the glass sat a impenetrable dark black fortress which no light could penetrate. No head what so ever which was a little strange. Aroma was peaty scotch, chocolate, leather, tobacco, malt, vanilla, raisins, and a underlying booziness. Palate was exceptionally pleasing with a great texture and feel similar to an almost milkshake. It was very viscous and coated mouth and lingered pleasantly. The taste was very complex and layered with chocolate,vanilla, toffee, peat, coffee and a boozy warmth. This beer is and will continue to be a great. Awesome brew!!
Very strong alcohol, bourbon burn.  One beer for the night and done, strange, but still very good .
name "brand".chocolate, coffee, black, brown foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,

Labeled: "Bourbon county Brand Stout" 2008. Black and clear. Has a light-brown head, diminishing. Heavy malty aroma, dark, black, chocolate, coffee, port. Flavor is heavy sweet, moderate bitter finish. Syrupy texture.

Pours black, like oil; short, resilient, creamy brown head tops the glass off. Huge chocolate aroma, almost like cake, alongside roasted malts and ethanol. Very smoky, oaky bourbon smell. This is also quite noticeable in taste, along with a very rich, creamy dark chocolate. Thick and syrupy; the most viscous beer I’ve had to date. Warm alcohol sensations in mouth and throat. A great brew, just not an everyday beer.

On tap at the Village Tap House in Chicago: pours jet black with a dirty, brown head.nice lacing. toast, oak, sweet bourbon, cooking chocolate, molasses, subtle dates. Taste is big bourbon, dates, figs, raisin, vanilla. Has syrup characteristics with a smooth, drinkability that makes this scary good. Reminds me of an Irish car bomb shot... with a long, distinct finish. Outstanding.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Poured black colour with thin brown head. Aroma is vanilla, dark fruit, brown sugar and bourbon. Flavour is dark fruits, light vanilla and slightly burnt dark syrup sweetness. Very well balanced and smooth.

Tasted on 1/1/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Lush University Village, vintage 2006. Pours a super thick oil black with a thin light brown head that leaves a very thin collar of light brown lace. The nose is cocoa, coffee, vanilla and oak bourbon, some nutty oxidation, and a very light alcohol burn. The flavor starts off with the lightly sweet vanilla, cinnamon, and caramel bourbon, moving to chocolate, creamy coffee, molasses, and some nuttiness. The body is huge, thick, and viscous and sticky with very light carbonation, and a long bitter finish that also features flavors of coffee, bourbon, cinnamon, and vanilla.

2009 bottle courtesy of BarZigKin. Pours brownish-black with no head. Aroma is of alcohol, maple syrup, licorice, coffee liqueur and prunes. Reminds me of the aroma of the 2009 Utopias. It’s smooth with light carbonation and the flavor is sweet bourbon and prunes. Excellent!

Black opaque pour, makes a small dark brown head that dissipates  very quickly to a thin ring.  Big chocolate, vanilla, and bourbon aroma on it, touch of wood and soy sauce.  Slick viscous body on it and a very warming, but not harsh feel.  Not very carbonated, carbonation is on the light side and the beer doesn’t seem to suffer for that.  Chocolate brownie batter, vanilla, oak, and char on the flavor.  That whiff of soy sauce I smelled doesn’t seem to appear again when I sip it.  A beautiful little sipper of a beer.

Found on tap, this stout pours thick, almost black with a thin tan head.  The aroma of bourbon is evident from the moment the glass neared my nose.  The bourbon-barrel aging is again evident in the taste - a powerful, but not overpowering bourbon flavor is laced through each sip.  Overall a stellar stout made for sipping and enjoying.

Bourbon County Stout 2009 is a black beer with a weak and beautiful brown head. Aroma is strong, lots of roastiness and salt liquirice with some warming alcohol. A full bodied and really smooth and slippery to drink. Taste is complex, roasted, salt liquirice, some whiskey and maybe even rum, hint of dark chocolate and also warming alcohol without alcohol taste. Strong, warming and complex beer to enjoy at cold winter nights.

Notes from 09/2008. 2007 vintage.

Ineffably black. I can already tell this beer doesn’t mess around. Virtually no head. Just a thin, 1/3 cm film on the edge of the glass, like a contact lens on an eye. 

Smell is bourbon, vanilla, then some dark, sweet-smelling malts. Really can smell (burnt) caramel. This smells exceptional. Liquid caramel on the tongue. Wow. The bourbon is devastating. Great balance in the flavor profile. Perhaps the most complex American imperial stout I have had: chocolate, caramel, butterscotch, oak, vanilla, bourbon. Malts abound. Almost cloyingly sweet.

This feels great. Silky body that demands sipping. Thick and chewy. Probably, as the bottle suggests, would go well with a cigar. Not much on cigars myself, but I can only imagine. Low carbonation which translates into a sticky residual feeling in the mouth. Very nice.

I’m not sure what to say about drinkability. Yes, pick this one up if you can. But I can’t imagine having more than one of these in a night. I can barely sip it given its heaviness, boldness, and complexity. This is the bourbon stout to try.

***

2008 vintage. Sampled 11/2010. Even better.

Pours opaque black with a medium sized tan, quickly dimnishing head. Nose of chocolate, dark roasted malts and vanilla. Sweet flavour of roasted malts, bourbon, dark chocolate, vanilla and roasted coffee notes. Full bodied. Oily texture. More dry and notable malt bitter finish. A delikat and very complex brew.
Lots of bourbon and lots of malt.  Poured black no head.  Scent of wood, malt, caramel, and bourbon.  Great finish.  Damn this is a great stout.

Hvad skal jeg skrive andet en RIGTIG GOD øl.
Chokolade, lidt kaffe, Svesker,blomme, portvin, træ.
Sort, kort  skum. Sød, lidt bitter. Blød og sirupsagtig.

22 oz. as gift. This is a bourbon stout done right. Powerful bourbon aroma stays throughout. Started out a little chilled so taste was slightly muted until it warmed up. Booze, cough syrup, chocolate, espresso, cloves, a numerous other tastes I can’t place. This beer is big in every sense of the word. After half a glass my mouth feels like 7 AM in Vegas. Makes Bud Light seem like a silly drink in comparison.
Definitely not a normal imperial stout. Lots of roasted complex barley, bourbon, dark fruits, and cocoa. The blend of the bourbon blends very well and balances well with this beer.

Strong but pleasant whiskey aroma. Extremely smooth. Dark chocolate, whiskey, wood, everything delicious. The flavors develop in the mouth with a slight kick at the end. Only complaint (maybe) could be a slightly alcoholic aftertaste - but only slightly.

12 oz. Bottle.
Black/dark brown opaque, bit of brown head that sticks around. Very strong aroma of coffee, chocolate, bourbon, some dark fruit, light nutty, roasted malt, complex and very nice. Sweetness up front, malt on the palate, some vanilla, caramel, bit of smoke. Full bodied, alcohol bite, still smooth. Malty bourbon finish. Excellent, but had some trouble finishing the 6 ounces that I had after splitting a bottle with a friend.
Complex with an almost never ending cascade of ingredient notes...bourbon, vanilla, molases, coffee, dark chocolate, etc.  They just keep coming, wonderful!

This is great, one of the best examples of barrel aging I’ve had.  Pours very thick black with a tan head.  BIGGG bourbon notes to it...chocolate, vanilla, whisky aftertaste.  Lots of hops, coffee from the stout.  Stuff is a warm sipper, and tastes great.  The one I had aged a year, which worked pretty well.

22 oz. bottle, produced on 10/09/2009, sampled on 12/22/2010. 13% ABV. Opaque black liquid with a small, light brown head. Aroma of black licorice, smoke, and vanilla. It actually smells pretty strange, yet enticing. The flavor is intense, with sweet roasted malts and boozy bourbon in the foreground, and dark fruity notes in the background. Incredibly smooth and creamy mouthfeel. The high alcohol content is hidden beneath many layers of flavor. It improves as it warms. A very sophisticated brew.

Poured from a bottle. Pitch black with little to no head. Smells of bourbon/whiskey with a vanilla oak. The taste is boozy but there is a lot going on with chocolate, vanilla, herbs and coffee. This beer would be great when warmed up a little more too even though I left it out of the fridge for 20-30 minutes. Definitely a great beer I’d love to chill with a cigar.

Bottle, vintage 2009. Pours a pitch black motor oil with a porous light brown head that disappears quickly. Huge aroma of toffee, milk chocolate, liqueur, vanilla, some port, sweet, dark berries, some salt, and perhaps hints of smoke. Taste: chocolate mousse, liqueur, licorice, cream, vanilla, warming alcohol. The mouthfeel is incredible, so full, creamy and liqueur-ish. Heavy, complex but balanced, and very tasty.

2010 12oz. bottle. Strong sweet oaky bourbon smell.  Deep dark molassas brown, with little to no head.  Thick and viscous with a lingering palate of sweet oak, light soy flavor, a hint of chocolate, and a alcohol presence throughout.  Decent beer, but perhaps I need to hang onto the remaining bottles for a while and see how they are down the line.

Had on draft at the Good Pie in St. Louis. Pours very dark with strong hints of bourbon. Tastes of bourbon with hints of chocolate. Goes down very smooth  for how high in alcohol. overall A very excellent beer.
Seriously: dark, dense, complex, heavy, alcoholic, rich, long. Really, a beer that slaps you in the face with every sip—but with a beautiful, lingering velvet glove.

12 oz bottle, 2010 vintage. Pours out a thick black with a very thin brown head. Aroma is staggering: hazlenut, cream, coffee, oat, and smokey cheese smells all coated by an almost overpoweringly strong bourbon whiskey nose.

Taste is almost too complex for words. The bourbon presence is strong, but does not hide the other flavors this stout brings. Its almost a feast for your mouth: coffee, chocolates, roasted nuts, and smokey bacon all seem to be present in this beer. Its truly amazing. 

The alcohol provides plenty of heat, almost too much.
It took me an hour and a half to get through this beer and I enjoyed every minute of it. As the beer warms up, more flavors begin to show their colors and the beer becomes more enjoyable. I would serve this at 55F and let it warm up. Fantastic beer.

Re-rating for the highest ABV version yet. Fresh 2012 bottle, poured into a GI tulip. Big, hot bourbon, with roasted malts, dark chocolate, toffee, and char. Boozy taste, very warming mouthfeel, with a bit of vanilla, caramel, and again, just a kiss of cheesecake. Not quite as thick as recent years. Definitely glad I’ve got a few bottles to sit on, as this doesn’t seem to be quite prime, but still a helluva brew.
Very dark pour. Head dissipates quickly leaving just a gorgeous beer with just a bit of wood flavor at the end. Pairs very nicely with a dark chocolate truffle.

2008 vintage.  12oz bottle.  Pours syrupy black with no head.  Aroma is stong bourbon.  Taste?  Surprise, bourbon with some malt backbone.  I enjoy bourbon stouts, but this one is WAY too cloyingly sweet to enjoy.  I tried my 2010 vintage as well - no appreciable difference to the 2008.  Dumped half of each down the drain.  Not enough beer characteristics to by drinkable.

This stuff is great!  A great balance of malt and burbon.  Very clean beer.  Big alcohol burn but still balanced.  One of the best burbon beers.  First rated this on Dec. 5th, 2010.  Full malted nose, with deep dark chocolates mixed with bourbons.  Magnificent flavors of thick clean malts with bourbons, mixed with chocolates.  Finishes with alcohol burn.

Ok so I love beer and I love whiskey, yet this one does not work for me or most other beer lovers I know. Crazy beers are great when they actually taste good. This might honestly be better if it was in those weird little 7oz Corona bottles. This just has an insane amount of flavors that are way too overwhelming.

On tap at the Happy Gnome. Wow!!! Really, really smoky with a hint of vanilla in the aroma.  Very thick dark brown with minimal head that is all but gone in 10 minutes. Very thick and syrupy with a lot of lingering bourbon flavor. A little, very brief sparkling bitterness on the tongue and the rest goes down like bourbon coffee mousse.

12 oz bottle. Black color, low tan head. Complex sweet aroma with licorice, vanilla and wood. Full chocolaty flavor with juicy malts, some Jack Daniel’s -style vanilla and a warming finish. Full body, medium-light carbonation. This is a pretty great beer. Reminds me of Pesäpuu Stout, but is notably less sweet. Would buy again!

12 oz. bottle.  Pours jet black.  Could already smell the bourbon while pouring it.  Smells of bourbon(of course) alcohol and chocolate. Very strong, but not too strong.  Good burn.  Probably even better after a year or so.

Smells strongly of bourbon. Taste is chocolatey, bitter, coffee; very strong potent flavor. Sort of a milk chocolate at the front of the mouth and a dark chocolate at the back of the mouth. Very smooth. Not really my cup of tea, at least not tonight. If you want a beer aged in bourbon barrels, this is the one for you. Goose Island Night Stalker is better.
12oz bottle.  Vintage 2008.  Black pour, no head.  Aroma of bourbon soaked oak.  Vanilla, chocolate, cherry.  Big burn, long legs.  Smooth, sugary texture, lots of alcohol.  Nice roast.

Thanks to BarZigKin & DarkBeerChick for sharing this.  Pours thick and black with a noticeable caramel coloring on the sides of the glass.  It sticks to the sides of the glass like used motor oil.  Very pleasing alcoholic chocolate cherry cordial aroma. Some wood cedar and pine is also present as it warms up in the glass.  Flavor is an awesome sweet dark chocolate mixed along with some dried fruit and fruitcake.  Overall, this is definitely good for sipping.  Liqueur like.  I could totally see smoking a cigar to this.  Very nice. ..

Bottled on October 8, 2008.

G: Poured into an oversized snifter.

A: Motor-oil dark with a thin, quarter-finger head with minimal amounts of carbonation. The beer is completely opaque and near black.

S: Roasted malt and a lot of sweet chocolate scent. Minimal hints of dried fruits. Definite bourbon scent and hints of aged oak as well.

T: The taste is absolutely exquisite. Hints of the aforementioned oak, along with plenty of bourbon. Some chocolate and espresso hiding in the mix. The perfect balance and extremely complex--I would give this a 5.5 if I could.

M: Quite thick and extremely chewy. It really almost feels as if there’s food in my mouth. A true "motor oil" beer. Moderate amounts of carbonation. Strong alcohol presence.

D: Very, very drinkable. This is high in ABV, but I could drink these until I couldn’t drink any longer.
Poured from 12oz bottle.  Pours black with a dark tan head. Smell is very much bourbon and molasses and some chocolate.  Taste is heavy in bourbon and toffee.  Amazing.  Heavy in bourbon.  Wow.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Bottled on 10/09/09.  Pours black with thin light brown head. Big bourbon aroma with chocolate, vanilla and booze. Sweet chocolate and bourbon flavors with some vanilla, caramel and oak. Full body with minimal carbonation and a slick, creamy mouthfull. A great brew. Thanks Peter.

Wow.  This was truly a feat in fine craftsmanship.  This beer is truly one of the best I’ve ever had the pleasure of enjoying.  First of all, the aroma is amazing.  It was sweet like maple syrup and had hints of roasted almonds.  The taste is on another plane, unmatched by beer for mere mortals.  The stout definitely shown through, with its deep, roasted flavor.  However, the bourbon-aged barrels in which this beverage is brewed, leaves a taste that is a mix of vanilla, caramel and heaven.  This beer is incredible.

12oz bottle split with McBerko. I wanted to give it a perfect score, really I did...but IF I did doesn’t that mean that perfection has been found? And if so surely my quest is at an end? Ah well, it’s as close to perfection as I have come thus far...Dark black with a decent tan head. Boozy bourbon smell with some woodiness. Taste is thick and sticky with raisins, molasses, bourbon. Finish is warm with alcohol but in the best way possible. Like velvet going down. Exquisite and gone far, far too soon.

Bottle from 11.12.09, courtesy of Dan.  I’m so excited to finally have tasted this beer.  Pours thick and black, opaque, with a very small dark brown head that disappears quickly; thick and sticky, this beer has some legs on it.  Aromas of charred oak, vanilla, graham cracker, bitter cocoa, cherry, bourbon, buttery caramel, and slight marzipan.  Flavor is sweet milk chocolate and sugar cane, cherry, bitter roasted espresso, and cocoa.  The finish is mild, mellow oaky bourbon and caramel.  Warming, creamy, silky, buttery mouthfeel, with low carbonation and a dry finish.  Wow, this beer is amazing; I’m getting new flavors with every sip.  Absolutely awesome.   A million thanks to Dan for sharing this one!

Bottle: Pours black with thin tightly bound tiny tan bubbles for a head.  Smell is sweet and fresh with a hint of whiskey and caramel.  Taste?  Wow!  This is flavor packed!  Immediate tastes of brown sugar and molasses.  Those whiskey notes finally make an appearance in the finish.  This has a very thick and full mouth feel - almost the same viscosity as skim milk!  Oh man, I literally can not stop drinking this stuff.  I realize this is 13% ABV but it is so well hidden by the overwhelming flavor of the beer.  This is a ledgendary beer that just made my top 10 list.  I can’t rave about it enough!

Very strong scent of chocolate, coffee and roasted malt. Full-bodied and sweet taste of roasted malt, with clear aromas of coffee and cocoa, wonderful barrel aged, warm spicy hints of alcohol. Similar to coffee liqueur. If you have the opportunity to taste this one, don’t miss it! Incredibly tasty!

Bottle pours deep brown, almost black, with a beige head.  Aroma is sweet with notes of bourbon, oak, chocolate, dark fruit, and roasted malt.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of vanilla and a touch of soy.  It’s like fudge soaked in whiskey.  Overall body is full and viscous and finishes with some nice warming alc.  Good stuff.

12 oz. bottle from De Bierkoning at € 7,50 (and worth every cent!). Strong smells of bourbon, soy sauce and roast upon opening the bottle. Pours black. No head to speak of, but still enough carbonation. More aroma’s of bourbon, vanilla, soy sauce, alcohol, oak, and sweet fruit/raisins, beautifully balanced. Flavor is quite sweet with all the aroma components still there. Full bodied, almost syrupy. Alcohol warms the throat. Long finish, but no new aftertaste. I guess barrel aged (imperial) stouts are really my thing...Delicious

12 oz. bottle, pours black with a tiny head. Aroma of bourbon, peat, brown sugar and molasses - divine aroma. Flavour is so dense / complex, wth molasses, bourbon, oak, vanilla and caramel, with a little coffee on the finish. The 13% is worked in extremely well, with only a slight alcohol burn on the finish. Absolutely divine - beer in its highest form.

I’ve had this several times now, and can’t say enough good things about it.  I’ve had the 2008 batch aged close to a year and a half, the 2009 batch aged  a year, and the 2010 batch fresh.  This is an intense sipper, best with some age but perfectly enjoyable fresh.  Fresh, it is a little hot.  With some age,  the alcohol is present on the nose, but not as much as you’d think for a beer so strong. The bourbon and vanilla notes are off the charts, backed up by a ton of bittersweet chocolate and black coffee aroma. It’s opaque, dark as night, pours with an incredibly rich but small head.  It’s so thick that it pours and behaves as if it’s flat, but it has a surprising liveliness on the tongue.  It’s sweet, rich, savory, without crossing over too much into soy territory.  Just a phenomenal beer.

Bottle.

A - Pitch black color, no light getting through. Small, frothy, creamy, dark cafe colored head. Average retention leaving a ring of lace with some patchy lacing.

S - Wonderful aroma. Bourbon is strong and definitely present, but the more I smell, the more undertones I pick up. Strong roasted malt and barley. The more I smell, the more nice chocolate and fudge along with plenty of vanilla and some oak. Burnt caramel and molasses come out as well. Faint coffee and anise. After smelling this multiple times I keep liking it more and more so I ended up bumping up the score as it is boarderline perfect score.

T - Definitely a strong bourbon flavor (probably doesn’t hurt that this was bottled 20 days ago) gives this beer a kick. Some roasted barley, but nothing overly bitter or really roasted. Strong dark chocolate with a good amount of fudge like flavor. Definitely has an oaky and vanilla flavor, but no real smokiness. Slight burnt molasses and caramel provides a slight sweetness. Alcohol is definitely present, but that is to be expected given the freshness. It isn’t overly strong though.

M - Full body with average carbonation. Full, creamy feel with a slightly slick finish.

D - Definition of a sipper. That said, given the ABV and strong bourbon aspect, I would love to drink this again later (not right away obviously). Great mouthfeel and tasty and complex taste makes me crave more. Alcohol is strong (see sipper).

Notes: Vintage 2010 bottled on 10/15/10. Wonderful beer. Strong bourbon aspect. Glad I have four more to age and will add on to the review when I try this later. Quite an amazing beer. Bourbon and alcohol are strong but there are so many other flavors as well. Great beer and I am really excited to age this and try it later. Get this if you can, especially if you love whiskey, if you don’t you are likely not to enjoy this as much.

This beer had exceptional taste.  The chocolate and coffee mix masked all of the aspects of "beer taste" that I have otherwise previously not likely in beer.  This beer is the reason I am drinking beer today.

On tap at the brewpub on Clybourn. Black with a thin head. Aroma of bourbon, taste of bourbon and chocolate. Incredibly smooth for 13.5% abv. I’ve had all the heavily hyped stouts (dark lord, KBS, speedway stout, Stone, Ten FIDY, etc.), and this one stacks up well against them all. It’s probably my favorite of them all.
caramel, black, heavy cloying sweetness, full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish,

12oz bottle poured into snifter.  Aroma is of alcohol and sweet bourbon.  The appearance is pitch black, with a minimal brown head that dissipates quickly.  The taste is carmel and burnt malts with some smokiness and a coffee finish.  Definitely get nice sweet vanilla bourbon notes coming through.  Palate is heavy body with little carbonation.  Overall, a very nice stout with bourbon overtones.

12oz 2007 btl split with FunkyBrewster with one more in the cellar. Amazing super sweet oaky vanilla aroma and some toasted marshmellow. Pours super inky with barely any deep brown head. Taste is fantastic vanilla sweetness with some perfect bourbon spice. Great and warming with a long finish of wood and bourbon. Aptly described by my brother as "the blood of a chocolate snowman." Coats you mouth and leaves your whole body feeling great. My favorite drink to date.

33 cl bottle from 2008. The pour is all black with a head that has a lively fizzy attitude. Its dark brown and frothy at first but fades slowly. The nose has lots of vanilla up front from the bourbon barrels - but still it leaves room for a burned malty sweetness and faint citric side-notes. The nouthfeel is thick thick thick - almost like drinkin direktly from a bottle of soya. its thick but the taste backs up the palate. Again its vanilla reveales itselves first. After that a lot of nice stuff is going on. Smoky notes along with a deep malty sweetness that blends in nicely with the vanilla and some bitter coffee. The finish is long with a fine alcohol burn along with a mild sticky sweetness
Intense bourbon on the nose. Very creamy and thick. No sediment or lace. Smooth chocolate/espresso towards the end

2009 Vintage. Pours a one finger brown head that quickly fades to a ring, leaving traces of lace. Black color no highlights. Light carbonation and heavy bodied. Bourbon and alcohol nose. Flavor is bourbon, molasses and some alcohol. Pricey at $6.30 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

aroma- thick molasses, brown sugar, chocolate, dark caramel, roasted malt, cream, oak.  pours dark brown/black with a dark brown head.  taste is roasted malt, molasses, bourbon, alcohol, oak, cream, light vanilla, finish is dark chocolate espresso beans. palate is heavy and creamy, rich.

Bottle.  2009.  Pours a black body with a fizzy, soda like brown head.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, roasty, and high alcohol.  Taste is bittersweet chocolate, vanilla, oak, and bourbon.  Nice alcohol burn.  Complex and awesome.  Really opens up as it warms.
Had the Bourbon County Stout 2008. Thnx Caesar. Malty aroma. Flavor has some sweetness, bourbon, caramel, dark chocolate and nice malts. Pleasant.

Bottled, bought in the USA in 2008 as Bourbon County Brand Stout. Dark color, opaque. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolat, bourbon, hint of cookie, hint of licorice. Lovely thick roasted taste, dark chocolat all over the place but with a roasted edge. Absolutely tremendous!
2008. Aroma of licorice, molasses, bourbon. Pours opaque black, thin head. Quite sweet; licorice again. Heavy malt mouthfeel.

Original rating: March 07, 2011, but I had to re-rate for this important note since the vintages are quite different - this is the 2008 edition. Saved this one for my 600th rating, since it’s been a very long time since I’ve had such a divine brew on my hands. It is currently my favorite imperial stout, and as such I’m now introducing a new habit: re-rating my previous favorite down a notch to represent my current favorite. Gotta show who’s on top. Anyway, Goose Island Bourbon County Stout pours a pitch black body with no head worth mentioning, but the aroma omitted by this baby virtually engulfs half the room when the cork is popped. Enormous complexity, to the extent that aroma and taste kinda wander into each other as I sip my way carefully through the smooth, silky, rich palate. What do I have here? What do I NOT have here?? Vanilla, booze, maple syrup, oak, bourbon, coconut (deliciously integrated in the flavor), dark chocolate, toffee and hints of molasses, peanuts and burnt toast. Extremely rich and complex; the strong coconut/chocolate profile being really original. Well, at least I haven’t tasted it before and it just WORKS in this beer. Each sips leaves me with a burning desire to acquire an extra bottle of this stuff. I am blown away. Totally amazed. What a beersperience. Massive respect to the creators of this awe-inspiring brew.
Weird, a 2008 at a tasting and I just got a 2007 in a trade sitting at home! Rating the 2008. Bourbon, licorice and molasses. The booze keeps building with each sip. Big and boozy. Malty.

I purchased this at Archer Liquors in Chicago, IL, enjoying during Monday Night Football Packers vs. Bears game.  Chicago beer while watching the Chicago Bears...nothing is better!  (well, other things are probably better, but not right now at least).  Aroma is a fantastic balance of vanilla, bourbon, chocolate, and deliciousness.  Appearance is pure black with a thin brown head.  Taste is immensely and dangerously smooth for a 13% ABV beer, vanilla, chocolate, a touch of coffee, and a finish of bourbon that reminds you not to drink this so quickly.  I’ve had this at least 5 times and it’s consistently great, I’ve also tried many other bourbon stouts and this one is hands down one of the best.
2009 vintage.  Bourbon barrel aged with robust and strong flavors.  Dark pour with minimal foam head.  A strong stout throughout with earth tones and bourbon notes.  Sip and enjoy!

Bottle. 2008 vintage. Pours a nice dark brown thick color with a slight tan red that collars around the glass. Crazy aromas in the nose including coffee, dark bittersweet chocolate, vanilla, molasses, and the ever present bourbon and oak notes. The bourbon aroma is much more subdued now than in fresher batches. The taste is just as complex and rewarding as the aroma. Full heavy mouthfeel filled with bittersweet chocolate, coffee, and oak flavors. The bourbon makes a bigger appearance in the taste as it warms but still is not overpowering. The alcohol too is fairly well subued and is only really present when you really are looking for it. Just an outstanding beer that in my opinion is one of the best IS’s out there.

This pours heavy and black.  No head to speak of.  Cocoa, sweet, alcohol, raisins all come through in the nose.   No doubt about the alcohol in this one, it hits you right up front with a slight burn.  Rich and heavy,  Definitely one to sit back and sip on.   Bourbon is right, thickly sweet and slighly cloying.  Must be the right night to crack this open but for tonight, just too over the top with the alcohol for me.   A big ’bad’ brew if there ever was one.  Not to be rushed but savored for hours.
12 oz bottle noted as 2008.  Picked up from Whole Foods, UWS, NYC

Bomber. Dense, black beer that poured with very little head or visible carbonation, but a head slowly grew and settled on top after the pour was completed. Despite what looked like minimal carbonation, this one has nice, sharp little bubbles giving it a surprisingly fizzy feel for the style. HUGE nose of lots of chocolate and some bourbon soaked wood. The bourbon is apparent in the flavor, but not as overpowering as sometimes happens with this style. I still tasted a lot of nice roasted malts giving it strong dark chocolate flavors mixed with some sweet, flavored coffee. Finishes warming and leaves me wanting more.
650ml, 2010. On the nose, fresh-baked bread, chocolate, coffee, caramel, and of course Bourbon and oak. Dark.  Strong bourbon/coffee in the mouth. Truly delicious.

2009 ed. Pours from the bottle with a deep, dark brown that looks as black as any good imperial stout. It seems flat at first, but a thin creamy head of tiny tan bubbles developed at the end of the pour. The aroma is a potent combination of whiskey and dark chocolate. The flavor is more of the same, with rich dark chocolate filling the mouth at first, and the bourbon taking over in the finish. The texture is certainly mouth-filling, with a resinous, boozy stickiness that isn’t entirely enjoyable.

12oz bottle. Totally opaque black with a fairly small head, medium brown in color. Nose brings rich sweet mapley bourbon, molasses, vanilla, and a little bit of char. The flavor opens with rich sweet boozy chocolaty malt, then leads into big warming bourbon tones. The finish is tingly booze at the back of your palate. Boy, does it open up when you let it warm a bit. Has the kind of nose that could fill a room, honestly. Really a very impressive stout, especially considering that it’s pretty much the pioneer of its style. I can clearly see why craft beer drinkers hold this one in such respect.

2009 Bottle - Great aroma off the pour. Small dark brown head, with minimal carbonation in this jet black beast. Incredible taste; Very rich, sweet stout. Great bourbon flavors cut through the chocolate and coffee, with a smooth finish.

Bottle of the 2009 vintage. Like pouring midnight out of a bottle, barely a trace of light from the edge of the glass. Rich chocolate colored head. Aromas of intense (understatement) malt, toffee, molasses. Translates well into flavor with added coffee flavors and bitterness. A bit of alcohol burn (13%, what do you expect?)  A bit more carbonation than I expected, but it lightens what would otherwise probably sit heavily on the tongue.

Bottled. Thanks myself for sharing with myself. The power of the aroma compels me with strong notes of oak, vanilla, hot chocolate, burnt malt and even carpmino (liquid additive for carp fishing based on amino acids - produced by Kevin Nash)! The liquid is black as midnight on a moonless night ("Thats black" - Pete Martell). The taste is highly complex dominated by everything brown, black and burnt from the place we call ’Earth’ followed by a palate that’s close to unearthly. This beer is by far the best beer i’ve rated (although it doesn’t say much) and is certainly one of the best beers i’ve ever tasted!

"Forty six and 2 - just ahead of me".

Woooo doggy a nice deep black pour with a robust and lasting mocha brown head.  A totally pined secretly sweetened caramel chocolate topped vanilla wafer with chipotle dressing is waiting for the aroma.  Sweetly complex to taste and almost cloyingly so.  The buxom bourbon roastiness is offset by a murky knee deep backwoodsy floral pined burn.  Egad a lot going on to taste but left with a medicinal burn and a lingering caramel sugar sweetness.  Complex tasty, I wish I could say one was enough but I would be lying.  Niiiiiice
Super deep raisin. Rich woody bourbon very porty. Wowzer, maybe a bit much.

BCBS is an incredible beer.  It’s relatively easily available and puts many hyped beers to shame.  While it’s not quite the best barrel-aged stout in the country, it defines the sub-style for me (and, I assume, many others) and has held up very well against a horde of fancified newcomers.  The beer is jet black with a healthy brown head, when fresh.  The head is much smaller with older vintages.  The aroma is big and rich with flavor.  There’s a ton of bourbon, but it doesn’t drown out the dark malt and other barrel notes.  Coffee, chocolate, roast, vanilla and oak aromas blend almost perfectly with the bourbon.  The taste is strong and assertive but also smooth and luxurious, just as a big stout should be.  There’s a good deal of booze, but it’s a warming, pleasant presence and the beer is better for it.  Mouthfeel is smooth and full.  Not to take anything away from the base stout, but Goose Island is simply better at barrel-aging than the vast majority of breweries.  I don’t know if this is experience paying off or if Greg Hall is just a genius brewer who nailed it on his first try, but Goose Island BCS is a modern classic of American beer.

355 ml bottle, 2008 version. Rated on 26.6.2009.

Thick, oily texture with a small dark brown head. Very rich aroma with lots of licorice, alcohol, vanilla and wood. Licorice, roasted malts, oak and of course bourbon on the taste. Very thick and oily mouthfeel, full medium/full bodied and a warming mouthfeel. Excellent brew. 9-5-8-4-17 4.4



355 ml bottle. 2009 vintage. Rated on 07.12.2012.

Pours a pitch black colour with a beige head. Aroma is extremely rich with roasted malts, licorice, sweet bourbon and dark raisins. Flavour is very rich as well with roasted malts, sweet bourbon, oak, tar, chocolate, raisins and some very mellow honey-like notes. Very complex. Full bodied, rich mouthfeel and a rich, complex, malty and really flavourful finish where the bourbon smoothens nicely. Alcohol warms a bit. Extremely well balanced. Basically a beer geek’s milk. After three years this has improved a lot. 9-5-9-5-17 4.5

Aroma is Bourbon, milk chocolate and hazelnut; majority alcohol. Smoky lighter fluid. Jet black with a halo of brown around the rim. An oily feel with a charcoal burn. Nutty as hell on the front with dark chocolate and burnt cookies. Severe alcohol but a tremendous beer. Tremendous. .......
-
2013 version: I’d still like a little more head on top, but I do understand that it’s not the style.

The aroma is boozy as $*%@, followed by milk chocolate, oak, a touch of black licorice, charcoal and slight vanilla and sour cherry. The booze absolutely hovers above the glass. I seriously feel a little buzz just sniffing it.

Feels thick, viscous, & milky. It burns on the way down too, with an abundance of alcohol burning a scalding path to hell. It’s almost redundant to call this beer world class.

Pitch black pour with a brown head. Pure darkness. Aroma of dark chocolate, wood, fruits, definitely bourbon and maybe even some pear liqueur.
Strong taste of bourbon but still balanced. Also get licorice and burnt wood. Mouth feel is sticky and oily with a long dry finish. I really like that the bourbon is so prominent. Very tasty.

2006 bottle courtesy of brewengineer.  Jet black pour with a ring of brown head.  Nose is sweet and vanilla, and chocolate, and a tiny hint of alcohol fuesels.  Flavor is dark chocolate, marshmallows, dark rum soaked plums, Wonderfully chewy thick silky body. Fantastic.
I knew this would be a beer to be reckoned with as soon as I poured it. Sweet bourbon stout flavors, dark as night and packs a punch. Great to sip on.
Thin head, opaque almost black color.  Bourbon, vanilla, and raisin aromas.  Very boozy.  Full, sticky palate.  Great beer, I think this is a good example of the style.

no head at all (eh?!), but it is pitch, pitch black. like, blacker than a carload of assholes. smells like vanilla, smoke, wood, chocolate, some nuttiness and goddamn, booze. Oh, and licorice. Flavors really complex, like the smell - all of that brewing together, with malts and this incredible booze finish. I can see why some might be annoyed by the bourbon resemblances.... but I really like boozy, especially when paired with fragrant things like vanilla/smoke-y/licorice(--and i don’t think this has enough malty to make it beer and not bourbon). and i don’t even like licorice. Nice thick palate, smooth. God, loving the vanilla/chocolate/coffee and licorice-combination that just lingers at the end.

RE RE RE Rate. This is an average rating of all the ratings i’ve done on this beer. 

Pours pitch black with a tiny brown head,
Aroma of dark chocolate, sweet bourbon, darker sweet fruits, coffee, caramel, and vanilla. The sweet bourbon is just outstanding! Taste is sweet and add some more sweet bourbony warming alcohol along with roasted malts, molasses, coffee, vanilla, dark sweet fruits, and wood. As you sip on this, you almost get some port-wine notes out of it. Really a treat! Mouthfeel is thick and smooth. This is an all time classic sipper!

Poured from bomber, pours black as night with nice tan head, aroma explodes with bourbon and malt,  flavor is complex with bourbon, raisen, chocolate that has a burn of alcohol in the finish, one of my favorites!

Rated at Keystone Colorado, around 9.3K Meters above sea level.   Rated in  typical ski chalet glassware.   Dark, black, some reddish hues.  Little or no head.  What is presented, graces the rim of the glass and is a smoky tan color.  Aroma is of bourbon......deep turkey nasty southern bourbon.   Sipping lightly, it appears a though was a cheap mix of Jack D and a moderately acceptable stout.   (Baltic or Russian).   Finishes with a kentucky type palate....more bourbon than beer.  Hmm... why is this rated so high (ABV?)

Pours a dark dark black color.  Has a brown colored head.  The head is medium sized and slowly goes away.  Smells instantly of bourbon.  Smells also of chocolate, caramel, and vanilla creme.  I have heard great things about this beer so i am very excited to drink it.  Tastes instantly of bourbon.  Tastes of chocolate and vanilla.  Taste is very rich and delicious.  Aftertaste has the bourbon taste again which pops up in the palette.  I see why i heard such good things about this beer.
This beer is a great full-bodied stout. I could only have a few because it was so big and BLACK! but i really enjoyed it and would drink it again as a dessert to a meal of steak and spuds!

2009 vintage.  Pours black with a red hue.  Beautiful red-brown head.  Strong bourbon barrel aroma.  Also mocha, Kahlua, chocolate mousse - extremely inviting.  Prominent bourbon flavor up-front, but is not overbearing.  Flavor that follows is sweet molasses, mocha, chocolate, and vanilla hues.  Light carbonation that compliments the flavor.  Heavy on the palate.  Roasted malt flavor lingers, alcohol warmth.  This one definitely as good as everyone says.  A little sweet for me and almost has the qualities of a "dessert beer."  Re-rate:Big bourban, but ultimately a bit too sweet.  Great in 4-6oz quantities.  Reality rate -0.2.

Tasted a bomber bottle from the esteemed South Bay Drugs in San Diego, California.  Wow.  This stuff is amazingly rich and complex.  Pours black with a brown head.  Has an enormous chocolate and bourbon aroma; you can really smell the alcohol.  This is a dark, full-bodied beer that will definitely coat the side of a glass.  Very rich and complex flavors: dark fruity notes; malty, smooth chocolatiness, molasses flavors, and of course, lots of tingly bourbon...also has a lovely, long, smoky finish with a really great coffee aftertaste that lingers.  This stout should be savored and sipped from a snifter or tulip glass that will really concentrate those wonderful aromas.  It’s so rich--you might want to share the bottle with someone...otherwise you will likely find yourself either sipping on it all night (OK, this could be fun), or unable to finish the whole thing.  Regardless, this stout is awesome and I highly recommend it.

Poured black with a very thin brown head.  HUGE aroma of bourbon, oak, butterscotch, and chocolate.  Full bodied with flavors of bourbon, vanilla, and chocolate.  The complexity is incredible, the flavors unravel as this beer is tasted.  Upfront it is mostly bourbon, then it transitions to smokey oak and chocolate.  The finish is very smooth and sweet; huge butterscotch notes with vanilla.  Alcohol is hidden very well, but it is slightly noticeable in the finish.  An incredible beer.

Bottled @ Beer Temple, Amsterdam. The aroma has chocolate, coffee, some vanilla, wood, bourbon. Black coloured beer with a small, brown-beige and lasting head. The taste is sweet, slightly bitter. It has chocolate, coffee, some roast, vanilla, some dark fruits, bourbon. Slight alcohol burn. Bourbon is quite well present, but the beer is still well bodied and full of taste. Nice.

Bottle, 2009 Vintage: Poured Jet Black, with a modest tan head. Smells of Coffee, Vanilla, Chocolate, Oak, alcohol. Tastes sweet with light bitterness, flavors improve with warming. Full, Oily, bitter finish. Excellent Brew from Goose Island.
Rarely do I rate a beer perfect but this is amazing. Pours a deep brown and smells of maple syrup. Very comparable to a zhukov from cigar city. Rich and full of flavor.

Bottle, 355ml - Opaque black beer with almost no head. Aroma is malty with notes of chocolate, vanilla, dried fruit and sourish notes of vinegar. Flavor is malty with notes of dried fruit, vanilla and alcohol and dark dark chocolate. Fantastic beer.

"Darkness washed over the Dude - darker’n a black steer’s tookus on a moonless prairie night. There was no bottom."  That’s this beer.  Jet black with a blood-brown edging which pokes through a quickly diminishing walnut head.  Then there’s the aroma.  It’s there the second the cap lifts from the bottle and from the first it’s overwhelming.  The bourbon and oak are undeniable, as are the notes of vanilla and port.  Then come hefty butterscotch and liquorice chords which are raised on the backs of the bitterest coffee and the oldest, woodiest hops.  The 13% ABV only serves to impress the whiskey connection and makes this the most spirit like beer I’ve had.  But the booze isn’t the only thing to take one’s breath away.  The flavours are endlessly deep.  The vanilla comes on strong but peels back to reveal chocolate and ash, tobacco and leather; but there are subtleties to be found.  Aniseed and lemon grass are noted at the back of the palate, as are cherries and raisins.  There is too a certain soy sauce flavour reminiscent of the bolder Mikkeller beers.  This cuts an edge into the caramel, coffee and bourbon.  Mouth feel is very thick, velvety, but also strangely chalky - possibly due to the high ABV.  The finish is everything of the nose and taste slowly developing and finding a final unity right at the very end.  A stunning beer.  The Dude abides.

Small coarseish dark brown head. Opaque black body. Chocolatey toffee and alcohol aroma with syrupy almonds notes. Dry-sweet alcoholic chocolatey burnt taste with vanilla and whisky notes. Hot, sharp mouthfeel. Full-bodied. Dry-sweet roasty chocolatey whisky aftertaste with buttery vanilla fudge notes. It’s very good, but a bit dominated by the alcohol, and could use more complexity. (0.33l bottle, Fish and Beer, Copenhagen.)

Not much head tan in colour very dark stout aromas dark oak caramel soy vanilla liccorice smokeyness some chocolate cocoa flavour smooth caramel dark fruit raisin vanilla soy rich coffee taste of cigarette or cigar like in the mouth mild alcohol but the flavours knock most of the alcohol dry a good ibu great aftertaste of top maltiness dry good bitter wonderful hop

Black with no clarity that I could discern, just an abyss of bourbon delights. A dark espresso crema ringlet is all that remains of her previously tan head, though with a few exploratory swirls, she puffs back up rather nicely. Wham! That’s the sound of bourbon hitting me front-and-center. Mm… Revelatory. Intense is her name, and I am basking in the warm glow of bourbon, thick caramel, vanillin, wood tannins, melted bakers and milk chocolate, vanilla root, and burnt cream. Sweet dreams are made of these… Now, how about that seductive body to be found within? Full, intense, and rich. Eyes closed, I savor each microscopic iota of flavor as it caresses every open surface of my mouth and throat. The top of my tongue shivers under her boozy ministrations while licorice, bourbon, spice and tannins, prunes and dates dipped in melted chocolate, burnt caramel, and a flourish of wood in the finish seduce. A fireplace sipper if there ever were one; I feel the urge to double my pleasure as I soak in the warm glow of crackling embers with a glass of Bourbon County Stout and a snifter of bourbon, my choice. Espresso crema leads into a river of melted chocolates and caramel, while bourbon esters and spice linger in each breath. Fantastic, I lick lips wet with pleasurable satisfaction. Setting tasting pad and pen down, I revel in our final moments together.

All I can say about this one is WOW!  Motor oil black color with a dark brown head.  Aroma is FULL of bourbon, oak, whiskey, vanilla, chocolate, coffee, and even a little vanilla.  Flavor has all of these and when the stout starts to warm up the chocolate really comes through.  Has a bourbon and chocolate finish.  Very Impressive.

Black,fast fading brownn head.Complex bourbon roasty aloholic nose.Huge bodied sweet profile,medium alcohol heat,roasty,chewy. Anisette and brown sugar overtones
A well made beer, but one I don’t personally care much for.

2009 bomber thanks to fear025.  Shared the bomber with a friend who didn’t like it, so I took the whole thing to the face... great idea.  Poured pitch black and viscous into a snifter with a two finger dark tan/brown head.  Aroma was heaviest on the vanilla and also had woody/oak, bourbon, more vanilla, some butterscotch candy.  I loved sitting a smelling in between each sip... great aroma.  Taste was similar.  Coated the palate with a thick vanilla and bourbon smoothness/sweetness on top of the roasted malt character.  Very well balanced.  Perhaps just a touch heavy on the vanilla notes, but that didn’t really take away from the brew.

pours black as the blackest black, with a small reddish brown head that fades quickly.  gee golly jeepers, does that smell good!  i’m not generally a fan of bourbon barrel aged stouts, but this stuff is incredible.  rich, overpowering scent (the smell is wafting to my nose from three feet away) of roasted cocoa malt, with rich dark and toasted fruits, hints of butterscotch and wood, all blended together seamlessly, with none vying for dominance.  the first sip is grand!  a wonderful roasty character provides the foundation of the flavor, with hints of cocoa, molasses, and black cherries giving it the depth of a good stout, when a caramel, vanilla, woody bourbon flavor comes in on top of it all to really push it over the top.  wonderful, complex, exactly what i like in a stout, with a little bit of oak and bourbon thrown in.  perfect balance in the finish with the bitterness mostly masked by the light sweetness and huge warming pop that fills your mouth as the beer drains out of it.  a-plus-plus, or something.  maybe it’s just been too long since i’ve had a good stout, but this is really very good.

Move over KBS cuz GIBCS is the real deal.  This 08 vintage bottle relinquished a snifter of indian ink as black as Joan Jett’s chopped locks.  The sweet smell of bourbon and roasted malt rose up into the air to greet me.  This beer is thick and almost syrupy with taste of vanilla, sweet malt, bourbon, and coffee.....

Bottle. 2009 vintage drunk summer 2010. Pours black with a small light-tan head. Aroma of coffee, raising, toffee and burnt malts. Sweet and sour taste. Small level of carbonation. Not far off that 14 year old liquid-plum-pudding Westmalle Double from the Kulminator. Could leave this a few years to settle. Still great.

Bottle. Dark creamy stout with a bit of head, which doesn’t last. Aroma is malt, alcohol, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, herbs. Full body with low to no carbonation. Taste is warming, a strong bourbon/whiskey taste there, plus  chocolate coffee, malt, vanilla, alcohol, some fruits. It’s heavy when you drink it and it has a LONG after taste, which is delicious. A beer made for the long winter nights. Very interesting, one of the best I had, but unfortunately unavailable in Quebec...Dammit !

355ml bottle, 2009 and 13%.  P ours pitch black with a very small brown head.  Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, chocolate and alcohol.  Burnt sugar to start, then some caramel before a big bourbon and roasted malt finish.  Thick and warm throughout.  All I need now is a big cigar!

On tap at White Horse SW6. Jet black (like the night) in colour, with virtually no head. Nose; bourbon, oak barrels, vanilla, caramelised fruit and burnt sugar. Initial bourban hit, syrupy, roasted coffee, caramel, burnt sugar, medicinal with very long finish. Complex and best kept for a cold-winter night.

2008 vintage...

Super dark brown pour with virtually NO head. Intense aromas of malts and bourbon. Flavor is more of the same but magnified immensely and with a nice bit of vanilla coming through in the finish. The bourbon in this 2008 version has mellowed out a bit making it more drinkable (IMO) and very delicious. A bit sweet, very syrupy (but not overly so) this is a sipper for sure, but an excellent beer no matter how you look at it. I am admittedly not a huge fan of bourbon so when you factor that into the equation this stuff is fantastic.

Will definitely drink this again.

Mini-vert thanks to my gal pal allendodd!  Shared with family and friends.

2006 pours black, no head, thick and syrupy like oil.  Aroma of vanilla, smoke, some hops underneath, bourbon.  Flavor is nice, chocolate, smoke, some underlying hoppiness, bourbon.  Not overly alcoholic.  Syrupy mouthfeel.  Delightful.  Aroma 9, Appearance 3, Flavor 9, Palate 4, Overall 19.

2007 minimal head, pours pitch black... red tint in the light.  Slightly more foam, slightly more sugary and funky smelling.  Leather/saddle.  A lot sweeter than the 2006, a lot more alcohol, smoke.  More sherry flavors.  Thinner than the 2006, but still really good.  Aroma 9, Appearance 3, Flavor 8, Palate 3, overall 17.

2008 Pours black, no head, aroma of alcohol, smoke, vanilla, crystal malts? Really sweet, less sherry flavor, sweet dark maltiness.  Medium mouthfeel.  Aroma 9, appearance 3, flavor 9, palate 3, overall 18.

I like what age does to this beer.  Really good.  Thanks again Dodd.

2007 bottle. Thanks to wnoble for the brew. Pours a jet black with no head. Aroma is dark chocolate, bourbon and liquorish. Alcohol is prevalent. Taste is coffee and chocolate, awesome caramel candy bar taste. Just a fabulous taste. Palate is awesome with a heavy mouthfeel and a strong warming ability. Overall an awesome brew.

Dark, in an 8 oz glass.  Aroma of coffee and whiskey.  Taste of coffee, chocolate, and plenty of whiskey flavor and alcohol bite.  It’s really good, but I still can’t help but think it’s "cheating" a bit to mix and flavor with whiskey.  But it’s so good....

Bottle 2009 Edition.  Dark black beer with a light fairly brown head.  The aroma is quite deeply roasted with a port like feel, and the flavour is very rich, malty and fairly bitter.  Overall a nice very strongly flavoured beer.

7/20/10 Rating 3.9:  650 ML bottle of 2009 vintage weighs in at 13%. Pours inky brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Excellent rich, complex taste. Wow. I love this one. Notes of chocolate and oak aging with bourbon flavor. Tumbs way up. 

11/17/12 The 2012 vintage is listed at 15% ABV. Mine was bottled on 9/26/12, so it is pretty new. Excellent, rich aroma of oak, bourbon, malts,  and dark fruits. Taste is just about perfect: hints of chocolate, bourbon, oak, and vanilla. Long lasting palate. THis is truly a great beer. Thumbs WAY up. 

12/3/16 The 2016 vintage is excellent. I picked some up in Butte at Front Street Market in Butte, MT.

Smooth  power bomb, milk chocolate aromas, black as nite, no head or lacing, smells of sweet chocolate, full bodied,   after extra consideration; too strong, undrinkable, something went wrong, it was a 2009 bottle drunk in july 2010.  not sure what happened. 5th of 10 in Chicago.

2008 Edition

Pours a night sky black, just like the box says: a dark hole. I tried to get some head to come up on this beer, but not a lot. It is extremely thick.

Wow the smell is amazing; it literally made my mouth water. It smells similar to a chocolate covered banana, but packs a big bourbon flavor. Also, a sweet caramel, with a hint of vanilla.

First sip was a big wow. This one is definitely thick. Taste is a deep bourbon with roasted malts. The fruit also comes out and near the end there is a vanilla flavor.

Mouthfeel is very smooth and creamy. After it lingers around a while, the 13% comes out and is very overwhelming. Full bodied beer.

Overall, this was a monster. Amazing beer and well worth the $21 for the 4 pk. This beer took a while to finish. I highly recommend it to anyone.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-06-2008 03:03:32

Stouts for summer. Why not? While lots of folks are reaching for a pilsner or pale ale, I figured I’d go the opposite direction, drinking some stouts, which I usually prefer to have in the dead of winter. 

2007 vintage.  Oh baby.  Syrupy pour with very little head that bubbles a bit but otherwise is unimpressive.  Color is coal, pitch black.  Smell is bourbon, wood, chocolate syrup, roasted malt.  Promises to be a hefty beer.  Tastes amazing, with caramel, toffee, butterscotch, and roasted flavors.  Hefty mouthfeel, with the ABV really apparant in the body of the beer, along with the barrel aging.  This is a sipping beer.  There’s really no comparing this to anything else on the market.  It’s simply incredible.

Very strong bourbon taste with a tremendous amount of alcohol. It seems as if someone dumped out half a stout and filled the other half with bourbon..I love imperial stouts but this on nearly took my breath away.It was hard to drink but great at the same time.Very hard to explain how thats possible but it is trust me.

A: Pitch black body. Thin medium brown head. Little retention. No lacing. Was promising on first pour, but failed to deliver after a minute or so standing.

S: Mostly bourbon... some chocolate and vanilla.

T: Amped up bourbon flavor. Dark chocolate, roasted coffee, oak and vanilla accents. Alcohol was perceptible. Slightly better than the nose which was rather one dimensional. 

M: Thick, creamy. Strong, crisp finish.

O: Alcohol was a bit cloying toward the end. Overall, a solid beer, if not a bit over-rated.

On tap in a tulip.  Black with a very little head.  Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate.  Very sweet flavor of chocolate, and a lingering chocolate finish with some vanilla tones.  A little sweet for an imperial stout.  Still highly recommended.

12oz bottle a year later.  The bottle version has much more bourbon and oak in the aroma.  The flavor has more of a bite too and is not as sweet.  Still a sweet finish of chocolate though.  An incredible beer

2008 vintage thanks to jake65.  Bottled 10/28/08.  Thanks buddy!  I cannot believe this it a twist off.  Anyway it pours as black as Johnny Cash on a Sunday, BLACK.  Oily pour.  Zero head, shows almost no carbonation.  After taking a sip there isn’t much to speak of, very lightly carbed.  Aroma is huge.  Lots of bourbon, roasted malts, and vanilla sweetness.  Wow.  Taste is in your face bourbon, malty as hell with some sweetness although its subdued and perfect.  Awesome mouthfeel, about as full as it gets.  Flavors range from bourbon whiskey to figs to vanilla.  All over the place.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden, zero heat in the finish.  This is one for the cellar.  Don’t drink em fresh.  One of the best stouts I have come across.  A real winner.

World Cup Beer tasting at Lazy Boy Saloon Beer #9.  Wow this is a dark one like trying to look through jet black velvet.  taste is of intense coffee and vanilla.  really thick and heavy I actually think this 6oz pour was enough for the tim eof year.  maybe in winter i could handle more.  quite the experience.
To date the best stout I’ve tasted. Smooth goin down and a delight for the palate. The 13% isn’t even a factor, you only know because its advertised. This is a must try for all Stout lovers.

Tallahassee Tasting at Proof/Liquor Loft - 22 oz bomber. Dark black pour,mocha colored head. Buttery aroma. Flavor has some strong chocolate notes, a bit of coffee, bourbon comes through as well. Slightly salty and turns a bit cloying near the end. Thickish mouthfeel.
Aroma of bourbon and very complex. The flavor is also full of bourbon, but also alcohol and prunes. Great beer and I have one more in my cellar.

Bottle from Tiffany’s. Pours thick black brew, tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, bourbon, vanilla. Flavour of massive roasted malts, coffee, bourbon, licorice, cream, dark fruits. Oily texture. Delicious.
From 12oz,soy sauce,black in color,no head,chocolate,burbon taste,thick body,slicky texture,I loved this beer.

A very rich and boozy stout. VERY flavorful with not hints, but loads of bourbon flavor mixed with vanilla and molasses. It takes a little getting used to, but when you do, you will definately come back for more.

2009 bomber.  Pours like a can of WD-40, with the bourbon content readily apparent from first smell.  Harsh bourbon burn near the end of each sip is likely to ease with time -- looking forward to sampling another 2009 after another 6-12 months.  Though the high ABV is obvious from the smell and burn, sticking with this stout for several sips will pay dividends as your palate acclimates.  Try this excellent Goose offering in an extra wide snifter if you especially like the olfactory rush of an aromatic beer.

Another stunning beer. Sharing a bottle of this with my wife and wishing I was back in Chicago. Great city, great beers. I’m having withdrawl from all the excellent microbrews in the Windy City. This one is nicely decadent, and boozy. Bourbon, burnt wood, vanilla, and coffee on the nose. Very similar on the palate. Great weight in the mouth, and drying finish, without astringency. Delicious.

My favorite beer of all time, and has been for a year and a half.  Other beers I drink a case or two of, and it turns out I don’t like it as much anymore.  Not so with this beer!  Very complex, ages well, and tons of Bourbon flavor!  Other beers, like DarkLord, come close, but nothing beats this beer!
from a 12 oz black in color smell of soy sauce but the taste is really strong and it sits on the palate for a long time so its worth it!

Bottle, tfs Vaiz!! Deep solid black, creamy small dark brown head. Massive aroma with peat, bourbon, dark chocolate, liquorice, coffee, spices, molasses, fruits and lots more. Wow. Flavour is subtle bitterness with coffee, peat, liquorice and bourbon and extreme sweetness with liquorice, dark chocolate, bourbon, caramel, vanilla. Sweetness fades quickly leaving a mild bitterness with some warming alcohol notes.
Very thick, sticky, syrupy palate. This must have at least 1000 calories.
Overall it could be better balanced, now it’s too sweet imho, but still very awesome.

(12 oz bottle). Note: this was left to room temperature.   Pours black with caramel colored head. Very small carbonation bubbles are visible when held up to the light.  Aroma of coffee, molasses, and bourbon.  Taste is sublimely sweet with vanilla being quite noticeable and even some coconut.  Full bodied with creamy texture.  There is a noticeable burn on the tongue from the alcohol.  The finish is smooth and keeps going.  Brilliant!

Bottle. Pitch black pour, thin creamy tan head. Very strong aroma is instantly airborne as soon as we start the pour. Loads of leather, plum, oak, vanilla, butter and caramel. Very intense, satisfying and balanced. Flavor is very intense, bitter pure chocolate, strong coffee with cream, hints of peaty bourbon with a slight sweet fruityness. All in a very nice balance. Quite buttery diacetyl side taste, but still a really amazing brew. Low carbonation, texture of pure cream. Amazing.
The first sip is almost over whelming, one almost feels smacked in the face with bold and delicious flavours. Some taste notes: oak, vanilla, toffee, chocolate, coffee, and malty

Pours out black with some foam. Smells like vanilla bourbon oak. Taste is sweet roasty boozey. Big flavors of vanilla, bourbon, oak,  and some liquorice, caramel, coffee, smoke, and dark fruits. Smooth and balanced with warm finish. Great stuff!

Tasted 2010-06-10. 2008 version. Pours oily black with copper brown head. Aroma of boubon, wood, alcohol, coffee and liquorice. Tongue burning stuff. Bourbon dominates big time. Not much bitterness. Some liqourice sweetness lingers for a long time. It’s very drinkable for an ABV like that. After the first few sips, I brought out some sweet liqourice to go with it. That is highly recommendable.

22 oz bottle Premier Gourmet Buffalo. Motor oil black in color quick milky/fizzy head. Big aromas of smoke, light whiskey, slight vanilla, chocolate, burnt caramel. HUGE flavors of smoked caramel, burnt chocolate, slight vanilla. Sweet, smoky, robust, smoked aftertaste, balanced, complex, amazing, thick mouth feel. If there ever was a Stout I could never get sick of it would be this one. One of the most amazing Imperial stouts I’ve tried thus far. The most memorable stout since the alesmith speedway stout. Such an astounding balance of sweet meets smoke meets complexity. A milestone above stouts.

Bottle.  Nose is vanilla and can taste the vanilla as well.  Taste is chocolate with warming alcohol notes, slight alcohol burn and is mildly roasty.  Completely black with great overall color.  The sweetness and complexity of the bourbon really comes through.  I tried this beer in April, I think it would be much more suited for the cold winter months.

From bottle@CBF 2010. Ruddy choco head. Pitch black body. 
Intense aroma of oak and hard roasted malts. Bourbon, coffe ground and dark dried fruits too. Big malt body. Lots of roastedness and some peppery caramel notes.  Very hot, vinous and oaky, with distinct bourbon tones. Fat body. Juicy texture. Bitterness reveals in the finish. A lot of everyhing here, extremely powerfull. Sipper’s delight.

Pours oily, dark brown and with a miniman tan head. Intense aroma is well balanced with vanilla and other bourboun notes, salty licorice and a huge amount of syrupy maltiness. Deeply chocolatey, coffeyish and slihgtly tar-like in the finish. Teh alcohol gives warmt but does not taste. Though sweet, it is somehow very well balanced with all the chocolate and barrel flavors. Maybe it is that light bitterning hoppiness in the finish? Anyway, the best IS that I’ve encountered by now.

Bottle @ CBF 2010 courtesy of PJClarke. Pours black with a small creamy light brown head that leaves a fair lacing. A rich and inviting aroma. Alcoholic fumes along with dark dried fruits and bourbon. Drinks sweet, acidic, alcoholic, and bitter bringing out even more dried fruits and roasted malts. Full bodied and oily.

Pours black with minimal brown head.  Smell is ridiculous: Vanilla, Coffee, Chocolate, all super-intense!  The taste is the same with a surprising amount of vanilla.  Overbearing, too thick, and while it is tasty, it’s difficult to drink.

Bottled. A black beer with a small beige head. Aroma is roasted malt and smoke, notes of chocolate, caramel and alcohol. Strong roasted malt taste. Notes of vanilla, wood, chocolate, licorice. Burning alcohol finish. Milky texture. Full body. Very complex beer

root beer, coffee, sugar aromas. not sure I’ve seen a darker head. flavors of molasses, vanilla, bourbon almost too sweet, the beer that seems most appropriate to pour on vanilla ice cream. the alcohol almost hidden. sticky finish. has no edge to it, no roast grumble, no sneaky hop rasp, This maybe my 4th Goose Island brew and I’m underwhelmed. At least i got this for half price at the local Fred Meyers.

Bottle.  Black with a beige foam.  Aromas are coffee, blackberry and yeast with whisky barrel oak.  Cream, marzipan and vanilla with peppery spices.  Leather and tobacco notes with citrus and herbal notes.  Soy sauce with oily margarine.  Flavours are deep roast malts with dark chocolate bitterness.  Quite fruity with blackberry and cherry.  Liquorice with peppery, warming alcohol.  Lots of marzipan sweetness with a dry very peppery, alcohol burn finish.  Imbibed in celebration of a Leicester Tigers final win - so tastes even sweeter.  A very good beer.

Now this is a bourbon barrel aged beer! Oak, bourbon, vanilla, burnt toast, roasted caramel, toffee, fig, coffee, cocoa, with a big hop balance. Black as black can be! Hints of alcohol, but in a way that a bourbon lover like myself can truly enjoy. Almost no head. Just fantastic!

2008 vintage. Bottle thanks to Rando7. Pours an oily jet black with no head. Nose is vanilla, muted bourbon, wood, brown sugar, molasses and toffee. Taste is very smooth chocolate, warming alcohol (no burn), vanilla bean, coffee, burnt caramel and butterscotch. Has the mouth feel of an old ale.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Pours pitch black with a small tan head and a sweet aroma of cherries, caramel, roasted malts and cream. The taste is sweet, with notes of sweet malts, milk chocolate, cappuccino, coconuts, cream, dried fruits, toffee and alcohol. The finish is sweet and sticky too. This beer is really complex, but I’m not totally excited about it. It’s pretty complex, but too sweet and there’s something unpleasant about the sweetness.

355 ml bottle. Deep dark brown, nearly black, with a thin brown head. Impressive and complex aroma of liquorice, roasted malts, vanilla, chocolate, oak and bourbon. The flavour begins sweet, with liquorice, bourbon and vanilla, and turns more roasted, coffee-like and fruity (raisins etc) towards the finish. The aftertaste is again sweeter, bourbon-like, warm and slightly bitter. Complex and delicious, definitely one of the best beers I’ve tasted.

Bottle shared by Tim, thank again 

Appearance: Pours black with no head, legs on the side of the glass 

Aroma: Bourbon, vanilla and chocolate 

Taste: Smooth mouthfeel. Bourbon, dark chocolates and vanilla 

Very nice Imperial stout.

2008 Vintage.  Pours a dark black color with an extremely thin caramel colored head.  Has an aroma of liqourice and dark fruit, with a hint of chocolate.  The booze comes through on the aroma.  Wonderful taste.  Is a bit booze, some further aging should help smooth this out.  But I can already taste that time has worked well on this brew.  Sweet chocolaty up front, then the bite of alcohol, dark fruit and more chocolate with some subtle bitters on the finish.  Very complex.  Has a creaminess to it.  Will age this another year and try again.  Can’t wait.  Better than its famed coffee stout brethren IMO.

2009 vintage.  Pours with virtually no head; the first time I drank it I thought I had a bad bottle.  A spare, tan head forms later, parsimoniously lacing the sides of my dimple mug.  The color is about as opaque and dark brown as one can imagine.  The malt aroma is rich and dark, and hints at but comes nowhere near to foreshadowing the complexity of the taste.  And what taste:  sweet, thick and creamy liquor carries boldly intermingled flavors of prune, chocolate, coffee, raisin and caramel.  As the stout warms hints of yeast and bread are clearly evident.  This is probably the best beer I’ve ever had and worth every penny even at $21 a 4-pack.

2008 Black of color with a small fast disappering brown head. An aroma of liqurice, chocolate, roasted malt. A flavor of liqurice, sweets, dark fruits, weak chocolate. and a weak alcohol burn. An oily texture.

2008 vintage Opaque black pour with a small, brown diminishing head. Aroma has a lot of wood, bourbon, vanilla, booze, dark berries, little roast, coffee, hints of smoke. Taste has coffee, roast, vanilla, bourbon, wood, oak, large, but nice sweetness, chocolate. Very balanced and a fair drinkability, oily texture, high viscosity, big body. (9-4-9-5-17 = 4.4)  Re-rate 2009 vintage  The booze is all over this vintage, messing up the balance I got from the 08. Both taste and aroma is hugely over the top with alcohol and bourbon, and the complexity suffers from the booze. (7-3-7-4-15=3.6) Current score is an average of the two ratings.

2009 vintage poured into snifter. Dark brown/black color with almost non-existant tan head. Aroma is overwhemingly burboun with a hint of chocolate and malt. Flavor is equally overhwelming of burboun, with some chocolate, vanilla, caramel, and roasted malt. A nice stout, did not live up to the hype, but tasty nonetheless.

Bottle.  Pours black with almost no head.  Nose is heavy on the bourbon with vanilla, oak, dark malt, alcohol.  Very full-bodied.  Sweet with more bourbon, well-balanced with the usual impy roastiness and some coffee, alcohol.  Finishes long, slightly bitter, more bourbon, caramel.  A great beer to sip on.

Probably my favorite beer so the rating is partial.  

Apparently forged with equal parts crack and heaven, this is an excellent stout.  Pours thick and black with a bit of tan head.  Thick and complex; great roasty, vanilla aroma which carries through in the flavor  with some caramel.
Dark brown with a medium brown head. Fruity and malty. Roasted, wood, fruit and vanilla. Full body with a long sweet and bitter aftertaste.

2008. 12oz at Toad in the Hole. Black with slight, low tan head; no lace. Aroma of black licorice, hazelnut, chocolate, and booze. Before flavors register, the fullness of the doublewide body fills the palate. Restrained carbonation lends an assist to bright, spicy hop undertone. I feel like a bit of a Ratebeer weenie giving high marks to another giant barrel-aged impy stout, but it’s truly a remarkable beverage.

Had from bottle at The Bruery.  Pours dark brown / black with no head and slight lacing around the edges.  Aroma of heavy bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, and alcohol.  The flavors are the same - lots of bourbon, fig sweetness, chocolate, coffee and a well-masked alcohol.  Finishes sugary sweet with coffee and smoke undertones.  Very viscous with great aftertaste.  Maybe needs a bit longer to mellow and blend, but still a very good stout with lots of wonderful flavors.
The only major draw back to me is the strong alcohol aroma before you drink it.

12oz bottle, 2007 vintage. Pours slick black with almost no head whatsoever. Aroma is of vanilla and bourbon, flavor is similar, also containing chocolate and soy. Mouthfeel is thick and oily. Huge beer.

In a word - WHOA!  This is, in a lot of ways, what I expected, and not what I expected in other ways.  It poured black with a very small tannish head that lasted for maybe a minute or so.  The smell was dominated by bourbon and chocolate, but other subtle odors came through.  The first smell gave me the "whiskey shudders."  The taste was very complex, which I expected, and tasted like a milkshake for grown-ups in ways.  There was a heavy flavor of both chocolate and bourbon, with charred oak and most of the other flavors others have described.  You can tell there is alcohol in here, but it’s not nearly as powerful as I would expect.  There is a little burn after a few sips, mostly on the tip of the tongue and the back of the mouth. It went down much smoother than I thought it would.   I wish this beer had been around when I was in college and that I would have had the funds for it.  It would be a great warm up on a night you feel the urge for a few drinks of whiskey.  I will be picking some up soon to age.  I think I will buy a 4 pk and have one each year to see how it comes along.

Bottle - 2007 (Aged 2 years). Pours black with next to no carbonation. Lots of mollasses and chocolate on the nose. The taste is complex to say the least- mollasses, chocolate, licorice, soy sauce, coffee, and a hint of alcohol. Mouthfeel is nothing but oil.

Bottle - 2009. Pours Black with a thin, wispy head. Mollasses and alcohol dominate the aroma. Loads of chocolate and alchohol flavor with hints of toffee, soy sauce, and coffee. Mouthfeel is extremely oily but creamy.

(Old BA rate - bottle, 2007 vintage cellared for one year and consumed in 2008)
Jet black color with a tan/caramel head. Surprising lacing for the style
 Bourbon right up front, but not overwhelming. Hints of smokiness and bitter chocolate. Bourbon/whiskey is predominant, but not a strong taste of alcohol. Bittersweet chocolate notes, and not as smoky as I got in the nose. Medium weight in the mouth, but smooth, rich and a little viscous. Very easy given the complexity and depth of this brew! Overall, I’m sure that this sample wasn’t cellared in the best way possible, but I still thought this was fantastic.
The bourbon-y sweetness can sometimes really pop out on this one, I think it’s best with a bit of age on it.  Just recently did an epic with 05 - 09 and it only got better as it aged.

2009 Bottle Deep black pour tan head aroma of smokey bourbon oak and sweet caramel malts .... tastes the same smoke bourbon oak, sweet caramel and vanilla bean .... bitter finish oily mouthfeel .... tons of flavor here 13% abv ... a beer to sip and enjoy

Pours out an oily black. Viscuous and thick with a small tannish head that lingers like an invited guest. Smell is smoky and rich, chocolate and molasses in there somewhere. Taste is exquisite, malt and chocolate in the vanguard; a warming transcendant alcohol presence is in the air. And yes, somewhere in the aroma is a touch of bourbon itself along with some vanilla overtones from the oak and some caramel presence as well. Mouthfeel is amazingly rich..
