I don’t want this sip to end. Quite simply one of the best things I have ever tasted.
Bottle: Opaque black brew with an beige foamy head. Very flowery, vanilla and caramel taste with an bourbon appearance.

Strong vanilla, coffee, caramel, and bourbon flavors.  Thicker than oil, with a nearly invisible (against the darkness of the beer) brown head.  Vanilla bean and alcohol are the finishing tastes.  Very complex, very delicious.
Black. Quite a spicy scent. Some berries in the nose. Thick. Mouth is cream, coffee, berries. Quite malty with an alcohol kick.

Aromas of vanilla, oak, coffee, bourbon, etc...a powerful aroma to say the least. The appearance is black as night, with a small brown head which quickly dissolves. A ton of coffee, sugar, alcohol with a A, and smoked wood on the palate. A sickly overpowering experience. This one kicked my ass, I wasn’t ready for it.

Thanks to Elric73 for this one! Great trader! 2006 BCS poured into my snifter.

A-Body is a viscous motor oil black that pours with an approximately 1/2 finger foamy cocoa brown head. Head subsides slowly to a thin collar and no lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Nose is robust and complex. The sweetness and astringency of bourbon comes through first with a big, thick, robust chocolate malt backbone.

T- The taste is very similar to the smell. The bourbon character balances with the roasted chocolate malt and hints of toffee also come through. The flavor is sweeter than most stouts I have had but it adds a nice touch. The flavors remain balanced but intensify for the finish. An alcohol warmth lingers also.

P- Nice, thick, vicious, warm mouthfeel with low to medium carbonation.

O- This was 13%? wow. did not realize that. Definitely an imperial stout but I would have guessed 9%. This one ages nicely and is very tasty. I would love to have it again! Thanks for the trade and the extra bottle!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-21-2008 02:37:19

opaque black, thin brown head, very thick and syrupy full body.



aroma: sweet vanilla oak, chocolate malt, alcohol, (no char, burnt, or hops).



taste:

T1= lots of vanilla oak, chocolate malt, co2.

T2= lots more vanilla oak, rich chocolate malt (but not roast, charred, or charcoal).

T3= sticky, alcohol warmth, slight bitterness (does not come across as alpha acids, burnt, or astringent. i don’t know what it is, except maybe a perfect balance of 2 or 3 of those).



a sipper for sure.  too much oak for me (not quite as bad as N.H. Dragon’s Milk, but close).

At a tasting, many thanks zvikar, opaque black colour, aroma of bourbon racing out of the bottle, behind it fruit compote, mild coffee, a touch charred wood, cocoa and vanila, flavours of sweet coconut and milk and dark chocolate, alcohol coming in the back and becoming stronger, also some cinamon, dried fruits and halva (sweet seasame paste) creeping in, relativly short sweet and sour aftertaste. Excellent original stout.

re-rate 04/14   2012 version bottled 9/26/12.      my original rate was a 2.3 due to bourbon taking over aspect of this beer.  much less bourbon aroma after 1.5 years of agin - actually not much aroma at all.   taste still has bourbon and also sweetness and fudge.  sweetness lingered for an hour after I was done.  much better than 2.3 rating but  not as high as most others have rated this.  I feel the 13%...      App - black oil little to no head.  Aroma - bourbon, taste - bourbon.   There was possibly other things happening but the bourbon aroma and flavor was so overpowering that is all I got.  I don’t get it - why not just have a bourbon, didn’t really taste/feel like beer.

Pours dark black and oily with a fizzy light brown head which dissipates.  In the nose is caramel, vanilla, oak, chocolate notes, dark fruit, and alcohol. The palate is slick and oily with a tickle of carbonation. It’s full-bodied with a long lasting finish. The taste is sweet with caramel and vanilla and finishes with an onset of alcohol warmth and a puckering bitterness of dark chocolate and espresso. This is a fantastic sipper with a lot of complexity.

Bottle at a tasting: that’s a great one, lots of bourbon, oaky, vanilla, fruity, roasted malt, dried fruits, milk chocolate, dark chocolate, coconut cookies, chocolate cake, molasses, wood, alcohol, full bodied a thick, a decedent imperial stout with a qualities of bourdon and barley wine, great.
To me this beer is nearly perfect,  I had the 2008 and 2009, and they were both remarkable beers.  I have a few in the cellar waiting for something special.

330cl 2009 bottle into a snifter. Pours jet black with a minimal head, and instantly announces its arrival with a strong waft of bourbon even before you get your nose stuck right into the glass. Tremendously strong aroma of bourbon, wood, coffee and bitter chocolate. Tastes as good as it smells with a somewhat heavy treacle finish on your tongue. This is a very good beer indeed, but watch for the strength. If you didn’t know it was 13% you’d probably guess 8% as it hides it well. I have a larger bottle which I’ll likely cellar for a year or so before cracking open.

This one is big and heavy, so much so that I had to take a bite of food after most every sip. The color is dark black, and thick, with a black foam head. The aroma is smokey with vanilla, chocolate and coffee notes. The ABV is only 13% but it feels really big.

2008 bottle from KnB. Pours black with no head and only a few bubbles. Looks like a flat coke. Aroma is bourbon dominated, but very nice. Flavor is wonderful combination of bitter chocolate and bourbon. Finishes pretty darn hot and boozy.

12 oz. pour from bottle obtained from BarZigKin in trade.  Bottom of a well dark.  Nose has hints of licorice, smoked wood and whiskey.  Taste is woody with hints of bourbon.  Small bite at the finish, without being overpowering.  Good stuff.

Roasted malts with vanilla and hints of bourbon on the nose.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Rich, thick, roasted malts, dark bitter chocolate with vanilla and bourbon, smooth oak flavors, hints of charcoal/smoke, with a sweet finish.  Excellent.

I’m not as big a fan of BCS as many other. I do beleiev Goose Island does a nice job of balancing the high alcohol in the flavor to compliment the vanilla and malt, but the bourbon is sooo heavy and the body is almost too thick. I believe this is a masterful beer- It’s just not my favorite. My inlaws and I had a competition of stouts and porters and this took second out of 32.

2009 bottle from VBS.  Nose is full of burnt molasses, bourbon, and maybe even some figs.  Motor oil black with a dark tan head that was gone in about ten seconds.  Sweet and syrupy, and liberal amount of heat from the bourbon.  Very smooth and almost silky as it rolls across the tongue.  This is a definite favorite of mine and it’s interesting to see the changes it goes through from year to year.

Poured ink/black with a 1.5 inch thick, dark tan head, that dissipates with an obvious crackling.  My glass is beer clean! The initial nose suggests smoke, bourbon and wet wood.  Medium high, silky body with extensive lingering and delicious hints of chocolate, coffee, dark caramel and bourbon-macerated dried figs.  The lace is mostly absent, excepting a few clusters of small spots that slide into into the stout.  Density is high!  The alcohol is evident and warming.  I imagine it would be excellent in a snifter. Drink with care and devotion.  The subsequent nose reminds me of Gethsemane Chocolate Bourbon Fudge. Although it is a warm spring day outside, the Bourbon County Brand Stout makes me think of winter and roaring fires.

2008 Bottle from my friend Greg’s collection that he and I split. Thanks bro. Pours black as the ace of spades with little to no head and a boozy sweet nose. First sip is pure heaven with coco sweet flavors along with brown sugar, leather, slight tobacco, roasted malt, bourbon, licorice, prunes raisins and oak. Finishes perfectly.

It pours as Black as oil that hasn’t been changed since the 80’s. Smells great with notes of fruit malt and a lot of booze. Flavour is great, malty, and fruity you can really taste the barrel of this beer I get some vanilla likely from the barrell. However it is very boozy and that kind of detracts from the flavour in my opinion.

Bomber. Black with small brown head that disappears. Aroma of sweet melted milk chocolate and vanilla extract mixed with sugar and milk, also light roast and noticeable whiskey. Taste is sweet chocolate syrup with whiskey flavors on the back end. More of a darker roasted chocolate. Oily and full bodied, sticky on the lips. Finish is medium bitter with light whiskey burn/bite.

Pours pitch black with small brown head; nutty sherry-like aroma of dried fruits, oak and hints of vanill; quite full-bodied with smooth, almost chewy texture; slightly hot on the palate, the flavor also has strong sherry notes, of dried fruits, almonds, hints of vanill and oak; sherry feel lasts long in the aftertaste, but is rivaled by (though somewhat lesser) whisky notes with hints of smoke.

2008 Bottle. Pours syrupy with a black tar color and a tiny layer of brown head. Powerful aroma of bourbon, smoke and caramel. Taste begins with an incredibly thick dark chocolate fudge and bourbon flavor followed by roasted malt, caramel, espresso and vanilla. Finish is creamy and slightly smoky with a warm alcohol burn. There’s a pleasantly smooth and sticky bourbon aftertaste. It’s got a wonderfully sweet and complex character to it with insanely rich bourbon chocolate flavors that coat your throat and warm your belly. It’s like eating a piece of fudge and chasing it with a shot of bourbon. A beast of an Imperial Stout.

22 oz bottle poured into standard pint glasst. Pours jet black with medium tan head. Smells of oak, bourbon and smokey malt. Taste is of molasses, vanilla and bourbon. Excellent beer hides the 13% extremely well.

The smell hits you right at the pour.  No need to raise the glass to your nose, but when you do... you’ll be overwhelmed with smoke, caramel, chocolate waves that are intense for a brew.  I’m glad I had a drinking partner this night.  About 6oz is all one needs to enjoy of this at a sitting.

Bottled 11/12/09 Dark balck pour with a dark brown head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, and wood. After the first sip, I have come to the conclusion that I have "sinned" for, even though this is a local available beer, I have not tried it earlier.The taste is bourbon, chewy, vanilla, oak, chocolate. The alcohol is noticeable, but not overpowering. Tye flavor sticks to your tongue, the sides of your mouth, even your uvula. If you swirl it in a snifter, you see it has legs just as a great whisky does. Forgive me G.I. for not trying this sooner and passing along the praises this beer rightfully deserves.  Bought a 2008- Same great taste as 2009, flavors have mellowed, but it still really kicks. It leaves such a great aftertaste. Great beer.

12 oz. bottled 21 Oct 08.  Opaque dark black with a light brown head.  Very sweet chocolate, coffee, caramel, and alcohol aroma.  Flavor folows suit with the addition of a strong coconut flavor.  Strong alcohol on the finish.  Thick mouthfeel.  This is a really big beer, but still very enjoyable.

650 mL bottle.  (bottled Dec 18, 2009).  Black, with just a film of brown head.  The aroma is decadent: vanilla, roast, coconut, smoke, alcohol, burnt caramel.  The flavour is the same, with the addition of a large amount of chocolate.  The flavour goes on and on, long after you’ve put the snifter down.  Full body.  Huge.  Some alcohol burn, but this is a very young beer.  Wow.  Can’t wait to taste one that’s been cellared a year or two.
Super thick and syrapy.  Dark chocolaty smell.  A little vanilla which works well with ice cream and other sweets!

Pours pitch black with a brown head.  Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, black licorice, and slight alcohol.  Flavor is sweet and a little boozy.  Tastes of chocolate and a sticky vanilla that lingers through a slightly boozy finish.  After drinking this i am quite glad i still have 4 more bottles sitting in my basement.

Bottle.  Pours a thick oily black with a minimal diminishing chocolate brown head.  Aroma is of chocolate and booze.  Flavor is sticky sweet, with tons of chocolate and some coffee.  The sweetness is mostly balanced by a nice alcohol burn that is more felt than tasted and the thickest mouthfeel of any beer I’ve ever tasted.  This is not a subtle impy stout.  It tastes like a Young’s DCS, with a shot of Jack poured in it.

22 oz bottle capped, poured into Chimay goblet.  Pours black with 1/2 inch brown head the quickly dissipates. Smells of oak, bourbon and smokey malt.  Taste is of molasses, vanilla and bourbon.  Extremely heavy beer but hides it’s 13%abv well.  Not for the faint of heart.
Bottle. Pours pitch black with a tan head. Flavor is chocolate, tobacco, bourbon, vanilla, caramel. So much flavor, delicious.
You can smell this a mile away. It is so overpowering with the taste and aroma of bourbon. It’s really not even a beer. Couldn’t finish the bottle. It’s syrupy with a coffee malt undertone.

12oz bottle. 2009 edition. Pours dark black with a very small head that immediately disappears. Smell is bourbon. Taste is bourbon. I don’t really like bourbon but somehow I do like this stout. Probably the best of any bourbon barrel aged anything I have tasted. Yet, because I am not a huge fan of bourbon I cannot rate it as high as it probably deserves. There are alot of complex flavors in there but the bourbon is so front and center that I cannot enjoy it as much as alot of the other impys out there. Plus, now that I have just drank 12 ounces, I need to go lay down...strong stuff.

Aroma is bourbon, wood, vanilla, caramel and anise. Flavor has notes of chocolate, bourbon, coffee and almond.  finish is long and beautiful.  The lasting impression is somewhere between molten chocolate cake and tiramisu,  A very impressive stout.

2014 13.8%abv Aroma- big, woody, sweet, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla.  Taste- chocolate, caramel, vanilla, raspberry, lemon and cream.  Mouthfeel is syrupy, carbonation fairly low. sticky on the lips.  finish is piney with notes of chocolate, anise, vanilla and cocoa.  Different than the last time I had it 5 years ago but still excellent.

250th rating.  12 ounce bottle from South Bay Drugs ($5.99).  2008 vintage -- I’ve been aging this one.  Pours pitch black with really no head at all.  Aroma is straight-up bourbon (almost stings the nose), campfire, molasses, and some vanilla.  Wasn’t sure what to expect from the flavor with all the booze in the aroma, but wow.  Flavor of campfire marshmallows, bourbon, rich dark chocolate, and wood.  Great complexity and not overly sweet.  Some alcohol burn in the finish.  A really excellent impy stout -- reminds me somewhat of The Bruery’s Black Tuesday which is a very high compliment.  (1255, 250)

Bottle. Black label - 2009. It’s a good thing I love bourbon. After pouring this coal black brew into a large ale glass, I could smell the bourbon from across the room. Then i took another wiff and got all that alcohol, bourbon cask and carmel malt. The is nary a hop to be detected in this brew. The key to enjoying this is to let it warm up a bit out of the fridge. The is brew is smooth and creamy and oh boy that bourbon bite is just wonderful. My only knock is the sweetness of the malt. It’s a little too much, but not really enough of a distraction. Overall this is outstanding. Once my wife gets over being pissed at me spending 13 dollars for one bottle, I will by more!

Big thanks to my SecretSanta wavers1 for this one. Bottle looks great as well as the beer in the glass. Wonderful complex-malty aroma. Starts wonderful strong and complex, intense notes of malt, liqourice and some chocloate. A little bit sweet in the background. Quite dry for a short moment. Long lasting finish, that burns more and more. Very well balanced. A beer to enjoy!

Looking forward to this one but a bit of a disappointment.

Bottle pours very thick and black with thin tan head that disappears very quickly.  Sweet bourbon aroma.  Taste is not subtle at all with strong sweet  heavy bourbon flavor.  Palate flat, thick and syrupy.  Not my cup of tea.

Re-rated the 2008.  Initial rating 3.0.  Still very boozy but somewhat better balanced.  Still like the coffee stout much more.

Re-re-rate: As my palate has evolved so has my appreciation for this beer.  Now one of my favorites, massive bourbon flavor still dominates so it’s really a matter of how you like that flavor.

22 oz. bottle- Pours black with not a great head, pours decent, then disappears fast. I taste vanilla and oak and some Bourbon but not as much as you would think, the taste is great but not as good as Ivan the Terrible, no one can beat Ivan dammit. This is the beer I drank directly after Ivan the Terrible.

Consumed @ Rake with Ang during Tom’s leaving bash. A lovely appearance. Thick head looks stunning. Brown sludge and black tar combine in the body. A sensational appearance and one of the best looking bourbon stouts I’ve experienced. Taste is very intense. A lot going on in this. Coffee, chocolate, caramel; oak, wood, light coccanut on the pallet and a strong edge of bourbon. Would go fabulasly with a strong cheese. Only regret was no cheese to consume with. Duh. Worth seeking out and hope to try this at home. This is the 2009 edition. Very fortunate to have. A special beer.

Dark nearly opaque color with chocolaty lacing. Oaky vanilla aroma that is a little more subdued than I expected.  Rich malty beer with lots of oak and vanilla. Finishes chewy with fig and lightly smoky tobacco.

Bottle split with Pat and Vin.  Pours a pitch black body with brown lacing. Aroma is buttery bread, vanilla and strong bourbon character.  Great mouthfeel with notes of rich bourbon, wood/oak character, maple, and some dark fruit.

Bottle. 12 oz. Courtesy of Vinny. Pours deep, deep black with a thin, beige head. Aroma is outrageous, unique, and delicious; freshly baked sweet bread with butter, toffee, vanilla, caramel, scotch, borboun, roasted malts barley, tea, and booze. Full, heavy, thick, syrupy body with a palate as smooth as silk. Finishes smokey-warm with a nice soothing, numbing effect on the throat and belly. Excellent.

12 0z. bottle to snifter. Aroma has a woody chocolate and vanilla molasses and boozey flavor. Appearance is dark clear yet creamy brown with thin tan head that dissipates to a constant ring. Taste is booze chocolat and vanilla also has a molasses taste with oaky flavors. Palate thick creamy and dry with booze finish. Amazing stout this is a great now and probably better later!

Bottle. Dark brown colour with a small brown head. Aroma of bourbon and liquorice. The flavour is also dominated by bourbon, notes of malt, alcohol, oak, liquorice and sweetness. Medium to full-bodied, alcohol and bitternss in the finish. Lots of flavour, but a bit unbalanced.

Bomber poured into red wine glass. Aroma is caramel, molasses. Pours black as a goose’s asshole (I think I said that about Ivan and Rasputin, didn’t I?). Nice. Taste is very bourbon, oaky, vanilla. Medium carbonation. This might be the first bourbon-aged imperial stout ever made, initializing the recent craze over this unique method of aging, but it’s not the best.
bread, caramel, dough, raisin, alcohol, brown, clear, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness, paper napkin, full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish,

Pours black with a small brown head. Aroma is rosted malt, coconut, chocolate, coffee and bourbon. A bit like a bounty bar with dark chocolate. Flavour is roasted malt, coconut, chocolate and alcohol. Really nice beer.

I’ve had this many times before but never rated it. I had a bottle of the ’08 last night. Colour... as black as black can be and no head at all. Nose... caramelized sugar, molasses, vanilla and marshmallow. Palate... thick and chewy with loads of burnt sugar and over-flamed s’mores (minus the graham cracker), followed by waves of charred oak, vanilla, dark caramel and booze. Glorious stuff! Definitely a sipper! I really miss the 12 oz. bottles. The ’09 is only in bombers, where I live.

12oz on tap at Sunset Grill

Aroma : Bourbon, hops and roasted malts.


Taste : Bourbon, hops and roasted malts... Finish is hoppy and quite sweet.


Overall : Really nice beer. Nothing really special. I preferred the WWS sampled just before.

Thick as sirup.

 Too long ago for a proper review, but rating and values apply.

Purchased at Hugos/Køge.

I’ve had the fortune of enjoying some really interesting and dynamic bourbon barrel bottlings and taps lately, which makes this a vast comedown.  Virtually no head, thick, syrupy (like corn starch), muted bourbon flavor.  Touch of indifferent coffee flavor. Basically: treacle - - molasses and vodka would be more interesting.  Terrible waste of the most I’ve ever paid for a 12-ounce bottle of beer (excepting Westy 12).

Drank from the tap at the Blind Tiger Ale House in NYC.  Pours a rich dark black color with a thin ringed head.  Aroma is a thick woodsy bourbon smell.  Taste is more of the same; heavy on the oaky bourbon flavor with notes of sweet flavors such as caramel and vanilla.  The alcohol flavor kicks in on the aftertaste but is at the right level were it’s warming and not overpowering.

2009 batch. HOLY MOTHER! this stuff is good. Pours black as the darkest moonless night, with a small brown head. The aroma is vanilla, coffee, alcohol. One sip, and I was in love. The initial sip is sweet caramel and vanilla, with lingering hints of espresso and warming alcohol. This is a beast of a beer, and having only one other beer to compare it to, Expy stout, I would say this wins hands down. Definite "sit back and relax" type of stout. Cheers, and congrats to Goose Island, for once again bringing a superbly impressive beer to the table,
thick black pour smells of bourbon and smoke -oily ,woody, caramel, chocolate, boozy. Warms the belly big time on the way down .Drink slow and enjoy.

2008 vintage (13% ABV) from JB. 12 oz bottle served in a snifter. Pours a clear brown-black with a small light brown head. Head fades, leaving minimal lace. Nose is dominated by molasses but burnt malts, coffee and barrel oak are also present. Hints of vanilla, anise and pepper. Flavour begins intensely sweet, developing spice through the middle. Finish is long and bitter. Alcohol is quite prominent, especially towards the finish. Medium-full in body, with a smooth oily/syrupy texture and virtually no carbonation. A complex brew that drinks almost like a spirit. Bourbon barrels have had a beautiful effect here. 2010-02-21

Thanks to Northernbrews for the 2007 and 2008 vintage.  The 07 is a little more mellow and sweet, but both are crazy delicious.  Vanilla, bourbon, chocolate and coffee.  A fantastic beer, no matter what vintage.

A brilliant thick dark and rich drink. Intense, warm, sweet and pleasant. A good night cap. Camel, chocolate, coffee malt. A nice dark golden brown appearance. A sweet aroma. Overall a really lovely drink.

A: A 2008 bottle poured into a snifter. The pour is dark as night with some thin mocha colored foam.

S: The smell is full of bourbon, chocolate, molasses, dark fruits, and a slight bit of alcohol.

T: This is one smooth beverage. Great bourbon, chocolate, oak, and molasses flavors. There are still some alcohol presence, but it’s nowhere near as hot as when fresh.

M: The carbonation is very light, but it works well with a 13% Impy Stout. The body is full, smooth, and creamy.

D: Even though the alcohol has died down quite a bit in a year+, it’s still a big, big beer. I need to go out and buy more of this, because I see this only getting better.

Pours with little to no head no matter how hard you pour it. Carbonation is light. The nose is awesome with oak, vanilla, caramel, and some smokiness. Pours pitch black. Oily full body that clings to glass and completely covers the palate heavy like syrup. Notes of chocolate, licorice, bourbon, vanilla, caramel, and coffee. Bourbon from beginning to end but is very smooth along with all the other flavors going on. All type of flavors stay lingering after taste. Best Bourbon Barrel Aged stout I’ve ever had. Goose Island, the inventors and perfectionists of the Bourbon Barrel aging game. All others still catching on. Vintage of this stuff is awesome!!!

2009. 12oz to snifter.  Deep black. Dark diminishing head.  Aroma is heavy alcohol, port, oak, vanilla.  No hops.  Slight malty soy sauce aroma and flavor that disappears after it sits for a while.  Full silky body with very little carbonation.  Very similar to a good tawny port.  Hard to believe it’s a beer.

2009 12oz. Bottle purchased from Villiage Beer Merchant in Buffalo. As expected, it pours completely ink black with the quickest glimmer of a dark tan head. Clings to the glass like "legs" Great aroma of scotch, vanilla, deep roasted coffee, cherries, smoke and chocolate. Flavor is full of sweet chocolate and bitter roasted coffee, nice balance. Full bodied, lightly carbonated. Alcohol can be detected throughout at 13% but I’m not complaining. Can be a bit cloying at times. Fantastic beer!

12oz bottle from Springhill in Little Rock.  Pours a pitch-colored body with a tan head that recedes fairly quickly.  Great, amber, sticky legs on the glass as I swirl it around.  Tremendous aroma of bourbon, caramel sweetness, milk chocolate, oaky and alcohol.  Oddly similar to the aroma of Utopias I had recently.  Flavor is chocolaty, vanilla, oak, bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, bourbon-alcohol and medium sweetness.  Medium mouthfeel and body.  Oily and coating on the palate.  A very intense, multi-layered beer.  I’ll split/share the next one.
First hit is very bourbon.  sugary. thick. almost like a coffee liquer.  pours a dark to blackish brown.  at the end I pick up some vanilla notes too.

Holy Moly!  I love bourbon, so needless to say, this beer is extremely impressive.  It resembles used motor oil when being poured into the glass.  Intense bourbon aroma to match the flavor.  My first one took about 50 minutes to finish, so plan on spending a lot of time with this beer.
Amazing Imperial Stout.  Thick rich black and choc malt flavor, color, and aroma.  One of the best stouts I have ever had.

Finally got around to trying this. Pours black with no head, like liquid licorice, prunes and molasses. Arouma is prunes, bourbon and alcohol. some chocolate notes. Springly carbonation keeps things lively. Some back tones of charcoal and roast that sits on the back of the tongue. Good in small doses... even 4 oz was a bit much.

A dark black beer with little head. The aroma had vanilla, chocolate, wood, & was a crazy knock you down aroma that shows it it one of the most powerful aromas in beer. The taste was a major vanilla taste with a lot of wood, very sweet, & reminded me of a chocolate covered Vanilla Wafer that had twice the vanilla in it. This is meant to be drank in small segments as this beer is one huge beast of a black liquid.
Pours black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is bourbon, oak and molasses.  Thick syrupy mouthfeel.  Tast is of bourbon and alcohol with a very sweet molasses aftertast.  Great stuff.
Bottle thanks to barzigkin. Dark brown pour with great legs. Aroma is caramel, cherries, bourbon, oak. Flavor is cherry, bourbon, caramel, nuts and coffee. Syrupy mouthfeel

Thanks to barzigkin for sharing this bottle.

Pours dark brown to black with no head. The aroma is bourbon, molasses, roasted malt and a little bit of soy sauce. The flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, oak, bourbon and some light soy sauce. Medium mouthfeel, low carbonation and a hot alcohol presence. Very good beer.

Bottle at Esbjerg beerfestival. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is dry, sweet, bourbon, buned malt. Flavour is dry, sweet, licorice, oily, bourbon, coffee, cacao, buned, malt, vanilla, hop. Full body. Very nice beer.

Thanks to zinister-via kaggie97. 2009 version. Black with minimal head. Overt whiskey and alcohol nose-you should know what you’re in for before the first taste.  No surprise here-thick, viscous, whiskey and alcohol dominate this wonderful sipper.  Full body and flavors-this one kicks butt.

Pours a dark brown, almost black color with a medium, mahogany head.  Intense aroma of cherries and hint of alcohol.  Extremely sweet, chocolate cherry taste.  The sweetness is actually a little overwhelming, but this beer is extremely complex and very good.  Very heavy beer with almost no carbonation and a smooth finish.

Bottle, at Esbjerg Beerfestival. It’s a black, oily beer with a small, tan head. Bourbon, burnt malts, alcohol, sweetness, licorice and tar, some hints of coconut and vanilla on the nose. Warming, oily and full-bodied on the palate, with alchol, some vanilla and coconut, burnt malts, a little licorice and bitterness, and a good sweetness. Lasting finish with alcohol, all good things dark, and sweetness. A wonderful beer, needs some time to drink it, it’s too powerful to rush down, but delightful as a companion to a good book I guess. Rating: 8-5-8-5-17-4.3. 091022

Bottle, 22oz. A small, tan head sits on top of a black body. Coconut, oak, some vanilla, roasted malts, chocolate and alcohol in a pleasant aroma-union. The flavor follows up, with a nice oaked touch to the the roasted malts and alcohol. Full-bodied, warming and smooth on the palate, ending with a lasting roasted, warming finish. Dang this is good. Gimme more! 110114

12 oz. 2009 bottle from The Party Source.  Pours very dark brown, near black, with a tiny brown head that doesn’t last long.  Big bourbon nose, with vanilla, charred oak, molasses, chocolate, raisins, tobacco, and figs.  The bourbon and molasses take over in the flavor, but the other notes from the aroma are all there, with the figs also coming out a bit more.  The bourbon really pops in this, and would probably settle down if allowed to sit longer.  It also makes for some nice warming alcohol and a mouth-coating richness, a great, not dominating bourbon and molasses moutfheel.  Full-bodied, with minimal carbonation.  I loved this, and probably would love it even more with just a little more time in the cellar. Re-Rate: 2012 edition. Every year I drink this. Every year I am reminded why it is the gold standard in bourbon barrel imperial stouts.

Enjoyed this at the Churchkey in DC. Lets just say my eyes watered after the first sip...soo good. The aroma is rich with burbon, oak, and cherry. The taste of burbon blends wonderfully with dark chocolate, vanilla, and smoke. Its smooth, silky, and delicate. A truely amazing beer.
From tap. Pitch black almost oily with hardly any head. Caramel & chocolate aroma. Intense mix of flavors with thick almost syrupy moth feel. Alcohol and flavor lingers.

Pours black with almost no head from the 12oz. bottle at Cigar City Brewing (Tampa, FL): Aroma is of oak wood, leather, coffee, bourbon and a slight bit of molasses. Smooth flavors of raisins, currants, leather, tannins and just a little coffee. Finish is a nice woody note that begs for more. Drinkability: Bomber. An Imperial Stout at it’s perfection. Rebuy: Yes. #255 on 23012010, DG.

2009 version, doesnt matter, 2008 is just as good.  Had 08 last night, 09 today.  Opaque, black as night .  Thin wisp of a head on a light pour.  Aroma of chocolate and bourbon mingled perfectly.  Some hints of sourdough.  They hit the description to a tee.  Chewy thick and rich, the chocolate and bourbon flavors keep flipping with each sip.  Sharing with a few friends and all are blown away.  Alcohol is definitely present, but does not seem 13%.  Fantastic

Aroma is amazing, some vanilla and the bourbon make me want to sniff it rather then drink it.  I must say this really sparked an interest in barrel aged beers for me.  I have 2 extra’s that i am going to cellar.

Pours an inky black, thick and opaque.  Pretty much no head at all on this one.  The aroma is sugary sweet with a lot of molasses and caramel.  The flavor is quite rich - chocolate and brown sugar predominate over a background of topsoil.  Feels lovely swishing around, thick and juicy.  The carbonation is sharp and more prevalent than expected.  Finishes dry with some alcohol warmth.  Leaves a bitter aftertaste with a bit of the alcohol coming back for a second go.  Hefty and deeply satisfying after a couple recent duds.

Pours a deep dark blackish-brown with very little by way of head. Aroma of bourbon is quite noticeable, along with the smoke and the malt of the grain. Flavor is almost too intense--sweetish bourbon-alcohol on top of coffee, chocolate, smoke, some fruits (raisin), spice, and so forth. The sweet aftertaste almost gets to be a bit too much (at least for me), but this is a pretty accomplished beer and definitely worth a try. A beer to be sipped and savored.

Bottle - Great beer for those bourbon lovers looking to experience a blend of malts and bourbon. 
  Nose is a heavy mixture of smoke, vanilla, and caramel with an oaky alcohol in the background.  Well rounded but warns of an exceptionally dangerous taste to follow.
  Appearance points cannot be docked by any reasonable taster.  Completely opaque brew pours a thick, frothy head that is closer to amber in color than just off white.  Head falls ever so slowly and leaves wonderful lacing.
  Taste makes you stand up to shake its hand.  Heavy flavors roll around your mouth that are both bitter and sweet.  The bourbon here really helps control the stout and keeps the complex flavors in balance.
  A full bodied beer both thick and creamy.  The soft and often times nearly flat carbonation does well to take a back seat in this pungent brew.  The finish offers a long bitter, if not slightly astringent, fade that lets you know this beer is best sipped to be enjoyed.
  A well rounded brew that should be shared with two or three friends if you go out and pick up a bomber... a little goes along way with this 13% bourbon stout.

The best tasting Imperial Stout I’ve ever had. Expected a stout with a lot of liquor/bourbon character, instead was treated to perfection. Aroma initially winey. Appearance jet black, little foam as expected for this style. Taste smooth, warming, like chocolate. Silky. Very complex. An enjoyable experience.

2008 bottle.
Dark brown with a minimum brown head. aromas of sweet cream, vanilla and dark rhum. Full body, so creamy, mega-thick mouthfeel, it feels like drinking liquid fatty cheese, but so sweet, nothing tart here. Wow! Lots of caramel, crème brulée, some vanilla, a hint of bitter chocolate, finishes on the sweet side with the bourbon coming trough ( alcohol warmth). A very delicious sipper brew.

A - Pours nice and black. No real head to speak of. Just a small film of brown bubbles floating around on top.

S - Alcohol! With some vanilla from the oak.

T - Rich with the dark fruit, vanilla and of course bourbon. Caramel and toffee are hanging around in there too along with the vanilla. This is just really good.

M - Nice and viscous. Tingly.

D - I don’t think I could take down more than two of these but I would definitely want to.

Bottled 10/02/09. Pours brownish black with practically no head. Starts with roasted malt, vanilla, bit of licorice and coffee notes. Finishes with woody alcohol, caramel and a little soy sauce with syrup.
355 cl bottle from 2008. Pitch black body with almost no head. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and notes of smoke and bourbon.

12 oz 2006 bottle received from Orbialr0x. The first smell let me know that this beer was going to be very good. The smell was chocolate and heavy. The color was black with a brown head. The taste was like Godiva dark chocolates with hints of bourbon coming through as it warmed. This was so amazing. Definitely the best bourbon barrel stout I’ve ever had if not the best stout in general. Alcohol was very well hidden.

Update 01/21/08 2006 bottle

Heavy bourbon smell, almost like sniffing a straight shot. Bourbon is also present in the flavor but there is also a nuttiness that kinda reminds me of peanut butter. There alcohol is well hidden, not a hint of the 11% in the taste and just a whiff in the nose.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-09-2007 16:09:06

Vintage bottle from 2008

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a stemmed glass.

The color is a complete black with a slight brownish head that disappears quickly.

The smell is of alcohol from the moment the cap comes off. Some maple flavor and a bit of dark chocolate in the nose.

The taste is pretty strong with some nice maple flavor. Some chocolate and toffee flavor mixed in there as well. It really takes a moment to really enjoy all of the flavors in this beer.

The feel of this beer is pretty darn heavy but it does have a bit of a smoothness that was enjoyable. It does leave a warm feeling on the way down and has a bit of a kick. Fantastic.

Bottle, 355ml (2009). Pours pitch black, with none to little head, but menacingly attractive on the eye despite that. Intense aroma of bourbon, chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Similarly intense on the palate, with the potency of the alcohol evident,  though not overwhelming. A little too much bourbon for this particular palate, but a very smooth beer nonetheless.

650 ml. bomber.  Pours a jet black body with very unique looking orange brown head which quickly is reduced to a thin veil of brown-sugar colored brown on the top.  Aroma of rich dark malt, chocolate, toffee, vanilla, smoke.  Taste is very complex, definite bourbon flavors, vanilla-bourbon sweetness, alcohol noticeable on finish.  This one is very nice, very complex, though it is a little too sweet for my personal tastes, would rather have a little more roasty malt backbone.  Overall very good.

Pours solid black with a thick creamy brown head. Heavy bourbon aroma with smoke, chocolate, vanilla and more bourbon. Taste is sweet thick creamy bitter roast and milk chocolate. Alcohol is hot and bold. Medium creamy body with an alcohol finish.

Pours like motor oil.  Absolutely no head to speak of.  Smells strongly of smoked bourbon.  It tastes just like a bourbon ball.  Hints of coconut and chocolate but the overwhelming smell is bourbon.  Legs that go on for miles.  A rich and flavorful beer experience.  Big and bold.  So good I can’t write in complete sentences.

Beer pours with all the appearance of cola.  The aroma was strong bourbon.  Okay, this is the same as almost every other bourbon beer.  The bourbon flavor drowns out almost all semblance of beer.  This teetered on the edge of sweet and undrinkable, but managed to keep from falling off the edge.   Strong notes of chocolate and coffee under some more subtle vanilla and oak flavors.  If you dig bourbon beers, this one is probably excellent, but for me, just average or slightly above.

Re-rate July 2010 - 2009 version.  Dude.  I gotta bump this thing down.  I just don’t get it.  There’s so much bourbon in this, I can’t taste anything else.  It’s really, really, really hard to drink.  It’s sweet.  It’s not good.

19th October 2008. 
This is a 2005 beer at a modest (!) 11.0% abv. Opaque black stout with a thin brown head. Spirity coffee nose. Dark port and brandy start with a coffee undertone. Smooth semi sweet vanilla oak. Bittterish coffee spirit dry finish. Chocolate spirit aftertaste. An awesome beer. Smooth, silky and sumptuos. 
 
 3rd November 2010. 
 A 2007 bottle at 13.0% abv. Opaque black beer, tiny tan head. Rich dark malt with a lot of strong bourbon. Offset by sweet vanilla wood. Finishes warm. Despite being 3 years old the power of this one does not appear to have faded much! Great stuff! 

4th January 2013
THE stout tasting Pt1. 2011 bottle at 14.5% abv. Thanks Jack for another bite of this classic! Palate is surprisingly light and airy, also a little dry. Rich malts, warming bourbon. Dark chocolate. Spirity aniseed but not too much, Finishes semi dry with a warming afterglow. 3.8

Poured viscous black with thin brown head, aroma is full of smoke, chocolate, coffee, and bourbon tones.  Taste is very chocolate and coffee up front, leading into the thick bourbon taste with some toffee and vanilla sweetness, and finishes with a smoky and bitter taste.  Excellent brew!

i drank this one about 10 days ago, i dont feel like i can do a good review whatsoever, rating it just for the fk of it. i recall it being a big one, but not as big as a bell’s expedition.

UPDATE 11-24-2010... 2010 vintage. very dark pour, almost no head, almost no lace. HUGE bourbon nose. BIGTIME bourbon taste. Boozy. This was certainly a sipper, but tasted very good. I drank it over the course of an hour, and when i was done i had a serious buzz.

This is a deep black with a very light brown head that had all but disappeared by the time it arrived at my table. The aroma is heavy bourbon with a hint of coffee, malts, & chocolate.Strong bourbon taste with some slight hints of coffee, chocolate, and a sweet alcohol finish. Delicious!

Bottled. Thanks to Magnus Ahlström. 
Pitch black colour. Very low foam. Really intense and full aroma, there is a blanket of syrup, vanilla, bourbon in aroma, and underneath a accompanying root cellary touch, that seem perfect.  The beer flavour itself is a bit on the sweet side, but oh what flavours we have here: vanilla, tar, wood, higher alcohols, darker malts, bourbon. It’s sweet and syrupy but damn tasty.

Rating 1400, on tap at Pacific Standard and since I have bottles of this at home from trades and my own purchases, I figured it was about time I actually drank some of this.   Pours a deep dense dark black with a thin to medium sized deep tan head.  Large bourbon and vanilla, chocolate, malt.  Viscous and thick, lots of plums and prunes, large caramel and chocolate.  The booze is well hidden until the finish when it starts creeping up slowly, gently warming with long bourbon, wood, and vanilla notes on top of the rich chocolate.

This kicks ass. Serious dark pour like used motor oil. This beer has no time in its busy schedule to generate a head...it is getting ready to assault your senses. Toasty, roasty battles with the wood and bourbon. If you don’t have any of this, go get it. If you do have some, go get more. I am...

Bottle. Good way to end the semester. Pours pitch black with only a slight wisp of of a chocolaty brown head (killed by the alcohol). Aroma is like a grill, smokey and charred, with the sweetness of chocolate and maple. Taste is incredibly strong with dark chocolate and orange, smoke overtones, and a nice woodiness. Alchohol is fairly apparent. Finishes like a syrup it’s so viscous, with a some sourness. Overall, it’s almost overwhelming; either open it at noon so you can finish by 8:00 or share it with about six friends. Still, a great and grand beer.

(vintage 2006) Pours a deep, thick black with a very thin brown head that dissipated quickly.  Aroma thick of bourbon with a hint of chocolate, toffee, toasted malts, a hint of coffee, and bitter-sweet.  Tastes heavy of bourbon with some hints of caramel, coffee, chocolate, and a bitter-sweet alcohol finish.  Very tasty!

Smells of bourbon and toasty with a bit of chocolate.  The bourbon taste in this brew is HUGE and I love it. This is far and away one of the best stouts I’ve ever had. I’m not huge on stouts, but this is one I would pick up again.

Bottle courtesy of furley of internet-fame.  Thanks!  Pours a pitch black with brown head.  Smell is strong vanilla and oak.  Tends to cool down a bit as it warms.  Very deep taste.  Bourbon flavor is apparent, as well as a very smoky wood taste.  Very good, but I can’t drink a ton of em.

2009 Bottle. Poured black with a dark wooden brown head. Aroma was full of bourbon notes with sweet caramel and a bit of nuttiness lying underneath.  Flavor began with caramel and sweet roasted malt and a bourbon flavor grows into the finish. Very thick on the tongue.

Pours a very dark brown/black with a tan head that has decent retention. Slight cherry, strong vanilla aromas and a slight hint of bourbon/alcohol. Chocolate, vanilla, and cherry flavors. Very bold but smooth body that lingers, medium - low carbonation. .
molasses, caramel, nutty, vanilla aroma.  silky texture.  can smell and taste the oak bourbon barrel.  it’s the best stout i’ve come across.

Pours a lasting ring of tan head with some lace and a dark brown body.  Looks like a shot of espresso.  Aromas of soy sauce, toasted and roasted malt, slight bourbon and vanilla notes.  Flavors of toasted, roasted malt, soy sauce, molasses, bourbon, wood.  Finish is a little hot, sticky, dry, vanilla coffee, bacon.
chocolate, smoke, black, cloudy, tan foam, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,

Tap.  Strong bourbon aroma up front with light chocolate malt.  Opaque black color with minimal head.  Strong bourbon flavor initially with a milder chocolate malt finish.  Nice - bourbon flavor pretty strong. / Bottled10-28-2008, drank Feb 9, 2019.    Bourbon, chocolate malt, dry hay aroma.  Black with minimal head.   Moderately sweet bourbon, chocolate malt. and mildly bitter hay flavor.   Great body and balance - nice bourbon aftertaste.

Completely opaque motor oil pour w/ effervescent caramel head that dissipates quickly, but continues bubbling like a cola, hugely complex aroma w/ vanilla, oak, cognac, butterscotch and chocolate, flavor matches aroma on front end w/ bitterness and booze coating the palate on finish, warming alcohol spreads completely to the back of the throat, massively large mouthfeel

The scene around the first barrel tapping of this must have been equivelant to the first nugget found at the California gold rush,  the first time an equation worked out for a young Einstein,  the glimmer of a bulb reflecting off of Edison’s spectacles or the first to witness a strapping green George Herman at a Baltimore boys school yard diamond.  You have achieved dark chocolate, black licorice, sherry, dark rum, and sweet cherry wood in the aroma.  You have achieved a flavor directly descendant of a brown sugar crusted perfectly smoked and barked sweet pork cracklin.  You have achieved a viscosity of richness and superb slick glory.  In this beer, Goose Island,  you have achieved and you should be proud.  Thank You Goose Island.  2008 12oz.

2008 Release: Black, lifeless body with s short head and a few spots of lacing, leaves good legs on the glass. Tons of roasted malt aroma with a heavy does of coffee and smooth bourbon. Chewy mouth feel, very filling and creamy. Smooth like a freshly whipped up batch of pudding. Spectacular blend of hearty flavors. Chocolate/fudge, bourbon, smoke, nuts, coffee and a light woodiness. Flavor is amazing and follows the perfect mouth feel respectfully. Top shelf, wish it were available in oHIo.
Vintage 2007... This beer was massive.. Tons of oak and booze....very much a slipping beer. You can really taste the 13% abv... I really want to try a new bottle to see the difference.

Wow. Pours thick and black with a dark brown head. Got it in chicago and i can’t wait to bring some back next time. Lots of coffee, caramel, and toffee flavors, hides the 13% really well I thought. This is by far my favorite stout to date.

Poured black with a dark brown, thick head. The nose is bourbon, dark chocolate, vanilla, and oak. The taste is similar with roasted barley and malt. The palate is oily and SO thick and chewy, oily as well. This is the best imperial stout I’ve had!

Re-rate: 2008 vintage drank on 07.26.10.
Wow! Need I say more? Pours so incredibly dark, almost pitch black except for the fizzy carbonated head that is deep chocolate brown and only lingers around long enough to notice it. The nose is HUGE bourbon, charred oak, peat smoked malt, caramel, vanilla, roasted malt, whoopers, and a hint of the 13% abv. The taste is initially roasted malt, charred oak and bourbon that transitions into hints of vanilla, burnt sugar, smoke, and caramel, all the while reminding you that it sat in bourbon barrels for 6 months. The delicious bourbon notes linger in your mouth for the entire drink. The palate is thick, chewy, and moderately oily while the mouthfeel has a perfect amount of carbonation for a beer like this. Amazing beer, absolutely one of my favorites. Glad I’ve got a 22 oz 2009 bottle to share with someone.

Black with a large-bubble head that settles quickly into three distinct islands (no kidding) and an edge of foam.
Aroma resembles Jack Daniels lite.
Flavor starts with malt and caramel, then progresses to bourbon, enough to mask most of the beer flavor.
Decent body, very smooth for a bourbon brew.
A slight toning down of the bourbon aspect would go over well, although this is an otherwise tasty beer. 

Addendum: vertical 2003 through 2009 courtesy of brad - thanks!  Just about killed us to do this one, but it was worth it.  A very tasty beer, mellows steadily with age.  No change in rating.

Bouteille de 660ml. Bière d’un noir dense et profond surmontée d’une épaisse mousse caramel qui disparaît en une minute environ, en faisant un bruit intense de pétillement. Elle dévoile un nez très puissant et complexe avec notamment des arômes de chocolat, de vanille, fruits confits, raisins secs, caramel, bois, bourbon, malt torréfié, alcohol et des notes de fumée. En bouche, on note encore une fois chocolat, vanille, fruits confits, raisins secs, bois, bourbon, malt torréfié, fumé et alcool. En réchauffant, elle se transforme en pannetone, avec caramel dulce de leche, cannelle, cognac et alcool. Elle est très ronde en bouche avec une texture plutôt sirupeuse et visqueuse qui contribue à préserver très longtemps toutes les saveurs en bouche. Avec le temps, il est de plus en plus rare qu’une bière m’impressionne, mais celle-ci est tout simplement phénoménale et d’une complexité exceptionnelle. Une bière d’hiver fort réconfortante et enivrante!

Wow, something finally good coming out of illinois.  Pours a deep 10-40w. Very nice bourbon aroma. From someone who loves bourbon this excells. Sweet chocolate notes abound also in the aroma. huge alcohol presense but it dies down over a period of time on the palate.  A great sipping beer, hopefully i can find a great madero cigar to go with it. Thanks sun devil liquor.
Pours deep black (2007 vintage) with basically no head at all. Huge vanilla/coffee/bourbon flavor along with hints of soy. Good stuff.

Yowza! Tap at Churchkey DC. Pours inky black with a thin dark brown head.  Huge aroma of vanilla, also some chocolate, malt, and oak.  The flavor is all of that - with the emphasis on vanilla - plus caramel, roasted barley, a touch of bourbon, and a little burn from the alcohol.  Aged a couple years this will be perfection.

12oz. Bottled on 10/02/09.  Appropriately viscous black pour with no trace of head or bubbles to speak of.  You can honestly get a whiff of this thing from a couple feet away. Gigantic Bourbon nose hits like a sledgehammer.  If you keep your nose down and get past the fact that it smells more like whiskey than beer, you’ll get hints of vanilla, burnt oak and caramel.  Not sure that I can adequately describe the flavor, has a bit of everything I would expect in a near perfect stout. Huge malt flavor with roasted grain, cocoa, black licorice, oak, vanilla and caramel.  A subtle Bourbon flavor hits right at the beginning. Can’t imagine how they could improve on the palate, sits just right on the tongue with a thick texture that supports the malt, but isn’t overly syrupy.  Slight hit of bitterness at the end and almost no trace of alcohol throughout.  Very impressive for a 13% beer that was just bottled two months ago. If you can find this one, make sure you pick some up. Simply amazing!

This beer is dark, really dark. And the flavor is very much of the same. The aroma is of vanilla, oak, coffee, chocolate, and bourbon alcohol. This beer is very well done and very smooth to drink, which is suprising with the strong alcohol percentage. The primary flavors are a burnt barley, coffee, bourbon, oak and vanilla. The vanilla flavor finishes the beer very well. If it wasnâ€™t for this beer being $10.99 a 4-pack, this would be a beer I would drink a few times a week. I canâ€™t wait to try this one on tap!!
12 oz. bottle.  Awesome bourbon aroma and flavor.  Goose Island did a great job with this one.

Pours thick like oil and is extremely black as well.  Very minimal head with very little lacing to speak of .  Ahhh...the aromas of bourbon!!!  Smells wonderful!!!  Aromas of vanilla, rich sweet caramel, a touch of chocolate and deep roasted coffee.  The aroma is simply fantastic and complex!  The flavor is incredible!!  Tastes of everything the nose delivers, vanilla, caramel, chocolate, the deep roasted coffee beans all come through so easily on the palate.  Yet, it’s so smooth and dangerously easy to drink.  The finish is long and continues to deliver delicious flavors of licorice and brown sugar.  Wow...simply wow.

Pours black as night with zero head into an oversized Lucifer snifter.  Aroma of alcohol (pretty damn similar to bourbon all around), plenty of malt, vanilla, chocolate, berries, licorice, caramel, chocolate.  Extraordinarily complex nose.  Upfront taste of vanilla-cocoa sweetness.  Solid malt backbone surrounded by an all-encompassing bourbon.  Licorice, toffee, raspberry, blackberry aftertaste.  Bourbon/toffee comes out almost exclusively as it warms.  Absolutely love the viscous, low-carbonation mouthfeel.  I can’t really see anything being better than this.  Glad I grabbed another for cellaring.  Utterly blew me away.

Perfect! 12 oz. bottle. Pours opaque brown/black, like used motor oil, with no head to speak of. Aroma is rich coffee, sweet sugar syrup, vanilla and oak. Flavor is heavy, sweet, sugary, vanilla, dark fruit, chocolate. Palate is thick, viscous, syrupy, almost no carbonation. This is so rich and flavorful that it absolutely overpowers anything you’ve ever tried. A definite must-have for any beer geek.

Aroma of bourbon balls with an ashy almond presence. Appearance is black with dark mocha head. Flavor of bourbon balls, Aztec cocoa, almonds and roasted marshmallows. Palate was bubbly and lively. A great American beer.

Sampled at friend’s beer tasting. Pours a black oil color with a deep tan head. Aroma is dark chocolates, vanilla, oak, coffee, caramel. Flavor is sweet, but with notes of bitter dark chocolates. Finish is smooth, and alcohol isn’t that noticeable, at least not at the amount I consumed. A wonderful, brew that could only have been better had it been served with a cigar on the side.

Bomber.  Bottled on:  10/16/09.  Different label than that in the picture.  A jet-black pour with an average-sized mocha head on top.  A powerfully rich aroma of dark chocolate, vanilla extract, caramel, roasted coffee, and burnt oak.  Full-bodied and sticky.  The flavor starts off super-sweet with loads of caramel, sweet chocolate, and vanilla beans.  Burnt toffee, vanilla extract, and an oaky quality follow.  A semi-bittering finish reminiscent of the last few sips of a cup of coffee that has long since gone cold.  Good stout.

dark fruits, malty extremely sweet, lacks hop balance on the finish.
Interestingly I just finished a glass of the Creme Brulee, and this is WAY sweeter and over the top.

2008 Vintage (10/21/08)

Thick, black, and oily liquid. Disappointingly though, there is no head to speak of, even with a hard pour. No real lacing, either. I swirled it to check it’s ’legs’ though. Hell, it’s wearing a skirt! Most impressive.

Smell is over-the-top boozey. Bourbon notes are ever-so present. Smokey oak and hints of sweet vanilla. Hints of chocolate. Big overripe dark fruits.

This reminds me of fresh S.A. Triple Bock. Wow. Bourbon warmth comes through prominently. Syrupy dark fruit flavors. Chocolate notes mingle with big vanilla flavor. Big malty backbone. Smokey oak flavor. Caramelized brown sugar. F***ing complex flavor pallette!
For all of the bourbon-like warmth that is here, combined with the 13% ABV, I find the alcohol to be remarkably well hidden.

Mouthfeel is phenomenal! For as big as this beer is, this is one smooth easy drinking bastard. Big, thick, chewey and oily, yet smooth and light on the tongue, at the same time. Amazing.

I would like to drink these, one after the other, over an evening. When the alcohol eventually knocks me out, I’d like to wake up and continue on doing the same thing...for like a week. Damn, it’s good.
This was so totally worth the wait and the effort. Worthy of seeking out.

As my friend Dean says, "I’ll drink the shit outta that one." Big bourbon, chocolate, light smoke and some oak. Lightly sweet. Just a beautiful mixture that comes together so well. One of my favorites, and it’s readily available these days. Gotta love it.

12oz of 2008 vintage - Two stroke oil pour, no fizz or head, oily mouthfeel.  It had the good roasted marshmallow start and bitter hops finish, but there was a peanut brittle middle that I didn’t appreciate.  Good not great.

Pours black with a light brown/tan head which quickly diminishes. Smells like bourbon and chocolate...what a great combo! Lots of chocolate and bourbon but the alcohol isn’t so overpowering that it takes away from the sweetness...perfectly blended together. Great feel in the mouth...like a chocolate milkshake with alcohol! A couple of these and I’d be feeling pretty good although I will say it’s an easy-to-drink stout, IMO.

bottle thanks to Daknole, pours thick black with a medium dark tan head.  Aroma is very chocolatey with some oak, oats,  and bourbon tones.  Flavors start with a strong punch of roasted malt and cocoa.  Really sweet and rich but balanced in a finish of bourbon and alcohol with light notes of wood.  Really well done, and nicely balanced.  The heat is a nice welcome and doesn’t overpower anything but rather sits along side some wonderful dark malt and chocolate flavors.  Good stuff!

Pours a dark black. No head at all. Wonderful aroma of dark chocolate and bourbon. Vanilla dances around the nose. Very strong flavor. Tons of chocolate and bourbon flavor. Strong alcohol burn feels like I just took a shot of bourbon. Wisps of vanilla finish this complex flavor. Slight bitterness in the end. Thick on the palate. Coats the mouth very thick. Minimal carbonation, ideal for imp stouts. Very BIG beer. Fantastic! Best at warmer temperatures.

Bottle pours a thick black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is intense, heavily bourbon, oak and vanilla notes present.  Taste is heavy on the roasted malt, chocolate, with a sharp bite of alcohol and bourbon finish.  Heavy bodied with intense aroma and flavor, but the alcohol bite is bit too much.

[bottle] Black and thick. Tan thin head with tiny bubbles. I can smell bourbon, vanilla, oak barrel along with dark fruits. Thick and full on my tongue, warming as it goes down the throat and some bitterness. A great beer to sip on a cool evening.

A pitch black colored beer, with a small beige head. Is disappears quickly. The aroma of wood, with dark fruits, whisky/bourbon. The taste of chocolate, wood with fruits and dark fruits. There is alcohol and notes of whisky/borbon. There are also flavors of vanilla. The aftertaste is bitter, warm with some wood with notes of sweet.

2008 bottle.  Pours thick inky black, with a thin chocolate-brown head, some lacing.  Intense bourbon nose even from a distance, deep malty aromas of chocolate souffle, sugar cane, vanilla, leather, and oak.  Thick body, smooth, creamy, medium dry.  Gigantic chocolate malt flavor, some coffee, cherry, and bourbon.  Chewy, warming, rich and savory.  Lightly bitter, lasting molasses and oak finish.  It’s hard to believe how much flavor they managed to pack into a bottle.

The pour was as black as black can be, with a very thin beige head. Aromas of coffee, toffee, chocolate, and bourbon. Tastes of chocolate and bourbon, with a very strong bourbon overtone. You can feel the 13% ABV in this one as the warming sensation begins quickly. Terrific beer for those cold winter nights in Chicago!

Brewed in the USA... Courtesy of FooFaa from B.A. thanks again Dan !!!  Pours black in color with a super thin beige head. Aroma of bourbon, roasted malts and oak. Taste is also of bourbon, oak, malts, caramel and some vanilla flavors. Mouthfeel is wonderful, it’s smooth and kind of creamy with some smoky notes at the finish. The 13% is completly hidden in this Stout, and that something special they brewed is fantastic !!!

A 2008 bottle shared by Dan (FooFaa) at the Beer Advocate - Brass Rail tasting. This might be the blackest beer I have ever seen. Even as it was slowly being poured the thin stream of liquid was jet black. The smell was very roasty with some coffee and bourbon notes to it. It had an extremely complex and balanced flavor of burnt caramel, coffee, bourbon, chocolate, vanilla, and a light touch of oak. Silky smooth in the mouth with zero alcohol burn. Easily my favorite beer of the night.

22 oz, Corvallis brewing supply, 11.79. Super bourbon, the bourbon was overwhelming, almost ended in a bottle pour i thought i bought a beer not a hard liquor.
I feel bad rating it this low but i honestly couldn’t taste anything over the bourbon. I guess it needed time in the cellar.

Received this beer as an extra from JoeyBeerBelly with many thanks.

Served in a beer tulipat ~40 degrees.

A-pours a jet black color with red undertones, no much of a head created during the pour and none was left after a few minutes

S-strong bourban smell, with a little bit of oak in the background

T-a powerful brew at 13% with the bourban dominating the flavor from start to finish.

M-almost no carbonation with kind of a weak mouthfeel for a stout.

D-I could see myself drinking this beer on the coldest night of the year. I have had better 13% stouts in my day, overall I didn’t feel like this beer lived up to the hype surrounding it. I tried to let it warm up because I believe a good stout tasted better warm...but alas I did not feel this way about this beer.

wonderful aroma. The 13% really hits you like a sledgehammer in a beautiful way. As others have pointed out, the flavor is a little thin, not as complex as some other stouts, but anything with a high gravity, stout flavor and bourbon tones wins my approval. Congrats to Goose Island.

Pours a very dark black with thin mocha head that disspaears before you can take the first sip.  Aroma is incredible with more than I can identify...begins with a nice bourbon aroma followed by notes of dark chocolate, caramel, coffee and faint vanilla.  Mouthfeel is full and vicous.  There’s pleny going on in the flavor...bitter chocolate, coffee and dark fruit.  A little alcohol in the finish but no alcohol burn whatsover.  A very complex beer...this one goes right to the top of my list.

This one will kick you in the teeth if you’re not careful.  Ink-black pour, dark cocoa lacing, thick and incredibly viscous, unctuous (yes, unctuous) mouthfeel with complex aroma profile.  Definite notes of toasted oak, and vanilla oak characteristics leads into a tiering of bittersweet dark chocolate, a bit of butter, touch of smoke, oaky vanilla, and an almost peat-like quality.  As it opens up I get a bit of dark sultana-like fruit character too, it hints at the very same enriched dried stone-fruit characeristic as a Belgian Dark Strong.

Bottle. Pours a black beer with a brown head. The aroma is roasted, alcohol, coconut and chocolate. The flavor follows the nose with notes of vanilla. The palate is slightly bitter. Overall a good, complex and balanced beer.

2008 vintage.

This one is as black as they come and is really viscous. I’ve had this before and I know it’s hard to get head development going. So I tried a rather aggressive pour into my snifter, but all I got was a minimal layer of dark beige foam that dissipates immediately into a minimal ring of lacings.

The smell is amazing. Massive bourbon aromas sit side by side with a wonderful smooth stout base. Vanilla, almonds, oak, licorice and a hint of soy sauce. Some hints of brown sugar and molasses. The roasted malts really need to struggle to keep up with the bourbon, but I think they manage quite well. The bourbon gets a little boozy and I pick up plenty of alcohol fumes.

The taste follows suit and surly doesn’t disappoint, even though expectations get cranked up by the appearance and smell. The bourbon flavors are really powerful, rich and full, but nonetheless the beer manages to stay balanced. Lots of vanilla and oak with notes of almonds. Hints of sweet licorice. Perhaps a suggestion of soy sauce. The roasted malty character is noticeable but it gets a little hard to detect with all the bourbon notes going on. Nevertheless, the malts manage to create a good balancing point for the powerful bourbon flavors. All in all, the beer has a pleasant balance between sweetness and a salty note. The usual flavors of dark fruits and chocolate are really hard to pick up in this one, but I do think here is a delightful note of truffles. The finish is loaded with boozy and hot alcohol that fits nicely with the sweetness from the bourbon and malts, but it gets a little too much here and there. Wood, notes of salt licorice, a light herbal bitterness and long-lasting bourbon notes round everything up.

Very very viscous and smooth - this one is thick like cream. Medium, well suited carbonation. Although both smell and taste is great in this one, the mouthfeel is really the highlight here, it’s just that great. It just delivers a sophisticated expression to an otherwise bold and cocky beer.

This is a good imperial stout, to say the least. Very powerful with a massive bourbon character. It’s quite impressive that it still manages to come of as balanced. However, it’s not perfect. Although this is obviously a sipper, the alcohol gets to demanding and overpowering every now and then. And due to the onslaught of the bourbon flavors, the beer looses some complexity.

NOTE: This bottle was about 11 months old. I’ve sampled a bottle from the same batch when it was reasonably fresh, and although I think it holds up really well with plenty of bourbon still hanging around, I think the bourbon notes have faded just a little bit.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

7oz Tap at Stub and Herb’s.  Pours a deep black with a brownish head.  Aromas of raisin, deep dark fruit, big bourbon, and brown sugar.  The taste is dark fruits and brown sugar as in the smell, and a huge wave of bourbon and alcohol roll across the tongue. Too me it still worked, but I did hear comments that there was just way to much bourbon on this one.  This was a great imperial stout on the night of just some insane taps.  Just keep in mind there is huge bourbon there, but it didn’t distract from the full body of the beer for me.  As Bill and Ted might say Most Excellent!

Draught at Wrigleyville BrewPub:  Sweet, boozy aroma of Bourbon, alcohol, slight roasted malt, oak, and light vanilla.  Poured pitch black in color with a very small brown head that lasted around the edges.  Very slightly sparkling.  Opaque.  Complex flavor is medium to heavily sweet.  Tastes of chocolate, oak, Bourbon, light vanilla, slight tar, and light booze.  Full body.  Viscous, slightly dry texture.  Soft carbonation.  Bourbon, tar, and oak finish is lightly dry and lingering.  Very good.  13.5%ABV is barely noticeable in the flavor.
Black as night with a boozy aroma.  Nonexistant head.  Powerful bourbon flavor with hints of chocolate and caramel.

Bought it expecting a stout with light bourbon flavor and aroma. I was wrong. The aroma and flavor are predominantly of bourbon. Whether this a good or bad thing depends on the drinker. Personally, I couldn’t handle it. One my friends though was more than willing to drink it for me. Be wary of this beverage not only for the flavor, aroma and sheer strength of alcohol, but also because it will burn your mouth like a shot of bourbon. The flavor was good, and the depth of the beer was astounding, but I just couldn’t handle it. It was too much for me.

Fantasic boubon barrel aged beer.  Jet black with a dancing brown head.  Super complex aroma, flavors and finish.  Its all in their; chocolate, bourbon, vanillia, coffee, caramel, lactose. Wow, fantasitc sipper.

Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Black, thick looking motor oil with a cappuccino head that attempts to form but mostly fails.

Aroma of oak, molasses, vanilla, chocolate and alcohol. The smell is simply overpowering, as is the taste. Definite Bourbon taste due to the strong oak, vanilla and alcohol. The stout characteristics of roasted malt and chocolate are present but in the background.

Thick, smooth, luxurious, warming and coating.

Great sipping brew but only an occasional drink and never more than one. Yet it is intoxicating (in more ways than one).

RnH: Damn!  Pours the darkest brown leaving a film of off white head.  The nose is pungent reveailing dark fruits, some bitter/ coffee, as well as some dark wood and cooked tones.  The taste is almost overwhelming... very deep, dark and complex.  Dark fruits, prunes, coffee, esters, medium carbonation (yet no head?), dark bitters.  Delicious!  One of the best beers I’ve tasted!

Bottle thanks to ucusty. 2008. jet black with a minimalistic light brown head. Almost a syrupy thickness--slightly thinner than a dark chocolate syrup some would pour over ice cream. Throws forth a piercing bourbon scent with the rich chocolate base. Some bourbon notes intermixed with dark fruit found their place within the taste. Not sure if it would be in my best interest to drink another immediately after the first, but I’d consider. Great beer.

Bottled 2007. Raisins, vanilla mocha, old books, dried fruits, nuts, pine needles, clear and robust. Complex as they come. Gorgeous in the glass. Explosive flavor that caresses the palate. Tannins have subsided at 6 years, but I wouldn’t recommend drinking this younger.

Had on tap at the hop leaf in Chi town. nose is chocolate and bourbon. dark dark brown almost black nice tan foam. flavor of bourbon is dominant it takes over unfortunately. there is chocolate and maybe a bit of Vanilla but its too much bourbon for me to enjoy it as a beer
Bottle thanks to Cavie.  Aroma is dark chocolate.  Dark like the Dove candies with a percentage on the label.  Taste is chocolate, caramel, and bourbon.  Very thick.

Tap @ Stub and Herb’s - 2008 vintage - Pours beautiful--black as night with a tiny tan head. Smells of sweet bourbon, but not much else. There’s a little vanilla and raisins. I’ve had some beers where the bourbon smell is really strong but the taste is a bit mellower. Not this one. The bourbon destroys all other flavors, not really letting anything else through. While I like the smooth, sweet flavor a bourbon barrel-aged beer has, I don’t necessarily like the flavor of bourbon. That’s what we have here--a big impy that tastes like it was mixed with a shot of bourbon. Not my thing, and couldn’t even finish my 7 oz. pour. Wondering what to do with the bottle in my cellar now...
2008. Bu en octobre 2009. Arôme très coconut et alcool. Saveurs de coconut/vanille, de malt chocolat et d’alcool. Belle petite touche de bourbon en finale. Vraiment merveilleuse.

’08 Bottle from Crown#6, poured into ’W’ brandy snifter (thanks Dan, 1st use). Nose is very nice strong bourbon with molasses, licorice, dark chocolate, roasted malt, brown sugar and some faint figs, very inviting. Taste is WOW! Loads of some of the best bourbon flavor a beer can contain. You’re gonna have to love bourbon to like this beer. I love bourbon and I LOVE this beer. The bourbon loads up so much, I don’t really get much beyond that other than a slight roasted malt backing and some brown sugar. Mouthfeel is smooth and slimy once it warms. Let this one warm for sure, it opens up into an amazing sipable delight. The ’W’ on the side of my glass must stand for ’Winner’, ’cause that’s what this beer is.

Wow! This beer is up there with Westy 12. The complexities are boundless. You get a nice bourbon and vanilla on the nose. Then a beautiful vanilla, oak, chocolate, and bourbon taste. Smooth mouthfeel, but this one is definitely a sipper. 

On tap at Rattle n Hum in NYC

Dark nectar of the gods. All the great traditional bourbon/whiskey flavors without all the alcohol. In addition you have the stout background wherein lies the chocolaty and roasty aspects. Great m-f’n beer.

Dark pour with small brown head.  Big nose of bourbon, wood and dried fruit.  Flavor is rich with roast, vanilla, dried prunes, hints of chocolate and alcohol.  Body is heavy with big hit of heat from the 13%.  Very complex and very smooth.

First turned onto it at Uber, and now in bottles all over town. This beer blows me away. Fruity yet the coffee/charred flavor comes throug as well. I always try to open a night of drinking with this one, as there is no way I’m doing one at the end of the night.

Bottle. 

A fantastic beer! I love the heavy, black oil thats in the bottle. So much flavor in the bottle, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, oak, caramel, roasted malts. Very well balanced beer. Great body and a fantastic mouth feel.

What a gem. stumble across this one by luck. Pours heavy short of syrupy. almost no head but the little that it displays is of translucent black.(is it possible). Aromas remind me of walking into a chocolate store. slight vanilla and the wonderful bourbon. taste are tremendous hints of bourbon and toffee. No chocolate flavoring which was disappointing. leaves a cote of sweetness that is always welcome by such a high gravity beer. found a new style to love. highly recommended it for those that are looking to explore something unique.
Wow!  Thanks to AJ!  Black color with no head.  Aroma of bourbon, oak,vanilla, caramel, and roasted malts. Flavor of bourbon, vanilla, roasted malts, and caramel.  Liquid heaven.

Before I put in the details.... WOW!! Bottle served at near-room temperature into a snifter. Minimal light-brown head that quickly rings to the side of the glass. Almost pure-black in color. Oil-like and reflects your mug from the top after the head has settled. Sweet, intense aromas of caramel, chocolate, wood, vanilla, alcohol, and roasted nuts. The flavor and palate have the dial turned up to 11. The fact that there is so much creamy, robust flavor in just a little sip is utterly spellbinding. The alcohol is there on the finish, but in a good way, prickling over your tongue and warming into your limbs. Again... Wow!!

Bottle bought @ Whole Foods NY, pours dark opaque and sticky with no head, aroma of scotch, raisins, chocolate, nuts and cherry, strong flavors of chocolate, raisins, smoked malt, hash, scotch, cherry liquor and bitter sweet long aftertaste, pretty amazing body. Outstanding

@Freaktoberfest 2008 bottle, pours total black with a small deep chocolate head, cream like aroma with some maple, toffee, caramel, vanilla, chocolate and cherry liquor, flavors of brandy, cherry, scotch, wood, caramel, liqurice and soy sauce, supreme brew with complex flavors and aroma, and great mouthfeel. WOW

This review pertains to the 2005 vintage.

Pours pitch black and completely opaque without even the slightest of lighter colored edges when held to a light source. Completely still with no head at all. This looks like a goblet of oil.

Aroma is dominated by a ton of oaky bourbon with hints of vanilla. Also, I’m picking up a lot of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee bean, burnt toast and bourbon, bourbon, bourbon!

Heavy full chewy viscous mouthfeel with such a smooth creamy body that I can’t believe this beer is 11%. The alcohol heat is excellently masked. Lots of wooden earthy oak notes and bourbon flavor with hints of subtle vanilla. Also a good bit of roasted chocolate malt, burnt toast, coffee, oatmeal and Bourbon! So creamy, smooth and well balanced. This beer is incredibly mellow afte the three years of aging. Nice alcohol warmth in the finish with some subtle hops. This beer is absolutely fantastic. I want to get a few more bottles so I can try it fresh and age a few for a decade or so. ISO more bottle!

whooo you can smell this stuff from across the room!  raisin/prune and alc aroma.  flavor is similar, it’s like a big mash up of raisins, wine, and chocolate. really winey.  very oily.  tons of flavor, alc apparent in finish.  really warming but not overwhelming.  it’s kind of crazy and i wouldn’t drink it regularly but it’s a real treat, really glad i was able to have one.
Huge thanks to coyotehunter for giving up a bottle.This is all about the bourbon. The flavor is strong, sweet, chewy and warm. A sipper for sure. If you like bourbon this is a  must have.

12 oz bottle of 2005 batch. Pitch black with a tiny head from a hard pour that disappears fast. Aroma is really boozy with chocolate, molasses, vanilla and oak. Flavor is huge, lots of sweetness and plenty of bitterness, there is also a alcohol flavor. Full body with mild carbonation and a creamy thick mouth feel. This is a great beer, a bit boozy but still a really nice sipper.

Rerate. 2009 650ml. Appearance: same. Aroma, a lot cleaner, no oxidation. Just cool sweet bourbon. Very smooth, low roast, low hops, lots of bourbon, dark sweet and rich. Very similar to barrel aged Speedway. Which means it’s really good.


8 4 9 4 17 4.1



Orig. rating. 2008 bottle.


Pours pretty dark brown, close to zero head. Smells a little oxidized. A ton of bourbon and chocolate in there. Take a deep breath for that cleansing rush of alcohol through the nasal passages. Very rich flavor - stands up to the richest Expedition Stouts. A lot of bourbon, very sweet, and again that distinctive bourbon oak flavor. Extremely smooth and creamy. Low roast levels compared to some other RIS examples. It’s really rather amazing that this is a 13% beer because it really comes off far from boozy. Very tasty and a good example of how to make an extreme imperial stout without going overboard.


7 3 9 4 17 4.0

Thick, oily, headless pour of a seal brown beer. Intense dark chocolate and vanilla extract aroma with secondary notes of bourbon, roasted coffee, and salt liquorice and a strong undercurrent of baked raisins. Balance is firmly to the powerful sweetness, though followed by significant roast- and hop-derived bitterness with a constant round acidity and moderate saltiness. Powerful flavors mimic the aroma but are viciously overpowered by a hot alcohol and salted, smoked fish combination. Thick body, oily texture, faint carbonation. 

Wildly out of balance, harsh, and difficult to drink. Bottled on 10/08/2008.

Finally decided to review this after a number of years and many samplings, but was finally motivated by the 08 draft version now on tap at Lunar Brewing Co. Oil pour to a snifter, with a dark, black/brown hue,  minimal foam, and a few spots of lacing. The aroma was notes of dark fruit, chocolate, wood, smoke, and caramel, but were mostly overwhelmed by the potent bourbon. The flavor exhibited the bourbon’s very warming qualities in addition to the blend of aroma notes. A syrupy, full bodied, kick-ass elixir!
Just recently shared a 2009 bomber with beer friends at Lunar Brewing Co., viscously poured to snifters additionally showing some garnet highlighting, leggy coating on the glass, a full nose of barrel notes, dark cherry sweetness, and mellow but strong, bourbony alcohol.
